TITLE.XREF: HEARING SERVICES AND AGHS REFORM BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment.
Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration at a later hour this day.
Bill presented by Mr Ruddock and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to amend part 3 of the Migration Act 1958 which provides for the migration agents registration scheme. The bill amends section 333 of the Migration Act which contains a sunset clause. Under this clause, the migration agents registration scheme will terminate on 21 September 1997, after having operated for five years. The amendment will have the effect of terminating the scheme on 21 March 1998.

Members will be aware that the migration agents registration scheme was recently reviewed by a task force within my department. The task force was guided by a reference group headed by Mr Ian Spicer, former Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

The review recognised that the migration agents registration scheme had provided a measure of consumer protection and had removed a number of incompetent or unscrupulous operators from the migration advice industry. It was supportive of the industry moving to self-regulation, where its members voluntarily join an industry body and agree to meet the competency and ethical standards set by the body. The body, in turn, sets in place procedures for disciplining members who breach its code of conduct.

In considering the task force's report, the government recognised that the migration industry is disparate and lacks a body with sufficient coverage and infrastructure to take on the task of self-regulation at this time. Consequently, the government has decided to introduce a form of statutory self-regulation as a transitional stage, with an eventual move to full self-regulation.

Under statutory self-regulation, regulatory power is delegated to an industry body and, subject to an agreement between the body and me, the body takes on the administration and enforcement of regulation. The Migration Institute of Australia is prepared to take on the role of industry regulator and is aware of the parameters under which such an agreement would operate.

In addition to improving competency standards and providing an enhanced consumer protection focus through a complaints resolution process, the industry body will also be able to impose disciplinary sanctions against agents who behave in an unethical or grossly unprofessional manner.

The proposed six months extension of the existing scheme to 21 March 1998 will enable the government to develop and introduce legislation shortly for this transitional period of statutory self-regulation for the migration advice industry. It will also allow the Migration Institute of Australia time to establish the infrastructure to take on this new self- regulation role. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

BREAK.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Tanner) adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: FAMILY COURT OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA (ORDERS OF REGISTRARS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Williams, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The bill contains no new policy but overcomes technical deficiencies in the way Commonwealth and state family law legislation and rules of court have applied in Western Australia. Western Australia is the only state to have its own family court. The bill is designed to complement Western Australian legislation addressing these deficiencies from within the legislative capabilities of that state.

The bill will create family law rights and liabilities for the many people who may be affected by a recent decision of the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in the matter of Horne v. Horne, 13 February 1997, Appeal No. WA 13 of 1996. In that case, the Full Family Court held that the family law rule that purportedly allowed registrars of the Family Court of Western Australia to exercise the power to make consent orders was invalid. As a result, many consent orders made by registrars in Western Australia are ineffective.

This bill will overcome this problem by ensuring that all affected people in Western Australia obtain enforceable, statutory family law rights and liabilities that mirror the rights and liabilities that would have been created by valid registrars' orders. The approach taken in the bill is based on a similar one approved by the High Court in R v. Humby ex parte Rooney (1973) 129 CLR 231, and subsequently in cases such as Polyukhovic v. the Commonwealth (1991) 172 CLR 500. This approach does not attempt to validate the purported orders made by registrars. Instead, it creates new statutory rights and liabilities that may be exercised and enforced in the same manner as orders.
The bill will not have any significant financial impact. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the government and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) are well aware of the importance of Townsville in the national economy. Last night I spoke extensively about my city, about how well the city is going and how indeed I believe it will probably be the fastest growing regional city in this country in the next year or so.

BREAK.PARA: I spoke about matters such as the importance of the sports and entertainment industry in the city where our football team, which is a member of the Super League, is attracting crowds as big as any team in the country except the Broncos. I spoke about how, even last week, the Broncos were unable to beat us, even on their home ground.

I spoke about how the Townsville Suns in the basketball are in fact third in the national league at the moment, which is a very creditable effort. I spoke about how they have established a professional sports record with 58 consecutive sell‐out home games of 4,500 people in the Furnace, which is in the Townsville Entertainment Centre. I alerted the parliament to the fact that, because we are filling these 4,500 places, we are going to extend that Entertainment Centre to 6,000 places—which is a great result for Australia's largest tropical city.

I spoke last night about the importance of the Australian Defence Force. I indicated to my colleagues that in my city we have Australia's largest defence base. We also have the Operational Deployment Unit, which is the unit that responds, within a set period of time, in the case of a national emergency. There is an awful lot of money going into that particular sector of the Townsville economy—millions and millions of dollars in terms of 10 Terminal Regiment, 5 Aviation Regiment, the Townsville Field Training Area and the new, modern, high frequency communications system which is based in Townsville.

I spoke to you about minerals development, and the fact that we are servicing the largest zinc deposit and mine in the world. And Century Zinc is yet to come on stream as well. We have a billion dollar investment in a new minerals processing facility which will process both zinc and lead, and that will complement the two mineral refineries that already exist in the city—namely, copper and nickel.

I spoke last night about the importance of James Cook University and how that university last year secured the lion's share of research grants for regional universities, and that is because James Cook is leading the world in such things as marine science, sports science and earth science.

I alerted the parliament to the fact that Townsville airport once again has resumed international services. I am fiercely proud of the state of Queensland, of course, and I can state that it has three international airports—which no other state can match—and Townsville airport is one of those. Milne Bay Air has established flights into New Guinea, which I certainly trust will be a great success.

I also spoke about road development in the city, the importance of the national highway, and how I was able to secure $21.5 million for the northern approach to the city. That is great news. I was certainly very proud to turn the first soil on that project last week. Mr Speaker, I had to drive a grader to do that; you would have been proud of me. If I lose my job here, I certainly have another job to go to.

Stemming directly from the government's financial responsibility, home buyers and small businesses in Townsville and throughout Australia are now beginning to see some real benefits. Interest rates have fallen 3.55 per cent since the coalition was elected. That is starting to filter through to my electorate. The real estate industry tells me that they are looking forward to a very good year. Home buyers can now access home loan rates as low as 6.99 per cent, meaning that home buyers in Townsville and Thuringowa can make interest savings of $292 per month—and that is after tax. It is the equivalent of a $100‐a‐week wage rise.

For small businesses, after years of rising taxes, it has taken a Howard coalition government to start turning that around. Provisional tax has been cut; fringe benefits tax has been cut and, on 1 July, capital gains tax will be cut, representing a significant easing of the burden on small business. The coalition certainly has paved the way for strong and consistent growth and, in time, Townsville—and indeed all of Australia—will benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When the now Prime Minister, John Howard, took the stage at the Wentworth Hotel on the evening of 2 March 1996, as he waved to a sea of Liberal Party supporters and campaign workers and suffered the glare of the television lights and all the camera‐flashes, he used in his victory speech the inclusive language Australians expected from their soon‐to‐be leader. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government that I will lead will be a Government not only for the people who voted for us but also for the people who voted against us.

He said the things that united Australians `were infinitely more important and more enduring than the things that divided Australians.' He spoke about `unity', `cohesion' and `a common point of view'. He spoke about `fairness' and `understanding', `good government', and `the welfare of all of the Australian people'. The Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong, said:

I will focus on the those things that bind us together, I will focus on our strengths, I will defend the interests and the values and the principles of this country both domestically and internationally.
He waved to the crowd again, hugged his wife and children, posed for some photos and walked off the stage with the applause and the shouts of joy still ringing in his ears.

And then he quickly and effortlessly forgot. He did not forget the applause or the congratulations; the backslaps and outstretched hands followed him around Australia for the next 10 months. He did not forget the momentous nature of his new position: he certainly had the trappings of Kirribilli House and the demanding schedule to remind him he was indeed the Prime Minister. He did not forget the pressures of office; he has had us to remind him of those every day of the week.

What the Prime Minister forgot was that he promised to govern the nation with an eye to bringing us together, not forcing us further apart. What the Prime Minister forgot was that he said he was going to govern for all of us equally—for those who had voted against his party and those who had voted for it. What he forgot was that he said he would govern with fairness and understanding and that under his government Australians would feel more secure—secure in their jobs, secure in their families and secure for the future.

Why do I say that he forgot all these things? Well, he must have forgotten because, as we all know, one cannot accuse another member of lying in this place. He must have forgotten because, as I look around my electorate, I do not see the face of a fair and understanding government. As my constituents now meet me in my office and stop me in the street, I do not hear from them the good news about how even-handedly they are being treated by this government. I am hearing about how very much more unsure they are feeling, how their future is far more grim, how they are going to have to struggle even harder to keep their families together—more so now than they have ever had to before.

The Prime Minister must have forgotten because in Prospect I do not see a community uniting as a result of this government's policies. I see a community dividing and falling apart. I see our local hospitals under threat from the $800 million ripped out of our public health system by this government. I see our young people unable to reach their full potential and obtain a university education, blocked by the increases in HECS and the $623 million ripped out of higher education. I see our long-term unemployed wasting away on the dole queue with no job training and little or no hope because of the $2 billion which is now earmarked for removal from the country's labour market programs.

I see the despondency and the social dislocation which is a natural follow‐on from such endemic and untreated joblessness. I have seen the heroin trade spread insidiously and with great effect through the suburbs of my electorate over the last 12 months. Because of the abolition of operational subsidies for community based child care, I see working mums and dads starting to take their kids out of regulated and accredited community child care and place them in unregulated, backyard operations. These parents can no longer afford the extra $20 to $47 per child per week, on top of what they have had to pay. These are the increases my local councils have been forced into making by this government, come 1 July.

I see the elderly suffering constant pain and the indignity of spending their days eating soup and mashed vegetables because they have been told they cannot get their dentures replaced until heaven knows when, now that the Commonwealth dental program has been cut to shreds. I see the elderly in my electorate frightened and unsure as they face the prospect of being forced to sell their own homes to get a bed in a nursing home.

I see Fairfield Legal Aid having to shut its doors to genuinely needy clients, turning people away as it and the entire legal aid system prepares itself and its meagre funds for the $120 million cuts which will come into effect on 1 July. I see Liberal Party senators coming into my electorate from Watsons Bay smiling and shaking our hands and waving about cheques for flood mitigation, as if we should be thankful we received any money at all after the urban flood mitigation program and its level of recurrent funding have now been abolished.

This is the Australia the Prime Minister and this government have given the people of Prospect in barely 15 months. Now, following this May budget, the latest chapter in what can only be described as an increasingly bitter story, I do not imagine that people in my electorate or throughout Australia are expecting it to get any better.

Looking at this latest budget, the people of Prospect have a right to believe that the Howard Government has chosen to look after its natural, more privileged constituencies at the expense of some of the most disadvantaged areas of Australia. The Treasurer's savings rebate scheme provides a striking example of the way in which the Howard government has washed its hands of Australia's working poor.

Forget the dishonest and shameful way in which this budget measure betrays the coalition's rock solid commitment to match Labor's superannuation co‐contribution scheme. Forget the fact that the superannuation and retirement incomes policy that the coalition took to the last election stated, `The coalition will meet the government's co‐contribution commitment.' Forget that just for the moment. Let us instead take a look at what this supposedly new, improved policy does to benefit the people of Prospect, some of Australia's most disadvantaged families—especially when compared with what it will do for the multi‐millionaires of Wollstonecraft and Kirribilli.

In the suburbs of Prairiewood, Bossley Park, Abbotsbury and Greenfield Park in my electorate, the mean taxable income, based on 1994‐95 tax office figures, is $26,355. The average amount of interest received on savings is $597. How much has the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia calculated that a person earning these amounts will receive from the government's savings rebate scheme? Ninety dollars per year—a lousy $1.73 a week. That is less than the cost of a loaf of bread at the supermarket.

The picture does not get much rosier elsewhere in my electorate. In the suburb of Prospect itself, the average rebate has been calculated at $97—$1.86 a week. In Carramar and Villawood the average rebate will be $103—a meagre $2 a week. In Smithfield, Fairfield, Wetherill Park, Horsley Park, Fairfield West and Fairfield Heights, the average rebate is going to be roughly $2.20 per week.

The Treasurer and the Prime Minister have tried to deceive the people of Prospect with all their talk about $450 rebates when for my constituents the reality is very different. I will let the Prime Minister and his Treasurer in on what is common knowledge around my way but what for them might come as a bit of a surprise. The majority of my constituents have not got $1,000 saved up in the bank, let alone the $60,000 needed to get the full $450 benefit from this scheme.

Most of the families in my electorate use virtually every ounce of their income to keep their households together—to pay off the mortgage, pay the rent, pay for the kids' clothes, put food on the table—the basic stuff that this government should be caring about. They have little or none of the disposable income to play with, to rack up the huge levels of savings which are required to gain the full up‐front benefits of this scheme. That is how the scheme short‐changes the people of Prospect in the short term. What about the long term?

The people of Prospect, especially the young men and women who are in their late twenties and early thirties and who are still at the beginning of their working lives, the people who will really need the support of a strong superannuation scheme by the time they have reached retirement age, have been robbed by this government. They have been ripped off to the tune of around $100,000.

The average worker living in Fairfield—the average so‐called `Howard battler'—who is perhaps 35 years of age and is earning about $700 a week, would have retired at 65 under Labor's superannuation scheme with a superannuation benefit of around $280,000. Now, thanks to the betrayal of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, this worker's final benefit will be around $170,000. That is a loss of around 40 per cent, or $110,000.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer are quite obviously working on the principle of `what they don't have now, they won't miss later'. They are hoping that a little sleight of hand, a little `watch me pull a rabbit out of my hat', will allow them to get away with what is palpably clear to all. And that is that the people of my electorate have had their future means cut out from under them on a scale never before seen, let alone contemplated. It is a heist on a scale which beggars the imagination, and in the process they are robbing the nation of the $400 billion which would have been a part of our national savings pool by the year 2020 under Labor's superannuation scheme.

Another front on which my electorate will take no solace from this Budget is unemployment. I am not only referring to the legions of unemployed in the Fairfield‐Liverpool region who will look at this budget with dismay for what it does, or should I say does not do, about creating jobs. I am talking about the families, friends and relatives who have to watch their parents and children go for months with no employment prospects and none likely to emerge. I am talking about the thousands of people who work in Prospect who are feeling increasingly insecure in their jobs and wondering how they and their families will cope if unemployment should befall them.

In the last budget, the coalition axed $1.8 billion from labour market programs around the country which were designed to get long‐ term unemployed Australians back to work. In this budget, an extra $320 million has been cut from vocational and skills training and general assistance to job seekers. Spending overall on labour programs falls by $300 million. Meanwhile, the Prime Minister is preparing for the dole queues to lengthen by putting aside an extra $200 million to pay for unemployment benefits—a move which exposes just how much he believes his own rhetoric about reducing unemployment over the next 12 months.

Instead of attempting to tackle the unemployment queues in Prospect and throughout Australia head on—my area, incidentally, has the highest unemployment rate in New South Wales and the second highest in Australia—instead of providing the long‐term unemployed with training and new skills, what we get in Prospect is the Prime Minister's supposed master stroke—work for the dole—a puerile answer to unemployment if ever there was one.

For Prospect, work for the dole really means having our young people—not the young people of the north shore or the eastern suburbs of Sydney, remember—cutting edges and picking up garbage for the privilege of receiving their unemployment benefit. That is what it means.

Work for the dole has failed before it has even begun because it contains no training component and thus fails to provide participants with the skills they need if they are to have any hope of gaining employment in fields where work still exists. The selective nature of the scheme exposes the Prime Minister's guarantee to govern fairly and equitably—irrespective of where you live or the levels of unemployment in your community—as lip service of the highest order.

Work for the dole is a cheap, populist gimmick at best. The fact that the Prime Minister of Australia is willing to manipulate the young people of my electorate as the guinea pigs in this ridiculous sham is, quite frankly, disgusting. Meanwhile, the drug abuse, the family breakdown, the crime and juvenile delinquency—the spin‐offs of unemployment in Prospect—only get worse.

BREAK.PARA: What we are seeing now is sad confirmation of what Voltaire said over 200 years ago: `Work banishes those three great evils—boredom, vice and poverty.' With the current absence of work opportunities in Prospect, I can assure the Prime Minister, we have all three evils in spades.

The other three great negative messages the government has sent the people of Prospect in this budget are in relation to child care, community welfare and pharmaceuticals. The decision in this budget to rip operational subsidies away from outside school hours child care can be seen in no other way by the parents of my electorate than another Howard government attack upon disadvantaged families.

As centres are forced to raise their fees to make up for their axed subsidy, and as parents who cannot afford such an increase remove their kids from care, we are going to see an explosion in the number of latchkey kids in my electorate. Thanks to this measure, parents in Prospect will be forced into giving their eight‐, nine‐ and 10‐year‐old kids a key and telling them to sit and watch the television until mum and dad get home from work. The consequences of such actions are on the Prime Minister's head.

The government's decision to close Fairfield's family resource centre, Ettinger House, takes another link out of my electorate's welfare safety net. Ettinger House assists the disadvantaged in the Fairfield area find the support services they need, especially in regard to domestic violence, drug and alcohol abuse and unemployment. Are we going to watch women from non‐English speaking backgrounds suffer abuse in silence now that this essential service is to disappear? The prospects of this occurring are very real.

Fairfield is an area of special need. We need services like the family resource centre at Ettinger House to fight the effects of joblessness in our community. Its closure is another shining example of the coalition's callous attitude towards the disadvantaged.

Meanwhile, the sick and the elderly are being made to pay more for their medication. The bottom line here is that if your doctor chooses to prescribe a more expensive drug because of its effectiveness and the fact it has fewer side effects, you could pay up to $20 or more for a script.

As for the medicines that have been taken off the pharmaceutical benefits list altogether—the drugs for skin complaints, stomach problems, diarrhoea and muscle pain—the people who need these medicines face an increase of $9 a script. How does this fit with the Prime Minister's desire to govern for the welfare of all Australians? As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) stated, `This is a directionless budget.' It is a do‐nothing budget, and as such confirms for us all that we have a do‐nothing Prime Minister and a do‐nothing government.

When he was in opposition the Prime Minister used to take stands. We on this side of politics may have disagreed with most of his views but at least we could respect the strength of his convictions then. Now, as Prime Minister, a role which demands of its office‐holder the very highest levels of leadership and a willingness to state one's case and one's vision for the sake of the country's future, the member for Bennelong's convictions, our Prime Minister's convictions, have turned to jelly.

The only things he believes in now are the opinion polls. The only policy directions he believes in taking are the ones his party headquarters told him went down well with the market research group on the previous weekend. The only stances he takes are on issues which are likely to win a few plaudits on talkback radio the next morning.

The only cuts the Prime Minister makes are to areas where he considers the political fallout will be the easiest to overcome, where the cries of protest will be the smallest—never mind if those cries come from some of the weakest sections of our communities. This is despite the fact that in another life the Prime Minister said: `If we lapse into cheap populism the future of this country will be at risk.' Yet here we have a budget soaked to the gills in populist measures such as the savings rebate scheme, work for the dole and the Federation `slush' Fund.

This budget confirms that the coalition is devoid of strong and intelligent ideas, and as such will continue to be mired in indecision—much to the country's misfortune. It adds to the insecurity and apprehension the people of Prospect are feeling at levels unsurpassed in recent times.

In the wide tree lined avenues of Roseville and Killara, in the harbourside mansions of Kirribilli and Mosman, in the boutique shopping districts of Rose Bay and Double Bay, residents have a federal government looking out for them and their interests, but not in western Sydney or in my electorate. In Prospect we have a Prime Minister and a government ignoring us; an inattentive and insensitive government that is oblivious to the problems that we face and the problems they are creating. What is more, they do not care to listen.

All the people of my electorate want is to be governed with the equal hand promised by the Prime Minister during his victory speech on election day last year. I do not believe that that is too much to ask. Judging by the Prime Minister's latest budget, we now have a leader who thinks that it is. We now have a leader and a government who seem to think they govern for those they care about and to hell with the rest of the people of Australia. I condemn this budget for the meanness of it. I condemn this budget because it does not project Australia into the future. I particularly condemn this budget and the coalition for dividing this country even further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a feature of our adversarial form of politics that governments propose and oppositions oppose. The contribution by the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), while I am sure well meaning, was certainly so negative that I found that the remarks I intend to make bear no resemblance whatsoever to the contribution from the honourable member. I wonder sometimes whether we have read the same documents, whether we are really considering the same issues or whether we represent constituents in the same country.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a budget about employment not unemployment. This is a budget about future employment for Australians. Why do I say that? The budget promises us a fairly contemporary reduction in interest rates. Why is interest rates being low good for us? Because it means that Australians at whatever income level can buy houses or obtain credit at reduced costs. The incomes of Australians at all levels—low, medium and high—are dramatically higher today than when this government took over after the March 1996 election. That is because interest rates have fallen dramatically.

At the same time, we are experiencing very low and falling inflation. Low inflation is good for Australia and it is good for business. It helps give business the confidence that they can build, they can design, they can produce under a financial atmosphere that is stable.

Industry needs certainty in order to provide jobs. This budget goes a long way towards providing the kind of certainty that industry has asked for for years. It is, in a sense, a bit of a steady as you go budget, accepting that the Commonwealth government has made a dramatic effort to turn around a budget deficit to a budget surplus.

Over the life of the first Howard government we will see budget projections fall from a budget deficit of $10.3 billion—that is, the Commonwealth's call on the savings of average Australians—to a budget surplus of $1.6 billion. That is a remarkable achievement. Business and industry cannot help but respond to the initiative that the government, the public sector, is reducing its call on Australia's savings and is actually contributing to Australia's savings overall. The reduced debt is actually very dramatic.

In the coming financial year we will repay over $5 billion of debt. For the first time in nearly 10 years the Commonwealth will not run up any debt, it will not call on the savings of Australians and it will not be a borrower in the marketplace. That is fantastic for industry. It provides industry more scope to find the funds that they need to fund expansion and growth in their operating costs within the Australian economy without having to seek funds from overseas to the same extent that they did in the past.

The turnaround from deficit to surplus is very dramatic. It provides industry with so much scope. That is just incredible. Interest rates are now, as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said yesterday, at a 28‐year low. 1969 was the last year that variable interest rates for housing loans were this low. That was the year that I came to Australia. That is almost 30 years ago. In the meantime, we have had the Whitlam government absolutely blow interest rates out of the water. We had the Hawke and Keating governments give us the greatest recession that we have had since the Great Depression. This government is now bringing down the deficit spending proclivity of Labor and turning it around to the Commonwealth actually becoming a net saver. Interest rates are responding to that and I think that is fantastic.

The other thing that we can say about low interest is that when we went into the last election and talked about industrial relations reform we said that we wanted Australians to be able to have secure jobs and increased incomes, but that those incomes should be based on improvements in productivity. It is worthy of note that while inflation is at two per cent and falling, wage rates have grown at less than five per cent but more than four per cent providing Australians with greater disposable income.

In a gross income sense Australians are far ahead of where they were when we took over from the failed Keating government. At the same time interest payments for housing mortgage loans and for general spending and credit card spending are dramatically down providing after tax income returns of as much as $5,000 a year for an average Australian family. That is good for families. It is good for the economy. It is good for jobs. It is good for growth.

At the same time that we have low interest rates and low inflation, yesterday we learned that new private capital spending rose 6.5 per cent in the March quarter. Capital spending was 18.6 per cent higher than in the same quarter last year. What does that mean? That means that industry and business and commerce are investing in new productive capacity, in new ventures and in new buildings to conduct their businesses in. That investment means new jobs for Australians, perhaps not today but, as the investment is realised, as they put plant and equipment into factories, as they build new production lines, as they purchase new systems to operate their businesses more effectively, more Australians will find jobs, and there will be a greater job market for those who need work. Equipment, plant and machinery investment rose 5.5 per cent in the quarter to be 10.1 per cent higher than at the same time last year. We know that means future jobs. As I said in the beginning, this is a budget about employment.

There is a whole range of initiatives in the budget that will help encourage Australians to find jobs, that will improve the job prospects of those particularly young people who need assistance to obtain the skills that are so necessary for them to find not only any employment but good, enjoyable employment that is productive and gives them an opportunity to really participate in the life of Australia.

Almost $6 billion has been allocated for employment assistance over the next four years. There are improved national literacy and numeracy skills programs for young people to gain more confidence. I have spoken in this place many times—so has the opposition member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis)—about the skills deficit that we have in literacy and numeracy in Australia. This government is paying attention to what the surveys have told us about the deficit that we have, with as much as 30 per cent of our youth not having adequate literacy and numeracy skills to serve them well in the job market that they will ultimately try to enter.

It is to our shame that we deny any young Australian the right to fully participate in our society, the right to have a meaningful job, because we have not taught them how to read and write in English and how to count and multiply and divide. New national literacy programs will help attack this deficit and help give young people increasing confidence. A new $1,500 completion payment for employers whose apprentices or trainees achieve Australian qualification framework level 3 competency will help encourage employers to put on more apprentices and more trainees.

The government's entire approach since coming into office has been to try to lift the number of new apprenticeships and new traineeships that apply to industry where we have not had such mechanisms before. The whole intent of government action is to make more opportunity available to those young people who will not go on to university, and I remind the House that at least 75 per cent of our young people on leaving school will not access university. Some of them, perhaps 10 per cent, will go on and achieve a higher qualification at TAFE, leaving about 65 per cent of our young people who will go directly into the work force and obtain their skills on the job or will attain some qualification or some skill classification through apprenticeships, through traineeships, through part-time TAFE, through out of work hours study, through whatever mechanism in order to help give them entry level skills that will allow them to progress through their jobs.

Through this budget, we will extend vocational education and training to students in year 9 and year 10 in secondary schools who are in danger of leaving school and dropping out of the system altogether. I have to say that this is an initiative that I am particularly proud of. There are schools in my electorate and in surrounding electorates that have been extremely concerned about this issue for a long time, as are schools around Australia.

Teachers tell us that they know generally those young people who enter high school in year 9 who are already at risk of dropping out of the system. Those who drop out at an early age have little chance of obtaining full-time employment and have little chance of progressing through employment to any sort of job career or satisfying employment. They generally wind up on the unemployment scrap heap. They may wind up in our penal institutions; they may wind up with drug and alcohol dependency problems. They need the skills that they obtain at school. They need the discipline of attending school and the discipline of learning in an active environment.

So that money is designed through the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation to assist schools to help those young people who are at risk of dropping out of the school system. Some of those programs will probably involve a change in the curriculum, allowing those students to spend up to two days a week at work while they complete their studies during the other three days.

The work component of the programs simply gives the students a reason for continuing with their education. It allows them to see that there can be real jobs at the end of the formal time in school. What those real jobs are all about is the kind of satisfaction that comes from going to work and doing a job and contributing to the company and contributing to society. So those sorts of curriculum initiatives will help encourage the young people to stay on at school. I congratulate the minister and the government for including that initiative in this budget.

There will be more than $45 million over four years for the community support program to assist some 250,000 job seekers. People with special needs will undergo a formal special needs assessment. Participants will receive individual tailored assistance to help them overcome their barriers to employment and to help make them job ready. The new enterprise incentives scheme will continue within the employment services market.

Extended assistance packages for the pharmaceutical industry to the year 2005 are another issue that particularly pleases me. Our pharmaceutical industry has prospered and has grown dramatically under the factor F scheme. I have always congratulated John Button for picking up that initiative and putting it in place, because our pharmaceutical industry was dying. There is no question about that. Since the scheme came into operation, our investment in research and development, our investment in new plant and new capacity, our investment in new jobs and our dramatic improvement in exports have been well documented.

This government, to its credit, has continued that scheme in a manner which is complementary to World Trade Organisation requirements and gives the pharmaceutical industry further certainty. In addition to that, the government has extended the patent life for pharmaceuticals by an additional five years, recognising the very long and expensive time between the discovery of a new chemical entity, toxicology trials, clinical trials and the final production and marketing of a new drug, recognising that there is a very long lead time between discovering the chemical entity and actually hitting the marketplace. The costs sometimes are absolutely staggering.

Glaxo, a major pharmaceutical manufacturer in my electorate, is now attempting to develop the flu drug. Hopefully, this initiative by the Commonwealth government will encourage the Glaxo board in London to allow the plant in Boronia to manufacture the flu drug when the clinical trials are finished and manufacture it for the whole world market. There have been estimates that that initiative could gain Australia as much as $1 billion a year in export income. That certainly will be good for jobs and good for Australia.

The work for the dole scheme is also another initiative that will help employment. It will not generate jobs. It was never designed to generate jobs. It will not even necessarily generate the skills that are necessary for particular career paths in industry. What it will do is give young people the confidence that they can participate, give them some sense of reality in actually doing something that is creative and help make them feel that they are participating in society and fulfilling half of their compact, if you will, with the Australian society—where society is taking care of them during their time of not having employment, they put something back into the community. That can be only positive, both for the people who work under the work for the dole scheme and also for those communities which pick it up.

The member for Prospect talked about the savings initiative in the budget and what some people in her electorate save now. I think the honourable member missed the point. The point is that the initiative is there to encourage people to save more than they are saving now or, if they are saving nothing, to save something. That is what it is all about. For the first time that anyone can remember in the history of tax initiatives coming out of this Commonwealth parliament there is an actual positive initiative to encourage people to save. It says that you get a rebate off your taxes if you save.

BREAK.PARA: Talking about what people save now is not what it is all about. It is what people will save in the future as a result of the initiative. The recent modelling work that has been done by Morgan and Banks clearly indicated that the majority of the initiative will go to those on low and medium incomes. That is precisely what it was designed to do. It will recompense every Australian, regardless of their income level, some amount for their savings, but those who receive the greatest benefit are those on low and moderate incomes. The savings initiative is a good initiative for Australia. It is a first and I am certain that it will accomplish its objectives over time.

I am very pleased to say to the House that the Commonwealth government agreed to up the ante to the ABC by over $13 million a year, which will help ameliorate some of the effects of the budget cuts to the ABC announced in August last year. The ABC now receives $500 million a year. That funding is guaranteed over the next three years in real terms—not in nominal terms—adjusted for inflation. So the ABC now can plan with certainty to restructure its operation in order to become more efficient and more effective and to use our taxpayers' dollars in a better manner. I am pleased that the ABC management themselves have complimented the Commonwealth government on that initiative.

While I am disappointed that Radio Australia will not continue all its programs, I am absolutely delighted that Radio Australia will continue and will continue to broadcast into Asia the voice of Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This budget is a budget that clearly is without direction. It is a budget that is without leadership. It is a budget without a plan. I guess in many respects that is an appropriate thing. It is just like the Prime Minister (Mr Howard); it is a mirror reflection of his leadership—the meandering government that we have become used to in the last six to 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a budget that does nothing to address the worsening economic situation that Australia confronts. It does nothing about the slowing consumer demand. It does nothing about the growing number of Australians out of work. It does nothing to create job oppor tunities. It certainly does nothing to provide job security for those Australians still in employment.

We now face a lost year, a lost opportunity. This is the Clayton's budget—some people will recall the old Clayton's drink—this is the budget you have when you are not having a budget. This is a standstill, a waste of 12 months, a lost opportunity, for the Australian people.

The government heralded the budget for its drive to return Commonwealth budgets to surplus. Indeed, just about every speaker on the government side makes a point of talking about this as the feature. There is not much else they could hang a hat on in a debate on the budget other than to refer to that. But even in that area the government has misrepresented the situation.

The budget papers themselves identify that the underlying deficit in 1997‐98 will be $3 billion or 0.6 per cent of GDP; that is, we are still running a deficit this year. On the budget's projections, that is, if everything the government says will occur does in fact occur—I will go to that in a minute because they did not do too well last year predicting how the economy would go—we have to wait until 1998‐99 before the government will find itself in surplus.

That is normally coupled with rhetoric from Liberal‐National Party members telling the parliament what a terrible legacy they were left with, what a terrible debt the former government put in their hands. It is about time we dispelled that in cold hard facts. There have been only three surplus budgets recorded by the Commonwealth since the Second World War. I do not have records going back beyond that. I think the accounting system changed around 1950 anyway. Unfortunately, the budget papers that this government produces stop at 1984-85. When we were in government we produced tables that went back to the 1950s so people could get a good idea of how the government was performing compared with previous governments.

The simple fact of the matter is this: from the end of the Second World War until now there have been three surplus budgets. This budget, on the government's own admission, will not be a surplus budget. They will be in debt again this year. The only three budgets that any Commonwealth government has delivered in the period since the Second World War—in 50 years—with an underlying surplus were in fact Labor government budgets of the Hawke‐Keating period. They were the budgets of 1987‐88, 1988‐89 and 1989‐90. In 50 years the Commonwealth has managed only three surplus budgets and every one of them was a Labor budget in the last period of Labor's term in office.

This government has inherited an economy and a budgetary situation for the Commonwealth which is historically at its best. When we came to office in 1983, inheriting a budget and an economy from the former Liberal government, whose Treasurer at that time was John Howard, we inherited a deficit that amounted to $24 billion in today's terms—more than 2½ times the deficit that they inherited and that they complain about. The undeniable fact is that the only governments that have produced a surplus, the only governments that have managed not to draw on overseas or public funds to fund their budgetary outlays, have been Labor governments led by Paul Keating or by Bob Hawke.

We should put paid to the argument that government members trot out every debate on budgetary matters, and usually in question time as well, to try to cry poor about their situation. In fact, their situation is remarkably good—so good that, were we in Europe, Australia would be one of, I think, three countries that would be eligible to enter the European Union currency. Most of the countries in Europe have a much worse budgetary and debt situation than does Australia. Australia sits at the top of the international list in terms of the range of tests that the European Union applies for entry into the common currency. Our position is indeed a good one.

The other interesting thing out of the budget papers that I am always keen to look at is the government's own assessment of what they think will happen in the economy, how they think things will go. The two key measures are the estimated performance of gross domestic product and what the government sees as the unemployment rate. Gross domestic product—that is, how much the national cake will grow by, how much more wealth we will generate in this country, the growth of the things we make—in the last year we were in office grew by 4.1 per cent. Last year, the first year of the Liberal government, that fell to 3.25 per cent on the budget's own estimate. A year ago when the last budget was introduced the government and the Treasurer said that they would get growth going along at 3½ per cent. That is, their aim was to have slower growth.

We had it running at 4.1 per cent just two years ago. Last year their ambition was to slow the economy down to 3.5 per cent because they were not capable of maintaining the growth. Growth is critical if you want to maintain jobs, particularly with an increased participation rate with more Australians wanting work. Last year they set out not to make the economy grow faster than it did in our last year in office, not even to make it grow as fast as we did, but to slow it down to 3.5 per cent, and they could not even do that. Their own budget now shows it running at 3.25 per cent. It went from 4.1 per cent under us to 3.25 per cent in the space of a year. They have slowed the economy down. That is why jobs are not available, that is why people are losing job security and that is why the unemployed are finding it hard to get a job.

So what do they think is going to happen with growth in the economy in the next 12 months? The budget papers predict that they will have a leap from their current abysmal performance of 3.25 per cent and that it will grow half a per cent to 3¾ per cent. They have now set themselves a target of growth which, based on their efforts last year when their ambition was not to make the economy grow but to make it smaller—and they could not even achieve that low ambition—few observers believe they will achieve.

The interesting comparison is what the budget papers say our trading partners will do. Bear in mind that at the moment the Australian economy is operating at 3.25 per cent growth. The budget estimates that our major trading partners will grow their econo mies at 4½ per cent. So the people we do business with in the world will have a growth in their economies of 4½ per cent. What is the Howard‐Costello government's plan for Australia? If they can reach it, it is to grow at 3¾per cent—three‐quarters of a per cent less than our trading partners, a significant growth on the last year. Given their performance of being unable to even maintain the former year's growth, that is a fairly ambitious target.

Unemployment is the crux of government responsibility, particularly at this time, when we know from all indicators that the economy is slowing, that business confidence is poor and that job security is worse now than it was 12 months ago. The budget papers show that when we left office unemployment was 8.5 per cent in 1995‐96. Last year, in its first budget, what was the Howard‐Costello government's aim for Australia? What did it want to reduce unemployment by? The answer is zero.

Last year, the government stood before the people and said they wanted unemployment to be 8.5 per cent. They did not even set themselves a goal of reducing unemployment in the last budget, but they could not even reach that. They could not even ensure that unemployment did not get worse. The budget papers demonstrate that unemployment is now expected in this year to average out at 8¾per cent. It has gone up. So what do they say is going to happen in the next 12 months? They predict that unemployment will fall from its current high of 8.75 per cent down to 8.25 per cent. They reckon they are going to take half a per cent off unemployment while the economy grows at less than four per cent. There is no‐one in the economic community who believes that is possible unless, of course, through other measures, such as removal of child-care support and a whole range of other things, they actually force people out of the marketplace—people who are looking for jobs today and say, `I give up. I can't get a job. Things are so bad I won't even put my name down and try to get a job.'

That is the only way they will get the unemployment figure down. They will get it down by reducing the number of Australians who are looking for a job, because the widely accepted view is that, to make unemployment fall in Australia, you need to run the economy at a growth rate of about four per cent. Even if all of their predictions come true—and, given that they got them all wrong last year, you do not hold out much hope that they will be right this year—and even if everything they wanted came true, their own estimate, their own target, is that the economy will grow at less than the required four per cent. No‐one is going to take that seriously. These are the principles that underpin the budget, and the people of Australia, unfortunately, are going to bear the brunt of those false assumptions. No amount of rhetoric and no amount of spin‐doctoring is going to make a difference to that sad fact.

The forecast that this government has given on unemployment is a disgrace. Jobs should be the priority. Job security is absolutely critical. Instead of talking about jobs and instead of talking about some of those facts to which I referred, most government members have announced with great fanfare the lower interest rates. I, like all people, am delighted to see the lower interest rates. They are a good thing for the economy. But what this government has lost sight of is that they are absolutely undermined by the loss of job security.

You have already seen that in the interest rate cuts that have occurred. If you had an orthodox view, a traditional view, about this, you would say that interest rates have come down, that there would be more growth, that people would spend more money, that the building sector would grow, that we would see job confidence up, and that we would see the Yellow Pages Small Business Index and all these things high. They are not. You do not need to read those surveys to find out. You just need to spend a day going around your electorate, talking to a few people in business, to know how bad things are. I spent a little bit of time doing that recently, and all bar one person I spoke to in small business said that this was the worst they had had for years.

It was interesting that they said they did not like my former government. They did not like Paul Keating. They were glad to get rid of us. But a number of small businessmen said to me, `We were better off when Paul Keating was Prime Minister. We are worse off now than we have ever been.' The truth is that only one small businessman I spoke to said he was doing well, and when I pointed out that that was a bit different from the reactions I had had from others, he—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is handling bankruptcies!

—Someone said to me that he was a locksmith—he was changing locks after the bankruptcy people came through. This fellow was actually genuine and he was puzzled because he agreed, and he said everyone he knew in the business community was going backwards and was doing it harder than they had ever done it before. He was not quite sure why he was getting people in the door—he was just glad they were coming. That is the legacy that the coalition has produced. It does not understand that, while it destroys job security, interest rates are not going to have an impact.

SPEECH.PARA: To someone who does not have a job, it really does not matter whether interest rates are 15 per cent or five per cent. They are not going to buy a new car. They are not going to extend the house. They are not going to build a new house. For someone who has got a job but has just seen a third of the work force—their workmates—lose their job through a restructure, redundancy or government downsizing, they do not have the job security to think, `Yes, I'll go out and take a loan and I'll buy a new car or I will go on a holiday.' The simple fact of life is that, without job security, interest rates are totally undermined, no matter what level they are at. People today have no job security because of what this government has done in the last budget where it deliberately set out to reduce gross domestic product. It achieved it, it did slow the economy down, it has increased the number of unemployed and it has set about laying people off in their tens of thousands.

Against that background, interest rate cuts will not stimulate growth. It is a simple fact of human nature and it is one that appears to have been lost on this government. People will not take out a loan if they are not confi dent they will have a wage in 12 months time to pay the debt off, and this government has taken away from most Australians that security of employment. In the course of the last couple of months, we have seen announcements that go to 8,000 positions in Defence being abolished and another 13,000 positions in Defence under review—under the knife. We have seen another 20,000 Telstra jobs announced to go, as well as 4,000 department of employment jobs, in this budget. There is a supreme irony in that: while unemployment goes up, this government is sacking the very people in the department of employment who are there to help unemployed people to get jobs but 4,000 people out of the department of employment get the axe in this budget. And, of course, the government stands by and does nothing while the so‐called Big Australian decides to lay off 2,500 workers in Newcastle.

To cap it all off, in a couple of months time you will close every CES office in this country—the very place where unemployed people have become accustomed to getting support, and you shut the doors! You have put out the `For sale' sign on the CES offices of Australia. What signal does that send to unemployed Australians? What hope, what opportunity, does that give them to get a job? Do not worry whether interest rates are five per cent or 10 per cent. The signal you send those people is that, firstly, you do not care and, secondly, you have no plan. Sadly, this budget reflects both.

Against that, there has been a bit of window‐dressing. There have been plans like Green Corps, which is an interesting scheme. I was particularly interested in it for a range of reasons, so I put a question on notice to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp). I asked about the number of people participating in Green Corps, and I got a reply on 13 May. In my state of Queensland, the total number of people participating in the Green Corps program is 40. In the entire state of Queensland, 40 people are participating in Green Corps and you herald Green Corps as a major initiative to help people who are unemployed.

BREAK.PARA: The real irony of this is that of those 40, 15 of them actually had a job before they went into Green Corps. So out of the 40, there were only 23 people in Queensland who were unemployed. So what has Green Corps done for unemployed people in Queensland? Twenty‐three unemployed people in Queensland have been picked up in Green Corps. And how many of those 23 were long‐term unemployed? Six. Six long‐term unemployed people in the entire state of Queensland are being helped by Green Corps. Isn't that a magnificent achievement!

Government members have been putting out press releases all across Australia saying what a great initiative this is. The sad thing is that it is not just Queensland that is in this situation. Every state is the same. The total number of people in Green Corps in Australia is 240. The Labor Party's program of assisting unemployed people by way of environmental programs employed 13,000 people every year. Do you know how many you have got on Green Corps? Two hundred and forty. And do you know how many out of that 240, right across Australia, were long‐term unemployed? Forty‐two. You have helped 42 long‐term unemployed people. Members of the Liberal and National parties, in debates and in press releases around Queensland, have been saying what a great thing it is. Quite frankly, it makes me a little sick.

I also want to comment on one of the planks that the government heralded with its budget: the savings plan. The savings plan means that, if you happen to have $60,000 in the bank, you can get a $450 tax deduction. When? In the year 1999. Just in time for you to buy your ticket to the Olympic Games, I imagine. But you have to have $60,000 in the bank.

I do not know about members on the government side, but I do not have too many friends or constituents who have $60,000 in the bank. The average person who has $3,000 in the bank at five per cent will get about $22 a year—about 50c a week. That will make a big difference. That will improve the savings. But the important thing is that this has been done at the cost of superannuation. Ordinary working Australians have lost their best chance at retirement funding, which was the superannuation scheme. You have traded that in for this program. What is worse, it has a negative effect on national savings. This will not increase Australia's national savings pool, and the government knows it. The Treasurer knows it. He has evaded questions on it.

What you are doing is transferring public savings to the private sector and you are doing it in a way which will probably be negative. Every review of these plans has come out with that assessment. You should be ashamed of the deception that you have endeavoured to place on the people of Australia in that measure. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the federal government's 1997‐98 budget is a practical, commonsense plan. I heard the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) say that there is no plan. But the plan is to create jobs. I will say something about that a bit later and comment on some of the things the member for Brisbane has said.

SPEECH.PARA: The budget is designed to help families who, heaven knows, after 13 years of Labor need some help. It is aimed at boosting small business, encouraging savings and repaying debt. The budget has been widely accepted and praised in all sections of the community. The reaction has been positive, which is not surprising given the government's economic strategies. With a forecast $1.6 billion surplus in next year's budget, this means a staggering $12 billion turnaround in the Australian economy we inherited from Labor in March 1996.

The member for Brisbane said that only Labor governments have produced surpluses in the past and that we were not fair dinkum in saying that we were left with a $10 billion deficit. I can assure the people of Australia that there was a $10 billion deficit.

The tragedy is that, if we had known the deficit was there, we would have done some initial planning and said a few words about it during the election campaign. But we were told there was no deficit, that everything was hunky‐dory and that the economy was well. We had suspicions that it was not. You cannot spend like Labor governments spend and not have a deficit. But $10 billion was absolutely staggering.

If we were to use the same accounting system that Labor used, we would be in surplus right now. But we are honest in our forecasting and we believe that we will have a $1.6 billion surplus in the coming year. As I have said before, to turn around a $10 billion deficit to a $1.6 billion surplus in next year's budget is an incredible performance. It is great news for all Australians and for their future standard of living.

As I stated, the reaction to the budget has been positive. This is supported by the strong ticks of approval given by experts in their appraisal. The Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said, `This is a very strong budget which will go a long way towards restoring growth and lowering unemployment.'

The Managing Director of the Housing Industry Association said, `The federal budget addresses Australia's twin problems of jobs and low national saving.' The Real Estate Institute of Australia said, `The government's debt repayment schedule will help keep interest rates down.' Business writer Terry McCrann said, `The path to prosperity—Peter Costello has decisively buried the Keating legacy in more ways than one with a very good budget.' The National President of the Council on Ageing said, `We are particularly pleased about the initiatives for carers . . . we appreciate the initiatives to improve acute care in the public hospital system.'

The most ringing endorsement of the budget came last Friday when the Reserve Bank cut official interest rates by another 0.5 per cent, bringing the total fall in rates to a massive two per cent since July last year. The government has managed to reduce interest rates to the lowest level in 24 years—an achievement that was way beyond the economic capacity of the previous government. We can all recall the painful and destructive interest rates spiral of the early 1990s. There are still people in the community who have not got over that, who have lost their businesses, their farms, their homes and so on.

The Reserve Bank has recognised the government's sensible approach to economic management aimed at eliminating the budget deficit during its first term. Low underlying inflation, good long‐term growth prospects and a continuation of the government's strong fiscal consolidation strategy confirmed in the budget were reasons given by the Reserve Bank for its decision to opt for another cut in interest rates.

Since the coalition government came to power the people of Australia have won an average cut in their housing loans of a staggering $225 a month. As the Treasurer said yesterday, comparing interest rates at the height of the Keating government to interest rates today would mean a difference of about $800 on an average home payment. That is about an average fortnightly wage. That has been a remarkable turnaround.

The coalition government's management of the economy and the creation of a strong economic environment will see benefits flow to rural and regional areas of Australia, including my electorate of Riverina. The coalition government has always believed that regional Australia, small business and family farms deserve a better deal.

The budget contained a number of initiatives totalling $4 billion in future spending for regional areas, which will begin the long process of overcoming the damage of 13 years of Labor. Rural health has been a major priority in this budget, which contained a range of measures designed to improve access to health care support programs for Australians living in regional and rural areas—programs taken for granted by those living in the cities.

The government's measures include: $17 million over four years to target major rural and remote health priority areas with emphasis on extending specialist medical training in rural areas; the creation of a rural and remote health support program to increase flexibility in addressing changing priorities; and $5 million for a one‐year pilot study to develop alternative funding arrangements for rural obstetric services aimed at improved access in identified rural and remote communities.

A number of towns in my electorate are experiencing difficulties attracting doctors to their communities—a crisis situation that has been exacerbated over the last 13 years. In sharp contrast to our predecessors, the coalition government, through a wide range of policies announced in its last two budgets, is making a concerted effort to tackle the problem of a shortage of rural doctors—an effort that is being given due recognition and praise in those affected communities in my electorate.

The battle was also won to protect Medicare offices in regional areas. Not one Medicare office outside the capital cities will close and the government has taken the initiative to improve access to Medicare services for country people by introducing electronic lodgment of Medicare claim forms direct from doctors' surgeries and the establishment of Medicare agencies in pharmacies.

The first round of those Medicare claim areas in pharmacies has been announced. I am hopeful that towns in my electorate like Leeton will soon be provided with that service. It takes up to 17 days for many people to obtain their Medicare rebate. I understand that part of the problem is a 10-day delay which was introduced by the previous government.

Our primary industries have also benefited from the budget, which contained a number of initiatives such as the integrated rural policy package worth $198 million, $76 million for increased quarantine services, $44 million to reform AQIS's meat inspection program and $37 million for the national land and water audit. The $76 million for increased quarantine services is very important, given the recent outbreak of fire blight in Australia. It shows just how vigilant we have to be with plants, animals and produce—anything that is brought into Australia that can carry disease into our area.
These measures are designed to improve the service provision of government programs which, under Labor, were of no real assistance to regional families.

The coalition government is committed to delivering a more efficient waterfront for Australian exports, and that means more jobs for our regions. Our high cost, inefficient waterfront costs jobs and millions of dollars in lost export opportunities for our regional industries. The government is determined to ensure that our waterfront becomes efficient and the proposed removal of cabotage could lead to reductions in freight rates of between 20 and 25 per cent or $120 million to $150 million on current figures.

There is also good news for country people on the education front following strong lobbying by National Party members and senators on behalf of their constituents. In recognition of the fact that country people face additional costs in providing an education to those children who have to leave home to further their studies at a tertiary or TAFE level, the budget contains an increase in the dependant deduction used for the parental income test for Austudy from $3,700 to $7,400 for families where two or more students have been sent away from home to study.

Our regions are also the big winners in the work for the dole scheme and the historic $1.25 billion investment in our natural heritage. That was an amount that was opposed by the opposition, but I believe this natural heritage program is one of the most exciting programs we have seen in Australia. Certainly in my area of the Riverina and the whole of the Murray-Darling Basin I believe great work will be done and it is certainly long overdue.

The budget recognised the high levels of youth unemployment in regional areas and it is now expected that most of the 70 projects, comprising up to 10,000 places, will be located in non‐metropolitan regions. My electorate in the Riverina of New South Wales is one of the largest irrigation and horticultural productions regions in Australia. The MIA's history spans 80 years and the system is now suffering from stress as well as rising levels of salinity, silt and pollutants. The Murrumbidgee River and the MIA must be given priority in the government's national rivercare initiative and national landcare program, which are vital strategies aimed at sustainable agricultural production.

Regional roads are also receiving a significant funding boost in the budget. In excess of $2.37 billion has been allocated for future roadworks Australia wide. In 1997-98, more than 90 per cent of direct Commonwealth road funding will be spent in rural areas, creating a total of 19,000 jobs. I would like to thank the federal government for the allocation of funds for the Kidman Way which is a very important alternative route from Melbourne to Darwin.

The lack of domestic capital is a major reason why many Australian companies go offshore to invest. Under Labor, there was no incentive to save. The coalition government, acutely aware of this problem, has taken action in the budget to reverse the situation and endeavour to return savings to their pre-Whitlam level in order to boost domestic investment and create jobs.

As part of that strategy, from 1 July 1999 there will be a savings rebate on up to $3,000 of combined personal undeducted superannuation contributions and/or net income from a broad range of savings and investments, including shares. Savers will be eligible for up to $450 per annum and there will be a transitional rebate of up to $225 in 1998-99. The coalition government is the first Australian government in history to offer a tax break on savings to give Australians an incentive to save. The innovative savings policy will not only boost savings; it will boost domestic investment and ensure Australian small businesses, farmers and families have a large pool of domestic capital to use in their economic activities.

The opposition's negative protestations on this issue have been shown for what they are—hollow rhetoric. The member for Brisbane, who spoke before me, also raised this matter. Claims that the savings bonus would only benefit the rich have been completely destroyed by the results of independent research undertaken by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling at the University of Canberra on behalf of Bankers Trust. This research revealed that 79 per cent of savings income eligible for the rebate is earned by people with taxable incomes of less than $40,000. It also found that half of savings income within the scheme's cap of $3,000 was earned by people with taxable incomes of less than $20,000.

Since winning government in 1996, the coalition has launched a wide range of initia tives aimed at boosting small business, and this program of assistance continued in the budget. Businesses with an annual tax withholding obligation of $25,000 or less under the PAYE and reportable payments systems will have the option to make payments quarterly rather than monthly. More than 300,000 small businesses, including those in my electorate, will be able to reduce their paperwork through this measure which builds on other reforms already put in place.

From July this year, small business proprietors will be able to gain relief from the capital gains tax when they dispose of their businesses to purchase a similar business, and up to $500,000 from the sale of the business will be exempt from the capital gains tax if that money is used to fund retirement.

I now want to comment on a few of the statements made by the member for Brisbane. I must admit that I have not heard many previous speakers, but there is no doubt that, as you travel around the community, there is a great deal of uncertainty in the community. I must agree with the member for Brisbane in that I think it is related to job losses, and that is a tragedy. One of the main aims of the present federal government is to create jobs and to create job certainty.

We have had a great deal of this uncertainty developing over the last 13 years, and even before that. Times change with automation, with computer systems and the need to improve technology if you want to survive in the real world. That does create uncertainty. I must admit that. It is this government's intention to try to overcome some of that uncertainty—to use the levers of fiscal and monetary policy to create a steady growth in the economy, not a boom and bust growth but a growth which people can rely on. We are hoping that, by the end of this year, that certainty will be there and that people will want to invest, will want to get on with the job.

But you cannot change what has happened over the last 13 years in 12 months. While I know that members on the opposite side have been asking, `Where are the jobs? Where is the growth? Where is everything else?', you cannot forget the foreign debt that was im posed on us by a previous government. You cannot change the fact that we had these tremendous interest rates which affected communities, and which still affect communities. You cannot have a system where you are creating all these phoney jobs and spending millions and million of dollars of taxpayers' money without any real relief and without any real jobs. You cannot change all that in five minutes. It is impossible for anyone to do.

We are doing our best. I can guarantee the people of Australia that this government has the interests of the nation at heart. We want to create jobs. We want to give certainty to people. We want to be able to protect families. As I said at the start of my speech, our main aims are to create jobs, to help Australian families and to give a boost to small business, and that is very important. While we are talking about small business, we do not have control of the Senate. Many of those measures that we are trying to bring forward to assist small business are being held up in the Senate. We want to encourage savings, and we have taken steps to do that. As I said before, it is not only the wealthy that will gain from this; it is right across the board. Finally, and very importantly, we want to repay debt.

I am very proud of the achievements of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in what they have done so far. We intend to keep on this path, a steady path, despite a lot of criticism. I am sure you will find that our record will compare more than favourably with the previous government's as we go about the task of creating jobs, looking after Australian families and creating an environment in Australia where there is security.

It is not only those things I spoke about earlier. Here in opposition we have people who were previously—and I just thought of this when I was speaking—all for tariff reduction. Now they have changed their tune. They do not believe in tariff reduction anymore. Then they were for privatisation. Now they do not believe in privatisation anymore. No wonder the people of Australia are uncertain. It is up to us in the parliament to create certainty in Australia. Through this budget, I am sure we are going to do that. We are certainly on the right path so that, when we come to next year, we will have a budget surplus and we will be able to do all these things that we want to do for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the major shortcomings of the government's budget for 1996-97—that is, the current budget—was the total absence of initiatives that might have encouraged an increase in private savings. In this way, that budget mirrored successive budgets of the former Labor administration. Despite its election promise to the contrary and at the expense of domestic savings, the Howard government continued to shore up the Treasury's coffers in the 1996-97 financial year by increasing existing taxes and introducing new ones under the guise of levies, surcharges and user pays schemes.
