SPEECH.PARA: By contrast, this budget incorporates several measures which, for the first time in more than a decade, have the potential to attract meaningful levels of savings back into superannuation and other savings vehicles. Some have argued that the proposed 15 per cent tax rebate on savings is not the most effective means of boosting domestic savings. But the government deserves commendation for engineering a scheme that is generous and easy to administer; that has negligible compliance costs; and which will apply to all taxpayers, regardless of income.

The broad based savings rebate rewards current savers and should promote a greater level of savings in the future. This measure at last gives something back to the people who voted the coalition into office at the last election but who got next to nothing from the new government in its first budget. It is true that the rebate on savings held in banks will mostly benefit higher income earners. But the application of the rebate to the first $3,000 in personal contributions to superannuation means that lower and middle income households will also gain from this initiative. The rebate will have the dual effect of reducing an individual's tax liability in the immediate term, while encouraging more Australians to become self-reliant in the longer term.

BREAK.PARA: The government has suggested that this rebate could be used to help finance private health insurance, and so reverse the trend which is seeing a record number of Australians relying on the public health care system. Hypothetically, this makes good sense. But the reality is that the maximum $450 rebate is insufficient to cover the annual cost of most private health insurance premiums, or even recent increases in those premiums. In some cases, increases in the cost of private health insurance will still exceed the combined benefits of the savings rebate and the new private health insurance rebate.

Twelve years ago, half of all Australians were covered by a private health insurance policy; today that figure has declined to, at best, one in three. Partly as a result, federal government spending on health care has increased by 20 per cent in five years.

Both the savings and health care rebates are welcomed. But they will not, of course, see any significant increase in the number of Australians reverting to the private health care system. So a problem for this and future governments remains.

Despite possible quibbles about some of the measures within it, this budget is a prudent one. It sees the continuation of a long awaited and much needed budgetary reform process that sets out to restore some balance to the nation's finances. Assuming that the figures provided by Treasury are indeed accurate, this budget will see the underlying budget deficit cut to $3.9 billion, or 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product—an improvement of some $3 billion on the current financial year.

In contrast to the budgets of the early 1990s, which bore little or no relationship to Labor Party policy, this budget is consistent with the coalition's election commitments—although by no means comprehensively so. It is the second of a budget trilogy that the government hopes will establish an underlying surplus in 1998-99 somewhere in the vicinity of $1.6 billion, with a zero government borrowing requirement and no further tax increases. If successful, the government should be complimented by all for turning around a chronic budget imbalance in a very short period of time.

By way of further contrast, the Labor Party's approach to fiscal policy was a sham. It refused to acknowledge the need for a broadening of the tax base, and continued to lean hard on personal and business income tax for revenue. In its relentless pursuit of revenue, the previous government did not only introduce new taxation measures, such as the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes; it expanded the scope and rates of the wholesale sales tax as well.

More insidiously, the previous Labor regime brought forward the times by which existing taxes must be paid. Imputation of company dividends, payment of business income tax by quarterly instalments and quarterly instalments of provisional tax payments, and the prescribed payments system, are all cases in point.

Simultaneously, Labor in government used fiscal policy to drive interest rates to historical highs. The effect of its raid on small business cash flows, by expanding the wholesale sales tax regime by new taxes and by the earlier collection of existing taxes, was to force business to either borrow or raise capital by either retaining profits or issuing paper.

Apart from the more obvious effect that this had on the efficacy of business across the nation, it further emasculated our private sector savings. That might have been all right if the savings were merely transferred to the public sector, but the Labor government spent the takings like a drunken sailor. The two budget surpluses it did manage in 13 years were as much a product of earlier collections of business taxes as of increased and new taxes. Forced as they were to collectively raise tens of billions of dollars instead of relying on cash flow, SMEs were devastated by the high cost of money under Labor.

And all for what? In the cases of taxes collected earlier than before, once‐off—at best twice‐off—benefit to the budget bottom line. Obviously the affected taxpayers did not pay more tax. What was paid earlier than usual could not be required later—hence the one‐off benefit to revenue.

This government, in the fullness of time and perhaps in the lead‐up to its next budget, might seriously think about giving the economic powerhouses that SMEs can be the chance to play a leading part in regenerating our national economy. It might reverse Labor's policy of earlier collection of taxes in too many cases payable before the SMEs had themselves been paid by their customers for the goods and services which gave rise to the specific tax obligations.

To do so will not adversely affect the budget bottom line after the first year. It would, however, return much needed working capital to SMEs without changing current tax obligations. Furthermore, such a reversal would eliminate one of the effects of the present regime of early collection of taxes which all too often requires SMEs to lend money to the Commonwealth because the final wash‐up of a year's trading reveals refunds of taxes paid in advance are necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the legacies of the former Labor administration was that Commonwealth general government net debts sat at around 19 per cent of gross domestic product when the coalition took over the reins in 1996. If the coalition's fiscal program delivers the goods it expects, then this compo nent of debt will be reduced by almost half to 10.5 per cent of GDP in the year 2000‐01.

BREAK.PARA: The 1997‐98 budget is premised on a more responsible fiscal platform, one that recognises that a reduction in the deficit must occur through the control of public expenditure and the encouragement of domestic savings, and not through increased taxes. But, while unemployment levels may be contained in the short term as a result of the government's decision not to increase the levels of income tax, it is no substitute for a sensible and thorough reform of our taxation system.

The decision to reward workers who defer their pensions for up to five years should impact positively on aggregate savings and in a small way improve our balance of payments score sheet. The maximum tax‐free lump sum of $21,251 for a single person and $35,450 for a couple is the equivalent of 47 per cent of the pension entitlement over a five‐year period. This initiative will cost the Australian taxpayer half of what it would cost to fund a full pension over the same period—a pretty substantial saving.

More than 80 per cent of people over retirement age currently rely on aged or service pensions as their principal source of income, and any easing of that funding burden should be welcomed. It will also mean an increase in compulsory personal superannuation contributions for each additional year of employment. Given that the participation of older men in the work force is undergoing a long‐term decline in Australia, the importance of initiatives such as this one should not be underplayed.

In the absence of policies which encourage an extended working life, future generations of taxpayers will have to sustain debilitating levels of pension support. Accordingly, the introduction of the tax‐free lump sum payment to those who postpone retirement should be applauded.

In the same way the coalition is right to introduce measures that will see the preservation of retirement savings for retirement purposes. The decision to preserve all superannuation contributions and savings until the increased preservation age of 60 by the year 2025 is an important one, despite the 28‐year lead time. This initiative demonstrates an understanding that there needs to be greater integration between social security and retirement income policies to cope with the challenges presented by an ageing population.

To those who argue that this initiative will encourage older Australians to remain active in the paid work force at the expense of employment for younger Australians, a recent publication from the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia, the CCIWA, on the factors affecting youth employment give that supposition some perspective. The CCIWA makes it clear that conversations about youth unemployment figures are often based on misinformation. It shows that not only have the number and percentage of young people looking for full‐time work in 1996 decreased from 1981, but that 40 per cent of all 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds who were unemployed in August 1996 were in full‐time education and looking for part‐time work.

Given that an individual can qualify for the new pension rebate by working for 25 hours each week, this initiative should see the creation of many part‐time positions sought after by these full‐time students. However, it is not contended that this initiative will solve our national unemployment problem—far from it. Nor, for that matter, will the work for the dole pilot scheme or the billion dollar Federation Fund.

The only solution to the perennial curse of unemployment is to improve national savings, reduce the budget deficit and foster business growth and investment while keeping inflation in check. A reduction in unemployment will only come about through a commitment to a policy line which might involve short‐term pain but is necessary to produce longer term benefits.

The government has indicated that it favours stronger economic growth to improve employment opportunities rather than policies specifically geared towards resolving the unemployment problem. There is a growth dividend in prospect, which promises to alleviate strain on the next and possibly ensuing budgets. It is banking on a strengthening of economic growth to 3.75 per cent in 1997-98 to maintain unemployment levels for that year. The government's claimed commitment to industrial relations reform and to reducing the budget deficit indicates that it knows the right path on which to travel to secure a longer term turnaround in unemployment.

It may be that a growth rate of less than four per cent will prevent unemployment levels from worsening, and it does seem unlikely that economic growth will do much more than preserve the status quo in the foreseeable future. However, economic growth, combined with mainly conservative estimates in this budget, will open up opportunities to ease the pressure of high unemployment in the future.

It is questionable whether this budget will facilitate adequate levels of business investment to stimulate longer term employment opportunities. Admittedly, industry has escaped the savaging it copped last year from the departments of Treasury and Finance.

But while industry might breathe a sigh of relief that assistance programs have not been further slashed, there is little in this budget that will directly promote a greater level of business investment. Take, for example, the infrastructure borrowing scheme. While the scheme has been maintained by the government, at least for the 1997-98 financial year, its eligibility criteria are now so narrow that less than 10 per cent of the projects currently in the pipeline would now qualify for the tax concessions.

There is a consensus amongst economists that a nation's rate of investment impacts directly on how quickly an economy can grow. There is clear evidence to suggest that declining levels in infrastructure investment over the last three decades have led to a decline in a sustainable rate of economic growth in this country.

An injection of investment expenditure is necessary to help reverse unemployment and the decline in public sector savings that became a long‐term structural problem under Labor. Further, the government should encourage revenue earning, productive investment. The government's estimates show that it anticipates total business investment will increase by eight per cent in the four quarters to June 1998. This figure represents less than half that experienced in the current year and may yet prove to be an unduly conservative estimate.

The decision to simplify and rationalise withholding tax obligations for some small businesses is good policy. Small businesses that qualify for this relief will see the number of their transactions with the Australian Taxation Office reduced to a third of the present level. This in turn should see the reduction in compliance costs for a number of small businesses.

The government stated in Budget Paper No 2 that this measure represents `a significant first step towards simplifying the range of withholding tax systems imposed on small business.' This would warm the soul of any small business proprietor.

The coalition professes to believe that small to medium sized enterprises—SMEs—provide the engine to economic growth and employment. The government is arguably correct in that assumption. Although it has claimed that small business has benefited or will benefit under its governance, it is far from universally agreed. Polls of SMEs would indicate the opposite—that, indeed, the government has a long way to go before its deeds match its rhetoric.

Except when called on to defend the election undertaking to reduce the incidence of red tape affecting the operations of small businesses by 50 per cent, the coalition no longer makes any pretence of meeting that goal. It will, however, not embark on reform of the taxation system as required by this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in rising to support the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. The fact that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has been able to reduce in the one parliamentary term a deficit of $10.5 billion to a $1 billion‐plus surplus is something that I think that he should be very proud of. This is a very sound budget and, as I said, the Treasurer certainly needs to be congratulated and indeed is to be commended for continuing the very difficult task of making this ship of state of ours seaworthy. We are now back on course.

SPEECH.PARA: Through this budget the coalition continues its commitment to helping families, boosting small business, creating jobs, and encouraging saving. Confidence and growth are the framework for the Treasurer's 1997‐98 budget.

The coalition's second budget provides us with mechanisms by which we can build a future of opportunity for all Australians. It consolidates the coalition's strategy of fixing the Commonwealth's finances and it provides choice and incentives. It does this without any increases in tax. With our policy of broad based structural reform of the economy, Australian businesses will be in position to enjoy economic growth and therefore create job opportunities for young Australians.

The coalition has continued its support for northern Australia. The Commonwealth's expected general revenue assistance to the Northern Territory for 1997‐98 will total $953.3 million. The 1997‐98 estimated general revenue assistance grant therefore represents an extra $28.2 million increase on the 1996‐97 general revenue assistance grant. This is an increase of three per cent on last year's grant.
I believe all Territorians will gain confidence from the important, informed statements by the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), in particular the statement:
The Northern Territory's economy has grown faster than the average for all jurisdictions in recent years; with this growth reflected in own‐source revenue.

That refers to revenue raised and collected in the Territory. This growth position has been achieved in spite of the Territory's fiscal disabilities associated with its small and widely dispersed population.

Throughout the financial year 1997‐98 we must hold fast to the fiscal balance position we achieved by last year's responsible, deficit correcting budget. From that position, together with the solid thrust of this budget, we have brought into focus that vital source of economic vitality and power—business competence. I believe that the budget policies of this government will lift the pace of economic growth in this country and create the job opportunities forecast by the Treasurer. You might well ask why I have such confidence. It is because I have close day to day contact with people in my electorate of the Northern Territory; it is because I am in touch with the wide range of business organisations operating in the territory; and it is because I know the mood of the people and of the business organisations in the territory. The economic growth of the territory is self‐evident to those with eyes to see and ears to hear.

Perhaps I should suggest to Senator Bob Collins that he opens his eyes and clears his ears. By so doing, he might see and hear for himself that economic growth in the territory is truly on the way up. In real terms, job opportunities continue to abound in the Northern Territory because there is a consistency and compatibility between the policies of the federal coalition government, led by our Prime Minister, the Hon. John Howard, and the territory's Country‐Liberal Party government, led by the Chief Minister, the Hon. Shane Stone.

I would like to take the opportunity to provide honourable members with evidence of economic growth and job opportunities within the Northern Territory. Firstly, the Northern Territory's economy continues to grow at a fast rate and is expected to continue to go even higher. The Hon. Mike Reed, Treasurer of the Northern Territory, states that the economic growth rate will be sustained at around five per cent per annum over the next few years. I am proud to say that this rate of growth in the Northern Territory is a testament to the responsible government of the Country‐Liberal Party over the last 23 years. The sensible fiscal management of the territory has meant that the territory is now enjoying a rate of growth significantly higher than that of the national forecast of around 3.7 per cent.

I am in no doubt that the territory's economic growth rate has been sustained by the flow‐on effect from the economic and fiscal policies of both the federal and the territory governments. In this context, and in terms of the territory government's specific budget policies, it is important to note that the private sector is a major contributor to the territory's economic growth. Private capital expenditure over the past few years has increased dramatically and is expected to continue to do so. As a consequence of business confidence, the territory's unemployment rate of 5.5 per cent is the lowest in Australia. This is more than three percentage points lower than the national average. It is evident to most of us that the private sector orientated policies do provide jobs. It follows that our policies have resulted in the territory's higher than average participation rate for its labour force. In particular, employment growth has been, and continues to be, positively influenced by the continuing expansion in tourism and an impressive growth in the mining and transportation industries, plus sustained growth in the rural sector with particular emphasis on the live cattle export trade to South‐East Asia.

From statements made recently by the Hon. Mike Reed, Treasurer of the Northern Territory, independent employment forecasts predict that Northern Territory employment will increase by 3.2 per cent during 1997‐98. Without question, the continuing movement of defence personnel and logistics in the territory will have a confidence‐building, beneficial flow‐on to the private sector.

The coalition's budget, as tabled, provides a catalyst for yet further improvement in the level of employment. The budget provides about $143.1 million for defence, for major and medium capital works facilities in the territory. These capital works include: $80.3 million for continuing work on the first and second stages of the army presence in the north project; $14 million towards the development of Bradshaw Station as a northern exercise area for the defence forces; $14.5 million—$13.3 million for base developments, stages 3 and 4, and $1.2 million for a child‐care centre at RAAF Base Tindal; $13.3 million towards the post‐force review development, involving a variety of works at RAAF Base Darwin; $8.3 million towards the north Australia naval infrastructure, stage 1; $3.2 million for the construction of airmen's reaction facilities in Darwin; $3.1 million on project DEF 333 at Shoal Bay; $3.2 million for extensions to technical support surface finishing facilities at Tindal; and $3.1 million for the construction of other defence facilities at Darwin and Tindal. These capital works projects will also impact on the territory's employment and overall economic growth position. Bearing these factors in mind, the forecast increase of 3.2 per cent in employment to which I referred previously is a realistic forecast.

Turning to the mining industry—the largest industry in the territory—this industry recorded an increase in value of production for the second consecutive year. Both mineral and energy production were up in 1996‐97, with the outlook for both sectors being very promising. Production for 1997‐98 is estimated at $1.8 billion.

There is one issue on which I find myself differing with some honourable members: the lack of progress on the commencement of uranium mining at Jabiluka. Honourable members will recall that this government has discarded Labor's restrictive three‐mines policy. I suggest that the economy and job opportunities across the country as a whole would be improved by the commencement of operations at the Jabiluka mine. In this context, it is to be noted that gold mining operations in the territory are increasing in value of production, with new gold mines and major upgrades of existing mines planned.

The recent agreement to go ahead with the massive Laminaria‐Corallina oilfield project has, without question, lifted the air of confidence surrounding the territory's energy industry. It is important to note that massive projects such as these will have a significant impact upon the overall national upturn in economic growth foreshadowed by the Treasurer.

The return contribution, that is, the flow‐on benefit back to the Commonwealth by reason of the territory's economic growth contribution via mining, tourism, pastoral and other major industries, should not be underestimated. It is a two‐way affair. It is the private sector's capital investment and growth activities in Australia that are fundamental to the success of the budget now before the House.

Other major capital works activity in the territory includes the federal government's road program. The upgrading of the Victoria Highway has resulted in a significant improvement to the infrastructure road system serving the territory's pastoral, horticultural and tourist industries. Following completion of the upgrading of the Victoria Highway attention will be directed to the Stuart and Barkly highways. The budget has allocated $53.02 million to the Northern Territory for road funding in 1997-98. That level of spending will create or sustain about 720 road construction jobs.

Included in this funding for the territory is $24.86 million for maintenance and construction on the Stuart, Victoria and Barkly high ways and $560,000 on selected accident black spots in the Northern Territory. There is a further $18.9 million contribution by the Commonwealth to augment spending by the Northern Territory government on major roads and an $8.7 million allocation to local councils for spending on minor roads under their control.

Funding in these latter two categories is untied and to the extent to which it is spent on roads will be at the discretion of the territory or council. In 1998‐99, work is expected to start on replacing the Elizabeth River bridge south of Darwin. It is likely that the existing bridge will be replaced by a high level crossing which would improve the flood immunity of the Stuart Highway and therefore allow easy road access to Darwin in the event of a cyclone or other flooding emergency. This bridge is expected to cost in the vicinity of $2.5 million. The overall strengthening of the infrastructure capacity of the territory and the importance of these and other territory roadworks to our industries generally is reaffirmed by this budget.

I now turn to the budget measures for securing the future of indigenous territorians. Of significant importance to the future of indigenous territorians is the government's undertaking that ATSIC funding would be guaranteed for four years. This guarantee will provide the ATSIC board with greater flexibility and greater financial security. There will be no funding cuts to the ATSIC budget and some extra funds will go to priority areas such as employment and business development. As well as maintaining the community development employment project—CDEP— quarantine provisions, the government will provide funding for some 30,800 places with an allowance for natural growth of some 600 places. In addition, the government has provided $5 million which will go towards programs to reduce high indigenous incarceration rates.

The government has also set aside $1 million for a range of pilot projects to integrate young offenders into economic and community life. A review of Abstudy will make sure that funds are used more effectively with $122.5 million for 1997‐98 and a further $493.3 million to 2001 in continued Abstudy support. Some $216 million per year from ATSIC's budget must be spent on community housing and infrastructure projects. An additional $10 million per year over the next four years will go towards economic initiatives. I consider the 1997-98 budget affirms the government's willingness to improve conditions for indigenous Australians and to provide the necessary resources in the most effective and positive way.

I would now like to turn to the budget papers covering federal financial relations for 1997‐98. The Treasurer and the Minister for Finance commented in relation to budgetary and financial developments in the Northern Territory:

The Northern Territory economy has grown faster than the average for all jurisdictions in recent years, with this growth reflected in own‐source revenue. Moreover, under the horizontal fiscal equalisation principles, the Northern Territory continues to receive a relatively large share of the pool of Commonwealth general revenue assistance.

The Northern Territory's fiscal contribution to the Commonwealth in terms of the arrangements agreed to in 1996 and 1997 at the Premiers Conferences is $6.3 million. The overall position of the territory is that, with the support of the Commonwealth funding and growth reflected in own source revenue, the Northern Territory's economy is on the move. Earlier in my supporting comments on the Treasurer's 1997-98 budget I detailed a rate of expansion of industries in and around the territory. I commented on the significance of continued Commonwealth funding and also highlighted the importance of the infrastruc ture improvements now taking place in the Northern Territory.

I will conclude my supporting remarks on the Treasurer's 1997‐98 budget with a comment on the Federation Fund. It is with great leadership and vision that the Prime Minister has established the Federation Fund. Clearly, this $1 billion capital fund is designed to be focused on providing support for major infrastructure projects of national significance.

TALK.START.PARA: —And marginal seats.

—Honourable members will no doubt support my view that the Darwin‐Alice Springs rail link is a prime candidate for approval under the criteria of the Federation Fund. That is not a marginal seat. That is a promise that the Commonwealth made to the Northern Territory in 1910.
—Order! The honourable member shall direct his remarks through the chair.
—I think the donkey vote got you over the line.

—It may have, but I am here. The Prime Minister's statement in this place made it quite clear that the fund would not be used to build 1,000 obelisks in 1,000 towns, but infrastructure projects that would link communities and employ a large number of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The railway has the financial support of the Northern Territory and the South Australian governments with each of them providing $100 million in capital grants. More than 2,000 jobs will be created in South Australia and the Northern Territory. Many more jobs will be created indirectly across Australia as a result of the opening of the southern states to trade in Asia. The Northern Territory Minister for the Railway, the honourable Barry Coulter MLA, has been kind enough to supply me with some figures which I believe reveal the significance of the project.

The railway will use: 155,000 tonnes of steel rail and 3,500 tonnes of structural steel; 2.3 million sleepers form 170,000 tonnes of steel or 240,000 cubic metres of pre‐stressed concrete; 100,000 cubic metres of reinforced concrete; 15 kilometres of concrete culvert pipe; two million cubic metres of ballast; and 17 million cubic metres of earthworks. These figures really speak volumes about the economic and trade benefits for Australia resulting from the railway. The construction of the railway will create jobs in our domestic steel industry at a time when the industry is facing increasing pressure to remain internationally competitive.

Honourable members are well aware that the Northern Territory is Australia's trading door to Asia. There can be no doubt that the Darwin-Alice Springs railway is an infrastructure project of national significance. The Northern Territory government estimates that the railway has an economic life of at least 100 years. This means a long-term benefit to the nation up to and surpassing the second centenary of federation. Once again I congratulate the Treasurer on his budget and commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans). In doing so, I specifically want to focus on a couple of the issues raised in the second reading amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Principally, as the shadow minister for employment and training, I want to pay some attention to the all important issue of jobs because, as the second reading amendment suggests, it is the nation's most overwhelming current economic and social problem. In that context I also raises point three of the second reading amendment, which goes to the continuing assault on families. To my way of thinking the most important issue to families at the moment is not only getting a job but the all important issue of job security.

Finally, I would also like to raise at the outset the community's reaction to the budget. That goes to the concerns expressed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, Mr Evans, in point six of his second reading amendment, which basically suggests that even the government's best friends have described this budget as one lacking in shape, direction and vision.

In that context I would just briefly like to remind the House of the reaction by the head of the Business Council of Australia, Mr Stan Wallis, just over a week ago and also the reaction by the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures in the form of Katie Leahy. They had some telling remarks concerning the budget, basically on the issue which is raised by Mr Evans in the second reading amendment; that is, the issue of jobs and the lack of direction and leadership that the budget gives on the jobs front.

On that note, can I say that I believe it is for that very reason that the Howard government has today got the wobblies—it is to a large extent because of the reaction by the Australian community to the budget. It lacks leadership. It has lost its balance and it is shaking. I know for a fact that that was the message given to the government, especially the backbench, when they returned to their electorates just over a week ago following the delivery of the budget by the Treasurer, Mr Costello.

It is clear today that in the cities, the towns, the suburbs, and the rural and regional areas the community has quickly given up on this government. The budget has disappeared. It is not an issue of major discussion out in the pubs and the child-care centres and the schools and the streets of suburban and regional Australia today. That is because the budget was a dud. It snubbed the unemployed. It gave no hope to families on the issue of job security.

It is for that very reason that the Australian community has given up on its national leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). He promised so much before the election but has delivered so little when it comes to the priority issues—the issues of jobs and job security. You yourself know that, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, because of the broken promise in your own electorate of Bendigo with respect to the issue of job creation and the promise given by the Prime Minister to construct that all important art gallery—the big black hole in View Street, Bendigo. That was a promise forgotten soon after the recent federal election.

That is because, unfortunately, Australia today has a road show. It is a road show best described as the Mr Wishy-Washy and Mr Smug budget road show. Can I say that in the lead-up to the budget I think the Prime Minister and the Treasurer went out to create an expectation across the length and breadth of Australia that the government was going to do something on the jobs front, but the problem is that the one clear reason that the community has begun to turn its face against the government is its actual failure to deliver on the jobs front.

I think that is just plain wrong. I suggest that it is plain wrong because the Howard government came to power saying that jobs were the No. 1 priority. That was the No. 1 issue that it was going to work so hard to create. The government said to the Australian electorate that it was going to go out of its way to create jobs, jobs and more jobs and, in doing so, lock into Australia a sense of job security. The real problem is that, when you really examine the facts as to the performance of this government over the last 12 months, the government has spent more time destroying jobs than creating jobs.

In an attempt to turn around the Australian community's negative response to this government's budget, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer spent much of the week leading up to the budget promising that the 1997 budget would be a jobs budget. They especially promised to do so much for jobs in regional Australia—regional seats such as the seat of Corangamite. That was the catchcry—be it in Bendigo, Ballarat, Townsville, Cairns, Broome, Launceston or Burnie.

The real issue for this government was to face up to the fact that regional Australia was demanding a sense of security and that the key to creating that sense of security in Australia was to create jobs. They talked it up and up: go out and examine the regional newspapers in the week prior to the budget. There was story after story about the need for this government to give a helping hand to regional Australia, to actually do something through infrastructure development and government activities to create jobs.

The problem for the government is that after that build‐up the Australian community was let down. What a big bang it was—all talk and no substance. When the Australian community actually went through the fine print of the budget, what it came out with was no real plan to do anything for jobs—nothing for jobs in 1997 and, more importantly, nothing for jobs in regional and suburban Australia.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer, I suggest, have made no attempt at all in this budget to devise a comprehensive job strategy. Instead, the 1997 budget followed the precedents of the 1996 budget. Unfortunately, not only does it not create jobs or create a sense of security on the jobs front in the Australian community but in actual fact this budget yet again abolishes jobs.

I go to the issue of direct Australian government employment. By the end of the impact of the first two budgets of this government, we will see 28,000 Australian public servants lose their jobs—16,500 of those public servants will disappear as a direct result of the impact of this budget. Australians are now starting to understand that those public servants are not employed in Canberra; they are actually employed in their local suburbs, in their towns and in their local regional centres. Those people were employed in such important work as providing essential services to Australians—the local Medicare office; the local CES office; the regional Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs branches; the local family law court in Tasmania; and the local branch of the Australian Taxation Office in Cairns.

In centre after centre not only are government jobs going and families and communities suffering as a result of those government jobs going but, importantly for those local communities, essential services are also disappearing. That is a huge setback for those centres—a setback on the jobs front and a setback when it comes to access for all Australians, irrespective of where you live, irrespective of the nature of the job that you have or irrespective of whether you require a service to try to get one of those all‐important jobs. The services that actually facilitate access to those opportunities in life have disappeared as a result of government employment being slashed.

For that reason, no wonder the Howard government has got the wobblies. No wonder it has lost its balance in the last couple of weeks. No wonder it is shaking, as reflected in the most recent opinion polls. No wonder it is clear that in the cities, the towns, the suburbs, and the rural and regional areas the community has quickly given up on this government. The community has quickly given up on the lack of leadership over in the oval office where the Prime Minister resides. It is no wonder, and we all know it.

What were we talking about very soon after the budget? Not questions of what the budget was going to do about jobs, not questions about what the budget was going to do to reintroduce services to regional Australia, not questions about what the budget was going to do to rebuild industry assistance to create jobs in the private sector. No, those issues disappeared within 48 hours of the delivery of the budget. What we then had to debate was a GST. A new smokescreen was created by the Prime Minister. Having faced up to the fact that, unfortunately, his budget was a dud and lost out there in the Australian community, he had to create a new issue for debate.

The 1997 budget has disappeared without trace because it is a dud. I will tell you why it is unfortunate that it has disappeared without trace: in the lead-up to the 1996 election, the then Leader of the Opposition made much of his comments about jobs, especially jobs for young people—those 92,000 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds who are out there at the moment desperately looking for jobs. They are told on a day-to-day basis by their mums and dads, `You have to front up and try to get a job.'

This is what the Prime Minister had to say to those mums and dads and those young people in the lead-up to the last election. The Prime Minister had many opportunities to make comments along these lines, as he did on numerous occasions prior to the election, but I refer to an article headed `Career goal is youth jobs'. Mr Howard, the then Leader of the Opposition, bravely told the West Australian on 29 February 1996, only just before the federal election of last March:
We have gone into this election campaign committing ourselves above all other things to doing something effective and doing something realistic to reduce the level of youth unemployment.

I will be a very disappointed man if I have not made very serious inroads into the level of youth unemployment in this country because I would like to see our performance in that area as being the mark of what we have been able to do as a government.

What has been the result of those brave promises 12 months on? It was the Prime Minister who made youth employment a key issue in the last federal election. But in the end you have to be measured by your performance, what you actually achieve in life.

It is interesting to note that, in the first year of the Howard government, youth unemployment has not decreased; in actual fact it has jumped—not by half a per cent but by two per cent, from 27.4 per cent to 29.4 per cent. It is not just the figures we look at. What does that mean in human terms? It effectively means that, after one year of the Howard government, 91,600 young people are on the jobs queue. But that is just the young people. In actual fact, officially registered, there are 802,000 Australians of all ages who are now regarded as unemployed and 246,400 of them are classified as long-term unemployed. That is 40,000 more than at the time the Howard government slashed access to labour market programs in May of last year.

I think the Australian community is now realising that there is a huge problem not just among the young unemployed and the long-term unemployed but especially among middle aged Australians, middle aged men and women in the suburbs in places such as Sydney, Adelaide, Hobart, Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong, Cairns, Burnie and Broome. The facts show that today, for example, that there are 146,000 unemployed 35‐ to 54‐year‐old men. What does the Prime Minister say to them? `This is how I am going to create jobs: slash expenditure on labour market programs, sack public servants and do nothing to restore industry programs.'

There were big promises in the lead-up to this budget. The community expected a brave Prime Minister to create a brave vision of how the Howard government was going to do something to tackle our growing unemployment queues. But, unfortunately, nothing happened. The Australian community is coming to expect that as part and parcel of the activities of the government.

On the growth front: we require a level of economic growth of four per cent to reduce unemployment in Australia. What is the forecast? It is 3.75 per cent. Last budget they suggested that the level of unemployment today would be 8.25 per cent. They then revised it to 8.5 per cent. What is it today? It is 8.7 per cent. Now they expect the Australian community to believe that in 12 months time it will be eight per cent. If you want to achieve a level of unemployment of eight per cent, then you have to be willing to intervene, to get your hands dirty and to actually do something to create investment opportunities and confidence in this nation.

That is the real problem for this nation because to do that you require leadership—strong, committed leadership, not wishy‐washy leadership that runs from the hard decisions such as the problems confronting Newcastle and the automotive industry at the moment.

Unfortunately for Australia, when it comes to leadership in the automotive industry it was not the Prime Minister of Australia who said that we had to freeze tariffs; it was the Prime Minister of Japan who had to come to Australia and lecture the Prime Minister of Australia and tell him that if we want to retain an automotive industry in Australia then we have to face up to the fact that the industry needs ongoing support in the form of a temporary freeze on tariffs. Again the Prime Minister went missing in action. The Prime Minister of Japan says, `Yes, protect jobs in Australia, protect the automotive industry,' and the Prime Minister of Australia goes missing in action yet again.

If we are going to make progress in Australia on the most difficult challenge confronting the nation at the moment—the issue of jobs and job security—we have to face up to the fact that it requires strong leadership, not wishy‐washy leadership. In that context, the detail of the budget offers no hope for the future of Australia on the jobs front—no hope whatsoever. What do they say is now the solution to unemployment in Australia? The solution is a mickey mouse program called `work for the dole'. Today they are threaten ing a double dissolution if they do not get work for the dole through the Senate.

Today there are 802,000 Australians unemployed, 90,000 of whom are young people aged 15 to 19 years. So here is the panacea for creating jobs in Australia: work for the dole—$21 million over 12 months and some pilot projects for 10,000 places around Australia. There are 90,000 unemployed young people in Australia aged 15 to 19 years. There are 800,000 Australians unemployed, and we get 10,000 places in work for the dole for $21 million, of which $6 million is actually going to the administration of the scheme. It is not even going to create opportunities for young unemployed people.

There is no mention of training—it is two days on, five days off. And they are threatening a double dissolution over work for the dole. What a joke. Australians want jobs, mums and dads want their kids at work, but they want five days on and two days off, not two days on and five days off as work for the dole suggests.

Then we go to expenditure on vocational education and training. You also have to look at that in the context of the recent changes in migration. The government is out there suggesting that it is concerned about unemployment at the moment and has based its migration intake on that issue. I go to the facts. This government has increased independent skilled migration by 50 per cent, which is untargeted and not matched with the skill and labour market requirements of this great nation. If that is not bad enough—and we have a major unemployment problem in Australia—what does this budget actually do about training Australians to take up those skills vacancies in the future? If there are skills vacancies, and the government is suggesting that it has to bring migrants from overseas to now fill those skills vacancies, then I would have thought that the government would have laid out a plan to train unemployed Australians to take up those jobs in the future and actually invested in the training of Australians.

But go to the fine print of the budget and this is what it does. At the same time as the government is increasing independent skilled migration it has slashed $269 million from vocational education and training programs and more than $2 billion from jobs programs aimed at getting Australians back to work.

It is time this government invested in getting Australians back to work. It is time this government stopped sacking Australians who deliver vital services to all Australian centres, be they in regional or suburban Australia. It is time this government did something to fulfil the promises that it has so soon broken. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the coming financial year the Commonwealth government will actually repay $5 billion worth of debt and by June 1999 the government will have turned a $10.3 billion deficit black hole that we inherited on coming to government into a $1.6 billion surplus. That represents the first ever serious and sustainable attack on public debt by federal government, which has inherited a legacy of endemic overspending, endless deficits and rising debt. It also represents a historic watershed in the politics of fiscal responsibility. Perennial overspending with spiralling debts symbolise everything that is wrong with government.

SPEECH.PARA: Government deficits, more than anything else, highlight a failure of the political process. For too long political expediency has dictated that interest groups be bought off with frequent grants, wasteful government programs and lavish taxpayer largess. Government spending has been perceived as a fail‐safe vehicle by which to placate special interest groups, reward loyal supporters and win the support of marginal groups through unfunded generosity—all ultimately aimed at winning votes.

The political imperative of granting special favours leads inevitably to a logical conclusion: more spending, higher deficits and increased debt. To illustrate the point, we should consider the fact that in 1960 total federal government outlays were 17½ per cent of Australia's GDP. By 1996, when the Howard government came to power, the federal government's spending had risen to 27 per cent of Australia's GDP.

BREAK.PARA: For 34 of the 36 years between 1960 and 1996, real government spending grew, sometimes by as much as 15 per cent in a single year such as under the Whitlam government in 1974. Only twice in that period between 1960 and 1996 did the government of the day see fit to actually reduce its real outlays. Since 1974 the government has run surpluses only on four occasions. In the early 1970s, the federal government owed no debt. By the time that Paul Keating became Prime Minister in 1991, the Commonwealth debt was $33 billion. By the time Paul Keating left office in 1996, the public debt had trebled to around $100 billion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a graph that demonstrates that position.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —This graph clearly indicates the path along which the Keating government was taking Australia. It would have led to a debt level of close to $120 billion by the year 2000. Under the Howard government's fiscal repairs, that debt is forecast to fall to over $60 billion by the turn of the century—a remarkable turnaround. These high debts, which the Howard government inherited, were accumulated because of politics and the tendency of governments to overspend, which has not altogether been confined to Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Virtually every Western democracy has been beset by its share of fiscal excesses, caused in large measure by the underlying desire of politicians to curry favour via the pork barrel. In Newt Gingrich's book To Renew America, he describes the situation in the United States in these terms:
. . . the Congressional voting card is the most expensive credit card in the world. Trillions of dollars in debt have been rung up on it. It has seemingly unlimited credit.
Each wave of politicians has taken care of its set of special interests without having to worry about fiscal limits.
Since there was no requirement for a balanced budget, each member of the House or Senate or each Cabinet officer could always find room for one more item.

No one had to be left totally unsatisfied. There were no limits and no hard priorities. Appeasing this year's interest groups was always more important than worrying about the burdens we were creating for our children and grandchildren.

The government deficits and public debt have become endemic quite simply because the political process has promoted overspending. David Stockman, the budget director under former US President Ronald Reagan, summed this up aptly in his book The Triumph of Politics :
By the mid 1980's the Reagan transportation budget in constant dollars topped Jimmy Carter's best year by 15%, Johnson's by about 40% and Kennedy's by about 50%.
Big Government? That was something for the speechwriters to fight as long as they didn't mention any names.

The problem with all these local roads and buses was that other politicians had an equally strong case for aiding local projects—classrooms, public libraries, day care centres, alcoholism clinics and jailhouses. Spending continued largely unabated in all cases.

Stockman's efforts to reduce government spending in the United States in the early 1980s largely failed because the reality of the political process would not allow it. Politicians made demands, based on political expediency, to be satisfied by an ongoing stream of largesse from the public purse. As Stockman recalls:
The politicians mostly got what their constituents wanted, but here and there we trimmed the edges.

But my relentless deal‐making inherently yielded savings that amounted to rounding errors in a trillion dollar budget because it was based on bluff and searching out for obscure titbits of spending that could be excised without arousing massive political resistance.
Thus for example, we did get the second tier cost of living adjustment in the railroad retirement program capped below the inflation rate. This reduced overall spending by 0.0001 per cent!
In other words, there was no constituency for fiscal restraint, but there were political rewards for uncapped spending programs and generous government entitlements.

In the 1990s, we are beginning to see a stunning reversal of that political orthodoxy. For the first time in a generation, the political process is generating fiscal responsibility as voters demand austerity, accountability and restraint from their elected representatives. The debts accumulated by three decades of politics are now being addressed and reversed.

In 1992, the Kennett government came to power in Victoria with a sweeping mandate for fiscal repair. It cut government spending, reduced the public sector and engaged in an ambitious privatisation program. The combined effect of these actions has been to halve Victoria's state debt, to run consistent sustainable budget surpluses and to move steadily towards restoring Victoria's AAA credit rating. More importantly, the Kennett government received an electoral dividend, being overwhelmingly re‐elected in 1996 with a renewed mandate for sound financial management.

In 1994, Newt Gingrich and the Republican Party won control of the United States Congress, campaigning on the basis of their Contract with America. That contract promised to put an end to overspending in Washington, introducing a balanced budget amendment to the constitution, and providing the President with a line‐item veto of any new spending proposal. I quote from the Contract with America, which states:
The American people demand responsibility from Congress. The spending madness must stop.

Our Contract with America begins with fiscal responsibility. Just as every American sits at the kitchen table and balances his or her budget, just as every small business must balance its budget, Congress must begin balancing our nation's Budget—now.

Earlier this month, President Clinton and Congressional Republicans announced a deal which will see the US government budget balanced by the year 2002. That deal will see reduced growth in the big‐spending areas like health and social security but will still cut income tax and capital gains tax by around $135 billion over the next five years.

Similarly, the Howard government was elected on a mandate to attack an inherited legacy of deficit and debt without new taxes or tax increases. In fact, the government will balance the budget over a three‐year period at the same time as providing tax cuts to families, capital gains tax rollover relief to small businesses, incentives for private health insurance, and now a tax rebate for savings.

The incessant growth of the government sector has been checked. When the Howard government came to office, government spending was 27 per cent of GDP. By the year 2000, it will be less than 23 per cent. Governments, politicians and voters are demanding fiscal responsibility, less government and an end to the debt habit.

The Australian electorate is increasingly aware of the drawbacks of excessive public outlays. The problem with government overspending does not stop with the spiralling debt it creates, although debt servicing is a problem in itself.

In 1997‐98, the federal government will pay $8.5 billion just in interest payments on the public debt. The debt burden of the past has become a major budget outlay—greater than the cost of Medicare payments or assistance to the unemployed. Also, as governments borrow a greater slice of available funds, big private investment projects face scarcity of capital, higher interest rates and, ultimately, a need to borrow more funds from offshore.

Those economies which are big savers effectively generate the capital for those who are poor savers, who increase their foreign indebtedness. Big spending by government also decreases the incentive for private individuals and households to save. The unchecked growth of government in Australia over three decades has seen personal responsibility eroded, giving way to a culture of dependency. Australians now know that if they fall sick the government will look after them and they have little need to privately insure themselves. If they lose their job, the government will come to their rescue, so no‐one needs to save for a potential future loss of income.

When they get old the taxpayer will provide, so personal superannuation continues to be optional. If they have children, their child‐care, education and Austudy expenses will be subsidised, so the incentive to take personal financial responsibility for children is lessened.

Every possible contingency—from illness to child-rearing to tertiary education—is covered by some form of government provided assistance. Is it any wonder, against that backdrop, that Australians are saving less? Meanwhile, the tax system which finances this public spending has traditionally been biased against saving.

Interest from savings and investment has effectively been taxed twice: once when the fortnightly income is actually earned by the PAYE taxpayer and again when that portion which is saved yields some interest income. Higher marginal tax rates on middle income earners exacerbate the problem.

Today, household savings in Australia are at an all‐time low. Having peaked around at 14 per cent of GDP in the 1970s, household savings have steadily fallen to around eight per cent of GDP today. Big government spending and ongoing deficits are symptomatic of the wider culture which no longer values frugality and thrift. Again, to quote Newt Gingrich of America:
. . . there has been a general rule that each generation would live within its means. As a result, our children would not be stuck with the task of paying off somebody else's debt.

The principle was that we would pay off the mortgage and leave the farm to our children. There was great delight in working hard and living within our means so that our children could be better off than we had been.
Only in the last generation has this bias toward the future been reversed.

It has now become imperative for Australia to invigorate the savings and investment culture. This budget's moves to reverse the anti‐savings bias are a solid start. This budget provides a 15 per cent tax rebate for interest on savings and for personal superannuation contributions.

Significantly, the government has also moved to provide `rollover relief' from capital gains tax for small business people who sell their businesses to reinvest or provide for their retirement. That move represents a sea change in the view towards capital gains tax. This is particularly true given the exemption from capital gains tax on the family home which provides a bias in favour of housing rather than more productive investment.

I note with some interest that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) recently mentioned in his address to the Sydney Institute his hope that the government would seriously look again at the capital gains tax and its appropriateness in a modern economy where capital is mobile and entrepreneurship and risk taking are vital to realising new investment opportunities. Will international investors see Australia as an attractive investment location if we are perceived to have a punitive capital tax regime?

Unlocking Australia's future economic prosperity relies ultimately on fiscal responsibility by governments, a tax system which encourages saving and a culture which rewards investment and risk taking. Fortunately, the signs are beginning to look positive. For the first time in a generation, the political process is ceasing to generate big deficits and unchecked growth of big government.

In the United States, in Victoria and here in the federal parliament, the political process is beginning to deliver fiscal responsibility; less government; a savings, investment and risk taking culture; greater public savings; and a reduced debt burden for our children and grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is very much a good‐for‐nothing budget—a do‐nothing budget. On budget night, I thought the Treasurer (Mr Costello) could have delivered his statement in the context of a 90‐second statement to the House, such was the lack of depth and quality he brought to the issues before the parliament. This budget also represents the dwindling cause of the coalition parties because they are essentially without answers to the major issues—economic and social—facing the Australian nation in the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two strains of political philosophy within the coalition. We have just heard one from the Son of Newt—the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur)—quoting Newt Gingrich from the United States. This is the economic libertarian strain within the coalition, which holds out the answer to insecurity as individualism: the idea that individuals alone can somehow manage to combat economic and social insecurity. The truth is that the widespread insecurity in our society can be met only through collective remedies—by people working together, by finding in the public sector an expression of their values and interests held in common. So the economic libertarian strain, whether in the United States or in Australia, has had its day. It is a failed political ideology from the 1980s.

The other strain within the coalition is the sort of conservative populism we get from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—very much the politics of nostalgia. But this, of course, is just Hansonism writ small. It is an appeal to an Australia long past; an Australia which was isolated in its economics, isolated in its engagement with the region and very much isolated in terms of its social values and inclusiveness.

The coalition is faced with the failure of these two strains—the economic libertarian strain, washed out from the 1980s, and conservative populism, typified by the Prime Minister harking back to an Australia long past, and we have no way back to the 1950s and 1960s. This leaves the Prime Minister as a strange beast indeed in Australian politics. He was only ever a reformer while in opposition.

That, of course, reminds me of what Eddie Ward had to say about Bob Menzies: that Menzies' brilliant military career was cut short only by the outbreak of war. So, too, for the Prime Minister, because his brilliant career as a public policy reformer has been cut short only by the outbreak of electoral success and actually winning office. Where now are all the reforms and ideas he hoped to place on the agenda from the 1980s? He has backed away from his reputation in Australian politics as an active reformer with a cogent set of ideas and answers for the Australian people. His brilliant career as a policy reformer has been cut short yet again, by the outbreak of electoral success and actually holding office.

That was the way it was back in the 1970s and early 1980s in the Fraser government. All those reforms of economic internationalisation that were left to Labor and in particular Paul Keating in the 1980s were reforms that John Howard shied away from. It was left to Labor to bring Australia out of its slumber in the 1950s and 1960s. Again, we find in the 1990s the Prime Minister has no answers to the main challenges we now face as a nation—that is, the challenges of widespread economic insecurity.

This budget is making Australians feel much less secure, particularly in the area of education. With Australia's education system still reeling from last year's budget, universities and TAFE have had to cop a double whammy of 1997‐98 cuts and bad policy changes. This year's budget confirms that the standing of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Amanda Vanstone, is as a minister against education rather than for it. While the vast majority of Australians see education as a sound investment in their future, Amanda Vanstone sees it as nothing more than a narrow exercise in cost saving.

Why else would the minister in this budget abolish a further 4,700 undergraduate places through the higher education Commonwealth industry places scheme, which has allowed universities, particularly in the regions, to establish strong industry links and funding sources? Why else would the government be planning a further one per cent cut in university funding on top of the $400 million cut in the previous budget? Why else would the government cut a further $70 million from vocational education and training?

I would maintain that Senator Vanstone has plainly misled the Australian public with her claim on 2 May that there would be `no more bad news' for the education sector in the 1997 budget. If this is her interpretation of no `bad news' then one can only wonder what sorts of cuts she would really like to inflict upon the Australian education sector. This is a government which cannot help itself when it comes to running down educational opportunities across the Australian population.

Cuts to vocational education, university industry places, Language Australia and Abstudy, plus ongoing confusion about the proposed youth allowance, represent bad news for our public investment in Australia's education system. More cuts on top of the $100,000 up-front undergraduate fees, 21,000 fewer university places and large cuts to government schools funding represent the politics of stupidity. This is a government which fails to understand that Australia's future—its economic and social security—lies in fully resourcing our education services, not subjecting them to a double whammy of budget cuts and bad policy.

In making these observations, the House can do more than just take my word. Roderick West, the government's own appointee to conduct the review of the higher education sector, the government's own selected expert on universities, was reported in the Australian this morning as saying:
The question to ask is will the cuts continue down the years, because if they will, then universities will become increasingly privatised.

That is what Roderick West, the government's appointee in higher education, had to say about the impact of the Vanstone changes. He also mentioned that federal funding cuts have damaged the quality of Australia's universities with tutorials and many good courses under the axe. The article states:
He cited the scrapping of some courses, widespread decline in the number of tutorials, and staff rationalisation as main results of budget cuts.
Tutorials had vanished in some courses. In others they had been cut from one a week to one a fortnight and group sizes had increased from 12 to 30.

Asked if quality had already been damaged by the funding cuts, Mr West said, "Yes. I think there's little doubt about that and the sector is looking forward to a further reduction in quality with further cuts."

There it is from the man appointed by the government, one of the acquaintances of the Prime Minister no less—someone chosen by the government to conduct the main review into higher education in Australia. What was his analysis of primitive Vanstonism in the university sector? Further cuts equal a further decline in quality. All this posturing we have seen in recent times from Senator Vanstone and in this House by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, about the state of the university sector is nothing but bunkum and an attempt to mislead the Australian people about the true impact of their cuts to universities.

The figures that have been cited by the minister and by her junior minister show that they are very much in a state of delusion and denial about the impact of their policies on the university sector. They have quoted some figures relating to enrolments which their own department describe as unreliable and as requiring a great deal of caution in their application.

Let us take the enrolment figures quoted by Dr Kemp and Senator Vanstone. Let us assume for the purpose of this exercise that those preliminary enrolment figures are accurate. They show is that all undergraduate enrolments are up by three per cent, but those commencing in first year are up by just one per cent. Enrolments in second, third and fourth year courses are taking place as a product of fear. The fear of students dropping out of university in 1997 and being affected by the changes to HECS has made them stay on in much greater numbers through the university changeover from years one to two, two to three and three to four than would normally be the case.

Even that increase in commencing first year courses of one per cent reflects the fear struck throughout the university sector of these policy changes. Universities always over enrol as a matter of course. This year the university sector has over enrolled more vigorously than ever out of fear of the potential impact of the HECS changes turning students away and out of fear of future funding cuts most of which, the $400 million cut, impact in 1997.

The government is in a state of denial and delusion by arguing that on these preliminary enrolment figures all is rosy in the university garden. The truth is that students are fearful of the changes. That is why the retention rate through years two to four at universities has been so high in 1997. They are so scared of dropping out for fear of then facing the Vanstone HECS system if they were to subsequently resume their university studies. The institutions are fearful of these changes. They are more vigorously over enrolling, compensating for Vanstonism, to the point where there has been a very small increase in first‐year enrolments.

The minister has made use of these figures, as has her junior, who is now in the chamber. Amanda Vanstone had this to say last week at the University of New England and also earlier in the month of May, `Higher education is thriving.' Try telling that to Roderick West, who she has appointed to investigate the university sector. He has been to every single Australian university to examine the impact of her cuts. He does not say that the university sector is thriving. He says that the university sector is essentially in crisis—losing courses, losing campuses, losing opportunities, losing students' places, losing academics. Right across the sector there has been a simple equation that this government needs to understand: further funding cuts equal a further decline in quality.

That is the truth of the matter. There is no thriving of higher education in Australia. The sector has been turned into crisis. Of course, the worst is yet to come, because the accumulated impact of these cuts will not be felt most severely until 1998 and 1999. When asked about that by the Australian newspaper, this is what Roderick West had to say:
The question to ask is will the cuts continue down the years, because if they will, then universities will become increasingly privatised.

After the failure of Fightback in 1993 to establish its credentials with the Australian people, we now have the Fightback policy by stealth—Fightback through the back door, these swingeing funding cuts which, according to Roderick West, will lead to the privatisation of the Australian university sector.

These are the things that Dr Kemp has always wanted to see in higher education—the Americanisation of our system where it is simply a matter of market forces, economic libertarian ideology and a two‐tier system where there is one set of opportunities for those who can afford to pay their way into university and a very different set of opportunities for those not so fortunate. So Roderick West has let the cat out of the bag. The smelly cat that Dr Kemp set running in 1993 in Fightback is back out of the bag. We have now the appointee of the government in higher education predicting increasing privatisation of the sector.

The Australian Labor Party stands firm against those changes. The Australian Labor Party believes that a university education is one of the core functions of the public sector. This is a public good as well as a private good. Unless there is a huge public investment in the quality of education in our society, then it is inevitably underresourced. It is left as a privilege of the rich while those who are not so rich go without. The Australian Labor Party is in the business of funding up the university sector as a public good, of public merit, as we did in government and as we will do after the next election.

BREAK.PARA: I now turn to the question of applications for university enrolment. This is the key test of the impact of the government's policy changes. Any university really can fill its places by dropping standards—that certainly happened in 1997—and by aggressive marketing, which the universities, out of fear, have also had to engage in. But the true statistical test of the impact of the changes in university policy comes from the application figures.

What have those figures shown for 1997? An 11 per cent drop in the minister's own state of South Australia; a 4.4 per cent drop in New South Wales and the ACT; a five per cent drop in Victoria; and a 3.5 per cent drop in Tasmania, impacting severely on that struggling regional economy. For mature aged students, there was a drop in university applications in 1997 of 10.6 per cent. So much for lifelong education. So much for people taking up a university opportunity because they hoped to re‐skill themselves, to find the education they need which establishes employability in the new economy.

These are the telltale figures of the impact of the government's changes in university policy. The application figures show that Australian students, young and old, have been driven away from their aspiration to take on a university education. They have been driven away from their opportunity to educate and skill themselves to be effective citizens and effective participants in the new economy. That is to the lasting shame of this government. That is the true test of what is happening in the university sector.

There is no doubt that the minister is engaged in this state of denial and delusion. Amanda Vanstone arguing that less is more is almost Orwellian—that $800 million of cuts in education somehow produces more places. It is straight out of an Orwellian novel—less is more. It is doublespeak from Amanda Vanstone, supported by Dr Kemp.

The truth is that the university sector is in decline. We are losing quality. We are losing opportunities. We are losing our unique chance to educate the Australian people in a competitive global environment where education counts for so much and to build up the virtues of enlightenment and tolerance through higher education. This is to the lasting shame of the government. The Labor Party will be reversing many of these primitive changes in university policy straight after the next election.

It is not only the fact that the government has a lack of direction in university policy and that it sees university funding as a narrow cost on the government budget instead of a sound investment; it is the fact that the policies are not only wrong but also backward looking without a philosophy of education or any clear public purpose for where universities in Australia should head. This reflects a broader problem for the government. It had a big intellectual investment in Fightback but then only a political strategy for trying to win government—not knowing how to govern according to a mandate for policy change given to it by the Australian people.

One of the tasks for the Labor Party is to not only point out the policy failings of the government and its regressive impact on a university education but also build a positive alternative. We believe passionately that nothing matters more to the Australian nation than the education of its citizens. Learning and social progress have always gone together, and the power of reason and knowledge exposes people to virtues of rational thought and problem solving. But now, in the new economy, education is much more than a tool of social enlightenment; it is, with the changing nature of work and production, the dividing line between the economic winners and losers in our society.

More than ever, economic value is being expressed through knowledge and the skilful use of information. As society continues to move from the industrial age to the information age, the role of government is in transition, most notably shedding its ownership of fixed industrial assets and investing ever more in the assets and capabilities of a learning society. The quality and equality of our society depend on the success of this transition.

Effective equality relies on something more than society's distribution of income and wealth. It is the interaction of these primary goods with social liberty and the skills of knowledge and learning which determine a person's overall freedom to achieve and pursue his or her wellbeing. This is the basic capability set which, if available to all citizens, gives a post-industrial society the qualities of enlightenment, effective freedom and equality.

Nothing matters more to this freedom to achieve than a quality education—the chance for citizens to uplift their skills and social capability. Hence, Labor's core goals for a learning society: giving each citizen a platform of enlightenment and learning on which to stand, recognising that security in the new economy requires a solid threshold of lifelong vocational skills and giving all citizens the freedom to achieve, according to their own ambitions and innate abilities.

Given the importance of skills and personal capability in a post-industrial society, it is more important than ever to ensure education is discharged as a core function of the public sector. The great bulk of its resources must be funded in the collective rather than through user pays. As a community and a nation, we are all made stronger, especially in terms of economic growth and shared prosperity, by a universal threshold of quality education and social capability.
