Labor recognises that all citizens have an interest in the provision of an adequate level of funding for the education system, especially when cast in terms of mass education. The appropriate tool for vertical systems of equity remains a progressive taxation system. This is, after all, what Australians have always meant by `a fair go': contributing to the common pool of public resources, according to their capacity to pay, and drawing from the pool, especially in the enhancement of education, on the basis of need and merit.

If I share one thing in common with Senator Vanstone, it is that I too want the rich to pay—I want the rich to pay more—but through the progressive taxation system rather than with $100,000 up-front fees that the average Australian family cannot afford. That is the folly of a two-tier education system—a government that is willing to quarantine defence spending but make education its No. 1 target for fiscal consolidation. What sort of a government is it that runs down our hopes and aspirations so much? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALKER.NAME: Dr KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having just listened to the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) deliver this appalling speech, I feel constrained to make a few comments on his continual misrepresentation of the facts and the highly distorted perspective he presented. I suppose that one of the remarkable features of the speech we have just heard from the member for Werriwa, the shadow minister for education and youth affairs, is its very great concentration, first of all, on university policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say, for a start, that the government is very proud of its policy for universities and the reforms that have been introduced. Of course, what the shadow minister completely failed to mention was that enrolments in the university system are up this year by some 12,000 students, and the total resourcing of the university system is up very substantially this year. In fact, the universities are estimated to have obtained in the course of the year an additional $250 million through their teaching services alone. So we have, under the government's policies, a more accessible system, with more students in the system and better resourced universities.

As somebody who has come out of the university sector, no-one would be more aware than me of the way in which that sector was run down by the Dawkins policies; it was starved of resources. The amount spent per student fell throughout the Labor years, as the Labor Party squeezed the universities but refused to give them the freedom that they needed to provide places for those Australians who were prepared to invest in their education.

It was the Labor Party that believed `equity in higher education' meant shutting out something between 20,000 and 40,000 qualified Australian students every year, while allowing students from overseas to obtain places in Australian universities. It was the Labor Party's distorted sense of equity that believed in charging university students who were doing the less expensive courses with lower income prospects at the end a much higher proportion of the cost of those courses in HECS charges than they were prepared to charge students going into courses with much higher income prospects.

That strange concept of equity, of course, arises out of the peculiar ideology the Labor Party promotes that, somehow or other, you must not allow people the freedom to invest in their own future, that you must not allow institutions to do something according to their own mission, that they must be tied into a system of bureaucratic central regulation which only leads to the running down of and the reduction of access to the system.

This government is very proud that it has expanded access to university education and that it has produced better funded universities. I challenge the Labor Party to go to the next election with a policy of reducing the universities' flexibility to raise resources for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —What policy is this?

—I challenge the shadow minister to tell us where this additional money will come from. It will come from higher taxes, as he said. So once again we see the old Labor philosophy that it is better for people to give their money to the Labor Party and it will spend it on their behalf than to leave it in their own pockets and allow them to decide where they will spend that money.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the features, one of the greatest failures, of higher education policy under the Labor Party is that the number of people from low income backgrounds accessing universities remains at around about 15 per cent of the total. Of course, with the fixation on universities that we heard again today in the speech from the member for Werriwa, we see that old Dawkins message coming through again that if you are not going to university you are not going anywhere. The problem is that those going to universities out of school are only 30 per cent of the total students leaving year 12. What about the other 70 per cent of students? What about those young people in the member for Werriwa's own electorate who have chosen another course?

BREAK.PARA: We know that under the previous government the number of apprenticeships and traineeships, as a proportion of the work force, fell to the lowest level for three decades. We know that there was no effort whatever to make sure that young Australians gained the basic literacy and numeracy skills they needed to get jobs. We know that there was no effort made whatever to make sure that the schools were offering the appropriate vocational courses to the students who were not going on in the academic stream.

In other words, the Labor Party throughout its entire 13 years in office abandoned the great bulk of young Australians and, as we know, condemned so many of them to long‐term unemployment. So let us not have any of the cant and hypocrisy that we hear and the sorts of remarks that were made by the member for Werriwa as he tells us how much more the government is going to tax and spend on the universities, totally ignoring the fact that, by freeing up the system, the government has expanded places and resources for the university system.

Let me direct attention to the educational and training interests of the 70 per cent of young Australians who are not going from school into university. In this government's vision, vocational education and training has an absolutely crucial role to play in making sure that young Australians get the skills that will get them jobs and that will enable Australian businesses to adapt flexibly and dynamically to the changes of the global economy.

Our vision recognises the importance of a quality, accessible national training system—and, of course, many young Australians are now choosing to go into that training system rather than go to university. The member for Werriwa regrets that because he believes in the old Dawkins' saying that if you are not going to university you are not going anywhere. But the number of places in TAFE this year will be up by 55,000. Not only is the number of university places up but the number of places in TAFE is up by 55,000 this year.

There are more and more opportunities for young Australians who want to pursue a different course on which to build their different careers. And this government is determined to make sure that those opportunities are available. Businesses, industries and regions need to take up the challenge to develop a highly skilled and flexible work force with greater adaptability to change and greater ability and readiness to pick up new technologies. That is what those higher skills and the government's greatly improved training system will give young Australians, because we believe in quality training.

The previous government spent $500 million on short‐term training schemes that shuffled young people through one scheme after another for six months and had a four per cent success rate. That is $500 million down the drain. This government is putting resources into quality training, apprenticeships, traineeships and into vocational education in schools. It is making sure that young Australians are getting those basic literacy and numeracy skills that are fundamental to them getting a job.

The government has embarked upon a major process of reform to vocational education and training to develop a new system that will generate confidence in business and individuals. We are establishing a training system which is responsive to the needs of industry and business enterprises, while operating within a national framework that ensures national standards and portability of qualifications are maintained.

This system will be built on an ongoing partnership between the training system and industry, under industry leadership. Of course, that is another dramatic difference between this government and the former government, because the former government believed that, after all, training was in the hands of the suppliers and that businesses should not be allowed to choose who was going to offer the off‐the‐job training to their apprentices; they should be denied that choice. This government, under its training reforms, is opening up that choice. The former government believed that the more you multiplied paper and regulation on small business the better. It is no wonder they destroyed jobs. Under our arrangements and reforms, 12 different forms across the states and territories to take on an apprenticeship will be reduced to one form.

The centrepiece of the government's reforms to vocational education and training is, of course, the new apprenticeship system. The new national apprenticeship system is bringing the concept of quality training, as embodied in the traditional apprenticeship, into new industries in a new and flexible way. New apprenticeships are being developed to expand the number of training opportunities for businesses by moving traineeships and apprenticeships beyond traditional occupations into new industries to take advantage of growth and employment potential. This is going to provide increased opportunities for young people who are looking for a career without going on to university.

As I informed the House on Monday, a historic agreement was reached last week in Adelaide between the Commonwealth and state ministers to introduce a new national system for apprenticeships and traineeships from 1 January next year. For the first time since Federation, Australia will have one national system of apprentices and trainees operating across all state and territory boundaries. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) includes funding to support the key elements of the new national apprenticeship system. This funding will underpin the development of a world‐class training system of which all Australians can be proud.

There has been a continual campaign of misrepresentation by members of the opposition regarding the funding being committed by this government to vocational education and training. Spurious claims have been made in this House this week about so‐called reductions in funding and cuts in spending. Let me place a few facts on the record regarding the impact of the budget. These are facts that are already on the public record; they are in the portfolio budget statements. If the opposition had the truthfulness to look at these figures, and the integrity to quote the facts as they are, then they would not be misleading this House and the Australian people.

Fact No. 1: in 1995‐96 when the Labor Party was in government, Commonwealth spending on vocational education and training totalled $1.2 billion. Fact No. 2: in this government's budgets for both 1996‐97 and 1997‐98, Commonwealth funding for vocational education and training totalled $1.4 billion. Claims by the opposition about funding cuts are simply untrue. These figures show that the government has increased spending on vocational education and training by $144 million, or almost 12 per cent.

There has been some reallocation of funds within this total package to target our highest priority, which is the reform of the vocational education and training system and the establishment of new apprenticeships. As I announced during the budget, the government is delivering on its promise to increase genuine job opportunities for young Australians. There will be $415 million available in 1997‐98 for the new national apprenticeship system. This will include $265 million for more than 100,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships in the coming year.

It is a priority for this government to establish the new national system for apprenticeships and traineeships. We are establishing a flexible, non‐bureaucratic, less regulated system that is easy to access and responsive to the training needs of Australia's small and medium sized business enterprises.

It will provide national qualifications that are built on the skills and competencies demanded by industry. This new national apprenticeship and traineeship system has been developed in close consultation with industry and will deliver the reforms that industry and employers are seeking.

The new national system will also deliver new opportunities for young Australians. Under Labor's policies, as I have already said, apprenticeship and traineeship numbers fell to the lowest proportion of the work force for decades. The apprenticeship in particular, the symbol of high quality employment based training, was totally neglected in the policies of the previous government. The decline in apprenticeship numbers during the recession years, induced by the economic mismanagement of the previous government, is one of the most disappointing facts, one of the greatest failures, of that government. In the last 12 months, the government has introduced reforms that will reverse the decline in the apprenticeship system. Under the new national system the concept of quality training will be extended into new growth industries.

This financial year, I am very pleased to report, there has been a record number of traineeship commencements. At the beginning of this week, we had already achieved over 42,000 traineeship commencements, which is 6,000 more than the total for the previous year. The total number of apprenticeship commencements and recommencements for 1996‐97 will not be known for some time because of delays in the collection of data. At present, the numbers are tracking at a marginally lower rate than 1995‐96, but we still expect to have some 47,000 apprenticeship commencements or recommencements in 1996‐97. Overall, therefore, the number of apprenticeship and traineeship opportunities for young Australians has expanded dramatically under the policies of this government.

Some of the significant agreements that underpin the new national system include, firstly, simplified regulatory arrangements which massively cut the red tape and workload for employers. This includes significant rationalisation of the paperwork involved in taking on trainees and apprentices. As I have mentioned, previously employers were required to complete up to 12 forms to take on apprentices and trainees. In the new national system they will have only one form to fill in.

Secondly, there will be national recognition of training providers and qualifications, meaning that young people who undertake training in one state or territory will have that training recognised wherever they work in Australia. This new arrangement, of course, will therefore greatly expand career opportunities for young people.

Thirdly, there will be new funding arrangements for off-the‐job training for apprenticeships and traineeships, allowing employers and their trainees to choose which provider will deliver their training. For the first time, we will have a demand driven training system, giving employers an unprecedented opportunity to select the training that meets the needs of their business. More than $500 million a year in federal and state funding will be available for competition by public and private training providers under this system.

Within Appropriation Bill (No. 1), over $265 million has been set aside to support the government's new employer incentives regime. As I have mentioned, this will fund over 100,000 new apprenticeships, including in the high growth industries such as technology, finance, tourism and the traditional trades—providing more opportunities for young Australians seeking a quality career based on industry recognised skills.

The new incentives regime will target Commonwealth employer incentives more tightly on quality outcomes and will provide greater incentives to employers to take on out-of-trade apprentices and trainees to ensure that they complete their training and gain a qualification that leads to real jobs.

The new regime also removes anomalies between the tax treatment of employer incentive payments for apprentices and trainees through the conversion of the tax rebate on apprentice incentives to outlays. This conversion, which is consistent with the National Commission of Audit report, will simplify payment arrangements, improve the transparency of payments and allow better accountability of Commonwealth financial assistance.

An amount of $24 million has been set aside to develop a new national network of one‐stop apprenticeship shops as part of the new employment services market. These one‐stop shops will provide streamlined Commonwealth and state services to employers wishing to take on apprentices and trainees. With a single phone call or visit, employers will be able to access the complete range of Commonwealth and state recruitment, administration and payment services.

These one‐stop shops herald a new era of cooperation between Commonwealth and state levels of government. They will remove duplication and overlap, and allow employers to access the training system through a single point of contact. Services will be delivered in a more timely and efficient manner, making employment based training through appren ticeships and traineeships a far more attractive option for employers.

Appropriation Bill (No. 1) also includes funding to support the expansion of group training arrangements. This funding will be targeted at servicing the apprenticeship and traineeship needs of small businesses, who often find it difficult to make a full‐time commitment to engage an apprentice or a trainee. Group training arrangements will help small and medium sized businesses access quality training offered through apprenticeships and traineeships. This training will deliver a highly skilled work force that can improve their productivity and help businesses gain a competitive edge in the global economy.

The new national system will also provide increased opportunities for young people. The government is committed to providing quality training opportunities to all young Australians, including those who are disadvantaged in the labour market.

Appropriation Bill (No. 1) includes funding of $20.5 million for the access program, which provides preliminary training to disadvantaged young people to help them successfully participate in an apprenticeship or a traineeship. Funding under the access program will provide assistance to around 6,000 people through programs which can demonstrate direct linkages into apprenticeships or traineeships upon the completion of training. One of the reasons we need an access program is that many young people are simply not equipped with the skills they need to enter the labour market. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Any hopes that Australians have had that the government can reduce unemployment are dashed by those members of this House who espouse their own ignorant views about the causes of unemployment. The member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) stated in her first speech:

SPEECH.PARA: Immigration must be halted in the short term so that our dole queues are not added to by, in many cases, unskilled migrants not fluent in the English language.

The member for Oxley is peddling a view to Australians who are hurting under massive increases in unemployment. This view is that they cannot get a job because immigrants are taking them. The truth about unemployment is that immigration, on the scale undertaken in Australia, has a neutral impact on unemployment. However, there are 30,000 more unemployed people in Australia since the Liberals came to government. The Liberal government will not admit that it has failed them—it boasts that it has kept their faith. The member for Oxley is providing false answers to the questions the Liberal government refuses to respond to.

The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) last year acknowledged research results which consistently prove that immigration has a neutral effect on a number of key aspects for economic life, including real wages and inflation, living standards and the balance of payments. This argument was based on the assumption that the balance of immigration under Labor was wrong, that it was too focused on allowing Australian residents to marry people from overseas and to have their families join them in Australia. This argument ignores the documented evidence that family ties are important for the establishment of a strong and cohesive nation and the successful settlement of newly arrived immigrants in Australia.

The Liberal government believes that skilled migrants are more important for Australia because they have lower unemployment rates than family reunion migrants. The government cannot have it both ways, however. It cannot tell us—to justify a reduction in programs—that migrants take jobs and then change the intake quota to improve the capacity of migrants to get jobs.

What is worse, this argument places the priority on fundamentally flawed concepts of an economic rationalist migration program which has been proven to be wrong over the last year. If the so‐called balance that the government has achieved in giving priority to migrants who are skilled is the correct balance, why is it that unemployment is still at 8.75 per cent? The answer, clearly, is that migration has, at worst, a neutral impact on jobs.

BREAK.PARA: The Liberal government has recanted on its original statements on immigration and has now cut the program, after telling us last year that its program was a better balance which would reduce unemployment in Australia without reducing the number of migrants who arrive in Australia.

The current immigration cuts proposed by the government in its 1997‐98 immigration program represent only 0.03 per cent—or one‐third of one per cent—of Australia's population. Is such a small cut really worth all of the angst, division and racism which has been beaten up in this country by the anti‐immigrant campaigners?

The government does not really even believe its own propaganda, in my view. If it did, why would it adjust its figures by statistical manipulation, counting concessional family entrants as skilled migrants? The truth is that the government knows that immigration does not create unemployment. Its stance on this issue is patently an attempt to convince people who are hurting that it is not the government's fault. The government's approach shifts blame away from itself onto migrants who come to Australia to start a new life.

Last year the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs also noted that the demand migrants create for goods and services when they arrive in Australia creates at least as many jobs as they occupy. When the government denies migrants access to social security benefits for two years after they arrive in Australia, they are creating a pool of essentially slave labour that will have to work for a pittance under the industrial contract system. Migrant outworkers are a clear example of migrants having to find any work that is available, even at severe risk to their health and safety. The two‐year waiting period entrenches a society where migrants are seen as a second‐class labour force. The member for Oxley says she is about equality but really, in my view, she is about cutting support for the most disadvantaged.

The government has created a myth that the two‐year waiting period was merely an extension of time—four times longer than the waiting period introduced by Labor in fact. The Liberals argue that they have maintained the exemptions to the waiting period which the Labor government established when it was in office. This is blatantly untrue. Spouse migrants make up nearly 40 per cent under the 1997‐98 migration program. Under Labor, this group of migrants were never required to serve a waiting period before they could access social security benefits, because the Labor government recognised that Australians should be allowed to choose who they marry and that they should not be punished for marrying people from overseas.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has said what we all know to be true—that the member for Oxley's anti-immigration agenda is more accurately described as an anti‐Asian immigration agenda. The member for Oxley suggests that Australia is subject to an invasion by people in the Asian region, claiming that, by the year 2040, some 53.6 per cent of our population will be Asian. The actual projections, based on current migration and growth patterns over the next 30 years, show that the Asian‐born population of Australia will be around 7.5 per cent—nowhere near 53.6 per cent.

The member for Oxley has been telling Australia that she is running the government's immigration program. And who could really reasonably disagree? We have a Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs who, under the Liberal government, was removed from cabinet—the government's key decision making body—and it appears that the member for Oxley's incoherent and discredited statements are now guiding policy on multicultural affairs and the immigration program in this country. What sort of new life can migrants make for themselves in the current environment? The race debate in Australia is damaging the very social fabric of our society. It rips away social cohesion and reflects the petty prejudice of those who feel that society owes them more than those who are systematically disadvantaged by racism and discrimination.

Racism is hurting the nation in the region and around the world. Australia has worked very hard for more than 20 years to dispel the old views of Australia on the international stage as being a nation of racist idiots. It was the Whitlam government, the Whitlam Labor government, which repealed the White Australia policy, and successive governments, until now, have delivered a multicultural policy to prove to the rest of the world that we are not a bunch of racist idiots. All of this good work, in my view, has been undone in the last year.

This debate means that people in Australia—neighbours—now view each other with suspicion and blame. Good people, people who are working, who are friendly and who want to work with each other, are being told that the people with whom they are working and living next to are the cause of all their problems. They are told that migrants and Aboriginals are being given `special treatment' by the government. If the government pays one cent towards assisting Aboriginals to recover from 200 years of discrimination and oppression, they are told it is `special treatment'. If the government recognises the value of migrants' contribution and seeks to enhance that contribution by providing them with language, training or job assistance, they are told that it is `special treatment'. If the government gives Aboriginals title to the land they already legally own, they are told it is `special treatment'. What they are being told by this government is wrong.

I will talk for a moment about the concept of equity of outcomes. There are no Australians in my view—or at least very few—who would like to see their fellow Australians victim to racist abuse or discrimination or starving in the streets. Yet Pauline Hanson and some of the pollsters in this country do not talk about racism in these terms. They pose questions which assume that migrants, Aboriginals and other disadvantaged groups in this country are getting special consideration.

There are people in Australia who wrongly believe that the government gives all migrants a new car and a mobile phone when they come into Australia. The only migrants who ever got a direct benefit from the government from migrating to Australia were the Poms who migrated to Australia under assisted package schemes—the so‐called £10 immi grants. This was an era when Australian governments knew the value of migrants and made contributions to their effective settlement.

The reality is that discrimination and racism do exist in Australia. They require targeted inputs to deliver equal outcomes. Contrary to the current Liberal approach, targeted inputs do not mean cuts.

Migrants have had a deep and positive effect on the social and economic development of Australia. The Snowy Mountains hydro‐electric scheme, for example, relied substantially on migrant labour. Throughout our history migrants have contributed vital new skills and training opportunities to the Australian economy.

Other nations are not deaf to the racism which is currently being articulated in Australia. How is this debate hurting Australian interests in countries our business people have fought long and hard to gain entry into? How do workers feel when they are denied jobs because their companies are denied contracts because we are considered in the region as a pack of racists? The government have done very little in my view to counter what is essentially a very large problem that is growing in the region.

Many people have complained about the lack of response from the government to the comments expressed by Pauline Hanson. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who discounts every argument he disagrees with as political correctness, has consistently defended the right of Pauline Hanson to express her views when he has been asked to explain the government's silence on the issue.

This budget has broken the government's silence on racism. This budget outlines in simple dollar and cents terms what stance the government has taken on racism. This budget has put the government's money where its mouth is. But it is a mean and stingy response; an impoverished response to the racism and discrimination faced by migrants, Aboriginals and other disadvantaged groups. There are several key areas in the budget which speak volumes about the Liberal government, how they really view the emerging racism in Australia in their cuts to Aboriginal affairs, cuts to education, cuts to multicultural affairs, cuts to Attorneys-General and cuts to health.

In National Reconciliation Week, it is vital that we scrutinise the budget to look for ways to ensure that past mistakes in this nation are not repeated. Many of the criticisms of the past revolve around the way in which Aboriginals were denied the right to self‐determination. This budget quarantines spending in a vast part of ATSIC's overall budget, including crucial employment and housing related programs, denying ATSIC, as the representative body of Aboriginal people and hence all Aboriginals, the right to appropriately allocate resources to resolve the problems which most affect them.

It has been estimated that, without a serious effort on the part of both the government and the private sector, and without the injection of funds to make this effort possible, unemployment amongst indigenous Australia will reach 47 per cent by the year 2006—more than five times the current national unemployment rate. The government must listen to the Aboriginal community and provide that community with adequate funding and flexibility to most effectively combat this disastrous prediction for the future.

Appropriate funding for education and training is vital to ensure that indigenous Australians are able to compete effectively on the job market, particularly in the face of the discrimination they suffer. In the area of Aboriginal education and training, we see massive cuts to Abstudy and other education programs for indigenous Australians. Where is the government's commitment to ensuring that unemployment problems faced by this generation and past generations of indigenous people are not repeated in the next generation?

Aboriginal health is another area of intense need. The Australian Medical Association has criticised this Liberal government's budget for its `steady as she goes' approach to dealing with major health problems confronting indigenous people, calling for an injection of funds into this fundamental area.

The status of health in the Aboriginal community is appalling in a modern country like Australia. Recently the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) have reflected upon this and have conceded that the real issue is how much resources are committed by the government. We like hearing the words, but what counts is the dollars that arrive at the end of the day. Comprehensive programs are desperately required to improve the health outcomes for indigenous Australians, not the half‐hearted attempt that the current budget offers.

I would like to turn briefly to part of my own electorate. The government is beginning to move some of its focus onto health and education for Aboriginal people. However, the Prime Minister is still talking about models of dependency rather than empowerment. The only effective model for real community development is the model that empowers Aboriginal people, and the model that Aboriginal people have adopted themselves has been that of land rights.

Booderee, formerly known as Jervis Bay, in my electorate is an excellent example of how an Aboriginal community has begun to be empowered by the partial realisation of their land right claims under the former Labor government, how they can work to effectively develop themselves. The model used by the community in Booderee has established a community which is beginning to regenerate itself. Houses are being constructed to replace the tin sheds which had no access to sewerage, water or power and that have been there since the thirties and the forties in some cases. This process is not complete, but it has been embarked upon. The community still needs help, but the recognition of land rights has increased the dignity and the capacity of the community to regenerate itself.

Clearly, this is a superior model than waiting for an ever diminishing socialised wealth which has been progressively cut by the current government. The empowerment model is a model which has been embraced by the Aboriginal community at Booderee. It depends on the land rights that they have been able to assert over the area. Land rights are a feasible vehicle for empowerment over dependency, which is why the Labor Party supports the recognition of native title. Booderee shows there is a better way to manage cultural diversity in the racist debate that is going on at the moment.

The budget goes against all of the values espoused by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. In his article, the minister recently debunked some of the myths that have been generated about migrants and their contribution to this country. He highlighted the damage that prejudice and racism have had in our society. Why then is he defending a 40 per cent cut to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission? What has changed in seven months?

These cuts have targeted the legal processes of the commission—the protection the commission provides to people who are victims of racial vilification and racial discrimination. The minister criticised recent racist statements as, at best, misconceived or ill‐informed and, at worst, damaging to Australia's interests. Language training is one of the greatest tools for engendering a sense of cross-cultural understanding. Why then does this budget abandon control of the Asian language studies program for schools to the states? Why does it refuse to support basic principles of productive diversity?

In the last budget, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs announced a $5 million anti-racism campaign and promised to review progress and consider further action in this year's budget to `build up on the momentum created in the 1996-97 budget'. Those were his words. Not only has there been no momentum to `build up on'; there has been no campaign, no extra money to get the campaign up and running this year, and half a million of the original $5 million essentially was lost by a sleight of hand.

That campaign is essential, particularly at the moment, to ensure that all of Australia appreciates the commitment and contribution that the entire society makes. The government should be spending more money in my view—or should at least be spending the money it has set aside—on anti‐racism education. It needs to encourage Australians to engage in a multicultural society by learning about the cultures and languages of our nearest neighbours.

There is widespread agreement that Australia must meet its international obligations to humanitarian entrants and refugees. Why then has the government cut funding for survivors of torture and trauma by 30 per cent? Some refugees arrive in Australia without a refugee visa. They are forced to undertake a lengthy process to prove their claims for refugee status. Why has the government cut nearly $3 million from the asylum seeker assistance scheme and foreshadowed a further cut of $6 million in forward estimates? Is the government's widely discredited economic rationalist agenda more important than our undertakings under international law, national law and common human decency?

In the same way that human development self‐empowerment models have contributed to a small but growing independence of the Aboriginal community in my electorate, these models can and should be used—and have been in the past—to assist migrants in settlement. The Liberal government came to power last year with a commitment to a settlement program which would flourish with further grants to community workers who assist migrants to make the transition to a new life in this country. The commitment was backed up by a promise to provide $20 million directly to the community over four years. Why then has this government ripped $1.4 million out of the community sector which provides settlement services directly to migrants? This equals approximately 40 community workers. That is 40 communities which will not have access to the same rights as others.

In my view, the Liberal government has taken away any effective strategy for dealing with racism in Australia by cutting the services which exist to protect and promote a united and culturally diverse Australia for all Australians. The Liberal government has betrayed Australians with its budget cuts to this strategy which would eliminate racism. Like many of the cuts this government has introduced across the board, the cuts are not planned in any logical manner to support the rhetoric it mouths as policy.

The only consistency in their response to the member for Oxley has been their failure to deliver any of the unity, any of the harmony or any of the respect and racial tolerance they talk about. The failure to rule out a cross‐party campaign of putting Pauline Hanson last at the next federal election shows that even when the Liberals disendorse a candidate the ties are still there. They can be seen from this budget. The member for Oxley is leading the Liberal government down a slippery slope which will destroy our future and multiculturalism. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vale, Danna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 August last year the coalition government handed down its first budget in 13 years and set out with determination and commitment to chart Australia's return to responsible economic management. At the time it was described as the `fair go' budget. On 13 May this year the Treasurer (Mr Costello) handed down the second budget of the coalition government and in doing so handed down a budget which will continue the coalition's course as planned and will put the Australian economy into surplus in our very first term of office.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a savings budget, not only in the sense that it is saving our economy but in the sense that it is saving our future as well. When we were elected to government on 3 March 1996, one of the most serious concerns on the minds of many people in my electorate of Hughes was the enormity of the budget deficit and the worry of how we would pay it off. After 13 years of aimless economic drift the previous Labor government left all Australians a losing legacy—an historic deficit of $10.3 billion.

Through its commitment to responsible economic planning, this government is heralding strong economic growth through its plan of low debt, low interest rates and low inflation. Around 200,000 new jobs are forecast to be created over the coming year. This budget heralds decades of long and sustained growth which will take us into the 21st century, based on its program of fiscal consolidation which will be achieved on the expenditure side of the budget. This budget also heralds its delivery of promises by its strong commit ment to families, to boosting small business, to creating jobs and to encouraging saving. No more will the Australian economy labour under Labor's high debt, Labor's high interest rates, Labor's high inflation and Labor's high unemployment.

This government's economic leadership has focused on monetary policy as a key element of macro‐economic reform, on fiscal consolidation through realising over $12 billion on its first three years and on wages through industrial relations reform and enterprise agreements. This kind of leadership has outcomes which put people first. Yet the Labor Party has fought hard on all fronts, and had it succeeded in winning any one of them Australian families would not now be enjoying the low interest rates and low mortgage rates that are currently in effect.

The fact that our Australian economy now holds such promise to work for the benefit of all Australian society is the brightest of all promises delivered by the coalition government—and no thanks to Labor. Such measures are of vital importance to the people of my electorate of Hughes which covers a large area of southern Sydney and comprises large residential suburbs, neighbourhood shopping centres and areas of light industrial activity. Such measures have been warmly welcomed by my constituents who understand the necessity of encouraging national savings and so reduce our reliance on foreign debt. They understand the need to finance more of our own investment to make our economy strong and to produce more jobs.

It is the measure of this coalition government that the losing legacy of the Labor years will be turned around in only one coalition term. Clearly this is an economic achievement of the greatest significance for all Australians. It means that after only three years of responsible economic decisions the Australian nation will boast a budget surplus of $1.6 billion. This is such a great achievement that it deserves repeating and it deserves to be trumpeted from this House into all the houses of the nation.

This coalition government will turn the national budget deficit of $10.3 billion into a $1.6 billion budget surplus in three short years. This is a phenomenal achievement by any standard, so let the trumpets play and let them sound the reveille for the Australian economy, for the reduction in official rates, now down to 5.5 per cent, and for current low inflation rates that are at a level unheard of since the pre‐Whitlam era. The program is now in place for long and sustainable economic growth with none of the boom and bust of the previous Labor years. In this financial year alone the coalition government will pay back $5 billion of Labor debt.

But while the families of my electorate have welcomed the strength of the economic responsibility shown by our government, they are understandably very concerned about the government's decision to include two sites in the nearby Holsworthy defence area as options for a second international Sydney airport. As the government will recall, this was not on the agenda before the last election when our government won such a resounding victory that was felt from coast to coast across the nation. It is important that the government is aware that, despite the respect within the Hughes electorate for the strength of our commitment to and record of responsible economic management, there is also a great sense of betrayal felt by the people of my electorate in that my constituents feel a tremendous threat to their families, to their homes and to their local neighbourhood communities at the prospect of an international airport almost within their backyards.

The EIS is now well under way on the two site options at Holsworthy. Two weeks ago the preliminary flight paths were released. It is appropriate that I draw the government's attention to one of the serious impacts upon my constituents, if it was decided that an airport should be located at either of the Holsworthy option sites. The most worrying concern, which has been expressed to me by many of my constituents, is the high level of pollution that can be historically expected to have an extremely negative impact on residential areas which lie within the proximity of an international airport. With respect, I would urgently draw the government's attention to just how severe and deleterious would be the collateral damage on the lives of my constituents should an international airport be located in the proximity of the neighbourhoods of my electorate.

The United States military uses the term `collateral damage' to mask any unavoidable negative impacts when some more `affordable' objective is deemed to be necessary. The affordable objective in this case is the consideration of the option of locating Sydney's second international airport within the Holsworthy defence area. In this case, unavoidable negative impacts include serious levels of atmospheric and surface pollution, amongst other things. A Boeing 747 does not simply waft into the air in a manner similar to hot air balloons. To get an aircraft weighting just short of 400 tonnes up to minimum flying speed of 300 kilometres per hour takes some effort.

One of my constituents is a Qantas 747 pilot who holds a degree in applied science. He informs me that, in order to complete a single take‐off, these massive jets expel more exhaust into the atmosphere than two million suburban lawnmowers, each running for 20 minutes. Figures from the Department of Transport and Regional Development air traffic forecasts for Sydney dated February 1997 predict the number of aircraft movements in Sydney to rise from 270,000 in 1996 to over 565,000 in the first quarter of the next century.

My constituent also informs me that, if the airport is centred at Holsworthy, the direct consequence of these movements will eventually be that around 594,000 litres of jet exhaust fumes, soot, combustion residues and raw, vented jet fuel will fall directly over the Woronora Dam and catchment area every year. And this figure will rise as operations increase. The bulk of these emissions will include minute particles of carbon dioxide, nitrous oxides, water vapour and a lethal mix of organic compounds. From the nitrous oxides we can expect various forms of nitrates such as nitric acid—otherwise known as acid rain.

Eventually from this single airport, some 60,000 litres per year will disperse in the form of concentrated benzene, formaldehyde, volatile organic compounds and polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons or PAHs. The United States Food and Drug Administration has deemed that there is no acceptable level of PAHs as a cancer causing agent to humans. Even in parts per billion they pose a serious risk. I am informed that benzene has been proven to cause leukaemia and birth defects and that formaldehyde is thought to contribute to lung and eye irritation as well as skin and brain cancer.

It should come as no surprise that airport refuellers are equipped with heavy industrial gloves and emergency shower facilities to protect them from accidental jet fuel contact. Yet, if an international airport is located at Holsworthy, minute particles of these toxic substances will either be present in the run-off or fall directly into the Woronora Dam and its catchment area within my electorate, and the Woronora Dam provides the drinking water for all of southern Sydney.

Many of these substances are powerful carcinogens and cannot be simply filtered from the tap water that generations of Australians, including my constituents in Hughes, take on trust to be pure and clean. The Woronora Dam supplies water to over 350,000 people living in Sydney's south. The families living in the neighbourhoods of my electorate from Helensburgh to Hammondville, from Como to Chipping Norton, from Menai to Moorebank and from Bundeena to Bangor, have every right to expect clean air and pure water.

It is impossible for the current EIS to predict the outcome of contaminating these two precious resources which are imperative to the health and wellbeing of the hundreds of thousands of men, women and children now living in the southern region of Sydney. Only long-term, large population studies can give answers to such questions, after which time the damage may be unthinkable.

Even without an EIS, one does not need to look too hard to find a predictive model. In the United States of America, Chicago's O'Hare airport is currently operating at levels that we can expect from Sydney's future second international airport. Given the O'Hare example, we can observe an increase in birth defects, respiratory illness, liver damage, heart disease and cancers in the surrounding population. American sources indicate over one million people are affected by pollution directly related to the O'Hare airport, which is detectable at 80 kilometres from the airport and progressively gets worse as you get closer.

An international airport in the Holsworthy defence area will be further complicated by the proximity of the Woronora Dam, which is located less than a kilometre from the southern end of the option A north-south runway. The preliminary flight paths released last week show flight paths over the Woronora Dam and the Woronora catchment area from option A and the Woronora catchment area from option B.
The American Natural Resources Defence Council or NRDC concluded in its 1996 report entitled Flying off course:
Living near a major airport is like having an oil refinery as a neighbour, except that refineries are subject to much stronger pollution controls and disclosure requirements.

How could it be logically explained that residents, who are prohibited from propelling a small powerboat around the Woronora reservoir `to preserve water quality', are now told that their government is considering the operation of literally hundreds of thousands of turbojet aircraft movements just a few hundred metres from the reservoir shoreline, both vertically and horizontally.

I am informed that aviation emissions appear as a tenuous, sticky mist that disperse over a very wide area. They attach to vegetation, they burn foliage and they acidify rain. These aerosols cannot be filtered by our lungs and are transmitted directly into our bloodstream as we breath them in. The NRDC found that America's international airports generate as much—and even more—emissions than major power plants, steel mills, refineries and incinerators.

As legislators, we would be ridiculed and laughed from office if we were to suggest to the Australian people that it would be economically beneficial to place an oil refinery inside a currently protected water catchment. But it has been pointed out to me by my constituents that locating an international airport within the proximity of residential areas, of the Woronora Dam and of the Woronora catchment area is similar to igniting that refinery's half billion litre produce and flying it overhead.

I am ever mindful of the strength of commitment shown by our coalition government in the mature and responsible economic leadership it has shown in the management of our nation, for the people of our nation and for the children of our nation's future. In the 1997 budget, our government continues its sound record of political and economic leadership which puts people first. Therefore, surely on the grounds of the serious impact of pollution alone upon the people of my electorate of Hughes and following our policy of putting people first as emphasised in the coalition 1997 budget, neither Holsworthy option should be justifiably selected for an international airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite its seeming innocuousness, the second Howard-Costello budget actually compounds the assault on decent social standards that they began in the first. It is another step toward producing a society characterised by private opulence for the few and public squalor for the many. It is built on the same dubious assumptions and mindless ideology and accelerates the destruction of consensus and generosity as the basis of public policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This budget demonstrates yet again—if we needed convincing—that the Howard government has uncritically embraced the ideology which insists on the necessity and rectitude of reducing government expenditure and of removing government from key areas of policy. This at a time, interestingly, when there are clear signs that the orthodoxies of economic rationalism and market based resource allocation are being challenged, often by those who were their most enthusiastic proponents to begin with.

We are led to believe that the reduction in the government deficit is to be the sole criterion for assessing this government's performance. Solving the problem of unemployment and providing for decent standards in health, education and social services is apparently relatively unimportant. This posi tion is not dissimilar to views espoused by sections of the business community and the financial press, and reflects an economic orthodoxy which, in my view, has not been sufficiently challenged, particularly given its obviously destructive effects on those who are less well off. I think it is time that more of us shouted, `The emperor's got no clothes.'

Familiar too in the assumptions shaping this budget is the pressure to reduce government involvement in policies affecting the quality of people's lives and to replace joint government action with individual decisions made in the marketplace, allegedly allowing the market to better allocate resources throughout the community. Accompanying these cuts here, as elsewhere where it has occurred around the world, is the crude rhetoric of `getting government off the people's backs'.

This rhetoric is predictably associated with mantras extolling the virtues of private sector efficiency and greater competition as the justification for cutting government expenditure, for selling public assets and for contracting out services, with the resulting loss of control over both the quality and the cost of those services apparently to be ignored. However, a recent analysis by Hodge of 245 studies of the effects of contracting out amongst some 20,000 enterprises found that, in reality, in areas such as policing, health and environmental management, changes in performance `were not significantly different to zero'.

One of the results of this government's obsession with smaller government is a substantial reduction in the size of the Public Service and, of course, a corresponding reduction in the expertise that is available for public policy and for service delivery. Recent insulting observations about the level of expertise in the service by Max Moore-Wilton highlight the inevitable consequences of his and the government's favoured strategies of `contracting out, downsizing, outplacement and right sizing'. All of these insidious concepts, many now repudiated by their originators, are basically code for removing people from jobs that they previously held and either replacing them with contract workers or requiring fewer people to do the same job—with greater stress, I might say. The expertise in public policy that we have had is apparently not valued by this government since it is being so easily discarded and then, I might say, illogically complained about.

A common associate of many of these free‐market nostrums that we are hearing from the government is that labour markets should be made more flexible—where have we heard that before?—for which read: it should be easier to sack people and pay them lower wages. Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) recently indicated that greater flexibility could mean lower wages for some—it has taken a long time to get that concession from him. The new Reserve Bank Governor was apparently unashamed, however, to recommend greater labour market flexibility while recognising very clearly that this contributed to greater inequality in Australian society.

This same outcome was also recognised by the Confederation of Industry which suggested the effect could be ameliorated by further taxpayer funded payments to the working poor—this while simultaneously recommending huge cuts in public service expenditure, except apparently when it benefits business. If the government's savings initiative introduced in this budget and the private health insurance and family tax rebates introduced in the last are indicative of their approach to assisting those on low wages, then it is clear that the real battlers—as opposed to the ones the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) likes to refer to—are unlikely to get much at all. Most are ineligible for the private health insurance rebate since they do not have private health insurance; many would not obtain part B of the family tax rebate since both are likely to be working, at least part time; and the savings benefit is insultingly small to non-existent for those with little saved.

Underpinning these budget and policy prescriptions is the proposition—and this is very clear—that individual gain and not the collective good should determine which services are paid for from taxes and which from individual incomes. For example, it has been argued that those on high incomes should insure privately, use private health services and send their children to private schools rather than paying higher taxes and, with other citizens, creating a universal, quality service which is then available to everybody regardless of means. I much prefer what John Kenneth Galbraith calls simply the `good society': a society where we work together for the greater good and share in the wealth of our community.

Much of the government promotion of smaller government and private provision uses, misleadingly, the rhetoric of choice to disguise that shift away from collective provision. Funds are being removed from government hospitals and schools ostensibly to give people greater choice to purchase these services with their own resources in the private sector. While the notion of greater choice is superficially appealing to a great many people, the possibility of choice, however, rests heavily on the individual's income.

The inevitable result is a two-tiered system of service provision: one for those who can exercise `choice' because of their wealth—with private health insurance, private education or private aged care—and a second tier which is clearly residual or marginalised, the charity system for the indigent. For working families, this choice is hardly a free one. The massive cuts to child care over two budgets—we have some $820 million removed—and the flow-on increases in the costs of care have swamped any financial benefits that may temporarily result from the much vaunted reduction in home mortgage rates for those buying their own homes. In some child‐care centres right now weekly fees have risen more than $50 per child, and some parents are either having to abandon work or study altogether or having to `choose' inferior, informal care. This, of course, is no choice at all, but a government enforced reduction in their self-determination and in their standard of living.

The cumulative impact of cuts to hospital funding over the two budgets—cuts to pharmaceuticals, to aged care and to child care—is already creating further inequalities of access to critical services and products. These are not discretionary. For example, the recently announced payment to nursing homes of $5 per day for each subsidised resident has rightly been attacked as derisory, particularly by the charitable sector. Alongside last year's decision to allow up‐front charges of an unlimited amount from those who do have some assets, this decision will inevitably lead to a rich man's and a beggarman's service.

Similarly, the budget decision to cut a further $700 million from expenditure on pharmaceuticals hits the poor hardest. They will be expected to be satisfied with drugs of reduced efficacy or increased side effects or they will have to sacrifice other much needed expenditures to purchase these more expensive drugs. Many simply will not be able to afford to do that.

I have already been contacted, for example, by a number of women about the removal of vaginal anti‐fungal creams and ointments from the PBS schedule. Since candida albicans—which usually causes this condition—is a persistent condition which often recurs and needs careful diagnosis and care, this decision will selectively threaten the health of those on low and fixed incomes. It will not affect the wealthy.

Reductions in university funding have already damaged the quality of Australian universities, according to the head of the government's own review of higher education, Roderick West. Mr West has found, from going around those universities, that many universities have cut tutorials, reduced staff numbers and axed many good courses on an ad hoc basis in an attempt to cope with the cuts—which are not yet finished. These effects, of course, are not being felt uniformly with older established universities, which are typically better endowed, likely to manage the cuts and attract more full fee‐paying students. This will inevitably be at the expense of the newer and less prestigious establishments, which usually operate in outer metropolitan and rural areas and cater for the less well off.

The view that is already held by some of the so‐called brownstone universities that they are superior institutions will become a reality under this government. Two classes of university will emerge again, this time based on ability to pay.

BREAK.PARA: In addition to attempting to persuade the community that cutting government funded programs means greater individual choice, this government has cynically and spitefully offered citizens an invitation to constantly measure their entitlements and benefits against those of others who seem to be getting `more than they deserve'.

There is currently a very divisive and calculated exploitation of what is called, quite reasonably I think, the politics of envy and resentment. We are being encouraged to define certain groups as `outsiders'—as objects for our resentment—because they get `special treatment'. The irony is that these people who are described as getting `special treatment' are often those who are already marginalised in our society: for example, recent migrants from Asia and our indigenous people. They are being scapegoated. I do not think there is any other way to put it. The cuts to ATSIC last year and to Abstudy this year are clear examples of this policy. It is exploitative.

These attitudes underlined in this budget and the previous one are part of a constellation of what I believe are deliberately cultivated values which are eroding the social contract between the government and the Australian people.

A very ugly side of this value set is the tendency to blame the victim. Those in society who have fewer resources are to be blamed for any disadvantages they suffer. For example, if you look at the official statements surrounding unemployment, which is one of the most involuntary statuses that we as a society can confer on anyone, it encourages us to think that the unemployed are `ripping off' or `bludging on' the system, to use two much used phrases. The last time the word `dole' was used as an official government description of unemployment benefits—at least until its recent disinterment—was in the early 1980s, when we were encouraged to think that the 10 or 11 per cent who were unemployed were taking the rest of us for a ride. The reality is that they were not and they are not now.

The great majority of people now unemployed would prefer to be in work. And many of those who are employed now would prefer to have more employment than they do. It is the governments which have failed them, not vice versa. The idea that those out of work should be compelled to work for the dole to repay society for giving them something to which they are really not entitled—that is the thinking behind it—is insulting and destructive. This budget compounds this insult by reaffirming the massive cuts to labour market programs and ignoring employment growth almost altogether as a major objective of its policy.

I must say I was flabbergasted last evening to hear the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) talking about the difference between the government's newly introduced Green Corps, which is a much smaller program than the former LEAP, which also covered conservation and environmental management. He told a rather small but startled audience that the virtue of Green Corps in his eyes is that it is made up of volunteers. The difference between Green Corps and LEAP is that LEAP participants were conscripts while Green Corps participants are volunteers. He goes on to say in the same speech:

There is an enormous difference between Green Corps and work for the dole. Green Corps is an environmental program for young people. Green Corps is a job; it is a job lasting for six months at the national training wage. It is a real job.
Presumably, we are invited to conclude that work for the dole is not. He goes on further and says:

. . . Green Corps is very much a quantum leap ahead of the LEAP program because of the fact that these people are volunteers. These are not conscripts. They are not slave labourers. They are not there because they have been threatened with the loss of any benefit. They are there because they want to be there. They are there because they are people genuinely committed . . .

In other words, these characteristics seem a virtue in the Green Corps. Yet this is the same government that has just introduced an insultingly small program called `work for the dole' which has all of those characteristics that the member was deriding.

I must say that I was amazed to hear the Prime Minister recently, when asked to defend cuts to higher education funds, express the opinion that many people who did not have a degree actually resented paying taxes so that others could pursue higher education. Whether that is true or not, the Prime Minister was inviting the listeners to feel resentful and refusing to recognise that there is a substantial collective benefit in having a well-educated and highly skilled population. His statement also ignored the fact that a fair and universal system is also likely to benefit most families directly at some time.

It is true that higher education confers an increased earning capacity on some—it depends on what sort of work you do; and they do make a contribution—but if we have a well‐educated, well‐informed, highly trained population, we all benefit enormously as a community.

This government's budget, and its previous budget, and associated policies, do not contain any recognition that there are very compelling grounds for caution in embracing prescriptions which recommend free market solutions to our social and economic problems—any or all of them. These reservations arise both from the shortcomings in the economic theories that drive them and from a growing body of evidence, which I think we ignore at our peril, that they actually fail to achieve not only their stated economic goals but their unstated social goals as well. Furthermore, I think it is clear to say that such policies have been instrumental already in producing social, environmental and political consequences which will prove inimical to civilised standards.

I think we need to be reminded that at the core of the free market program embraced by this government and this budget is the extension of the market principle into almost every part of community life with targets as diverse as health services and university places, with contracting out and market testing being applied to everything from labour market programs to information technology.

It is important to recognise too that the emphasis in a lot of this change program—it is not reform—is largely or solely on efficiency, not on effectiveness or improving outcomes for society, or improving the status of the disadvantaged in our community. I have to say I agree with John Ralston Saul that efficiency is a low‐level technical objective, one we expect of everybody. Efficiency is a criterion of dubious benefit when assessing public goods or natural monopolies. For instance, a school may have fewer teachers per student and lower operating costs than another, but a very poor educational outcome.

Many have observed that the unrestricted operation of the market can produce perverse, not to mention socially damaging results. For instance, when contracting out occurs, the costs of contract development and the monitoring of performance of contractors is often not acknowledged. The result is the development of another tier of government which is not delivering a service or developing a policy, but monitoring those who have been contracted to do the work. What emerges is a very extensive bureaucracy devoted to auditing, managing and evaluating contracts over which effective control has been relinquished. Just ask Jeff Kennett about the ambulance services in Victoria.

I am already receiving complaints about the operation of the private sector in providing case management for the long-term unemployed, including concerns about serious privacy breaches which, I am pleased to say, are now being investigated. These relate to highly sensitive questions about mental illness. I have here a copy of one of the questionnaires that is used by one of these private providers. It asks the potential user of this service, `Tick any of the following mental health problems you have had: diagnosed depressive illness, diagnosed schizophrenic illness, mood swings, suicide attempts, anxiety attacks, panic attacks, phobias, hospitalisation.' The person concerned rejected that and resented it and, I am pleased to say, with my assistance, has made that known to the department. But, at the time, no‐one from the department was apparently aware of these possible breaches. That was a contracted out service.

There is no doubt too that we are seeing increasing dislocation and disaffection as a result of many of these so-called `globalising economic pressures'. Furthermore, as Walter has argued, `It has been resort to a single principle in public life which we've been persuaded to call economic rationalism,' which has been so damaging.

The fact is that it is not particularly rational as a framework for deciding how we run our lives. We are told that there are no options. Those who voice objections to this view of the world are derided as economic pygmies or ignoramuses who are out of touch with right thinking. We are told this in the context of outcomes for the wider community which are clearly far from perfect.

It is fair to say that, wherever these experiments have occurred—for instance, in the UK, New Zealand and the US—growing inequality has been their hallmark. Governments should intervene to reduce and remove inequality. Where governments do not intervene, or where they intervene less effectively than in the past, the result is, and will be, growing inequality. Cuts to government programs and benefits will further widen these gaps.

As Kapstein said plaintively in a recent edition of Foreign Affairs `this is not how things were supposed to work'. Kapstein, along with others, had advocated expanding the role of the marketplace, increasing privatisation and having smaller government. He now decries the fact that today's advanced global capitalism has failed to keep spreading the wealth and that inequality has worsened. George Soros—also a recent convert—said:
Too much competition and too little cooperation can cause intolerable inequities and instability.

The more governments withdraw public funding from education, health and housing and insist that the individual pay his or her way, the more we will see Galbraith's private opulence and public squalor—walled cities within cities; and it is already happening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to follow the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), who is probably one of the socialist icons of this place, in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). It is also interesting to try to understand the thinking of members of the Australian Labor Party, and to reflect upon their record—particularly the record of the member for Fremantle who managed the Western Australian economy, which had to be resurrected. The same could be said about the situation in Canberra and the effects that is having on Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 May, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) delivered the second Howard‐Fischer budget in this parliament. The Treasurer made it very clear that the government had not forgotten the reasons why the people had elected this government. They were concerned about the state of the Australian economy. They were concerned about the debts that had been run up over a number of years. They were concerned about the effects that was having on the Australian people, particularly with high levels of unemployment. They were also concerned about the effects that long‐term debt would have on this country.

Long‐term debt is not just a problem for the generation that we represent in this particular parliament. The real problem with long‐term debt is what it does to generations to come and the fact that our grandchildren will have to pay because we borrowed on the world bankcard to suit our purposes in this particular generation.

During the election campaign, the state of the budget was debated very actively, especially what the financial position of the country would be, no matter who won the election. It was made very clear by the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), as finance minister, that everything was okay. He said that we would have a balanced budget, that the Keating Labor administration was managing the country very well, and that there was no need to be concerned.

As we clearly found out with the change of government, and with the first Howard‐Fischer budget that was presented last year, the accounts were different from what we were told before the election. Instead of having a surplus, as was claimed at one particular stage—and then that was revisited and we were told we would have a small deficit—in reality, the budget came down with a $10.3 billion deficit.

One can only think that the previous government knew they were not going to be re‐elected and so went out and spent to try to buy their way back into government. To hell with the consequences; the next administration would have to try to straighten out the affairs of this country. Of course, that is never easy and trying to balance a budget having been left a $10.3 billion deficit causes considerable pain in certain areas.

I think it is to the credit of the Treasurer that he could announce in this year's budget that, while we are still to have a relatively small deficit this year of $3 billion, by the time the term of this government is completed there will be a surplus budget in this country, estimated at this stage at about $1.6 billion. That is really a remarkable turnaround under the circumstances. I think that sets the stage for business and the community to go forward with confidence, knowing full well that we are not going to carry on going down the track of borrowing more and more money overseas.

The fact that this country now has very low interest rates, very low inflation and the budget under control puts us on a very sound footing and enables us to go forward. In fact, the Treasurer made it very clear in this particular budget that, through the sale of assets, $5 billion worth of debt would be repaid. How different that is from some of the asset sales of the previous administration, the proceeds of which were put straight into the current account to be spent in the one year. That is like selling your house and spending the proceeds in one year. It was totally irresponsible—selling off the farm and doing nothing about debt that might be accumulated. That was a totally irresponsible economic situation.

This government obviously has a different agenda. It is determined to hand over to the future generations of Australia a country that is in good condition and a country that offers some incentives and opportunities. Not only did we show in this particular budget that we had addressed some of the fiscal problems of this country; we also started to show that this government understands some of the things needed to get individuals and the economy moving.

I think the rebate on taxation on savings introduced in this budget is commendable. I know that those opposite have ridiculed and condemned this particular measure, saying that it is not enough and that people will get only a small amount, et cetera, but you have to start somewhere. I think it is commendable that this measure is being put forward as a policy of this particular government to encourage people to save.

Whenever you are trying to save, you do not save a lot in the first year, but as you continue to add to that then obviously your income from savings increases. This is a 15 per cent rebate which is not capped, so anyone who wants to improve their savings situation and continue to add to their savings obviously has an incentive. I think this will be of great benefit to Australia in the long term.

This measure affects many other areas. There is always a very valid criticism in this country that we are losing too much of the control of our own companies, that overseas people are buying out our companies. The reason overseas interests are buying out Australian companies is that we in this country do not have enough savings and do not have the ability as individuals to invest in our own companies. If you look closely at our near neighbours in the Asian region—Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore—you see that there is a much higher level of investment by those individuals in their own companies because there is a much higher savings level. That is something we must address in this country. This government has certainly taken a very positive step in that direction.
