In an electorate such as Page, on the north coast of New South Wales, anything to do with pensions and superannuants is very important as it is an area with a high percentage of retirees. In this budget the government has honoured the commitment it gave to pensioners during the election campaign—I think the legislation has been introduced to this place—to legislatively guarantee pensioners 25 per cent of male average earnings. Added to that is the fact that we have low inflation and should have—I think there is probably some debate about it—low increases in costs. That is of great benefit to that particular section of the community.

Superannuants were addressed in the last budget. They were treated in the same way as pensioners in the eyes of the tax system. I am sure those two areas are very important ones the government needs to address.

Harking back to statements by the member for Fremantle, something the Labor Party never seems to be able to come to terms with is that you cannot be a compassionate society and you cannot look after those who are in need in society if you do not look after the income you generate in society. If you do not have anything, you cannot be compassionate. I think that is a very important ideological difference between the coalition parties and the Labor Party.

Because I am a regional member, I will devote quite a bit of my speech to regional issues. I commend the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), and I dare say the Treasurer and Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), for the allocation of $800 million for roads in regional Australia, part of the infrastructure that is vitally important to this country in light of the need these days to compete on a so-called level playing field. We need to be able to transport our produce, particularly to the ports but also in reverse, in an efficient way and we need to ensure that country people have access to different areas. In this regard, the federal government is looking more at the national highways, at the roads of national importance, which is a new category, and at an agreement with the New South Wales and Queensland state governments for the Pacific Highway.

The Pacific Highway between Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane is the busiest highway in Australia. It is not a national highway. Some of the road alignment between Brisbane and Sydney is not adequate for a highway of that category. There is no doubt that the commitment given by the federal government in conjunction with New South Wales and Queensland state governments will see a very big improvement in the Pacific Highway. I believe that will be a great advantage to the country and its economy.

The other area that is very important for regional Australia is that of roads of national importance. The one road in my particular electorate that has had some benefit from this scheme is the Summerland Way, which takes off at Grafton and moves through the towns of Casino and Kyogle into Queensland. This is a very popular route for heavy transport. It is a substandard road which has a number of problems; for instance, the very fact that it must go up the main streets of the towns of Grafton, Casino and Kyogle. Some of the alignment is impossible for a major highway, which takes a considerable amount of heavy traffic. The $25 million that has been allocated over a five-year period will certainly be of great benefit in this regard.

There is some problem at present with the New South Wales state government, because they are refusing to accept that this should be a road of national importance. I believe the government of New South Wales should take heed because they did make a promise before the last state election that they would contribute considerable funds to this particular road. There is no doubt that this is a road of national importance. I urge the government to acknowledge that and commit funds towards it.

Something that is very dear to my heart is the $250 million that has been allocated to regional telecommunications. I do not think there is anything more important to regional Australia than the telecommunications network that services—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. Why when the Prime Minister is so hotly prepared to pay compensation to people who lose their guns is he so cold to compensating black Australians who have lost their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has made a submission to the inquiry conducted by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and that particular submission rested on a number of propositions. One of them is the very strong proposition that the practices that occurred over a period of time involving indigenous children were practices that were authorised by the laws in force, as I understand it, in the various states and territories where the practices occurred.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said at the convention on Monday, I continue to feel a deep personal sorrow for people who have suffered injustices under past practices, but I and the government believe, as a matter of law, as a matter of good government and as a matter of commonsense, the notion that, once any contemporary society goes down the path of compensating for conduct which, although at the time it was embraced was legal and was believed by a significant number of people who were involved in it to have been carried out for a positive purpose, however much we now in the fullness of time and with the passage of time might regard that as being an unacceptable practice, there is in fact no end. There will be no end to the number of claims that can be made and allegations that can be made that the conduct and practices of an earlier generation, judged at the time to be acceptable by people on both sides of politics in that earlier generation—let that not be forgotten—are now in the light of different attitudes to be regarded differently.

The government gave a lot of thought to this. I do not believe that the analogy in relation to guns is a relevant analogy in relation to contemporary action concerning contemporary possession and contemporary ownership of weapons. This is asking one generation to accept legal responsibility for the acts of earlier generations, sanctioned by the law of the times, over which it had no control. That is the basis of the government's attitude and that will remain the government's position.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Makin.
—Mr Speaker, I ask a supplementary question.
—I have called the honourable member for Makin.
—You have to hear him.
—I had already called the honourable member for Makin. If you were prepared to listen rather than offer advice, you would have noted that.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. In light of the reduction of the ANZ standard variable home loan rate yesterday, can the Treasurer advise the House whether any other institutions have followed suit? Can the Treasurer also detail the reaction of lending institutions to this new competitive environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Makin for her question. I also thank her for her invitation to her electorate last week which gave me the opportunity to meet constituents and young home buyers at Tea Tree Gully who are very concerned about their home mortgage rates and of course welcome the representation that they have in this place from the member for Makin.

ANSWER.PARA: I can inform the House that the St George Bank yesterday announced that its variable home loan rate would fall from 7.55 per cent to 7.05 per cent. The St George Bank has passed on the full half a per cent interest rate reduction in its standard variable mortgage rate. This reinforces the cuts which were announced by the ANZ Bank yesterday and which proved that, amongst the big four banks, ANZ is certainly the most competitive when it comes to home loans. Yesterday it announced more than the half a per cent reduction; it announced a 0.56 per cent pass‐on in relation to standard variable rates, taking its standard variable rate down to 6.99 per cent. ANZ customers will have seen their variable rates decline from 10.5 per cent when the coalition first came to office to 6.99 per cent now—interest savings of $292.50 per month. I encourage those people who are taking out home mortgages to shop around and get the best deal they can.

I have also said that this government believes that competition is the best way to get the best deal for home borrowers and business lenders and its our policy of competition which is working. I was somewhat amazed to read on the AAP news this morning a statement from the Leader of the Opposition. He said that the government could not claim credit for low interest rates. The Leader of the Opposition said:
The low inflation rate was delivered five years before Mr Costello came into office.
He is stealing credulity with his claims that he is in any way responsible for the contemporary situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's dead right.
—He is dead right, is he? Five years before we came into office, in March 1991, the Labor Party was working on the recession we had to have. GDP was minus 1.4 per cent.
—What is it now?

—What is it now? It is over three per cent. It was minus 1.4 per cent. Any other interjections? Any other questions? The CPI was 4.9 per cent and it is now one per cent. What was the home mortgage rate five years ago? The home mortgage rate was 14.5 per cent. Five years ago you were working on the recession we had to have. It takes your breath away—the absolute ignorance of the Leader of the Opposition. I can just imagine that, when the banks came around to discuss margins, he pulled out a ruler and drew a line down the page. That is what he thought they meant by margins—one‐inch or two‐inch.

ANSWER.PARA: I wake up this morning and I see that the Commonwealth Bank is taking out ads against me. All the time it was the responsibility of the Leader of the Opposition. Why aren't they taking out ads against Mr Beazley? Hey? Why aren't they? You had better ring up the Commonwealth Bank and tell them who was responsible for all that competition in the sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, really! Competition in the sector!
—Yes, yes, yes.
—You goose. You complete goose.
—I have said it before—psychobabble followed by exaggerated laughter. Five years ago he was working on the recession we had to have.
—The dog wagging the tail.

—Yes, and now we have the height of economic modernity. We have the old ACTU presidents—the member for Batman and the member for Hotham—working out there on modern economics. What did Lindsay Tanner say? He said, `A trip down memory lane arm in arm with Pauline Hanson.'

ANSWER.PARA: I would recommend a new Left-Right alliance between the member for Melbourne and the member for Werriwa, who got thrown out of any Treasury responsibility because he showed signs of being rational. You know that is true. Against the Right-Left alliance of the old ACTU presidents, the trip down memory lane arm in arm with Pauline Hanson.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Liberal dominated Western Australian parliament passed a unanimous resolution yesterday apologising to the Aboriginal people on behalf of all Australians for the past policies under which Aboriginal children were removed from their families and that the South Australian parliament, similarly dominated, is going to consider a similar motion today? Is he aware that we have been advised that in the other place today there will be an opportunity to consider these matters following a statement by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs? Will the Prime Minister ensure that the minister's representative in this chamber makes a similar statement here today and that appropriate time be allocated for debate on it forthwith? If not, why not?

—I am generally aware of the resolutions that have been carried in the other parliaments. This parliament will be aware of the resolution that was carried yesterday. The parliament will also be aware of the statement that I made to the council for reconciliation on Monday. I can assure the honourable gentleman that my ministers, as always, will make appropriate statements of government policy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Visit to Australia of Chinese Delegation

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the current visit to Australia by Vice-Premier Zhu Rongji of China, together with a large and high level delegation. I ask him: what is the significance of the visit in terms of outcomes for Australia and for Australian interests in China and the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Hindmarsh for her question and for the interest she has shown in the visit by Vice-Premier Zhu Rongji because this visit, as I reminded the House earlier this week, is the most important visit to Australia by a Chinese leader since 1994. There is no doubt that both our side and the Chinese side believe the visit has been an outstanding success.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a visit that has underlined the strength of the bilateral relationship between China and Australia and also the breadth of that relationship. It also illustrates very strongly the government's deep commitment to our own region and the way in which week by week Australia in broad terms, not just at the level of government but across the board, is building those ties with its own region.

This visit particularly strengthened the economic relationship between our two countries. The Chinese side gave a commitment to invest in joint ventures in the direct reduced iron industry, and two memorandums of understanding were signed. They agreed to buy more wool from Australia and to reduce wool tariffs, which is very important to all those members here who represent rural electorates. I think they would be pleased to see the coalition government once more doing something constructive for wool growers. The visit also led to the announcement by China that they would issue a new licence to an Australian law firm to operate in China in the form of the firm Blake Dawson Waldron.

Can I also mention that in the discussions with the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism there was progress made towards Australia being defined as an official tourist destination for Chinese tourists. As the minister would be happy to tell the House, if the opposition were to show an interest in the issue, the potential for tourism from China is simply massive. So I was delighted with the progress made in those talks.

Finally, let me say that there were three other issues that came out of the visit. Firstly, both sides confirmed that the human rights dialogue Australia and China are to enter into will begin in August of this year. We are delighted that we have been able to put together this initiative as quickly as it has turned out to be. Secondly, Zhu Rongji made it clear that China would have no objections whatsoever to Australian participation in the Asia-Europe summit meetings. Thirdly, there have been some press reports critical of the Australian alliance with the United States and suggestions that somehow China disapproves of this relationship. I can just say that in response to an article that appeared in the China Daily a couple of days ago, Vice-Premier Zhu Rongji said that that article did not reflect the views of China's leadership or the Chinese government.

So this was a visit which was truly a very substantial success and which has taken the relationship between Australia and China forward significantly. But, I suppose, above all, this is a very good illustration of the breadth and depth of Australia's engagement with Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a parliamentary delegation from Mozambique. We also have present in the gallery Mr Doueihi, a member of the parliament of Lebanon. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.
—Hear, hear!
