If so, Prime Minister, why did you recently tell the parliament, `One of the great things about BHP has been the way it has been able to increase its export performance. The comp any and the unions deserve credit for that. John Button deserves credit for what he was able to do'? If the Button steel plan was a success, why won't you now show some leadership and develop a new steel plan for the nation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want a 10-year plan?

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition has asked his question.
—This is Stalin's economic policy—a sort of Marxist‐Leninist policy. You will have Nkrumah's economic policy next.
—These asides across the chamber do not help.
—It is being drawn up by Lindsay Tanner and Mark Latham.
—No, they are the good guys.
—Yes, they are the good guys. They are putting a bit of hard edge into opposition policy at the present time.

ANSWER.PARA: The question asked by the Leader of the Opposition raises a number of important issues about the future of Newcastle and about the Australian steel industry. It is true that, in answer to a question some time ago, I had some mildly complimentary remarks to make about some aspects of the previous government's policies. Being a person of generous spirit, I have never been reluctant to remind the Australian parliament—it is a long time ago; that is why you have to keep reminding them—that on occasions some of the things that the former government did had some merit.

Nothing could alter the fact that the circumstances that ultimately led to the decision taken by BHP in relation to Newcastle were essentially put in place during the 13 years that the Labor Party was in power. You cannot have it both ways. You cannot say that you had a wonderful plan, you ran the country for 13 years, you got a new government and after 13 months something happened which has clearly been the result of circumstances in train for a long period of time and then turn around and say, `It is all the fault of the way that you have run it over the last 13 months.'

The member for Newcastle, who asked me a question about this in March of this year before the announcement was made by BHP, in the preamble to his question actually acknowledged the non-viability of certain BHP operations in Newcastle. That was the whole premise of his question. I remember it very well. You lot now come along, devoid of any kind of credible industry policy, as the member for Melbourne has quite rightly pointed out. The member for Melbourne has done the debate on industry policy an immense service because what he has really done is expose the complete humbug of the member for Hotham, the good old Mr Flip Flop on protection.

When he was a minister, he used to go down there and make these hairy-chested speeches about globalisation. Now that he is a cheapjack opportunist as an opposition spokesman—`a cheapjack opportunist' has a certain ring about it to me; I like that—he is now flipping and flopping. I think you ought to listen to the member for Melbourne. He speaks a lot of wisdom and he shows a lot of policy courage. He, along with the member for Werriwa, represents the hard edge of Labor Party thinking in their barren years in opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister outline the government's plan to improve the quality of nursing home and aged care in the country? Can she also respond to some of the irresponsible scare tactics that have been peddled by some in the community about the government's changes?

—I thank the member for Richmond for his question. Unlike the people opposite here, who sat on their hands and watched the standard of Australian nursing homes decline seriously over 13 years, this government is committed to ensuring that we address that crisis in nursing homes today. We will face a crisis in nursing home accommodation in this country if the government does not act and if it does not act now.

BREAK.PARA: How did this impending crisis occur? Did it just happen overnight? It did not. For the last 13 years this problem has been growing and staring us all in the face. Who was in government for all of that time that this crisis was growing? Who was in government? Who was advising the minister responsible for aged care for many of those years? We know that it was the member for Jagajaga, who is not here today—the `do nothing but scare' shadow minister.

The government's aged care reform package will bring significant and lasting reforms to the aged care sector. It will provide for those residents comfort, dignity and security in their most frail years. It will provide the incentives for the providers to rebuild nursing homes and to provide a decent standard of care to those in our community who are the most frail. It will introduce strong protections for residents and it will create incentives for providers to invest in and to maintain the buildings and the stock. It will ensure that access to quality care is based on the needs of the people in the community, not on their means, as those people would go out and have people believe.
Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Prospect!
—I warn the member for Prospect!

—These are some of the pillars upon which the government's aged care reform package is being built—solid plans born of extensive consultation and a responsible economic and social policy approach, a far cry from what we got from the opposition, which was just a series of lies and distortions. Day after day the half-truths and the distortions are peddled by the `shadow minister for scare'.

BREAK.PARA: It is not only the opposition which prefers to trade in half-truths and misinformation and to beat up on the government's aged care plans. You just have to look at last night's 7.30 Report to see proof of that. According to the 7.30 Report last night the government was allocating just $5 a day to frail, older disadvantaged Australians. That is what they would have you believe—just $5 a day. That is an absolute and utter distortion of the truth. This additional $5 subsidy is indeed an additional $5 subsidy. It builds on an amount of up to $100 per day that is paid to residents in nursing homes. This subsidy will be paid by this government not just to people in hostels but also to those who reside in nursing homes. That is something the Labor government never did when they were in government.

You would not know this if you had watched the 7.30 Report last night. You could be forgiven for thinking that all we were paying was $5 per person per day to disadvantaged people. Neither would you know from watching last night's report that the Labor Party policy at the last election promised—and the emphasis is on the word `promised'—to spend a pathetic 18c a day on people suffering from dementia. Don't you wave your $5 note here in this House. You were prepared only to make promises of $5 a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister will address her remarks through the chair.

—In fact, they were prepared to give operators only $3 a day to help them with the capital upgrade of their homes. We see their total commitment by the policy they took to the last election. It was a one-page policy comprising eight paragraphs. As I said, their commitment was mainly to try to resolve the problem of dementia to the tune of 18c a day.

BREAK.PARA: Despite the attempts of the opposition and some third parties to derail this government's plan for aged care, we will move forward with confidence and with the knowledge that what this government is about is delivering good quality care to our most frail residents—something the opposition clearly have no interest in whatsoever. For that they should be condemned by all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Administrative Services consider it appropriate for the Liberal Party's submission to the Queensland federal electoral redistribution to have been prepared on a computer in his Brisbane office? Was this publicly funded computer and software available to anyone else other than Liberal Party personnel? How does this affect the integrity of the Liberal Party's submission? Given the minister is responsible for electoral matters, how does he explain this conflict of interest and the use of his office for party activities?

—By an arrangement with the Australian Electoral Commission these computers were provided to all major political parties in both Brisbane and Canberra to help in their submissions to the independent redistribution of Queensland electorates.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Can the minister provide the House with details of the whole of government information technology outsourcing initiative as announced in the budget? Can the minister also inform the House as to what steps the government will take to ensure that privacy of personal and other sensitive information is protected under the outsourcing arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for her question. As honourable members would probably be aware, at the time of the budget it was announced that the government would outsource its information technology on a whole of government basis. This sets the scene for a significant opportunity for small and medium enterprises and it will also save the Commonwealth some $1 billion over the next seven years. The initiative is designed to improve the delivery of service, to reduce the duplication of management and to standardise and consolidate information technology across Australia. The initiative will be undertaken through multiple competitive tendering processes over the next two years.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to note that part of the criteria for the outsourcers will be to demonstrate a commitment to providing employment in regional Australia and a capacity to partner with local small and medium information technology companies. Already regional Australia is embracing this concept. I have noted, for example, that the Ballarat Courier—supported and encouraged by the member for Ballarat—has put an article together on its front page which indicates that it is `our chance'. In addition to that, with the support of the honourable member for Bass, Tasmania has recognised this as an opportunity as well. The Mercury provides a headline which says `Tassie answers the call'.

I have noted also that in Canberra a number of companies have already started to take some initiative in this particular area. A group of some 16 small to medium enterprises have formed a partnership in the Australian Capital Territory under the name of Outsourcing Information Technology Pty Ltd and they are going to be ready for the opportunities that will be provided. The multinational EDS has formed a consortium with a small business here in Canberra, a company called Select Computer Technology, also to respond to the opportunities that are there. So this means opportunities for jobs in regional Australia.

To address the second part of the honourable member's question, relating to privacy, I should state firstly that the property remains with the government. The property in the hands of the contractors remains the property of the government. The contracts will provide very stringent obligations to ensure that privacy is protected. But, perhaps even more importantly, the government has made it abundantly clear that it will extend the Privacy Act to cover the contractors, to cover the outsourcers.

A second concern was that the data processing might occur offshore. I can indicate quite clearly that, following further examination of that particular matter, the tender documents will contain provisions that all data processing occurs in Australia. I should add that this outsourcing of information technology was the policy of the Labor Party. To outsource information technology was in the industry statement that was made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and in a document released in 1995 by the now Leader of the Opposition

Not one effort was made in respect of privacy by the Labor Party, even though the Department of Veterans' Affairs in 1991 let a contract to a company called Ferntree for a period of some five years. There was nothing about extending the Privacy Act in there and there were no contractual obligations. Despite all the scare that the Labor Party have tried to whip up on the question of privacy, supported by their friends in the CPSU, was there any breach of privacy in that five years? There was one. It seems that the Labor Party arranged—and this was told by Senator Faulkner in the Senate last year some time—to let go of the names and addresses of all the veterans in Brisbane so that the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Alderman Soorley, could have a Christmas card list of some size. He was struggling for names, so the Department of Veterans' Affairs, helped by Labor, gave him a list of names and addresses of veterans in Brisbane.

The government's initiative will save the taxpayers of Australia some $1 billion over seven years. It will provide jobs in regional Australia, and already we have seen initiatives taken by regional Australia in that regard. Protection of privacy is to the forefront of this initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer him to a statement he made in this House about Labor's steel plan: `Not one cent was ever paid over the life of the plant in Newcastle for the manufacture of steel product. The steel plan did nothing for Newcastle.' Is the minister aware that the bounty was paid to a number of Newcastle based companies such as BHP owned Tubemakers, that BHP invested over $200 million in Newcastle as part of the steel plan and that the steel plan included a $58 million structural adjustment and diversification package for Newcastle. In light of this, has he misled the House?

—The quick answer is no, because the member himself quite clearly misunderstands the question. The famous Button plan was paid as a production bounty and, as I have said before, not one cent of that bounty was paid to steel produced at BHP Newcastle. You now refer to whether the bounty was taken up by some other elements who bought steel from BHP. The facts are that the steel that was made in Newcastle was not the steel that was bountiable.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Could the minister advise the House of the impact on the work force of Australian National if the sale of Australian National is blocked by the Labor Party?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question. He, of course, has a very great interest in this issue and has been very concerned about the future of AN and its work force. Particularly, of course, members on this side of the House have been trying to do things to provide AN and its work force with some certainty.

ANSWER.PARA: Members will recall that last year the government announced a $2 billion rail reform package, which involved the sale of AN to provide AN with certainty that it has not had over the last few years and to provide it with a new owner, with fresh capital investment, with new management expertise and with a new direction.

This, of course, was seen by many people, in the industry, in the community and within the work force at AN, as the end of the era of uncertainty and death by a thousand cuts which had been inflicted upon them by the former Labor government in its management of AN. Now it appears, following the caucus decision yesterday, that the Labor Party, in opposition today, seeks to block the legislation necessary to see the sale of AN proceed and to see the certainty that that sale would offer the work force of AN and the communities that depend on AN for their future.

It is the same Labor Party which yesterday decided to oppose privatisation of AN and which, when they were in government, were enthusiastic and, indeed, led the charge for privatisation in a number of sectors of the economy such as the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank undertaken by the Labor Party, the privatisation of Australian Airlines and the privatisation of Qantas. Now, 13 or 14 months after they have lost office, they have done a complete reversal of that attitude and have opposed the sale of AN. Of course, if the parliament were not to pass the sale bill for AN, the work force at AN can continue to expect to see the sorts of bad policy decisions inflicted upon AN and its future.

When AN was being managed by the Labor Party when they were in government, some 7,000‐odd jobs were lost at AN. Some 16 lines were closed by the Labor Party when they were in office. Some 1,300 kilometres of rail track were ripped up by the Labor Party when they were in office. Six or seven passenger services were closed down when the Labor Party were in office. Indeed, what the Labor Party inflicted on rail in Australia was death by a thousand cuts.

This proposal that the coalition government puts forward gives a certain future to AN and its work force. The only people who appear to be opposed to the sale of AN are the Labor Party here in Canberra. If you speak to the workers, they have a totally different view of the government's proposals.
Within 24 hours of the Labor Party announcing they were going to block the sale of AN in the parliament, I received a letter from workers at AN in Port Augusta. It states:

. . . we wish to advise you of the support of the majority of employees within the Port Augusta Workshops of the action being taken by the Government to sell the business activities of Australian National.
Support from the workers, who voted in many cases for the honourable member for Grey, and who stand by the decision made by this government to sell AN.

It is not only the workers but also the community representatives who support the government's actions. There is no community more dependent on AN and its future than Port Augusta. The mayor of Port Augusta, Joy Baluch, who was recently re‐elected with a very comfortable margin, said:
You would have to be deaf, dumb and blind with a labrador dog to suggest that AN should continue to be operated by government.

Everybody—whether it is the workers, their community representatives or the people who are elected to represent them here in the parliament of Australia—wants to see the government's rail reform policies put into action and put into legislation here in the parliament. There is one exception: the Labor Party. When in government they were keen on privatisation but in opposition they have done a complete backflip and now oppose what could only be seen as the most sensible proposition for the certainty of rail, for the certainty of those people who work at AN and their jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. I refer to reports today that BHP's refractories at Port Kembla, Newcastle, Unanderra and Whyalla are up for sale. Does the minister regard this as another `regrettable' decision? What action will the minister be taking to guarantee the jobs of the 860 workers at these operations? Doesn't this show that the absence of a national steel plan is causing the piecemeal breakup of the Australian steel industry?

—I was talking to BHP and I can confirm that some discussions have taken place as to the future purchasing of the refractory division of BHP. They inform me that there is no intention at the present moment to move in that direction. There are three refractories covered by this: one in Newcastle and two in Port Kembla. I am told at this stage that there is no movement on that front. While I am here, I should also point to—
—They announced it yesterday.
—I can only confirm what BHP told me this morning: that people are interested but there is no movement at the present moment.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice. Is the Attorney‐General aware of a letter currently being distributed in my electorate of Leichhardt—and, I understand, in other areas as well—by a Caroline Cormack, on behalf of an organisation called the Australian Christian Coalition, suggesting that this government is currently considering legislation that will, among other things, permit sexual activity between adults and children? Can the Attorney‐General assure the concerned constituents in my electorate of Leichhardt that there is no basis for these disgraceful and misleading comments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Leichhardt for his comments. I am aware of this letter and of the allegations it contains. The same issues have, in fact, been drawn to my attention by other members, including the member for Longman, the member for Lyne and the member for Kingston.

ANSWER.PARA: The letter refers to a discussion paper entitled Sexual offences against the person which was developed for public consultation by the representatives of the New South Wales government on the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee. All states and territories, as well as the Commonwealth, are represented on that committee. It is important to note at the outset that the contents of the discussion paper do not represent the views of this government or any of the governments, or even any of the individual Attorneys‐General.

The officers committee will, in due course, report to the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General, SCAG, which will no doubt take into account community views expressed on the issues in question. It is also important to bear in mind that, under the federal system, primary responsibility for the offences dealt with in the discussion paper rests with the states and territories, and the governments ultimately will deal with the matters.

In the letter, the Australian Christian Coalition is disseminating extremely misleading information about the proposals in the discussion paper. Several of the recommendations attributed to the officers committee are quite outrageous. The allegation referred to by the honourable member is an example. One of the claims made by the Australian Christian Coalition is that the discussion paper proposes that it be lawful for adults to engage in sexual activity with children. This is absolutely untrue. Under the draft legislation proposed in the discussion paper, it would be illegal for an adult to have sex with a child under 16, regardless of whether the child consented or not.If an adult has sex with a child—and even if the adult genuinely believes that the child is consenting—that adult would be guilty, under the proposals, of a serious offence and subject to severe penalties.

While public comments on the actual proposals are welcome, the circulation of misinformation does not assist the committee in formulating final recommendations. The interests of Australian children and the protection of important family values are not served by grossly misleading material that deceives rather than informs.

I am aware that some of the committee's recommendations which deal with quite sensitive issues have given rise to legitimate community concerns. As the Prime Minister indicated earlier this year, this government will only support proposals for change which reflect and take full account of the values of the broader Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. It refers to an earlier answer about his `recognition' of BHP's magnificent export performance under Labor's steel plan—a performance which saw exports of steel treble over the 13 years that we were in office. Is he aware that nine days ago BHP announced, `With the decision to close Newcastle, exports will decrease from 40 per cent to about 30 per cent of BHP production'? Prime Minister, hasn't your weak leadership in failing to develop a steel plan led directly to a cut in Australia's exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Hotham continues to peddle this line. In the words of the New South Wales Premier—and he ought to be listened to a little more than Labor Party opposition members; he is at least in government—it has to be said that this is being done `predominantly because of BHP's assessment of local factors'.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth is that the Labor Party on this issue has been bouncing from one side to the other depending on who the spokesman is and depending on what day of the week it is. This is what the member for Hotham said on 13 May: `Had Labor still been in government what was announced two weeks ago would not have happened.' What did he say a few weeks later? `What we now need is steel plan mark 2.' Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition wants steel plan Lindsay 2.
I take the members of the House back to what was said by Mr McNeilly, the General Manager of BHP. He had this to say on 29 April 1997:
We do not believe there is anything that we can envisage that the government can do to change the decision.

The Leader of the Opposition did not believe that the government should offer any financial assistance—although a few weeks later the Premier of New South Wales did offer some financial assistance and my government has indicated that it will match the financial assistance offered by the Premier of New South Wales.

Australians know and the steel workers of Newcastle know, and increasingly I believe members of the Labor Party know—and they are now showing their embarrassment by advancing alternative plans—that the much vaunted industry policy of the member for Hotham is nothing short of cheapjack opportunism. When he was a minister he was prepared just occasionally to argue some kind of rational consistent approach to industry policy.

Now that he is in opposition he believes that the path to political success, economic salvation and building something decent for the workers of Australia lies in cheapjack opportunism, running around any part of Australia where he can spread some misinformation, where he can create a bit of instability. He grins at the fact that he creates instability. You can go to a work force and you can misrepresent the situation. You can threaten people's jobs by irresponsible statements. But in the long run that kind of conduct will find you out.

As the member for Melbourne and the member for Werriwa know, what a sensible opposition ought to do, particularly in the early years that it is in opposition, is sit down and reflect on why they lost, try to understand why they lost the support of their traditional workers, develop some alternative policies, put forward some long range vision for the future of Australian industry and, if you do that, after five or 10 years the public might start taking a bit of notice of you.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Northern Territory Communities: Assistance from Defence Force

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. The Oombulgurri Aboriginal community in Western Australia was severely disrupted by floods in February this year. Can the Minister for Defence outline what assistance the army has been able to provide to this remote community to repair the flood damage and improve the community's infrastructure? Can the minister also inform the House what other remote communities, especially those in the Northern Territory, will receive assistance from the Defence Force under the ATSIC army community assistance project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for the Northern Territory for his question. As he said, in late February this year the Oombulgurri community suffered extensive flood damage, which resulted in the evacuation of all 375 people to Wyndham. I was asked for help in March by the Western Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Originally this was to be an emergency fix to the barge landing site to get people back from Wyndham. I am pleased to say that it was able to be included eventually in one of the six pilot sites for the ATSIC army community assistance project announced later by Minister Herron.

ANSWER.PARA: Fifty‐five army personnel, mainly from Darwin, went to Oombulgurri on 23 April. All the equipment was brought in by barge. They had graders, a crane, medium and light bulldozers, rollers, water tankers and dump trucks. They installed a new barge landing area in a better location allowing easier access and improved the lighting and refuelling capacity in the town. They levelled and resheeted the airstrip, upgrading it to allow larger aircraft to land, as well as doing ongoing maintenance to the community's 33 houses. That included plumbing and electrical services. For extracurricula activities they reactivated some of the waterlogged vehicles along the way.

BREAK.PARA: This urgent support work was undertaken in cooperation with the Western Australian state authorities and completed earlier this week. Contrary to some of the nonsense that was put about before this work was undertaken, I am informed that the Oombulgurri community is most appreciative of the army's assistance. I can assure you and members of this House that the army is equally appreciative of the opportunity to be involved. They achieved their training outcomes and had a marvellous time while they were about it.

In answer to the latter part of the member's question, the other five communities in the Northern Territory are Bulla, Milyakburra, Galiwinku outstations and Kaltukatjara, and Oak Valley in South Australia. Army assistance to these communities will involve upgrades and maintenance to housing, water, plumbing and power supplies and infrastructure repairs.

I am delighted the question came because Aboriginal communities and people help the ADF right across northern Australia, particularly through involvement in surveillance and patrolling activities. This project, particularly the one at Oombulgurri, was a great opportunity for us to repay the compliment. Unlike the opposition, the Australian Defence Force is interested in doing things, not talking about it, and I am delighted to be able to talk about it for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that his budget tax changes have meant for Newcastle that, while on the one hand a loyal, long‐serving worker forced by the closure to take a redundancy package will now have to pay the 15 per cent new superannuation tax surcharge, on the other hand a BHP manager with $110,000 in company shares, if he realised the 50c a share gain in the share price flowing from the closure decision, would now collect a $450 savings rebate from you? Is that what you mean by governing for all Australians?
—I will naturally, as I always do, analyse the questions of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. But my under standing is that eligible termination payments have been excluded from the surcharge.
—I call the honourable member for Fisher.
—Order! I have called the honourable member for Fisher. Resume your seat.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —He has forgotten he is not in government, Mr Speaker. My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What benefits are likely to be seen by the successful resolution of the Wik issue under the Wik 10-point plan by groups other than pastoralists and Aborigines? How important is it that the uncertainty created by the Wik High Court decision be resolved for the benefit of the economy and indeed all Australians? I ask whether the Prime Minister has seen a report in yesterday's Australian which quotes Mr Kawarabayashi, Director of Mitsui and Chairman of the Federation of Japanese Chambers of Commerce, as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . from a Japanese perspective, resolution in this matter—
is essential to begin to restore investor's confidence in the future of mining and energy projects in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It does give me an opportunity to say something to the House about the importance of resolving what is a very difficult issue for this country, and that is the appropriate legislative response to the decision of the High Court in the Wik case. We have made our position very clear. The Australian Democrats have made their position very clear. But, of course, once again the Australian Labor Party is trying to have it both ways.
—Show us your legislation.
—Is the member for Banks in favour of the 10-point plan?
—No.
—You are not in favour of the 10‐point plan?
—No. It's unconstitutional. It's an abuse of power, and you know it.

—We have the member for Banks, the leader of the opposition. He is the leader of the opposition on native title. The Leader of the Opposition, this bloke here, is trying to have it both ways. Whenever he is talking to Daryl Melham, he is saying, `Yes, Daryl, three bags full, Daryl, yes, Daryl.' His attitude on this is like his attitude on immigration.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: in terms of the directions you gave the other day, you clearly specified that all comments need to be directed through you and that references will be made to members of this House by the seat that they hold. I direct you—
—Order! Members on my right!
—I ask you to direct the Prime Minister to adhere to your ruling, because clearly he tore it up yesterday.

—I thank the honourable member for Hotham for his point of order. There is no doubt that the settling in process associated with an attempt to create new conventions in the House is taking a little longer to effectively introduce than I anticipated. However, the Prime Minister was digressing, and I do call him to address the specifics of the question.

—Mr Speaker, can I say that I am enjoying question time more and more. You really get a lot of information out of the opposition when you get asked a question. I am very grateful that the leader of the opposition on native title matters has declared quite affirmatively that the Labor Party is against the government's 10-point plan. He joins the honoured ranks of the member for Melbourne and the member for Werriwa.At least he is prepared to have a point on view on this issue.

BREAK.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition's attitude on native title is like his attitude on immigration. On immigration he runs around the country stirring up dissent about the decision that we have announced, saying out of the side of his mouth, `Oh, it's terrible, it's absolutely shocking,' and when I say to him, `Do you support the cut or do you oppose it?' he says, `Oh, actually, I support the cut.'

This is the sort of pathetic, weak leadership that we are now getting from the Leader of the Opposition. It will be very interesting to see where the Leader of the Opposition ultimately comes out. Is he going to agree with Daryl Melham or Gareth Evans on the subject of native title? We all know that there is quite a gulf between Daryl Melham and Gareth Evans. It is important because of the enormous complexity of the Native Title Act—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the Prime Minister is defying your ruling and I would ask you to call him to order in accordance with the document you require us to operate by. We have, and they won't.
—Order! I thank the honourable member for Hotham. The Prime Minister is aware of the conventions of the House and of my statement of a few days ago. I call him to address the question.

—The member for Fairfax asked me a very, very sensible question about native title. As I was saying, it is important in the interests Australia that the very unworkable, the very time consuming, the very obstructive, the very anti-investment Native Title Act 1993, which was opposed by the Liberal and National parties, I remind the Australian—
—Shameful!

—I do not think it is a shame to have opposed a piece of legislation that has brought investment and mining in this country virtually to a halt. I make absolutely no apology for that. In many areas of Australia it has had a disastrous effect on investment and a disastrous effect on mining. I want to say to the member for Fairfax that it is very important for the future of Australia.
—He's got the title wrong.

—I want to say to the member for Fisher, and also to the member for Fairfax—and, in fact, to all members on my side of the House, who are interested in long-term investment in this country—that we think it is important to investment stability in Australia that amendments to the Native Title Act to render it workable are made as soon as possible.

BREAK.PARA: That is why the government—after very lengthy consultation with leaders of the Aboriginal community, after very lengthy consultation with leaders of the mining industry, after lengthy consultation with leaders of the agricultural community, after lengthy conversation with the pastoralists at Longreach and, indeed, with other sections of the Australian community—has been prepared to promulgate a 10-point plan which respects the spirit of native title as laid down in the Mabo decision. But also it is a plan that will give to the mining industry and to the pastoral industry of Australia the security and the guarantees to which they are entitled. It will underwrite an increase in investment in Australia and it will deliver the fair balance which, demonstrably, the Labor Party's Native Title Act failed to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to an Aboriginal matter before this Parliament today, as opposed to the one which is still coming with regard to Wik. That is, I refer back to the question I asked the Prime Minister earlier and that he did not answer.
—To whom are you addressing your question?

—The Prime Minister. Given that the Prime Minister has now had half an hour or so to consider the matter and has discussed it with his Leader of the House, will he now undertake that this afternoon we have an opportunity to debate in this chamber Senator Herron's response to the Bringing them home report?
—My reply to the Leader of the Opposition is that the order of business that has been laid down will be adhered to.

SSO.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith:
That:

(a) recalling the Australian people's overwhelming decision in the 1967 Referendum to confer upon the Commonwealth Parliament responsibility for enhancement of the rights and well being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(b) reaffirming the abhorrence of racism shared by the Australian people and their Federal and State Governments;

(c) reaffirming Australia's recognition of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the International Convention on the Prevention of All Forms of Racial Discrimination;
(d) recalling the Parliament's commitment in October 1996 to the principles of racial tolerance; and
(e) recognising the profound economic and social disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—
this House—

(1) affirms that the tabling of "Bringing them Home", the Report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families, presents the nation with an unprecedented historical opportunity to render justice and restitution to Indigenous Australians, for the good of all Australians;

(2) acknowledges the immense trauma inflicted upon the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia as a result of the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families under past government policies in place from before the time of Federation until the early 1900s;
(3) affirms that these racially discriminatory policies and their continuing consequences are a matter of national shame;
(4) affirms that current future and Federal and State governments are responsible for assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to rectify the ongoing effects of those policies;
5) affirms its commitment to a just and proper settlement of the grievances of people adversely affected by those policies; and
on behalf of the nation—
6) unreservedly apologises to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for the separation policies;

(7) calls upon Federal and State governments to establish, in consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, appropriate processes to provide compensation and restitution, including assistance for the reunification of families and counselling services;

(8) calls on the Federal Government and State governments to establish appropriate education programs to enhance community awareness of the history and continuing consequences of past practices and policies of racial discrimination; and

(9) calls upon the Federal Government to declare a National Day in recognition and remembrance of the great suffering which flowed from the separation policies, and to affirm our nation's commitment to justice for Indigenous Australians, today and for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —After question time, we will take this matter. We intend to finish question time. On that basis, I would move that the member be not further heard.
—We'll accept that.
—You are happy with that?
—Yes, after question time.
—In those circumstances, I should ask leave to withdraw the motion—that would be the appropriate thing—and bring it in immediately after question time.
—Leave is granted.
—Leave is granted. I thank the Leader of the House; I thank the Leader of the Opposition.

—I address my question to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Will the minister inform the House what steps the Commonwealth government is taking to ensure that all Australian school students have an understanding of this country's constitutional, political and legal traditions and systems so that our young people are properly equipped to participate in Australian society as individuals with equal rights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Bendigo for his question. I believe that members of this House are certainly growing in their conviction that it is vital that young Australians have an understanding of the demo cratic principles which underpin our peaceful and tolerant society, and of the institutions which embody and protect those principles. It is clear that many young people do not know about Australia's remarkable democratic heritage. The report of the most recent Constitutional Commission showed that 50 per cent of Australians were unaware that Australia had a written constitution.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is, in fact, one of the world's pioneering democracies and is today one of the great democratic nations of the world. How many Australians, I wonder, realise that this nation was one of the first countries in the world to remove the property requirement from voting; that in Australia women got the vote nationally decades before they obtained it in the United States or Britain; that secret voting in elections is known in the United States as `the Australian ballot'; and that it is this democratic heritage which requires that we cannot have other than policies such as a non-discriminatory immigration policy, and that has made this country such a successful and tolerant society.

It is our democratic heritage that requires us to recognise the cost of establishing this democratic society, and of course that is the dispossession of the Aboriginal people. And it is our democratic heritage today that demands that we address these issues with reference to the dignity of all Australians.

Talking further to Discovering Democracy, the government civics and citizenship initiative I recently launched, I want to make the point that this initiative establishes a very strong historical focus on the history of Australian democracy. The students will study the responsibilities of the different levels of government, how and why the basic freedoms of speech in Australia were established, and the history and role of indigenous Australians. The federal government will be providing some $17½ million over the next three years to establish the civics curriculum.

The Civics Experts Group has been expanded in its membership to include as chair Dr John Hirst, the reader in history at La Trobe University, and Professor Greg Craven, the professor of law at Notre Dame University. The remaining members of the group are Professor Stuart Macintyre, Ms Susan Pascoe and Dr Ken Boston. Students will be surveyed each year to determine their level of knowledge of the history and working of Australian democracy, and a national award will be established to recognise outstanding achievement by young Australians in civics education.
The government is very proud to be initiating the Discovering Democracy program, and I urge all members of the House on both sides to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel. Last year the minister told the RSL National Congress that the government would honour its pre‐election promise to award the Australian Service Medal 1945‐75 to all defence and former defence personnel who served in that period. Why has the government reneged on the promise to make that award?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that, before the election, there were statements made about the awarding of the ASM 1945‐75 to people who served in the Korean War, the Malayan emergency and the Indonesian confrontation. I said at the conference that was mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition that we were honouring our promises. I also pointed out that, as the proposal was to award the ASM to people for active service as distinct from non‐active service, or non‐warlike service, there was a required change by Her Majesty the Queen to the regulations to allow the ASM to be awarded for active service. I then instigated the process to obtain that concurrence.

ANSWER.PARA: In the course of that, discussion arose as to the question of double medalling, and it was indeed then discovered that those people had been awarded an Imperial Medal at the behest of the Australian government, and therefore it was an Australian medal rendered in respect of that active service given in Korea, in the Malayan emergency and in the Indonesian confrontation. Accordingly, the government made a decision that that would represent double medalling and that that would not be done.

The government gave the reason that it was important to protect the integrity of the medal already given and therefore the decision was made. However, all the other medals as promised regarding the lessening of time for the receipt of the ASM 1939‐45—down from 180 days to 30 days; the awarding of the ASM 1945‐75 in respect of the Far East Strategic Reserve, in respect of Papua New Guinea, in respect of BCOF—the British Commonwealth Occupation Force in Japan—and in respect of the Berlin airlift, were all honoured and have been awarded.

There was some publicity in the press that said that those medals would be affected. In fact, they will not. I repeat: the reason that the government made the decision arose from the process that I had instigated to obtain Her Majesty's concurrence, and it was then that the discussion on double medalling arose and the government took its decision that no double medalling would be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer to the positive action taken by the government in establishing the Supermarket to Asia strategy aimed at taking fullest advantage of our potential to boost agrifood exports to countries to our north which are home to half the world's population. I ask the minister: in what ways is the government backing the Supermarket to Asia commitment in order to enhance our export performance and, furthermore, what will be the benefits for the agricultural and horticultural industries of the electorate of Mallee in particular?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I thank the honourable member. With his electorate and its horticultural production, he is particularly interested in making sure that we take advantage of the emerging opportunities in Asia. The Supermarket to Asia Council, which is actually chaired by the Prime Minister himself, brings together key ministers in the government and industry leaders, and it constitutes a cornerstone of our efforts to achieve the government's vision of a truly competitive Australian agrifood industry which is able to take as big a slice as possible of the emerging action in Asia.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia exports around five times as much food as we import. There are some 400,000 people directly employed in producing agricultural product and another 200,000 people in the manufacturing sector in food processing alone. That is the largest single sector in manufacturing in this country. This strategy will undoubtedly bring more investment and more jobs to rural and regional Australia. That is the key message out of this for the bush.

The government has committed total funding of some $11.8 million to help implement the strategy. There is $2 million per annum, for example, to be used to fund a technical market access program. That will see, amongst other things, two AQIS technical access experts—one in each of Japan and Korea—to vigorously pursue Australia's access concerns in those and other Asian markets. Members will be aware of the broad parameters—some 78 new products now enjoying access to some 35 different countries throughout Asia as a direct result of activities in recent times.

There is $1.4 million per annum for three years which has been provided to establish and run the council itself. In addition, there is funding for the quality food Australia proposal and there is seed funding for the assistance of the promotional activities in Asia in 1997, with industry to be responsible for this program from the beginning of 1998.

Then there are working groups, one of which, for example, is the Asian Marketing Working Group. It is looking at undertaking coordinated retail and food service promotions in Asian countries with Australian food companies, promoting a quality food Australian logo and establishing a network of contacts throughout Asia which will assist current and new exporters with the development of their business.

There are program such as the `delicatessen', as it is known, to assist Australian food processors to better appreciate the specific requirements of Asian customers. There are efforts being made to promote new—in many cases, new for Australia—products or different varieties utilising currently ignored by‐products or changing the presentation of traditional products to meet specific Asian market requirements.

We want to build on all of these things, because in turn they will contribute to an increase in the volume and the variety of exports of high value products from rural and regional areas. We are very good at these things, but we want to maximise our opportunities because it is a large part of restoring job opportunities to rural Australia after the mess that you people opposite left it in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move the suspension of standing and sessional orders in the terms which I previously read to the House.
—It might help the House if I say that the Leader of the Opposition is entitled to move a motion to suspend standing orders. He does not need to seek leave.
—You said you would let the matter on.

—In fairness, the words that I used during question time were to the effect that we would have the suspension motion debate after question time—that we insisted on having a full question time. Our intention is that we will have a debate on the suspension motion in the same way that we had yesterday. There will one and then two speakers on the opposition side and the government will respond.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving the following motion forthwith:
That:

(a) recalling the Australian people's overwhelming decision in the 1967 Referendum to confer upon the Commonwealth Parlia ment responsibility for enhancement of the rights and well being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(b) reaffirming the abhorrence of racism shared by the Australian people and their Federal and State Governments;

(c) reaffirming Australia's recognition of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the International Convention on the Prevention of All Forms of Racial Discrimination;
(d) recalling the Parliament's commitment in October 1996 to the principles of racial tolerance; and
(e) recognising the profound economic and social disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—
this House—

(1) affirms that the tabling of "Bringing them Home", the Report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families, presents the nation with an unprecedented historical opportunity to render justice and restitution to Indigenous Australians, for the good of all Australians;

(2) acknowledges the immense trauma inflicted upon the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia as a result of the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families under past government policies in place from before the time of Federation until the early 1900s;
(3) affirms that these racially discriminatory policies and their continuing consequences are a matter of national shame;
(4) affirms that current future and Federal and State governments are responsible for assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to rectify the ongoing effects of those policies;
5) affirms its commitment to a just and proper settlement of the grievances of people adversely affected by those policies; and
on behalf of the nation—
6) unreservedly apologises to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for the separation policies;

(7) calls upon Federal and State governments to establish, in consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, appropriate processes to provide compensation and restitution, including assistance for the reunification of families and counselling services;

(8) calls on the Federal Government and State governments to establish appropriate education programs to enhance community awareness of the history and continuing consequences of past practices and policies of racial discrimination; and

(9) calls upon the Federal Government to declare a National Day in recognition and remembrance of the great suffering which flowed from the separation policies, and to affirm our nation's commitment to justice for Indigenous Australians, today and for the future.

The motion which I read to the House earlier on is a motion which is a direct response to the issues made in the Bringing them home report. It is motion and a proposition which we anticipated that we would have an opportunity to debate here today. People who are listening to this ought to know that that there has been a sense around this parliament for the last three days that on this day this parliament would discuss this report. It has been an understanding that that would occur both here and in the Senate. This day it will occur in the Senate; it will not occur in the House of Representatives.

Of course, the significance is that it gives us an opportunity to pass and move resolutions related to it. In case people defend themselves in this place for the fact that we have not had the opportunity to debate these matters by reference to the propositions that were put down yesterday, it needs to be pointed out that those issues that we considered in the resolution on Aboriginal matters yesterday did not go to the matters related to the Bringing them home report; they went of course to a recognition in this parliament of the 30th anniversary of the consideration by the Australian people of the referendum empowering the Commonwealth to make laws for the benefit of Aboriginal people.

Of course, when that particular referendum was passed, it meant that for these sorts of issues the buck stopped in this chamber. The speech that I want to make here today is not about apportioning blame in politics. I do not want to do that, nor to claim that there is some special position in relation to the Australian Labor Party that applies to us and not to other people, as far as this chamber is concerned.

I had an opportunity to read a fair proportion of this report last night, and one thing is amply clear to me. As I read through that report, the materials contained within it refer to operations that occurred when the Labor Party was in office.

For those things that we are responsible for I apologise, as Leader of the Australian Labor Party. This is a terrible, terrible record. This record does not deal with the experience of Aboriginals in good‐hearted homes with kindly foster parents. There may be some reference to that and the consequences of that, which of course were the consequences which were the least difficult to bear for the Aboriginal people. Many very decent people took up that fostering status, and they did so without maliciousness and with the very best intentions. This report is not really about them. That is the truth of the matter.

It does refer to them of course in the context of the extent to which those people nevertheless, without knowing it, were implicated in a deculturalisation of a race, with all the loss of identity that flowed from that and the extraordinary difficulties that they confronted. However, what the report does detail is very different experiences, experiences of viciousness of extraordinary dimensions—experience of sexual assault, of physical assault, of overt pressured propagandisation.

This is not a matter that we can sweep under this table. This is not a matter that we can stand aside from. This is not a matter about which I direct blame at this government. It is not a matter about which I would believe that I am in any moral position to do so, and that is not what my intention is here today.

My intention is to try to provide this parliament with an opportunity that the Western Australian parliament, under Richard Court—of all people—and the South Australian parliament, under John Olsen, took without any blush, without any concern for their reputations and without any worry about what might be the legal implications of what they said. They decided that they would stand in their parliaments and apologise; they would stand in their parliaments and make a statement about what their intentions were. This is what we believed that we would have an opportunity to discuss here today. We have not.

BREAK.PARA: I raised a question earlier on: the question of compensation for the situation in which the Aboriginal people of this country found themselves. The question of compensation is a question which governments consider repeatedly. They consider it in relation to people who have committed acts, either whilst in government or in private organisations, without any maliciousness at all. The people who invented particular breast implants procedures, for example, did not invent those with an intention to do malicious harm to women in our community. Yet compensation is expected of them. What about the people who originally planned, for example, situations which saw folk who were not actually orphans, nevertheless declared such, taken out from Britain and settled in Australia, and themselves experiencing some of the things—not all of the things, but some of the things—that the Aboriginal community experienced? There are committees of parliament in other places in this nation which are contemplating the compensation issues related to that. There is no maliciousness there. There may have been abuse experienced in some circumstances, but no maliciousness.

To take it a point further, there are equivalents elsewhere in the community of acts which are detailed in this which were perpetrated upon members of the European community, if you like. The Catholic Church is struggling with the issue of compensation now to deal with very equivalent acts to that.

Why should not the Aboriginal people of this nation be accorded equality? Why not? Why not let the Aboriginal people of this nation have the same experience and the same access? When, for malicious reasons or non‐malicious reasons, deep personal damage is done to you, you have recourse. Why not? Why should that not happen? Why are they not people who are at least equal to us in the opportunities that are available to them?
That is not an easy process to contemplate. I was going to read some of these cases, but I cannot. I was up pretty late going through it—and this would have been a better speech if I had not.

Mr Speaker, you cannot walk away from them. This chamber cannot walk away from them. The government cannot walk away from them. They have to be confronted. There are processes by which you can do that. You can do it the easy way, or you can do it the hard way. The easy way is to allow a motion to proceed to make the first step of restitution: that is the apology. That is part of the easy way. The second part of the easy way is for the Commonwealth to engage the states in a conversation as to how they will handle it. The third part of the easy way is to deal with this, possibly, in the way in which the land fund has been dealt with—there is an opportunity not to do the compensation on budget, but to draw down from it from time to time. The fourth part of the easy way is to get a formula in place, as suggested at length in this report, whereby, for various types of problems, people's situations are assessed and dealt with. That is the easy way.

The hard way is this: ignore it and let those compensation cases roll through the court with every piece of disturbance in race relations in this country that follows as, one after another, the courts compensate Aboriginal people for the wrongs done them. That is the hard way; it is the divisive way in this community.

I urge the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to seize this opportunity now and to take the easy way for all of us, and to reach a conclusion on this that will ensure that this parliament performs its responsibilities for an apology, and that this parliament performs its responsibilities for restitution. It is a situation that lies in his hands and cries out for leadership—he must provide it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) sought public office. Normally, prime ministers grow in office, they do not diminish in office. What is required in response to this report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families is generosity of spirit, not mean‐spiritedness. There are two stories that I want to read onto the record in the short time that I have. The first appears on page 211:

BREAK.PARA: I was there for 16 years and I was brainwashed every day of the week. You never go near Blacks. Your people don't want you anyway. They're just dirty. They don't want anything to do with you . . . We were playing in the schoolyard and this old black man came to the fence. I could hear him singing out to me and my sister. I said to [my sister], `Don't go. There's a black man'. And we took off. It was two years ago I found out that was my grandfather. He came looking for us. I don't know when I ever stopped being frightened of Aboriginal people. I don't know when I even realised I was Aboriginal. It's been a long hard fight for me.
That is the story of what happened to someone in the 1940s. Lest we think that those stories were in years gone by, there are recent stories. On page 168 of the report this story is recounted:

The thing that hurts the most is that they didn't care about who they put us with. As long as it looked like they were doing their job, it just didn't matter. They put me with one family and the man of the house used to come down and use me whenever he wanted to . . . Being raped over and over and there was no-one I could turn to. They were supposed to look after me and protect me, but no-one ever did.

That person was aged 13 and taken away in the 1960s. Yesterday the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) gave a compassionate speech. He gave a speech that the Prime Minister should have given. He said:
The difference with Aboriginal people is that they have suffered systematic discrimination at the hands of government.

It is very easy, with hindsight, to say things were wrong. It is very easy to talk of words. Clearly what happened to the children who were removed from their families was wrong—deeply, horribly, morally wrong. Taking children away from their parents is wrong. Placing them in institutions, denying them the truth about their past and denying them access to information about their parents, is wrong—deeply, horribly, morally wrong.
Of course it not only struck at the core of Aboriginal communities in the end it diminished all Australians.
Words are cheap. Motions are cheap. What is required is a generosity of spirit.

That is what is required from this Prime Minister—leadership from the top. Instead we have had mean spiritedness. I was there on Monday. Aboriginal people are generous people. When the apology was first given they turned and looked at the Prime Minister and clapped spontaneously. But then the qualifications came. It was a mean spirited, grudging apology from a mean spirited and narrow minded Prime Minister.

He not only diminishes his office but also diminishes the nation. The nation is watching. The world is watching. Prime Minister, leadership is required—leadership from the highest office. You shame your office by your conduct. You shame the nation by your conduct. In 1967 this parliament was given the power to protect Aboriginal people, to act to their benefit, not to continue the discrimination against them. They are entitled to equality before the law, to respect before the law and to respect in all matters that others are entitled to. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the opposition has moved a motion to suspend standing orders to debate a very important report—a report which was tabled in this parliament and which this afternoon has been the subject of a preliminary response from the government by the minister responsible in the Senate. In due course, so that there can be a proper response, there will be a full government response tabled in the parliament and a debate will ensue. The reason we do not have a government response this week is, as is the usual practice with these reports, the report is tabled and the government then consults with the very many interested parties who are involved in this matter so that we have a comprehensive response.

SPEECH.PARA: No-one could not be touched by the examples read out by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) about the disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal Australians. No-one could deny the injustices that some of our fellow Australians have endured. But in our response it is, in my view, our responsibility to focus on the substantial injustices and to focus on the practical remedies that will genuinely respond to these injustices of the past, the difficulties of the past and the disadvantages which are today suffered by so many Aboriginal people.

These are not easy issues. If they were easy issues then many of them would already have been the subject of a more satisfactory response from the body politic than what we have so far seen. It does not help in attempting to put together an element of political support for practical changes when this issue is used as a means to attack the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the personal—
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left—and on my right!

—The interjections can only send a single message, and that is that there are some people—not all—who think there is party political advantage to be achieved in this. Do not sit in here with your cheap personal insults and then stand and say to us that the slinging around of personal insults is somehow a pathway to fixing some of the issues which confront us.

SPEECH.PARA: The position is that yesterday we did have a resolution in this House. I think it is a shame that the opposition were not prepared to attempt to find common ground in a successful way so that we could have had one resolution. The reality is they did not. Why didn't they? Because sometimes it suits oppositions not to find common ground.

So yesterday we had a resolution. There were opportunities for people to speak. This motion to suspend standing orders today is therefore both repetitive to the debate that we had yesterday and pre-emptive of the debate that will ensue in due course when we have a proper, full response by the government to the report that has been handed down.

It is not as though these issues have not been the subject of a lot of public debate and comment in the national arena. Both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) spoke at the convention this week and, as I have referred to already, there has been a report handed down and a statement made by the responsible minister.

BREAK.PARA: In that statement he has said that the government does not support the concept of cash compensation. I was very interested in the questions which came from the opposition today on the question of compensation. I must say that I was under the impression that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) had ruled out cash compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true. You lie.

—I do not lie. I said I was under that impression. So I think it will be interesting for the opposition to have an opportunity to spell out exactly what their policy position is. The government has spelled out its position, and we await some definition of the opposition's position in response.

BREAK.PARA: So we treat this motion on the basis that we had a resolution yesterday and opportunities for various parties to speak. The report was tabled earlier this week. The responsible minister has made a preliminary response on behalf of the government to accompany the tabling of that report. But so as to treat the report properly and comprehensively, the government now will, in a measured way, continue the process of consultations with the interested parties so that we are in a position to provide the comprehensive response that this important report deserves.
On that basis, we do not accept that today is an appropriate occasion to have the more broad ranging debate which is proposed by the opposition. On that basis, we reject the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the House clearly understand the extent of the responsibility that has been abdicated by the government here today. Let the House clearly understand the failure of leadership on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) today: first, to get to his feet and, second, to lead his side to an understanding and acceptance of what is involved in this particular motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is not being asked by this motion to respond in detail today to this report. What the government is being asked to do by this motion is acknowledge the immense trauma inflicted upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by the separation policy. What the government is being asked to do with this motion today is to join us in affirming our commitment to a just and proper settlement of the grievances of the people affected by those policies.

What this motion asks the House to do today—and this is all it is asking the government to do—is to agree to appropriate processes to provide compensation and restitution, including assistance for the reunification of families. What this motion is asking the House to do and the government to do today is not, again, respond in detail but to establish appropriate education programs to enhance community awareness.

But what, above all else, this motion is asking the House to accede to, the government to accede to and, above all else, the Prime Minister to accede to—because he has abdicated and failed every exercise of his responsibility to date on this—is to unreservedly apologise—apologise—to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for these appalling separation policies. That is the issue before the House. That is the issue about which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) spoke so movingly a few moments ago.

Was that emotion reflected in any way in anything we have heard, or anything we have seen, or anything that we have experienced from that side of the House? We heard nothing from the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, sitting in the chamber, could not bring himself even to get to his feet and begin to respond to the sorts of points that were being made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: That the motion (Mr Beazley's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
