PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Anderson, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill represents the culmination of a process aimed at providing the Australian wool industry with a clear direction for the future. It is the final stage in preparing the industry to stand on its own feet, unencumbered by unnecessary government regulation and direction. It heralds the end of an era in Australian wool, an era that has been marked by significant debate and controversy.

Last year, this parliament passed a bill providing for the final stage in the disposal of the wool stockpile which was created during the last years of the reserve price scheme. The bill I now present establishes the wind‐up procedures for Wool International, through liquidation, and the distribution of equity to wool tax payers in Wool International.

Above all, this bill represents the success of the consultation process established in the early months of the life of this government which has had the ultimate aim of developing, with industry, a clear future direction for Australian wool, including finalisation of the sale of the wool stockpile, retirement of the associated debt and deregulation of the industry. Furthermore, the government will provide for the distribution to wool tax payers of equity in Wool International, providing wool growers with much needed, and deserved, entitlements to profits from the sale of the wool stockpile and associated assets. The granting of entitlements to wool tax payers will also provide a more secure basis for those wool growers in most need to either sell, or borrow against, their entitlements.

A further, related, development in the wool industry has been the emergence of the proposed wool marketing joint venture, Global Wool. This proposal will only be developed, on a commercial basis, with the concurrence of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission and the government. I emphasise that the government has no direct role to play in Global Wool. If the venture proceeds, Wool International's only proposed involvement would be by way of establishing the vehicle for wool grower investment.

This bill provides a package of measures which will see wool growers given entitlements in Wool International. As well, it will see the development of a loan facility which will allow growers to better use their entitlements as security for loans; provide for the liquidation of Wool International; enable interim and final payments of Wool International assets to wool tax payers; and offer a mechanism to allow growers to invest their equity return in a growers' investment trust, which might participate in the proposed Global Wool wool marketing joint venture. It will also introduce the corresponding changes to the objects and functions of Wool Interna tional and reduce the size of the Wool International board.

The first and most fundamental of the amendments is that of giving wool tax payers entitlements in Wool International. When Wool International was established in 1993, it was intended to corporatise and then privatise the organisation by 1 July this year. Although the act never provided for this to happen, this government has made a commitment to provide growers who paid the debt component of the wool tax from 1 July 1993 to 30 June 1996, including voluntary contributions, with an entitlement to equity in Wool International.

All wool tax paid up to 30 June 1996, including voluntary contributions, is to be converted to units. Wool tax payers are to be issued a statement of unit holding on the basis of a unit for every dollar of wool tax paid. Depending on the net assets of Wool International, each unit would then have an implied value which can be used as a basis for trading units.

This will give wool growers not only a right to the equity of Wool International, which has been an intention of the act since 1993, but the ability to trade their units. Similarly, wool tax payers will be able to offer their entitlements in Wool International as additional security when taking out a loan with a financial institution. Wool International will maintain the wool tax register to record changes in ownership in future equity and, in the case of a loan over the units, the register will record the financial institution's interest in the units.

Wool International will issue wool tax payers with a consolidated wool tax record in early June this year. Wool tax payers will be required to respond as to the completeness and correctness of this wool tax record as soon as possible. I cannot overemphasise to wool tax payers—I must stress this—the importance of a prompt response to ensure they gain their correct entitlement to Wool International equity. When finalised, this register will be the basis for entitlements and equity distributions.

Further, the legislation will allow Wool International to arrange, through a public tender process, a loan facility with a financial institution for the benefit of wool growers who hold entitlement to equity in Wool International. It is expected that this arrangement will produce more advantageous terms than would otherwise be available to borrowers negotiating individually. In performing this function, Wool International will be required to complete the tender process by 31 December 1997.

Having provided wool tax payers with rights in Wool International, the scene is set to enable the liquidation of Wool International and, in the meantime, to make interim cash payments to wool tax payers of Wool International equity.

The liquidation of Wool International will take place by removing reference to the privatisation of Wool International currently set out in section 3(3) and parts 10 to 12 of the act. Further, it is necessary to provide in the act for the final wind‐up arrangements of Wool International. These include the provision for leftover funds, treatment of small holdings, the final annual report and ensure provision for the wind‐up costs of Wool International. It will also provide for a scheme for the distribution of entitlements to the beneficiaries of deceased wool tax payers and insolvent businesses.

Interim and final payments to wool tax payers of equity in Wool International is another major aspect of these amendments. Wool tax payers will receive their interim payment as a cash entitlement. The payout to wool tax payers of funds held under section 51 will not delay the retirement of the debt associated with the stockpile.

The act will provide for wool tax payers to have the option to invest their initial payment, from the first Wool International payout, in a growers investment vehicle—which may subsequently invest in a wool logistics and merchanting venture, commonly referred to as `global wool'. But the act will not involve Wool International other than to facilitate investment in the proposed growers' trust by those growers who elect to do so.

The act will require Wool International to receive my approval to establish the growers' investment trust. Wool International will be allowed to support preliminary steps in the establishment of the proposed trust, and will also be able to undertake, in a limited way, feasibility studies and related activities for possible investment targets for the trust, including the global wool joint venture proposal. As I have indicated previously, global wool will not proceed without clearance by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

A final distribution will take place after the stockpile has been sold, and will signal the liquidation of Wool International. It is intended that the stockpile funds after sale and disposal of the stockpile will be the last of the Wool International assets available to wool tax payers.

These amendments clearly signal the government's withdrawal from the wool market. Wool International will also be required to reduce its activities to the core functions of disposing of the stockpile and retiring the associated debt. This will result in the phasing out of the subsidiary functions of Wool International and the corresponding reduction in the size of the board.

The provision of services to the Australian wool industry, the development of a viable international wool futures market and the development of mechanisms for the sale of wool to allow more efficient management of risk, will be phased out as functions of Wool International.

It is, however, necessary to provide for the winding up of several current Wool International functions not associated with selling the stockpile and retiring the associated debt. These are to ensure that Wool International can continue the education program on forward marketing and a market reporting service on a commercial basis. It would be disadvantageous to the industry to remove these functions at this stage and under the legislation these functions will cease by 30 June 1998.

Provision has been made to give Wool International the role of establishing the growers trust an investment vehicle as I mentioned previously. An end date of 30 June 1998 has been included to ensure Wool International's function in this area is short term and on the basis of a simple facilitation of investment by wool tax payers.

Under the legislation, Wool International will be able to spend up to $1 million on the establishment of the investment vehicle and in contributions to the development of the global wool proposal.With the functions reduced to only core activities, it is appropriate for the board to be reduced in size. In keeping with the phasing out of subsidiary functions, this is to occur gradually, with the board being reduced from its present number of 11 to five by 1 January 1998 as the workload associated with liquidating the organisation declines. I would take this opportunity to thank the retiring board members for their valuable contributions during their service on the board. The composition of the new board will be announced in due course.

As I stated at the outset, these amendments signal the beginning of the final stage of government's involvement in the wool industry. It will of course still collect wool tax on behalf of the industry, contribute to R&D and continue negotiations with customers on trade access issues. From this point forward the industry will have a clear view of the future and can plan a new, prosperous and independent environment. I commend the bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Latham) adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: COMMONWEALTH VEHICLES (REGISTRATION AND EXEMPTION FROM TAXATION) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Fahey, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This legislation is one of two bills arising from issues associated with the sale of DASfleet. The other companion bill is the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill. The government announced in 1996 its intention to either sell its vehicle fleet business, DASfleet, or refinance the vehicles which DASfleet operates. The government decided to approach the market for bids based on both sale and refinancing to ensure the best possible outcome for the Commonwealth.

This government is committed to public sector reform and has sought to identify functions where direct Commonwealth involvement can no longer be justified. In the case of DASfleet and the other Department of Administrative Services business units currently being offered for sale, the government has identified areas which do, or could, compete directly with private sector suppliers. It has decided to divest itself of these functions, while at the same time ensuring a fair return to the taxpayer for these quality businesses.

The operation of the Commonwealth motor vehicle fleet has historically been undertaken internally and the origins of DASfleet can be traced to the Department of Defence in the early 1920s. At that time, the options available to the Commonwealth for the provision of motor vehicles were limited. Today, however, the provision of motor vehicles and fleet management services is undertaken by a dynamic and competitive industry and the case for maintaining a Commonwealth owned vehicle fleet is no longer compelling.

The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill and the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill have been prepared in the context of the government's decision to sell or refinance Dasfleet. The ongoing measures in these bills will, however, apply to vehicles leased to the Commonwealth by any company, not just the purchaser of Dasfleet. In addition, because Dasfleet currently provides only half of the vehicles in the Commonwealth's fleet, the ongoing provisions in the bills will extend to any future sale and lease‐back of Commonwealth vehicles.

The two pieces of proposed legislation are intended to ensure that registration, taxation and third party insurance arrangements which currently apply to vehicles used by the Commonwealth can continue once those vehicles are privately owned and leased to the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill will establish a Commonwealth register of motor vehicles in which vehicles owned by or leased to the Commonwealth may be registered rather than being registered under state or territory law.

The use of Commonwealth number plates allows ease of recognition of Commonwealth government vehicles and has proven to be an effective mechanism for the regulation of their usage. This bill will allow for the continued use of Z and other Commonwealth number plates on vehicles once they are no longer owned by the Commonwealth but are leased for a period of at least three months to the Commonwealth for its use.

The bill also allows for the making of regulations which will provide for details of how the motor vehicle register will be kept and other matters such as how registration plates and labels should be displayed. Further, I intend that public trading enterprises will be exempt under regulations from the coverage of this bill and its companion bill. This will ensure that the proposed legislation does not impact on the competitive position of Commonwealth business enterprises which operate in the market place.

In addition to establishing the motor vehicle register, the bill contains measures to exempt the transfer of assets, as well as the ongoing provision of vehicles to the Commonwealth, from state and territory taxes.

Under the Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill, the transfer of Dasfleet assets, including the motor vehicle fleet, will be exempt from state and territory imposts. This will allow all Australians to benefit from the full proceeds of sale, rather than a proportion of those proceeds being distributed to those states and territories in which the transfer of assets happens to take place.

The Commonwealth currently operates several thousand vehicles which it registers under state and territory law, most notably vehicles which are provided under the senior executive vehicle scheme. While the Commonwealth pays registration fees, by virtue of its constitutional exemption from state and territory taxes, it does not currently pay stamp duty on the registration of such vehicles. The Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill will maintain this position by extending the exemption to the private owner of vehicles where those vehicles are leased to the Commonwealth for at least three months.

In addition, where a vehicle is leased to the Commonwealth for a continuous period of three months, these leases will be exempt from state and territory taxes levied on leasing arrangements. The three‐month period is intended to capture leases which could be considered to be long‐term leases and exclude the short‐term rental of vehicles for which the taxation exemption would be overly complex to administer.

The measures in the bill now before the House are not intended to change the Commonwealth's position with respect to the states and territories. They are merely intended to ensure that the Commonwealth is in the same position with respect to state and territory law and third party liability coverage after the sale of its vehicle fleet as it was before the sale. This bill together with its companion bill will ensure a minimum of disruption to the supply of vehicles to the Commonwealth once these vehicles are privately owned.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Latham) adjourned.

This legislation is one of two bills arising from issues associated with the sale of DASfleet. The other companion bill is the Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill.

The Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill will ensure that the provisions of the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act 1959 will continue to apply once vehicles used by the Commonwealth are not actually owned by the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The various provisions of the bill should be seen in the context of the government's ongoing commitment to quality, diversity, equity and innovative change in the higher education sector. It strengthens the framework initiated by this government last year on which the sector can build for the future.

The bill provides supplementation for price movements covering items such as superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals, special capital projects, grants to open learning organisations and the total limit for certain grants. The total increase in 1998 will be $9,658,000.

The bill also provides $26 million over the next four years to fund the rationalisation and restructuring program as announced in the budget. This program complements the existing provision that allows institutions to receive an advance of operating grant to assist with the cashflow implications of restructuring. The program will assist institutions with restructuring and rationalisation activities that will lead to permanent benefits and which are beyond the funding capacity of the institution involved.

The funds will be used to support a variety of proposals including rationalisation of programs, the joint development of infrastructure, including electronic infrastructure, and the collaborative use of shared activities and resources with other institutions. Assistance provided under the program is anticipated to be of particular benefit to regional institutions.

Through this bill, the government is furthering equitable access to higher education by introducing a 25 per cent discount for partial up‐front higher education contribution scheme payments of $500 or more. This will benefit students who have been unable to access the previous 25 per cent discount available only to those students who were able to pay their full HECS contribution up‐front.

The measure also redresses the existing inequity between an arts student receiving a 25 per cent discount on an up‐front payment of their full HECS contribution of $3,300 and a law student who might wish to pay the same amount but would not be eligible for any discount unless they could pay their full up‐front HECS charge.

This measure provides an incentive for students to partially pay their HECS contribu tion up‐front and will be of real benefit to HECS liable students. The arrangements build on and strengthen the essential features of HECS to continue to ensure that no qualified student is prevented from entering higher education because of an inability to pay at the time of enrolment.

The bill also provides for streamlining of the application arrangements for remission of student debts incurred under HECS and the open learning deferred payment scheme, OLDPS. This measure will make the remission arrangements simpler and more accessible to students by replacing the complex two‐tiered application process with a more generous set 12‐month time frame for all remission applicants.

As a result of this measure, most students will actually have longer to seek remission of their debt. Students will no longer have to apply within a set three‐month period which has been an artificial barrier for students seeking to have their debt remitted. The new arrangements make the application process more transparent and accessible to students and are less cumbersome to administer.

At the same time, this government has moved quickly to address concerns expressed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal about the legal limitations of the guidelines that have applied to the remission of debts. The bill will now give legislative force to the administrative guidelines on remission of debts by providing for them to be a disallowable instrument.

This bill reflects the government's commitment to a relevant, high quality education system which is striving for excellence and innovation in teaching and research. I commend the bill to the House and I present one signed copy of the explanatory memorandum.
