SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was interrupted prior to question time, I was dealing with the $250 million that had been allocated to telecommunications support for regional Australia, and I had noted that this was very important to that particular area of Australia. As a member of the National Party, I believe that to be absolutely imperative if some of the decline we are seeing in regional and rural Australia is to be reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that, with the policies being adopted by the private and public sectors at the present time, there has been a decline in regional jobs, a decline in regional growth and that many pressures are being placed on small local communities. If they do have the ability to compete with cities with the fibre- optic cable, then I think there is a tremendous opportunity for decentralisation of services.

`Decentralisation' is a word that has been bandied around by many governments for many years, and it is very difficult to achieve if you do not have a market or a raw material—a resource. We do have many resources in Australia. However, I believe that those particular areas in many instances are exploited. Also, we do get as much as possible the value adding that can be found in the natural resources of the country.

But in this particular instance where there is an argument being put forward that, in fact, services can be centralised with the technology we have today, I believe that it is a very sound argument that those services can be delivered from regional centres. In fact, with many of the information services, the 1800 lines and even computer services, if these telecommunications are available and can support such a system, then the regional centres, such as the great regional centres of Australia—and particularly that of my north coast area—can deliver such services. History has proven that the type of work force you can get in regional Australia is very dedicated and very loyal and, of course, there is a very good working environment. That all adds to the service that can be provided.

So I think the government is certainly moving in the right direction in this area, and obviously we should be taking advantage of it in regional and rural Australia to see that the pressure is put on government and also the private sector to move some of these services from Sydney and Melbourne. When we consider that half the population of Australia resides in Sydney and Melbourne, then there is plenty of opportunity to have some of those services decentralised and relocated to regional Australia.

Also within the budget I note that there is $48 million for regional forest agreements. This, of course, has been an ongoing process now for a number of years. But in New South Wales it has not yet been resolved, and I have great concern about some of the processes that are being put in place in that state. I come from an area that is, and has been for a number of years, very dependent upon the forest industries, and they have been very well managed in that area. But we do see a Labor state government, the Carr government, in New South Wales taking the opportunity with these regional assessments to put in place their agenda of more national parks, more wilderness areas, without any socioeconomic studies as to what effect that might have on small country centres.

Part of the national forest strategy, the national forest policy, when being implemented, was to look very closely at the socioeconomic effects. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has made it very clear that he is committed to that. With some of the proposals that are being put forward being the protection of 15 per cent of forest areas pre-1770, I believe that that type of area must be looked at very closely. There is an agenda in New South Wales being driven by that state's Minister for the Environment, Pam Allen, and it has no regard for those country areas and it has no regard for the effects some of these policies will have upon those rural communities. I think that has to be looked at very, very closely.

I also note that there is a continuation of the regional minerals program, which I happily say I was involved with when I was the minister for minerals in New South Wales. That program is looking very closely at areas like Broken Hill, which is one of the great mining centres of the world, let alone Australia. But the resource is declining in that area , and there is a grave concern for the city of Broken Hill as to whether it can be sustained into the future.

When you take into consideration that the lode at Broken Hill is no more than three kilometres long and about 230 to 240 metres wide at its widest, you can easily see that such a lode—given that it might be underground and not on the surface, such as the lode at Broken Hill—could be easily overlooked. The purpose of these aerial surveys is to locate areas where there might be more mineralisation, hopefully close to an area such as Broken Hill so that that city can be sustained into the future. I commend the continuation of that operation.

BREAK.PARA: It is impossible in the 20 minutes available to me to go through all of the issues in the budget. I note there has been an increase of $75 million for AQIS. In recent times we have seen the necessity for such a body to oversee and protect the industries that we have in Australia. With fire blight and the debates about the chicken meat industry, the pork industry and the salmon industry—especially under the World Trade Organisation and the agreement—we can see that an organisation such as AQIS has to be efficient and vigilant to ensure that our great industries are protected.

Other speakers have talked about the work for the dole scheme. This scheme is important in my area, where we have 16 per cent unemployment and 30 per cent youth unemployment—an area that we have to address very clearly. Some $20 million is provided for depressed areas. As I have already said, this clearly outlines that my area is a very depressed one.

Austudy is another area of some concern. The minister has addressed some of these concerns in the budget to try to alleviate some of those problems. In the little time that I have available, if I have any, I would like to talk about the money provided for credit care—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think that the honourable member's time—
—I think I've got plenty of credit; there is no‐one else here.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired—he dobbed himself in.

—This is the second coalition government budget. It is structurally rather different from the one they brought down last year. Last year's budget was characterised by some fairly draconian spending cuts in a variety of areas. The underlying rationale for those cuts was that the government allegedly faced some sort of fiscal crisis when it came to office, characterised by a large black hole in the budget.

BREAK.PARA: The reality is that, if you compare Australia to other developed countries, our stock of public debt as a proportion of GDP is very much at the low end of the range. Our deficit as a proportion of GDP is likewise very much at the low end of the range. We are in considerably better shape than most of the countries affected by the Maastricht Treaty in Europe. In general, the claim that there was some sort of crisis that required drastic measures to resolve was clearly untrue. A number of decisions taken in last year's budget have had very adverse effects on a great many people and significant adverse effects on Australia's long-term prospects—particularly such things as the cuts to education and training.

If you aggregate the cuts to higher education, which, contrary to the claims of Senator Vanstone, were very much more than a nick, the cuts to vocational education, which, particularly when combined with decisions taken in this year's budget, exceed the extra money that the government provided for aspects of its new apprenticeship and traineeship scheme, the very substantial cuts to labour market programs which the government is seeking to replace with mickey mouse schemes like work for the dole and the green corps, then there are some major adverse impacts on this country, the effect of which will come to bear as the years go by.

I think many of those decisions will produce some tragic consequences and will severely undermine much of the good work that was achieved by the former government. The rationale for all this was the alleged need to engage in fiscal consolidation in order to increase national savings. The Labor Party have never disputed the need for a fiscal consolidation program. There was an argument about whether it needed to be proceeded with at the rate that the present government believes is appropriate. The long-term need to achieve a better balance between savings and investment in this country is not something that we disputed. Indeed, the former government put in place long-term structural measures designed to improve national savings. The most important of those was the succession of initiatives in the superannuation area.

If you look at the various modelling exercises that were undertaken by the previous government, there is no doubt that over a period of decades those measures would have significantly increased national savings. The outcome of those modelling activities was very clear on that point. Contrary to what the present government claims, these were effective measures to raise national savings through the extension of superannuation.

As part of an overall long-term strategy to ensure that future governments of this country are in a viable fiscal situation which will enable them to sustain an adequate social safety net and cover all the other various functions of government that governments ought to carry out, we put in place a good framework. For example, if you look at retirement incomes, in the year before last the World Bank brought out a major report on approaches for getting a retirement income structure in place that was capable of dealing with the phenomenon of ageing populations.

The kind of model that we had established was pretty close to what they regarded as the desirable model—that is, one that has the inherent flexibility and capacity to sustain decent retirement incomes over time. It was based on a combination of provisions through private savings and a targeted safety net pension arrangement, and was increasingly supplemented by contributory superannuation. That three‐tiered retirement income provision was a pretty good way to go. We believe this approach was the right one to get Australia's fiscal circumstances into proper shape for the long term.

This year's budget of course did not have anything like the same fiscal impact as last year's budget. When you take into account the major savings measure in the budget—that is, the removal of the superannuation co-contribution—and the fact that all that it did was increase the level of public saving at the cost of private dis‐saving and you factor that into the way you look at the impact of the budget, then its effect on savings is not only negligible but actually adverse when you take into account the tax rebate that was brought in in conjunction with the abolition of the superannuation co-contribution.

I think it is important to stress that fiscal consolidation is not an end in itself. The aim of fiscal consolidation is to raise national savings, and any measure that simply substitutes extra public saving for an equivalent amount of private dis‐saving really does not contribute to the goal of achieving a better savings investment balance for the country in the long term.

When we are talking about investment, of course it is important to bear in mind that investment is more than private business investment; it should include a whole raft of public activities, whether it be in education and training, environmental protection, physical infrastructure and so forth.

The budget does nothing to increase national savings. In fact, the tax savings rebate reduces national savings. It costs more than $2 billion in a full year and there is little reason to believe that much of this is going to be saved. If the average household savings rate at the moment of 4½ per cent continues to apply, less than $100 million of this will be saved, so that private saving will go up by less than $100 million but public saving will fall by over $2 billion, which is a net loss of national savings of $1.95 billion as a result of that.

The suggestion that the rebate will bring forth an increase in private savings exceeding this cost is absurd. The rebate is not targeted to people who are increasing savings. You can be running down your savings and still receive the rebate. There is no incentive for further savings by those already eligible for the maximum benefit of the rebate, and the rationale the government puts forward does not take account of the fact that there are a number of motives for savings.

In traditional Keynesian analysis, three motives are identified as to why people save. You have precautionary savings, savings for a rainy day. And you have people saving with some target in mind—for example, to buy a house. Likewise, the rebate makes no difference to that sort of motive. In fact, it could reduce private savings by helping people reach their target earlier but not much earlier.

For example, a young couple saving $5,000 a year for three years to achieve a $15,000 house deposit would receive under this rebate $19 in the first year, $56 in the second year and $94 in the third year—a total of $169 in all. The rebate would help them achieve their savings target all of 12 days earlier. But there is no reason to suppose that this sort of measure will increase the saving being undertaken for that motive.

It is only for people who engage in what is referred to in Keynesian terms as saving for speculative purposes that the rebate will be an incentive. Again, this is likely to be a relatively small proportion of total household savings. And it is not much of an incentive either—equivalent to 0.75 percentage points on a deposit paying five per cent interest. So if this was going to make much difference to savings behaviour, then presumably you would expect that we would have had very substantial increases in savings at times of high interest rates. Of course, we did not.

The rebate is even worse when you set it alongside Labor's superannuation contribution, which it in effect replaces. Every cent of co‐contribution would have gone into savings and, by association with increased employee superannuation contributions, would have induced a further substantial increase in private savings. So the impact of Labor's measure was unambiguously beneficial for savings.

In 1999‐2000, for example, Labor would have spent $2.4 billion in a manner that induced an increase in national savings. The coalition, in contrast, will spend $1.4 billion and reduce national savings by nearly that amount.

The net economic impact of the budget, once this anti-savings feature of the savings tax rebate is recognised, is a contractionary effect of $352 million in 1997‐98 and $863 million in 1998‐99 and an expansionary effect of $403 million in 1999‐2000. These numbers are derived from the budget papers, pages 1 to 5, and from pages 11 and 162 of Budget Paper No. 2. So it is not a set of numbers that justifies all the rhetoric of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on the subject of savings.

Even this includes some measures that increase savings from the budget at the cost of other savings, with no net impact on national savings. For example, we have $800 million in property sales. As real and not financial assets, these remain classified as part of the so‐called underlying deficit. Yet the same argument applies to these asset sales as to others: the money to purchase the asset comes out of private savings, so for every dollar increase in public savings there is a dollar decrease in private savings—national savings are unaffected.

The public debt interest effect of the $3 billion Telstra payment this financial year is another example. At current bond rates this represents a PDI saving of over $200 million a year, but savings by the public trading enterprise sector will be reduced by this amount or more through the increased interest bill on Telstra. The net effect on national savings will be at best zero, at worst negative. That is to say nothing of the reduction in private savings resulting from the transfer of some pharmaceutical expenditure from the Commonwealth to individuals, or of the anti‐saving effect of some of the government's superannuation measures. The bottom line is that the budget that pretends to be pro‐saving is in fact anti‐saving.

The other problem with the rebate is its regressivity. The government has tried to argue that the measure is not regressive because it is capped and it is a rebate rather than a deduction. That is to say it could have been worse—it is not a progressive measure, it is just a regressive one that is not as regressive as it potentially could be.

The other argument of the government is that low income earners, such as self‐funded retirees, will benefit. That is, it is regressive in life cycle terms; only people who have had the capacity in the past to build up savings will benefit, and that is demonstrated by the fact that not one cent of the rebate will go to maximum rate pensioners.

Obviously, there is a correlation between the capacity to save and income, particularly over the course of an individual's life. Equally obviously, the rebate reinforces this distributive pattern; to suggest otherwise is disingenuous, and to defend it on the basis that it could have been worse is absurd.

The final issue relates to the morality of applying a higher rate of tax to earned income than to unearned income. The opposition has indicated that it will seek to inject some equity back into the budget, particularly through income testing the savings tax rebate. This means that the opposition is prepared to do some of the work to increase national savings which the government has shirked in this budget.

In the time remaining to me, I would like to speak about a number of specific measures. My parliamentary colleagues have spoken about the effect on different groups of people of many of the measures that have been talked about in this budget. I would like to mention briefly a couple of matters that relate to social security. Having been Minister for Social Security for three years, it is an area that I have some familiarity with. In particular, there are some specific matters which I would like to raise in relation to the measures which affect retirees.

Firstly, the government claims that it has legislated and made provision in this budget to maintain pensions at 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings. The government says that it has met its pre‐election commitment in this regard. This was announced last year, of course, and funding was included in the contingency reserve in last year's budget legislation, which was introduced on 19 March. The government is trying to pretend, in the context of this budget, that it has announced a new initiative, but in fact it is in effect the third reannouncement of the measure.

What the government neglects to mention is that this adjustment is retrospective. That is, when pensions are adjusted each March and September, they will be aligned with 25 per cent of the latest available estimate of average weekly earnings. These estimates will be months old. With average earnings growing by 3½ per cent to four per cent a year, this means that at no time will the pension actually be at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. At each indexation point, the pension will be about 24.6 per cent of average weekly earnings, declining over the subsequent six months as average earnings rise.

In contrast, Labor kept the pension above 25 per cent of average earnings at all times. It was at 25.3 per cent at the time that Labor left office. This is a significant difference. The government, in saying that it has adhered to its pre‐election promise to maintain pensions at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, has adopted the most parsimonious interpretation possible of that commitment.

When we were in government, we took the view that there were basically two ways you could interpret that commitment. One was that the pension would be above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings at all points in time over the course of the year. The other was that it could be interpreted as meaning that the pension would be above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings on average over the course of the year.

The fact is that we, in practice, managed, from April 1990 onwards, to adhere to the more generous interpretation of that commitment. But the government is claiming to do no more than keep pensions at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings at two points in time during the course of each year—at the indexation points of March and September. And, for the reason that I have outlined, it does not even do that because the wage figures that are being used for calculating the benchmark are lagged.

So what the government has got by way of adhering to this commitment to keep the pension at or above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings—the mechanism they have put in place—guarantees that the pension will never reach 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Even at the most favourable points—the two indexation points—it will be below 25 per cent. In between the indexation points, the position will deteriorate further. I believe that this is a very clear breach of faith by this government with retired people and pensioners.

The brief to the incoming government—which we received a copy of—when it came in in March last year provided costings to adhere to this commitment. It gave figures as to the cost of the measures, which are roughly, even on the less generous interpretation, double the costings in this budget. Even when you take into account parameter changes and so forth, what that indicates is that the government is massively underperforming on this key commitment to Australian pensioners.

The other thing I would like to mention is the so‐called pension bonus plan which the government seeks to present as a win‐win situation; something which benefits some pensioners on the one hand, but which, on the other hand, also produces budget savings estimated at $42 million a year when it comes fully into effect. The problem is that it takes no account of the longer term impact on the budget of this measure.

When we were in government I, as minister, asked the department to prepare a brief on precisely this sort of proposition. If there was something that would produce budgetary savings and did not seem to hurt anybody—well, why wouldn't you take it? The reason we did not take it is that it built a significant structural hole into the social security budget in the long term. The reason for that is quite straightforward: once people start to become eligible for a lump sum, a proportion of the people who would benefit from that are people who would have remained in the work force beyond the pensionable age anyway, even without that sort of incentive. So there is a class of windfall gainers and these, by and large, will tend to be the better off amongst the pensioners. It is not a savings measure; it builds in a significant long‐term structural hole.
These are just a couple of the aspects of the dishonesty in the way some of the measures in this budget have been presented. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Somlyay, Alex, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson), who sits at the table, and I were elected in 1990, so this makes it the eighth budget that he and I have sat through. I made my maiden speech in the debate on the appropriation bills later in 1990.
—And it was a very good speech too.

—It was an excellent speech. After eight budgets I ask the question: how do the people of Australia rate the second Costello budget? The first six budgets in my time were delivered by four different Treasurers—Keating, Kerin, Dawkins and Willis. I was elected to parliament just past the halfway mark of Labor's 13‐year term of office. Treasurer Keating had delivered seven budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Hawke and Keating governments, budget speeches achieved an art form of doublespeak and half‐smart cliches. Treasurer Keating year after year held out branches of hope and promise to all Australians only to then let the nation down year after year. They let everybody down—the rich and poor, the worker and the employer, the needy and the disadvantaged, the elderly, the aged and the young, the primary producer and the small businessman. They let Australia down budget after budget. I will put that into context. Let me take you back to Labor's first Keating budget in 1983. Paul Keating said in his budget speech:
Obviously the economic policy of the previous (Fraser) Government have failed to come to terms with Australia's deep‐seated problems.
Then came the promise of hope when he went on to say:
1983‐84 holds promise of a considerable improvement in economic performance.
That year Australia's foreign debt was $23 billion. In his 1984 budget speech, Paul Keating said:

I am proud to tell the Australian people that we now have a strong economic growth, many more jobs, a substantial fall in inflation and declining interest rates. The Government's policies are on track.
That year foreign debt was $27.9 billion. In his 1985 budget speech, Keating stated:

I have outlined the Government's strategy for the new financial year. It's a strategy that builds on our very significant successes and puts further behind us the despair and economic failure of the former government.
How prophetic. By then Labor had discovered that they had a bankcard because our foreign debt had in two years ballooned out to $51.2 billion. In the 1986 budget speech the Treasurer said:

BREAK.PARA: The 1986‐87 which I have presented tonight brings the changes on a more robust, aggressive Australian economy.

In that year foreign debt was $75 million. That was the same year that Treasurer Keating gave his infamous banana republic warning. In 1987, Keating said in his budget speech—and how things change in the course of a year:
Notwithstanding the enormity of trade difficulties we had faced—
he should have said `we have caused'—
our economic strategy was bearing fruit.
In that year foreign debt was at $83 billion. In 1988 he said:
The nation is successfully emerging from its most severe economic crisis in a generation—this is the one which brings home the bacon. Our foreign debt burden has already stabilised and begun to fall.
In that year foreign debt was $93 billion. In the 1989 budget speech, the Treasurer said:
As a result of government's economic policies Australia will emerge from the recent high level of spending without a recession and with its economic and social structure improving.

In that year foreign debt passed $100 million. That was the legacy of Labor's first seven budgets from 1983. Looking at these budget quotes in the context of performance over time, they reveal a conspiracy of lies, deceit and a perpetration of the cruellest hoax on the people of Australia ever in our short 200‐year history. They reveal the machinations of a government that governed not for the common good of all Australians but for the good of a group they called the `true believers', the union affiliates, who were growing wealthy and fat on the blood of small business and families from middle Australia. I sat in this House when Paul Keating told Australians in his in 1990 budget speech:

This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up—delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.

Foreign debt that year was $124 million. By 1992, foreign debt was $145 billion. In nine short years it blew out from $23 billion. Despite Treasurer Keating saying that the budget was delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession, we were in fact in the worst recession since the Great Depression—the worst one in 60 years. Even given that background, Labor won the 1993 election by more lies and deceit.

We were accused of failing to sell the GST. I defy a car salesman to sell a Holden while there is someone outside the car yard holding up a placard advertising, `Don't buy this car—it's a lemon.' That is what happened. It was not a debate. That is what Keating did to the GST, a tax which in 1985 he believed in with a passion. Labor never governed for Australia; they governed to stay in power. They killed manufacturing, they killed off small business and they killed off our competitiveness by dropping tariff protection without reform and without proper deregulating the labour market. They sold off our assets—the family silver.

Housing mortgage rates reached 17 per cent and were finally capped at 17 per cent. They had won the 1993 election depriving the people of the reforms Australia needed so badly. The people gave Labor another three years to rack up further debt and economic fraud. It is against this background that we were elected in 1996 in the biggest swing against Labor since the people so unceremoniously dumped the Whitlam government in 1975. They say the more things change the more they stay the same. There has never been a Labor government that has not ultimately been a financial disaster.

Year after year Paul Keating's assurances proved wrong. For 13 years the electorate at large became more and more cynical as Paul Keating destroyed any credibility and respect that politicians and the parliament may have had. The ultimate act of treachery was to knowingly leave this country with a $10 billion deficit when Keating and the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) pledged that the budget at the time was in surplus.

It is important to remind the Australian people of this era of Labor disaster and deception. People in Australia are sick of political parties which promise the earth but on election discover the cupboard is bare. Therefore, election promises made which require expenditure suddenly become undeliverable. Such actions add to the cynicism of the electorate.

This government decided to introduce honesty and integrity back into the budget process and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) delivered this by introducing the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill. Never again will a government be able to deceive the people as Keating and Beazley did before the 1996 election.

The growing electoral support for Independents and other new political movements is a straight‐out reaction against the sad depths of indecency that political processes have degenerated to, particularly during the Hawke-Keating 13‐year era. Political parties must hear this cry of dissatisfaction and despair. The people of Australia need help. Members of the parliament should reflect their needs, aspirations and vision. We must reform parliamentary behaviour.

I urge the new members in this House to mingle anonymously after question time with people who fill these galleries. When you do, listen to their disgust at the behaviour in this chamber. They leave here in the belief that we are arrogant, disrespectful morons. They want to feel that the people who represent them in this chamber are one of them. They want us to spend our time debating the problems of this nation. They should leave the public galleries with a good feeling—a feeling that they have been somewhere very special, listening to people who have been entrusted with the important task of leading the nation and positioning Australia in its rightful place in the rest of the world.

The budget process upon election was not easy. The people were told that the budget was in surplus. We had a $10 billion deficit. This government takes a long-term budgeting view. The previous government took a year by year view, lurching from crisis year to crisis year—each year was a crisis year—selling the family silver and our great national icons and squandering the proceeds instead of paying off debt.

In stark contrast, this year the budget pays off $5.3 billion worth of debt. A $10 billion deficit converts to a $1.6 billion surplus in the space of three years. The debt to GDP ratio of 20 per cent under Labor—one of the highest among the OECD countries—will fall to 10 per cent, one of the lowest in the OECD. Make no mistake and let there be no doubt that our low interest rates are a direct consequence of delivering a responsible budget, paying off government debt and moving the government out of the borrowing market. As I said, this budget process of fiscal consolidation is not easy. Savings had to be made and the burden of expenditure cuts had to be distributed broadly and fairly. Only Defence was quarantined from budget cuts.

The reaction to the 1996 budget, which set the foundation for the achievements of the 1997 budget, was very positive. People knew it was time to pay off the bankcard after Labor's mad spending spree. I said previously that the budget process was tough, but it was right. Having built the foundation in 1996, the 1997 budget starts to deliver what we were elected to do: get the country out of the red and get back on our feet.

Again I say to new members: judge the public acceptance of the budget by the number of calls you receive in your electorate offices. In the week after the budget, I received three calls indicating general approval and acceptance of the budget. In my eight years in this place, I do not think I have had one call from a constituent to say that everything was fine and that they had no problems. So it is fair to claim a positive acceptance of the 1997 budget.

Rather than speak about individual measures in the budget, the importance to my electorate of Fairfax in regional Queensland is the positive impact for business and, therefore, employment. Government was a borrower; government is now a saver. Interest is the price of money. The government has left the money market as a major borrower, releasing funds for lending to others and, therefore, causing the price of money—interest rates—to fall. The official interest rates fell within 10 days of the budget as a direct consequence of the thrust of the budget.

Those families with mortgages, investors with mortgages, are the big winners under our two budgets. Our budget strategy has deliv ered home owners with a $100,000 mortgage a $292 saving since we came to office. On the ANZ rate offered the day before yesterday, you would be paying $834 a month less on a $100,000 mortgage than you did under Labor when interest rates were 17 per cent in 1989.

Members opposite say, `What about the renters? They get nothing.' This is really when mortgage interest rates are important. It can now be cheaper to buy a house than rent a house. On a $150,000 mortgage, the interest repayments should be approximately $10,500 or $202 per week. Rental for the equivalent home would range from $200 to $240 a week. So why rent when it is cheaper to buy?

It is the building industry which is the engine of growth in my electorate. When building activity is high, it is reflected in retailing and other small business. The budget lowers interest rates and that will reflect in new building activity.

Employees in retailing on casual rates lost hours when the building industry turned down. They did not lose their jobs, they lost hours. Many went from 35 hours or more a week to 15 or 16 hours a week. There are already some signs of recovery and an indication of an upward movement in hours being received by people in casual employment in retailing. That augers well for future job creation.

The electorate is not happy and many are disenchanted with the government, but they will not return to the Labor Party fold at any price. People want to know why Labor allowed imports to destroy our industries, why Labor allowed people to be sacked and retrenched while our traditional industries went offshore, why foreigners buy up Australian companies and properties when we cannot do the same overseas, why Labor let families and middle income Australians bear the major burden of the tax take, why Labor went soft on so many traditional family values and why Labor let so many of our great primary industries and the economic conditions of farming families deteriorate so badly. Most importantly, people want to know why we have not fixed all these things in our first year in office and why we allow ourselves to be dictated to by unrepresentative vocal minorities who used to dictate the agenda of the Labor Party.

Two indications last week by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) have warmed my heart and have given people hope. Firstly, tax reform is firmly back on the agenda. I am on the record in this place as saying tax reform is the single most needed and urgent thing we can do to take the burden off business and families, create exports and jobs and have a fairer and certain tax regime. Secondly, the government has warned the Senate that it will not tolerate the progress of our reforms being held up by minorities without a mandate. The people want these changes and they want them now.

The most important aspects of this budget are the macro-economic policy settings, not the individual measures looked at in isolation for whatever reason. The budget is pro-savings. It repays debt. It abandons the borrowing culture of Labor. It restores our economic integrity in the eyes of the financial world. It brings the budget to real surplus, not an artificial surplus brought about by the proceeds of asset sales used for current consumption. The budget entrenches a low interest culture underpinned by low inflation. I commend the budget to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Our ability as a nation to innovate, to generate new ideas, to spread those ideas throughout the productive sectors of our economy and then to bring those new ideas into effect is one of the single most important determinants of our likely future prosperity. Our standard of living, the quality of our lifestyle, our place in the world—all these are linked directly to productivity growth and to innovation through science and engineering.

SPEECH.PARA: It is estimated that over half of all real growth in the US economy over the last 40 years is based on technological innovation. Profits and wages both depend on the ability of the economy to deliver ever smarter and more sophisticated ways of doing old things and efficient and effective ways of doing new things. Research drives innovation, which drives investment in industry and commerce, which in turn creates jobs and disposable income for all Australians. This is a vital equation and dependency relationship which must be central to any debate about R&D policy.

Technological innovation does not usually come about in the way that Newton is alleged to have discovered the notion of gravity. In fact, it is much more along the lines of one per cent inspiration and 99 per cent perspiration. It is a combination of factors with people and organisations, such as firms and research laboratories, building on the work of others who have gone before them and acting in partnership with one another.

It is the role of the government to provide the framework to ensure that Australian industry, commerce and public sector research and development are encouraged and the results of it are defused throughout the economy as fast as possible. This has to be done in 1997 against a background of global change. To talk about the globalisation of the economy is to repeat something of a truism these days, but the reality of global competition, rising standards of education and skill formation in developing economies and the increasingly open market for goods and services around the world can be ignored only at our peril.

While the need for our technology and innovation policies to take account of the globally competitive environment in which we find ourselves is obvious, the consequences of that for domestic policy and politics cannot be overlooked if we are to have a consensus about policy in these areas. I believe that it is essential that a form of national consensus evolve around these issues if we are to have consistency and predictability about policy, a prerequisite for long‐term investment by the private sector given the fact that capital can find a home almost anywhere around the world these days.

The recent government decision to end syndication and reduce the taxation concession for research are dramatic reminders of the way in which policy settings can be changed overnight in a way which frightens off long‐term private sector investment, especially in the face of our near neighbours, who offer even more generous inducements to prospective new firms.

Technological change, innovation and the need for a clear policy framework are all part of the necessary interlocking building blocks for a successful economy in the 21st century. The public sector science agencies such as CSIRO, the universities and the private sector must all work together to deliver economic gains to Australia, but they will also deliver gains in areas like health, the environment and other human needs which our community also seeks.

It is worth looking at some of these human questions at the outset because they are fundamental to the development of a sustainable innovation culture. At the start of the Industrial Revolution the competition between man and machine was one of brute strength. It soon became clear that the steam engine was going to win out over human muscle and society accepted that after a certain degree of protest.

A few centuries later the contest has shifted to a more cerebral plane with man and computer fighting it out over the chessboard. The outcome of that contest is now clear even if Kasparov likes to put his own spin on the result. Human vanity must never be underestimated.

In the end we are left with human creativity, our will to win and grow and our sense of pride and achievement as the defining characteristics which separate us from the machines we build. After all, it is human ingenuity which has turned the sand into the silicon which beats at the heart of Deep Blue. It is that human spirit which Australia must also cherish if it is to be a major player in the innovation stakes. Science and engineering are the educational cornerstones of any technologically advanced society and the universities play a vital role in basic research and the diffusion of technology as their graduates move into industry.

Any research based economic strategy must make science and engineering careers more attractive both financially and culturally. The tendency of many young people to see scientists as eccentric nerds in white coats is one of the greatest threats to our economic future.

BREAK.PARA: The decision of government to place a premium on a science based university degree also sends the wrong signal, especially to the risk averse group of lower to middle income families who are considering future educational options for their kids. Unfortunately, education, particularly at the tertiary level, has taken a bit of a beating lately. The last two budgets have not been kind to many people, least of all the higher education sector. If you add together the cuts to operating grants of some $600 million and the abolition of discretionary funds, which is in excess of $200 million, you have upwards of $800 million cut from the higher education sector over the period of the forward estimates. This does not include the failure of the government to provide supplementation for academic salary increases, which will have a very significant effect on university operating budgets or the further one per cent efficiency dividend which was buried in last year's budget and which finally came to light during analysis of the current budget.

Estimates of the final impact of these cuts in funding on our universities range from 10 to 15 per cent depending on the institution. That is something of a nick made with a machete. This will hit the sciences much harder than the humanities. Science costs money to do and to teach. Cash strapped university administrators will no doubt find it easier to make ends meet by cutting the science and engineering based courses first.

One US study has concluded that investments in academic research return in excess of 25 per cent on an annual basis, exceeding even the stock market in the long haul. Another study found that newly awarded patents draw upon current findings from academic research at a greater rate than ever before. There is no doubt that California is the premier area for research and innovation in the United States. One of the main reasons for this is the presence of so many major universities working in partnership with industry and government to bring about innovation and to help get leading edge technology out into industry.

Recent OECD studies have shown that technology diffusion—getting the message out to where it can be used—is at least as important as innovation itself. The knowledge is no good locked up in a laboratory. It must get out into the commercial environment and the universities are a great way to combine research and teaching to produce innovation and diffusion. Innovation and diffusion are body contact sports: you need contact between those who are working in the universities and laboratories and those who are working in industry to deliver productive gains to the economy.

We need to see expenditure on science and research in universities in the context of an investment, not as an expenditure. The returns are there for the nation as a whole. Expenditure in these areas is a public good for which the government must make provision, not exclusively but substantially and with certainty and predictability.

Given the acknowledged importance of our human capital, what else can we do to encourage innovation and to foster research that is relevant and productive? You cannot do good science without a sound base. This applies not only to the base of scientific knowledge on which each generation of scientists builds but also to the research and skills infrastructure and to the public policy structure which underpins private sector investment in R&D.

The most obvious need is for private sector investment in research and development. Australia has lagged behind other OECD nations in this area in the past. The tax concession introduced by the former government addressed this problem in a serious way and business was beginning to respond. As I said earlier, the sudden reduction in the value of this concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent may be expected to have a long‐term negative effect on both actual levels of expenditure and on the board‐room psychology of the culture of research and development, which is almost as important in the long run. A sustainable research culture depends upon a continuing commitment by those who direct private capital investment and certainty of public policy is a major determinant of their future action.

The taxation mechanism is one way of encouraging private sector investment in research, but it needs to be recognised that business tends to underinvest in long‐term research and in public‐good research. That is where direct federal government investment is essential. Basic research must remain a focus for the government, and that is why I was very concerned by the long‐term cuts to the budgets of organisations like CSIRO, ANSTO and AIMS as well as the grant funding bodies like the ARC and the NHMRC.

The federal commitment to research is shown to decline in the out years of the budget well past the turn of the century. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) has claimed that the budget was kind to research, to public sector support for science and to agencies like CSIRO in particular. On budget night, the minister claimed that the government had increased direct Commonwealth spending for science and innovation by $43 million in 1997‐98 to a total of some $3.55 billion. The minister also claimed that CSIRO would receive an extra five per cent in funding. Unfortunately, those claims simply do not stack up.

The reality of Commonwealth support for science, research and innovation can be found in the government's own science and technology budget statement for 1997‐98, which was released a few days after the budget together with the departmental portfolio statements. These show that, when you factor out the effect of inflation, there will actually be a cut to funding of about $38 million or 1.3 per cent. Those figures are contained in the government's own statement which, unfortunately, was not released on budget night, and I would challenge the minister in future budgets to release that statement on budget night so that everyone can have a real and ready reference from the government's own sources as to the reality of its budget rhetoric. Having those two documents available on the same day as the budget is critical to budget analysis.

There has also been a silent unheralded revision of the projected effects of the cuts made in last year's budget. The stated inten tion then was to reduce the level of expenditure by some 5.1 per cent in real terms. The revised cut is more like 9.6 per cent in real terms. The minister has made history through his ability to cut science and technology funding—unfortunately, history made for all the wrong reasons.

CSIRO is an icon for Australian public sector science and a model of how the public sector can form effective and valuable partnerships with industry, especially in the traditional areas of agriculture, resources and manufacturing, as well as in the exciting new areas of opportunity like genetic engineering and information technology as well. The government promised in its election policy documents to increase funding to CSIRO by $60 million. It did that all right but, as we saw in the first budget, its generosity was very short‐lived. It demanded increased efficiency dividends from CSIRO and indulged in some corporate asset stripping requiring CSIRO to repay in total all the increases it had received, and then some. The government's understanding of accounting tricks is somewhat better than its understanding of the needs of science.

The government has sought to justify this mean‐spirited treatment of one of our premier research and development institutions by claiming that it could have been worse. Of course, it was worse. This year's budget sees the CRCs cut by some $10 million over two years. Cooperative research centres are a vital part of our research infrastructure, and this will also have an indirect impact on the CSIRO.

Partnerships, and the CRC concept in particular, is also an area that is essential to the long‐term sustainable research driven future we would all like to see for Australia. The CRC model seeks to tackle both technology diffusion and innovation. It brings together industry and the public sector in a way that encourages the exchange of ideas and the transfer of new technologies. The government's response to the successful model: cut funding. Existing CRCs will now find their room to grow severely constrained by the funding cuts and new proposals will be that much harder to get off the ground.

Speaking of getting things off the ground, the space CRC seems to have gone from our radar screens altogether—an important industry sector for Australia. Where is it now? The government abandoned the national space program and moved resources to CSIRO and the space CRC, yet this sector does not appear in CSIRO's annual expenditure profile statement for 1997‐98. I look forward to the minister's explanation of how all this makes for a bright future for our space industry, and I sincerely hope I have misjudged his intentions but the facts do not support an alternative choice at this stage.

The situation in respect of the Antarctic and Southern Ocean CRC is even worse. Because of funding guidelines that require external industry support for the CRC to obtain further funding—an absurd proposition for the Antarctic CRC given our international obligations against the commercial exploitation of Antarctica—the government proposes to allow this CRC to lapse when its funding runs out. This is a tragedy for Hobart, a tragedy for Australian climate change research and a tragedy for Antarctic and Southern Ocean research. The public‐good argument for this particular CRC is overwhelming, and the failure of the government to be sufficiently flexible so as to accommodate this CRC within the program illustrates its inability to grasp the significance of the work or the nature of the cooperative regime that the CRC model encourages. I appeal to the government to re‐examine the case of the Antarctic and Southern Ocean CRC. This is a vital component of our research effort in Antarctica.

One of the reasons that the former government adopted the syndication mechanism for taxation concessions for R&D was that those with the capital are rarely that technologically innovative, but those small new firms with lots of ideas rarely have the funds to bring them to market as fast as modern conditions demand. Some variation of the syndication taxation model and legal encouragement to form pre‐competitive research groups must be high on the agenda of any government concerned to foster innovation in a small economy like ours.

We must use every technique at our disposal to ensure that research, innovation and technology are supported, and that means going beyond the obvious areas I have mentioned so far. Questions of the level of protection for intellectual property rights, the communication system available throughout the nation, freedom of expression, quality of life for people at all levels of the work force and reform of the economy generally are very much part of that equation. Even decisions like the commitment to long‐term funding programs for research based institutions can have a marked effect on output.

Another vital area of the budget in science and technology is information technology. The Australian government's response in the context of a massive shift throughout the world to use and develop information technology is to sell our IT infrastructure to overseas multinationals. While I accept that, under limited circumstances involving partnerships with the private sector, outsourcing has a role to play, there are a number of problems with the current proposals to outsource IT by this government.

The large scale of the shift is significant. At the end of the process, the government will have little or no expertise in‐house to enable it to control and manage future developments. The problem is that you cannot manage what you do not understand. I think that the government does not understand the nature of the IT industry and the nature of the loss to Australia and the government when that is sold and the infrastructure is no longer under the direct control of the government.

One of the major concerns has got to be privacy. No‐one has any illusion that this government will act to safeguard privacy. The assurance we had from the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) today that the Privacy Act will be extended to cover outsourcing is a worthwhile step. He has taken that only under pressure from the public and the opposition, but the critical factor is: will that legislation be enacted and be in place before the outsourcing contracts are let? I doubt it, given the government's present level of commitment to this area of privacy. The reality is that, for us to have any confidence in that, the legislation has to be in place before the outsourcing contracts are let to the private sector.

Unresolved questions also exist across the board about the extent of savings that will be obtained from the outsourcing structure, the way in which employees' rights will be protected and safeguarded and the need for an industry policy for IT given the large scale of the information technology infrastructure which is being given to the private sector.

The issue of industry policy will return to haunt this government at every turn. The reality is that they do not have an industry policy to protect the steel industry and they do not have an industry policy to protect the IT and communications industry. Our trade deficit in this area continues to get worse. Recent ABS figures show that our trade deficit in IT goods and services and communications was a total of over $7 billion. What is the government doing to ensure that that is rectified?

Science has a vital role to play in any budget deliberation. This budget speech ignored science and technology. That a budget speech on the eve of the 21st century can fail to mention science, innovation, engineering and education is an enormous misunderstanding of the importance these areas will play in the future of Australia. Australia must invest in a sound research and technology capacity. It is a challenge which this budget fails to meet. The consequences of that failure will be felt for a generation and beyond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1997‐98 budget has been widely acclaimed as one which will help families, boost small business, create jobs and encourage savings. Some people have described it as too tough and others have described it as not tough enough. On balance, I think, as the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) was saying earlier, it has been very well received, and a measure of that is the input that we have had from our constituents on it.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it represents a monumental turnover in the Commonwealth finances: from the $10 billion deficit that we were faced with when we took over from the previous government to what will be an underlying surplus in the 1998‐99 budget. As I also heard the member for Fairfax saying, that is directly responsible for the low interest rate regime which is now firmly in place and which will benefit Australian families and businesses.

I might also say that the results we have achieved to date—to the great credit of the Treasurer (Mr Costello)—have been largely achieved without tax increases. I am pleased to see that not only is this government committed to lower taxes as a matter of policy but that the Prime Minister has put on the record his commitment to comprehensive and detailed tax reform, which is absolutely vital.

Many of the budget measures impact favourably on my own constituents in McPherson. I am pleased that there is at last some tangible recognition for carers. I happen to have the largest number of over 65‐year‐olds of any electorate in Australia. For a long time, the previous government failed to recognise adequately the amount of money that carers have saved the government and the very hard work they actually do. So I am very pleased to see the government announce in the budget a 28 per cent increase in the domiciliary nursing care benefit.

I might also say how pleased I am that we are starting to see the effects of the Natural Heritage Trust. It is already impacting on my electorate where the Surfrider Foundation has been given a grant for its Respect the Beach campaign. In an electorate like mine—based as it is on the Gold Coast where tourism and our beaches are so vital—that particular campaign is one that I support strongly and I am pleased to see that it is being funded.

As far as tourism is concerned, again the budget was very positive and there are benefits there as we run downhill towards the Sydney 2000 Olympics. Additional money has been given in the budget to the Australian Tourist Commission and I believe that money will be used well. There is no doubt in my mind or in the minds of many of my constituents that the Sydney Olympics is not just about two weeks in the year 2000; it is about the years before and the years after. The whole of Australia will benefit from Sydney staging the 2000 Olympics.

BREAK.PARA: I should say that tourism continues to be a vital industry for Australia. It is responsible for more than $8 billion of what are effectively export earnings for this country, and that probably makes it Australia's major export earner. Therefore, I am pleased that in this budget the government has given tourism full export industry status by extending the export market development grants scheme to the tourism industry on the same grounds as it is available to other exporters. The previous government, for 13 years, failed to recognise the importance of the tourism industry in that situation. The member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) is frowning. He does not need to be reminded about that particular decision in respect of the export market development grants scheme, I am sure.

The tourism industry continues to grow strongly despite the anti‐Asian comments of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). It needs to be understood—and it needs to be said in my electorate, which is absolutely tourism based—that these comments are a serious threat to our tourism industry. Let the point be made clearly by me and, I hope, by others in this place that those sorts of anti‐Asian sentiments are very much against Australia's interest as far as our tourism industry is concerned. I also believe they are representing a threat to the wider interests of Australia in our relationships with our Asian neighbours.

Yesterday's debate in parliament on the motion by the Prime Minister on Aboriginal reconciliation was an important debate. I am pleased in the end that the Prime Minister's motion was supported almost unanimously. The member for Oxley actually took part in that debate. I was interested to reread her comments in the Hansard. There is no doubt that this particular week has been a turbulent week, not only here in Canberra but in Australian politics and in Australia generally. Events in the parliament today reflected that. It is a very emotional issue that we are currently faced with.

I commend the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) for his speech in the parliament today. I thought it was a genuine speech. The motion, in a sense, may have been something of a political stunt—I do not know. But I do not in any way diminish that his remarks were made absolutely sincerely. I did not think they were helped, incidentally, by the member for Banks (Mr Melham), who took the opportunity to make it a political issue rather than to seek some genuine bipartisan solution to the current serious problem which we face as a nation and, I think, which is broadly acknowledged on both sides of the House.

Despite the resolution that was carried almost unanimously yesterday, the process of reconciliation in the course of events this week has not been assisted. Some people in Australia, no doubt, care little for the process of reconciliation. I happen to care about it. For the sake of our future as a nation I believe there must be reconciliation. The member for Oxley says, and reiterated yesterday, `I resent being made to feel guilty for something I did not do.'

Having thought about those sorts of remarks over the years I have been here, having been here through the Mabo debate and events before and since, I do not think we are talking about people feeling guilty; what we are talking about is people accepting responsibility. We cannot ignore our history. I thought an analogy might be that we expect today's generation of Japanese not to feel guilty about the Second World War but to understand their history, accept it and accept some responsibility.

In fact, we also demand an apology from the Japanese, which has never been forthcoming, for the way they treated Australian prisoners of war. That does not mean we do not operate with Japan as a close friend and trading partner at all, but we still have those demands which we place upon them and we do expect at some future time to have an unequivocal apology from the Japanese government of today for what they did to Australian prisoners of war, in particular, in the early 1940s.

We have got a serious problem in our nation at the moment and it is not going to go away. It is no good people saying that they do not want to feel guilty about it, that they do not want to hear about it, that they do not want to know about it, that it is not their problem. It is their problem; it is our problem. Reconciliation, as I see it, is a process. It is a journey but it has an ultimate destination. Basically it requires forgiveness on all sides and an understanding on all sides.

I believe that those who turned their backs on the Prime Minister during his address at the national reconciliation conference became part of the problem, not the solution. I am pleased that Dr Lois O'Donoghue today, as I understand it, has offered to apologise to the Prime Minister for their having done so. If my understanding is correct, I congratulate her and believe that is the sort of action that needs to underpin reconciliation.

I believe that we can reach the destination that we are headed towards and we can do it by the year 2001, but it will require goodwill and forgiveness on all sides. Fault on all sides has got us where we are today. The member for Oxley, again in her speech yesterday, called for the abolition of ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good idea.

—I am sure the member for Kalgoorlie thinks it is a good idea. The formation of ATSIC was not strongly supported on this side of the House when we were in opposition. In fact I think we sought to oppose it for very good reasons. But it is today a fact of life and from the Aboriginal point of view the right to self‐determination is fundamentally important. There is no doubt that ATSIC has not been perfect—far from it. Everybody acknowledges that. The government—and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) in particular, to his credit—is addressing many of its deficiencies.

BREAK.PARA: The government in the budget—and we are dealing particularly in this debate with the budget and the Aboriginal affairs portfolio appropriations—showed clearly that it is moving towards a goal of greater economics and independence for indigenous people through their self‐empowerment. I am pleased that ATSIC funding will be guaranteed now for four years to give the ATSIC board, under its new leadership, a fair go and to give it greater flexibility with program planning and, indeed, more financial security.
The member for Oxley's remarks on ATSIC may strike something of a popular cord in the community but I believe, once again, yesterday they were ill‐advised, ill‐timed and extremely unhelpful.

TALK.START.PARA: —And true.

—And not true. We have many challenges ahead of us as a nation. The eyes of the world will be on Australia as we head down the track towards the 2000 Olympics. What I think Australians need to come to grips with is the question of what we want the world to see when they look at Australia. We want them to see hopefully a nation that is united. We do not want them to see a nation that is divided by the hatred and prejudice that we hear coming from people, even a limited number of people in this place. We want them to see a united nation.

BREAK.PARA: We want to be proud of Australia in the year 2000 when the Olympics are held in Sydney. Running an Olympic Games is not an easy task. It is easy to criticise some of the arrangements but, in the end—the opposition whip, the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) represents a Sydney electorate—Sydney will do a fine job and we will put on a great Olympic Games, perhaps the best one ever, and all Australians will be proud of it.

But let us be certain that we face the challenges that we have ahead between now and then. The challenge of reconciliation is one of the greatest. I do not pretend that it is easy. I am by no means one of the wets, as one of the Sydney papers portrays us, surrounding the Prime Minister trying to—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never alleged that.

—Thank you. I am not one of those trying to extract some sort of an apology out of him. That is not where I am coming from. But I do have a fundamental belief in the process of reconciliation for the sake of our nation and for the sake of my children.

BREAK.PARA: I actually happen to believe even more strongly that there is a spiritual dimension to this process of reconciliation that I am acutely aware of. I believe that Australia is diminished as a nation until the issue is resolved. It will not be resolved by shallow, populist rhetoric.

The government understands, and it is reflected again in the budget papers in this particular area, the imperative of overcoming the disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal Australians. I am pleased that many initiatives have been taken in the budget to deal with that particular fact. We cannot deny it is a fact. There are some people who think that it does not exist or who want it to go away. Once again, we cannot deny the fact that Aborigines are amongst the most disadvantaged of Australians. In that context, I think we can argue that, because of that—and because all of our welfare system, as extensive as it is, is based on need—their needs are amongst the greatest.

In terms of life expectancy amongst Aboriginals, only one in three will live to the age of 65. They have 2.6 times the level of unemployment of other Australians. As far as education is concerned, half of them leave school before 16 compared to only a quarter of other Australians. Some Aborigines still do not attend school at all. In all of these areas, they are severely disadvantaged.

This government, which I am pleased and proud to be a part of, is addressing those issues. It is not easy. I do not want to overstate the political side of it, but hopefully some of my colleagues on the other side might, in quieter moments, acknowledge that money has been wasted, and, in many respects, wasted for political purposes.

That is behind us. This government is aware of the widespread concern in the community about that, and the understandable and justifiable concern in the community about that. But now this government is doing something about the problem. I believe it deserves credit for that. As I read the budget papers in respect of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, it is clear that something is being done about it.

Finally, in the context of this budget debate, I want to say a couple of words about something in the Attorney-General's portfolio which has become dear to my heart. I am the Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority. I was very pleased to see the additional funding of $20.4 million in the budget over three years to target fraud against the Commonwealth.

There has been, in recent times, some criticism of the NCA. In a sense, it is an organisation that will always be operating on the edge and one which will always be vulnerable to criticism. There are those who say its powers are too great. There are many who say its powers are not great enough to do the important job that it has been given to do. The member for Kalgoorlie seems to want to fit into the former category. Let me put it to him that the NCA, the National Crime Authority, is in the forefront of the fight against organised crime—

TALK.START.PARA: —Corrupt and elitist.

—I assume the member for Kalgoorlie thinks that it is important that we do have a concerted effort in this country to combat organised crime and the war against drugs. I assume the member for Kalgoorlie is in favour of us taking the threat that drugs represent in our society seriously. If he does, then he will understand that the NCA, the National Crime Authority, is at the forefront of that fight.

BREAK.PARA: I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the war against drugs can and must be won. I do not think that, in recent years, despite the efforts of the NCA, we have made the inroads we should have. Perhaps resources is one of the answers as to why not. That is why I am pleased that the NCA has been given additional support by the government in this year's budget. In these times of financial stringency when budgets, generally, are being trimmed, $20.4 million over three years is a significant vote of confidence by the government in the National Crime Authority.

I do not believe that we can surrender in this war against drugs by promoting soft laws as some, including the member for Kalgoorlie, would advocate. I do not believe that is an option. The war against crime can and must be won. I am pleased that I have the opportunity of being chairman of that important committee. As I say, I am particularly pleased that the government has seen fit to give the National Crime Authority a significant vote of confidence in the current budget.

I will explain the circumstances at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Dobell from moving an additional amendment to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

—The opposition wishes to move this amendment because we have made a mistake. When I finished my Higher School Certificate my father often encouraged me to do law rather than engineering. On a day like today, I wish I had considered a career in law rather than engineering.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why the opposition is seeking to move this additional amendment is that, due to an oversight on our part, we have failed to delete a crucial clause in the legislation. Just to give the background for the House and honourable members, when this measure was first introduced to the House, the government's intention was to remove the right of two groups to access the services provided by Australian Hearing Services. The two groups affected were 19‐ to 21-year-olds with hearing disabilities—that is, deaf kids—and also several tens of thousands of seniors, being those people who hold health care cards.

The opposition believed that it was unfair to take away from those two groups the right of access to Australian Hearing Services. Our amendments were rejected in the House of Representatives. But we were very pleased that the government picked up one set of amendments that agreed to not proceed with the measure that would affect deaf children between the ages of 19 and 21. Also, there was a majority in the Senate, made up of the opposition together with the support of the Democrats and Senator Harradine—and I am not sure whether Senator Colston was helpful—ensuring our ability to amend the legislation in the Senate.

The problem was—and this was our mistake—that, despite the collective wisdom of the opposition, the Democrats and Senator Harradine, we amended one part of the legislation: we deleted item 3 from schedule 1 of the legislation, which removed subsections (ac) and (ad) from section 5A(1) from the Hearing Services Act. What we failed to notice was that another part of the legislation, item 23 of schedule 1, deletes all of section 5 from the Hearing Services Act. In fact, it takes out of the Hearing Services Act 1991 the eligibility provisions and places them within the Hearing Services Administration Bill 1997.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you and every other member would have known that is as clear as mud and would have quite obviously realised that the opposition should have moved two amendments rather than one to try to protect seniors. That is the mistake that we have made.

What is the effect of this? The effect of it is that the opposition, the Democrats and Senator Harradine have protected the senior health care card holders and they will retain their eligibility until 1 July. After 1 July, the government's item 23 of schedule 1 bites, and those seniors lose their eligibility on 1 July.

The problem is that the group of people affected are, in many cases, farmers, self-funded retirees—people who are perhaps asset rich but income poor. The opposition believes that, having extended this concession to seniors five years ago, it is quite penny pinching of the government to seek to take away from people such as farmers and those self-funded retirees the right to be looked after by Australian Hearing Services. What does it do? Australian Hearing Services ensures that, if those elderly Australians are assessed as needing a hearing-aid, a hearing‐aid is fitted, provided and maintained. It is a service which is quite helpful to those many self-funded retirees around Australia.

Given that I understand the government intend to accept the opposition's first amendment, which extends the eligibility of the senior card holders till 1 July, if they are serious about making sure that these people are protected, they will allow the opposition to move this additional amendment which does seek to ensure that the eligibility is protected forever, not just until 1 July. With that, I will try to finish early to make sure that we move through this as quickly as possible. But the point we are trying to make is that this is the best way to make sure that those 33,000 seniors do continue to have access to Australian Hearing Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Family Services)

SPEECH.PARA: This is not something I particularly enjoy doing, but we had to make a lot of tough decisions last year with the financial position we found ourselves in after the election. Our principal concern was to see that we could get the budget back into surplus over this term, health had to play a part, and this was a direct consequence of the deficit. So, as it has already been substantially debated, both here and in the other place, I do not see any need to further debate it. We do not agree to the suspension.

In the past we were told that there was no saving as a result of this change.
