SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Appropriation Bill I want to reflect on the budget and some of the effects the budget will have. It is, in my view, quite a clever budget. It does not offend any group in society with any power and it is, in fact, an ideal budget on which to go to a double dissolution.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not, however, do a lot. I think its great distinguishing feature is the lack of industry policy, although there are some things in the budget which I applaud. I applaud the government's reduction of the taxation level on savings. I do so because it institutionalises it in the system and, hopefully, the scheme can be made more practical and less regressive in some future budget. I think this could be done by either reducing the amount of taxation involved or giving a complete exemption, thereby benefiting people on lower incomes.

However, I want to deal with industry policy. It is quite clear that there is no recognition of the need for a policy. In fact, one would almost think it is anathema to the interests of the nation. The problem we have in Australia is not clearly understood by the Labor Party. Indeed, although I think the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) understands it, he does not have the intellectual rigour to apply it. Industry policy is a mixture of a lot of things. You cannot talk about industry policy in isolation. You have to talk about education, training and immigration. You have to talk about a whole host of other costs to society. That is clearly something which the member for Melbourne is not prepared to do. In my view, his posturing on industry policy has a rather hollow ring. I think the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) has a much better idea about it. It remains to be seen whether the member for Perth will be able to influence the Labor Party in the future.

There are many things which a government can do in industry policy. It is not just, as some people say, a matter of bringing back tariffs. This would do as much damage as good. It is certainly a policy which I would not advocate. It does not mean that I resile from tariffs. I think there is a place for them, as there is for bounties.

A clear example is that of high‐speed aluminium boats. Australia is the world leader in this area. We had a third of the world's trade—the most expensive third. Tasmania has had some publicity in this regard, but by far the bulk of the industry is situated in Western Australia. It is interesting to note that a large customer is mainland China. They are so pleased with the service they get that they send the boats back to Western Australia to be refurbished.

It is simply ideological nonsense for the government to talk about removing the five per cent bounty. If you look at the world situation, Finland, which is our main competitor, has an 11 per cent bounty and shows no sign of reducing it. In fact, Europe has made it clear it will not reduce the bounty until the United States does. The United States has an open‐ ended policy and shows no sign of reducing its bounty.

Japan does not allow the entry of our vessels, even though they are very competi tive. They will buy the technology in an endeavour to try to replicate the efficiencies we have in Australia. Australian builders tell me they have no qualms in this regard because they say they are already moving ahead of their existing technology. It would be a crying shame if the blundering, ideological stupidity of this government saw the ships bounty phased out. Indeed, I have a philosophical view that you should support your successful industries, not penalise them.

What other things can governments do? It is quite clear that the Australian government is by far the biggest single customer in Australia. In fact, it is true for any economy, whether it is Stalin's Russia or Reagan's America—the government is the biggest customer. And what the government does with that buying power has an enormous effect on industry.

If government purchases were bought on the through‐life cost of equipment rather than on the capital cost, Australian industry would shine. It would shine because parts made in Australia are invariably cheaper and more readily available. We are in the ludicrous position of having allowed our army to buy Mercedes Benz vehicles when Acco Inter vehicles were available. The army had worked with International for two years to develop the vehicle they wanted. We then let the army buy a foreign vehicle at a cost which was 50 per cent higher than that of the Australian vehicle. That was, I believe, the last nail in the coffin of International, which was surviving and profiting as a truck manufacturer in Australia, and could have continued to do so. Now, of course, it has simply gone. I think it is a tragedy.

As a consequence of that, we have Unimog, which has a torsion bar suspension. Australia was, and probably still is, a world leader in leaf spring suspensions. We still do not make torsion bars for the darned things. I know that a couple of years ago New South Wales railways, which had bought one of these things, had to wait six weeks to get a replacement part flown out from Germany. That is an example of the stupidity that we inflict on ourselves.

BREAK.PARA: If government were to say to the Public Service—and remember that many purchases are made at a very low level in the Public Service—`You don't have to buy the Australian product but, if you don't buy it, we want you to put in writing why you haven't bought it,' assuming that one is available, this would have two benefits. You would find that a lot more Australian products would be bought. You would also find that where there were genuine flaws, they would be brought to somebody's attention and they would be fixed.

Just after we went down the Mercedes Benz road for our army, I visited France. I talked to people in the army there. I said, `You are part of Europe, you are very close to the Germans. Are you considering buying the Mercedes Benz, the Unimog?' The answer was, `Monsieur, we have very good French trucks. Why would we do anything like this?' I applaud the French position. I wish some of our governments could be bitten by Frenchmen.

I recall attending a pastoralists and graziers meeting and being regaled with the evils of tariffs and how tariffs were the bane of their lives. Of course, tariffs are not the bane of the rural sector. The real problem for the rural sector is access to long‐term finance and the fact that we deal almost exclusively for our major exports in corrupt markets. They put it to me at this meeting that tariffs were their major problem. I remember saying, `If we were to take tariffs off motorbikes tomorrow, how many of you would buy a new motorbike?' Apparently, they all would, because they all put their hands up to indicate that they would upgrade. I had pleasure in telling them that they could rush out and do so because there has never been a tariff on motorbikes in Australia.

That does not mean, however, that motorbikes are cheap. By world standards, they are not. A motorbike in Hong Kong, where there is a 25 per cent tariff, costs about the same as it does in Australia. The reason is that the Japanese are not stupid. They simply charge what the market will bear. I believe a tariff would not have a significant impact on the price of motorbikes. In any case, with the advent of quite good bikes in China, competition would soon drive them down again if we were to source bikes from China. It would mean pastoralists would have to have a model which was a couple of years old, but I see that as no hardship whatsoever.

Just before the interruption to the debate a member was talking about ATSIC. It is true that the Liberal Party opposed the ATSIC legislation, and so did I. It was my opposition to it and the opposition of a few other members of the Labor Party to it that forced Gerry Hand to rewrite the legislation and get rid of some of the worst and most offending areas. However, I did not support the legislation in its final form and all the problems that were apparent then are now abundantly clear and with us. ATSIC has nothing to do with self-determination. In fact, it is quite the contrary. I know because I spend a lot of my time trying to protect Aboriginal people from the bureaucratic excesses of ATSIC. For many people self-determination is a myth. It is a myth which organisations such as ATSIC and the Aboriginal activists hide.

You cannot separate the native title issue from the welfare of this nation and from the costs imposed on this nation. It is something that has to be considered in the budget context. It is my view that the Mabo decision was a social engineering decision. It was not based in law. I think the reason for that was that when we had appeals to the Privy Council there was some intellectual rigour imposed on the High Court. In those days, we arguably had the best appellate court in the world. Those days have gone. There is a no rigour imposed on the High Court and it has sunk into social engineering. In the Mabo report you have Deane and Gaudron talking about `our unspeakable shame'. What sort of emotive language is that? What sort of legal terminology is that? They on their high salaries, because they said they could see it, were absolved from any responsibility.

So that was forced on us. But the Keating government in its legislation went far beyond the original Mabo judgment, and the High Court has simply leapfrogged to catch up to be once more a leader, which, of course, is not the job of the High Court. We now have the absurdity of the judgment of Justice Kirby. That is something that Justice Kirby will have to live with, although I doubt whether it will ever give him any great concern, such is the nature of the man.

It is also true that Paul Keating believed absolutely that pastoral leases extinguish native title. Because Paul Keating believed this, every one of those so-called and self‐appointed Aboriginal leaders believed it because they were flocking around Keating like a swarm of worker bees. They believed therefore that it was gone. But the High Court's silly, stupid decision on Wik simply rekindled all their hopes.

Similarly, Keating believed there was a prima facie case, but the act was such a mess that it was not in there and the Federal Court determined it was not. It is true that the act probably would not have been such a mess had the opposition and the mining industry made a contribution to the legislation. As it was, the ATSIC Act was written mainly by the left wing of the Labor Party. You get what you would expect from such a source. I think one of the great truths is the statement by Prescott, the Chairman of BHP, who described it as like reading porridge. That is probably the best description of the act I have heard.

It is quite clear that if nothing is done there is going to be rising insecurity and uncertainty in the mining industry. For a long time governments used to say, `It is not having an effect. Gold production is rising.' It was rising, but it was rising because gold production was invariably from brownfield sites. It was associated with existing mines and native title was not a consideration. That is changing. We are now moving to greenfield sites and native title is an enormous consideration.

There are many leases in my electorate of Kalgoorlie where you have overlapping claims. There can be half a dozen or more claims on the one piece of land and that is unworkable. I believe that the government should have had the nerve in the early days to extinguish native title. They should have been prepared to have a double dissolution. I do not think they would have had to because the Labor Party are not entirely stupid and they know that, had an election been held, they would have lost even more seats. The Liberal Party never had the nerve to do that. The reason is, as Senator Minchin succinctly put it, that they have as many bleeding hearts amongst their ranks as the Labor Party does.

There will be a cost from this and there will eventually be a reckoning. It is my view that we ought to have a referendum on the High Court decision. The question ought to be whether we return to terra nullius or stick with the nonsense which they have imposed on us.

If you look at the history of Britain, you find that their method of operation throughout the world was to sign treaties. The instruction was that people sign treaties with the natives. For that reason, New Zealand, Fiji, Malaysia, Ceylon, India and North America are covered in treaties—which have their own problems. The instructions to Captain Phillip were clear—to sign treaties with the natives. The reason he did not is that he could not. There was evolved the doctrine of terra nullius.

We on both sides of this parliament allowed Keating to carry on with the nonsense that he did: `Those unspeakable British, how arrogant to say there was no‐one here before them?' Terra nullius did not mean that at all. It meant basically no use of the land. High courts throughout the world—in Russia, Spain, Portugal, North America, Australia and Britain—had all held that occasional traversing of the land by nomadic people did not constitute use of the land. That is how terra nullius came about.

There were large parts of Australia where there was no Aboriginal habitation at all. The Nullarbor is one such place. There were no Aboriginals there because they could not exist. There was no surface water. On that vast limestone plateau rain sinks straight through. There was no way that anyone could survive out there unless they had the means to harness the underground water sources.

When I first went to the Nullarbor, there were no kangaroos for that very reason. Four years after putting down the bores, I could shoot 100 kangaroos a night. Immediately native title came in, my brother had two overlapping claims on his station—a station where there was never, ever any Aboriginal occupation. Such is the nonsense that we have been faced with.

I think it is about time, as we have had conspicuous failure from government and opposition, that the people of Australia had the chance to put things right with a referendum. I think 30 years after the first referendum in 1967—which we are celebrating now—would be a good time.

We have had a lot of talk in this parliament on that referendum. I voted in that referendum and I, like the vast majority of Australians, thought we were voting to give equality to Aboriginal people. Instead, we were not. We were voting to give special powers to the Commonwealth—powers which have largely been abused. I will be talking about this in the adjournment debate, so I do not want to go much further into that, except to say that there has to be a reckoning in this area.

I represent more Aboriginal people than any other politician in this parliament, and I know what Aboriginal people are saying. They know that there is nothing for them in native title. They will be no better off. But they can see a backlash coming, and they know that they will be the recipients of the backlash. Many of those people who are now leading the charge will simply disappear. Many of them will become white again. I think it is a disgrace.

I also think it is a disgrace when you look at the part of the legal profession. I think particularly of activists like lawyer Ron Castan, who represented Aboriginals in the Mabo decision. He is a great champion of native title. One wonders whether Ron Castan et al had the same regard for Palestinian land rights, for people who were dispossessed in a much shorter time frame. But then that is the sort of tautology, the sort of hypocrisy, that the legal profession is so grounded in. I do not think they will have any trouble reconciling the irreconcilable.

Unless we get a return to our manufacturing industry, there are no jobs in the future and there is no end to the current account deficit. I can say here and now that this budget which has just been brought down by the government will not see a reduction in unemploy ment. The government is only hoping for a very small reduction—something in the order of 0.5 per cent. Remember, real unemployment in this country is far higher than 8.5 per cent, which is the official figure, and I can see nothing in this budget that is going to reduce that.

I can say here and now that at the time of the next election the current account deficit will be even higher. I am sure there will be some reason for this and it is all going to be addressed in the next budget. But the truth is that, unless there is a return to the manufacture industry, there are no jobs for our kids. This must be faced up to. This is not, as I say, I wild plea for tariffs. There are lots of other very sensible things that governments can do—things that do not offend GATT. We must begin by scrapping this rational economic nonsense of the level playing field, because I can say to members of this House that the level playing field is clearly a flat earth policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews, Kevin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In a week notable for the fall of official interest rates by a further 0.5 per cent to 7.2 per cent, we should be cautious about any premature euphoria in housing purchases, for the brute facts, as revealed by the release of a report this week from the Real Estate Institute of Australia, show another picture. That report notes that historically the proportion of first home buyers in the housing market has been inversely proportional to mortgage interest rates. Rates come down and people make what is their major financial commitment for life to buy their homes. It has always been the Australian dream, and Paul Keating's attempts in the past to talk down the quarter acre block have not changed that.

SPEECH.PARA: What is different now is that the continuing falls in the interest rates over the past six months—which have taken almost $300 a month off the average $100,000 home mortgage since the coalition came to power—have not directly flowed through at this stage to home buyers coming into the market. Instead, as the REIA reports, first home ownership rates have declined. That is something which we must keep under scrutiny.

BREAK.PARA: The reason for this is not hard to find. The REIA report states that real estate agents say that unemployment, combined with high job uncertainty, is the primary factor keeping many people out of the market. This problem is so serious that many more young people do not believe that owning their own home is a realisable goal. A couple of years ago, social researcher Jeanne Strachan concluded:

Young couples today are the first generation since the war to face the reality that they often cannot obtain, even with two full-time workers in the house, what their parents saw as a fair and reasonable reward for their hard work.

The economic result is yet another disincentive to save and an increase in consumption which flows on into a rise in imports to this country and a worsening of Australia's national savings position and the current account deficit.

The reason for this problem is obvious. The coalition government came to power on the back of the Labor government policies that created some of the highest levels of unemployment in this country since the Great Depression. We on this side of the House never envisaged that after 13 years of Labor it would be an easy problem to fix, and so it has proved.

The trend unemployment rate increased from 8.4 per cent in December 1995 to 8.7 per cent in December 1996. The male unemployment rate rose by 0.1 per cent in the year to 8.9 per cent in December. The female unemployment rate fluctuated during the year from 7.9 per cent in December 1995 to 8.4 per cent in June 1996.

Of most concern are the long-term jobless figures. In trend terms, the number of long-term jobless fell from 233,100 in December 1995 to 212,100 in May 1996 before rising to 232,400 in December 1996. Long-term unemployment fell from 30.4 per cent of total unemployment in December 1995 to 29.2 per cent in December 1996. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, despite some fluctuations during the year, in trend terms, unemployment levels ended 1996 at a higher level in all states than 12 months earlier. Only 20.7 per cent of employers surveyed national ly were planning to increase their work forces in the three months to July.

Yet in a sense the reality behind the figures is worse than this. A 1995 Senate report found that Australia's unemployment rate was double the official rate. The difference between the official rate and the estimated real level of unemployment and underemployment was that the latter group included people who could not get work, those who were working one day a week but wanting more, and those who had simply given up.

Several groups suffer disproportionately—the young, the old, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, people in some rural areas and outer suburbs, and many non-English speaking migrants. Professor Helen Hughes stated in 1995, `High overall unemployment, together with the lack of English, is creating high concentrations of poverty in migrant communities.'

In July 1995, when the official unemployment rate for Australia was 8.4 per cent for males and 7.2 per cent for females, the rate for people born outside Australia from some countries was much higher—notably, North Africa, 22.7 per cent for males and 22.1 per cent for females; Lebanon, 29.8 per cent and 18.4 per cent; South-East Asia, 19.7 per cent and 13 per cent; and Vietnam in particular, 31 per cent and 25.4 per cent. I believe we need to keep those figures uppermost in our mind. The government has acted on this knowledge in the reduction in the number of migrants to this country and in the new focus on migrants with skills.

The Labor government in almost a decade and a half presided over the increasing casualisation of the Australian work force. By 1995, 6.5 million workers in Australia were casual workers. Casual workers lack the benefits of service enjoyed by the rest of the working population and are subject to even greater uncertainty in the continuation of their employment.

The Labor government also presided over an increasing polarisation between higher and lower level workers as the proportion of middle income earners slumped and the pay rates of senior executives increased by nearly 60 per cent to 1995. According to the Prices Surveillance Authority, senior executives have been drawing salary rises 1.5 times larger than the average full-time employee's and more than double the rises won by workers whose wages are restricted to award rates of pay—and this is under a supposedly Labor government.

It is time, I believe, for us to renew our aspiration for full employment. The 1945 white paper entitled boldly Full employment in Australia stated: `Full employment is a fundamental aim of the Commonwealth government.' Unlike the former Labor government, which made fiddling the unemployment figures into an art form, churning the long-term unemployed through so-called employment programs that eventually returned many people to the ranks of the unemployed no more employable but registered as newly unemployed, the Commonwealth government in 1945 dedicated itself to stimulating real employment. Its manifesto asserted: `There will be no place in this full employment policy for schemes designed to make work for work's sake.'

The government in 1945 prefaced its policy for full employment on the dire period between 1919 and 1939, when more than one-tenth of the population desiring work were unemployed in this nation. At the nadir of the Great Depression, well over 25 per cent of the country's work force could not obtain work. The solution then was Keynesian. The government spent on public works to stimulate private investment. The attraction of private investment was seen as paramount. The white paper explained:

A major cause of decreases in private capital expenditure in the past has been the tendency of many businessmen, farmers and other investors simultaneously to contract their capital expenditure because of the fear of a reduction in spending. This was inevitable in an economy in which total expenditure was expected to fluctuate, and in which businessmen were extremely sensitive to their rivals' and associates' estimates of movements in spending in the near future. Simply because businessmen tended simultaneously to contract their capital expenditure, they contributed significantly by their very actions to the fall in total spending which they feared.
So the government determined to keep Commonwealth spending at a high and reasonably constant level as a consequence.

The government of 1945 totally rejected the claim that occasional depressions are necessary to remove inefficient firms and to speed up the transfer of resources from declining to expanding industries, which it maintained `cannot any longer be supported in view of the miseries imposed on large sections of the community by those depressions'.

Rereading the white paper of 1945, it becomes apparent how the perceived role of government in this country has changed. In 1945 it was possible to put in place import quotas when there was a severe and prolonged fall in export incomes. For less permanent declines in Australia's trading fortunes overseas, an alteration in the exchange rate was seen as the appropriate method of correction.

Some commentators have dated the abandonment of the aspirations of the 1945 white paper to the Fraser government's election in 1975. Then the government chose to fight inflation first rather than deal with the high rates of unemployment as a priority. The emphasis was on keeping money supply steady. Policy makers from that era onwards returned to the classical view of unemployment as purely the result of excessive real wage levels, which had risen dramatically prior to 1975 under the Whitlam government.

These policies largely excluded the possibility of active government intervention to achieve full employment. However, an adverse consequence of these decisions was to expose Australia to the ill winds that blow from offshore. Economic policy became a matter of anticipating the reactions of the markets. So the values of the foreign exchange market speculators came to dominate economic policy. As we saw in the 1980s, a wave of unproductive speculative activity was unleashed in this country.

As most monetary levers had been given away by government, it was left to curb high inflation with the bluntest of blunt instruments, high interest rates, which sent many small businesses to the wall, never to return. At every point the judgment seems to have been wrong. Mr Keating variously told the Australian people that the recession was the recession that we had to have and that there would be a soft landing. He never did bring home the bacon as promised and the Labor Party is now in limbo because of this.

A worrying concern for many Australians is their perception that these trends of globalisation have removed full employment from the national agenda. The truism is that by being competitive in a survival of the fittest contest the most efficient companies will survive and it will not matter that the rest will not. The phoenix will rise again from the ashes in the form of new businesses and industries. Many Australian manufacturers find that to compete with the low levels of pay possible in industries in South‐East Asia, for example, they have to increasingly `downsize'—that euphemism from the 1980s.

The litmus test for the Australian economy is the development of high value added industries and exports, particularly in areas such as elaborately transformed manufactures, ETMs. In the late 1980s it seemed as if giant strides were being made in this country in ETMs. In 1985 ETMs and other manufactures accounted for 20 per cent of total commodity exports. By 1993 this position had improved to a point where ETMs and other manufactures accounted for almost 30 per cent of total commodity exports. Even the ratio of exports to imports slowly improved for ETMs and manufactures as a whole. In 1986 ETM exports were 15 per cent of total ETM trade while by 1993 exports had moved up to 35 per cent.

The other half of the equation, however, was that imports so far exceeded exports that, according to Stephen Bell in an article in the Journal of Australian Political Economy last year, the relative growth rates of the 1980s would have to have been maintained for several decades to bring any marked improvement in net trade outcomes. That is the position we find ourselves in at this particular time.

Moreover, the trend towards a deteriorating trade balance in manufactures has been accompanied by a fall‐off in investment in import competing industries. The problem is compounded because whenever the economy starts to pick up so does our buying of imports and the current account deteriorates further.

The manufacturing sector is thus peculiarly vulnerable to the imports assault. Bell points out that the import penetration of manufactures increased by almost 50 per cent between 1970 and 1989. This figure is even way above the OECD average—in fact, 24 per cent higher than the OECD average. Many imports no longer compete with any local products. Worse, the ETM trade deficit worsened from $20 billion in 1985 to almost $37 billion by 1994. Amongst the imports there is only little evidence of the capital goods component that is necessary to rebuild industry. The conclusion that Bell and other commentators have drawn is that Australia is actually becoming more, not less, dependent on non-manufactured, largely low value‐added exports.

Labor failed to develop an industry policy except on an ad hoc basis for the industrial basket cases. Yet I believe industry policy can be the means for reducing the extent to which adverse economic outcomes are determined by international market forces. Its value is in ensuring the development of a diversified national economy at least partially insulated from the fluctuations in price and demand in world markets. Despite its bleating in recent weeks, the previous government failed to develop an adequate industry policy. The ongoing problem for national economies is to wind up old industries and structurally realign others and to adopt new technologies and retrain the labour force.

Industry policy requires the support of the state apparatus to identify trends and opportunities. The success of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, known as MITI, in Japan shows the advantages to be gained from a national approach to industry policy formulation and implementation. We have only to look to the Asian tigers to see the benefits of such an approach.

MITI is quite small and its personnel are recruited from the brightest and best graduates of the best universities in Japan. The funds it controls are small, about one per cent of government department outlays. Its influence is not in granting large sums to industry. The US grants three times as much, for example, by way of research and development. Industry policy, as practised by MITI, is therefore a government strategy to help important business sectors. This is not a call in any way for a return to the inefficiencies of protectionism that we have had in this country in the past. It is more future oriented and, unlike the industry policypractised in Europe, not so hog-bound by short-term political interests. Japanese industry policy is inherently discriminatory, but of sectors rather than of individual companies.

An important function of Japanese industry policy is to facilitate structural adjustment, helping some industries to grow and others to wind down in a more orderly fashion. It is described as `market conforming', anticipating where markets will be and speeding up adjustments to them.

The Howard government has acted to free up the bureaucratic restrictions on small business, to get rid of industrial employment laws that act as a disincentive to employment and to abandon the many mickey mouse training programs that have been in existence over the last decade. This budget, in continuing the policy to replace the Commonwealth's $10 billion deficit with a surplus by the end of the Howard government's first term, is an important step towards the improvement of national savings, but much remains to be done. We have only started on what is a long road, given the history of what has happened over the last decade or more in Australia.

What I would like to urge is that there must be a national objective, namely, full employment, and that every government program should be tested against whether it is going to achieve that end. The previous government failed this test. It is in the interests of Australia, of all Australians today and of Australians in the future that we cannot afford to fail this test also.

Therefore, in speaking on this appropriation bill, I commend the budget to the House. I believe the steps taken in it, particularly in relation to national savings, are important steps because if the Commonwealth itself can bring its deficit under control and create a surplus it will be making an important step in terms of the long‐term future of Australia. That step is not simply in relation to what the Commonwealth achieves itself but to the signals it sends to the Australian people and the encouragement it gives to them to practise national savings on a scale that is so necessary for the future for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis, Ralph, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make three basic points about the budget. Firstly, it reveals the unambiguous failure of last year's budget to deliver on its economic forecasts. Secondly, it demonstrates, by breaching two key front‐and‐centre election promises, the utter deception of the Australian people by the coalition at the last election. Thirdly, it fails absolutely to deliver on the major claim that the government is making for this budget, which is that it increases savings.

SPEECH.PARA: Expanding on those points, let me say firstly that in last year's budget the government claimed that, despite the contractionary budgetary policies that it was pursuing, it would still achieve substantial economic growth and enough employment growth to reduce unemployment. We argued that, because of the contractionary impact of the budget, the economy would be slowed and unemployment would be likely to be increased. This budget confirms that we were right and the government was wrong. Economic growth and employment growth were both notably less than forecast and unemployment increased, not decreased—at least that is the expectation of the government as revealed in this year's budget for this current financial year.

Let us look at the details. In last year's budget, they forecast that for 1996‐97 we would have growth of real GDP of 3½ per cent. This budget says it will only be 3¼ per cent. They said we would have employment growth of 1½ per cent. This budget says it will be 1¼ per cent. They said we would have an unemployment rate in the June quarter of 8¼ per cent. This budget says it will be 8¾ per cent. Quite clearly, there has been a failure to deliver on the forecasts.

That failure is what we predicted but also, importantly, we should remember that these forecasts were indeed modest. They were less than Labor had been achieving when it was in office. We had been achieving for the previous three years rates of growth of output of over four per cent a year. Employment had been increasing at an average of 2.8 per cent per annum over the previous three years. We had a forecast here for a lousy 1½ per cent, and they could not even achieve that.

Against these outcomes, the Howard government's economic growth and employment forecasts obviously have not been achieved. Even though they were very modest forecasts, it still failed to deliver on them, the result being that we have got an unemployment rate forecast for the end of this financial year—for the June quarter of 1997—which is higher than for the June quarter of 1996 and, indeed, higher than for the June quarter of 1995. There can be no doubt that this budget reveals that the government's key economic forecasts in last year's budget were not obtained, and that the opposition's contention—that the contractionary Costello budget would slow growth and increase unemployment—has been shown to be correct.

The second major point I want to make is that this budget, by breaking two key front‐and‐centre election promises, reveals the coalition's deception of people at the last election. The first one was the promise to boost employment growth. The now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised in his policy launch statement on 18 February 1996 to boost job growth. There was no more central promise he made than that—to boost job growth. To this point in time, we have seen an abysmal failure by the government to deliver on that election promise, and this budget confirms that there is no possibility of this government anywhere near matching Labor's employment growth, let alone boosting growth higher than that level.

Compare the record of the two governments to this point in time. This government has been in office 14 months. In that first 14 months, it has achieved employment growth of 92,000—1.1 per cent. In Labor's last 14 months, employment grew by 263,000 compared with a lousy 92,000 under this government. Our growth: 3.3 per cent compared with their 1.1 per cent. In Labor's last 14 months, we had growth in full‐time employment of 192,000. This government has achieved just 4,000. In male full‐time employment, we had growth of 114,000. This government has reduced male full‐time employment by 16,000 in its first 14 months.

The number of unemployed in our last 14 months decreased by 26,000. Under this government, it has gone up by 35,000. The unemployment rate went down in our last 14 months by 0.6 per cent, from nine per cent to 8.4 per cent. Under this government, it has gone up to 8.7 per cent. The number of long‐term unemployed went down by 56,000 in our last 14 months. In this government's first 14 months, it has gone up 14,000. The teenage unemployment rate went down by 0.7 per cent in our last 14 months. It went up by 1.5 per cent in this government's first 14 months.

What all these figures show is that, far from boosting employment as promised, this government has boosted unemployment. Furthermore, this budget demonstrates that there is no chance whatever that the government will be able to meet its election promise in this term of office. Labor, in its last term of office, increased employment by 733,000 or 9.65 per cent. That is what the Prime Minister promised to beat: he would boost employment growth. He would do better than Labor.

So far, in its first 14 months, this government has achieved only 92,000 additional jobs. So it has got 641,000 additional jobs to create in the next 22 months just to match Labor's additional jobs, and if it wants to match Labor's rate of employment growth—that is, the 9.65 per cent—it would need to create an additional 712,000 jobs in the next 22 months.

This budget demonstrates that the government has no hope whatever of matching Labor's employment growth, let alone surpassing it. Its employment forecasts are for 2¼ per cent employment growth in 1997‐98 and again in 1998‐99. Assuming that these forecast increases were actually achieved and assuming that the rate of growth would commence from now and not July, then in 22 months time—that is, in February 1999—they would have increased employment by a further 351,000. With the 92,000 they have achieved so far, this would mean an increase in employment in this term of office for the Howard government of 443,000 or 5.3 per cent. That 443,000 is 290,000 fewer than Labor achieved in its last term of office. So this government is on track to achieve an employment outcome of 290,000 fewer jobs than were created in Labor's last term of office. Some terrific achievement that is going to be when you finally roll up to the election in February or March—whenever it is—of 1999 and say, `Look at our great achievement. We have increased employment by 443,000, just 290,000 fewer than Labor.' What a pathetic performance that will be! But that is what this government is on track to achieve.

Even if they did a little better than they have forecast, which is highly unlikely given their record, they would still be way behind Labor's achievement. And if they were to match our rate of growth—9.65 per cent—they would need 360,000 more jobs than they are on track to achieve.

This government is falling lamentably short of its promise to boost employment growth. It has, in a major way, decreased employment growth and shows no signs of turning that around. So it is now quite official: this government's most fundamental and central election promise—to boost jobs growth—has been abandoned after only 14 months in office. The budget in fact is a surrender document on employment. It is a total admission of failure to anywhere near matching Labor's employment growth, let alone surpassing it.

As realisation of the crushing failure to match Labor is hitting home, we are seeing the government turn to distractions and excuses. They are turning to things like work for the dole—a parody of their promise to create real jobs—and to excuses like the unfair dismissals legislation. If only we would agree to amend it one more time, that would enable them to create some jobs, ignoring the fact that in the year after the unfair dismissals legislation was introduced by the Labor government—in March of 1994—employment grew by 327,000! It did not stop us creating an awful lot of jobs, so don't rely on that excuse either.

I will turn now to the second breach of election promise, and that is the coalition's promise at the last election to meet the then government's co‐contribution commitment. That commitment was to match employees' contributions to superannuation dollar for dollar up to three per cent of average weekly earnings and, subject to an income test, that would phase the contribution out altogether at twice average weekly earnings.

The now government promised at the last election, unambiguously, to match that—to introduce the co-contribution—and it has clearly not done that as shown by what is in this budget. This was a $4 billion promise, but it was not some minor promise. This was a promise to pay $4 billion per annum when the thing was fully phased in to the working people of Australia—not just to the wage and salary earners but to the self‐employed as well.

It was the largest promise that the coalition made and it was worth substantial money to working men and women. For instance, a worker on average weekly earnings would have been required to contribute three per cent of his pay to his superannuation fund and would have received from the government a matching $1,000 into his superannuation fund. So he put in $1,000 and he got a $1,000 matching payment from the government.

In this budget the promise by the coalition to pay that money is abandoned. Instead, there is a different savings scheme, which costs only half as much as the co‐contribution when fully introduced—that is, $2 billion compared with $4 billion—and which pays a 15 per cent rebate on superannuation contributions up to $3,000 per annum or savings investment income of up to that amount without any means test.

For ordinary workers, this is daylight robbery. The scheme robs them of $2 billion a year in overall funding of the scheme. Secondly, by paying only a 15 per cent rebate instead of dollar for dollar, it robs them of much more than half the original benefit. For instance, for that worker who put $1,000 into his superannuation, he now gets a 15 per cent rebate, which pays him $150 compared with the $1,000 he was going to get under the co‐contribution approach, which we promised to introduce and which the coalition promised to introduce as well. The coalition is now welshing on that promise and robbing this worker of $850 per annum. It is not some minor breach. This is probably the most outrageous breach of election promise that has ever been perpetrated in this country. I cannot remember a $2 billion breach of promise before. That is what this is. In fact, for the workers involved, it is much more than halving it; it is almost taking most of the benefit away.

High income earners, who would have been means tested out of the co‐contribution scheme, can now receive the maximum benefit under this new scheme of $450. An executive on three times the average weekly earnings would have got nothing from the co‐contribution because of the means test, but now that there is no means test he picks up the full $450 while the worker gets screwed for $850. What is being perpetrated on the workers of this country is an outrage. The whole thing is being distorted in so far as it takes away from them anything that does exist and gives it to the higher income earners.

This is made more so by a wider range of investment income qualifying for the rebate. So it includes interest, dividends, rental income, trust income—you can split your income in lots of ways through various trusts; they all pick up the $450—partnership income other than wages and salaries, capital gains, et cetera. The recipients of this type of income will be very largely higher income people. Much of the benefit of the scheme that is now being introduced will go to people whose incomes are well above the cut-off point that would have applied in the co-contribution scheme. So it is biased heavily towards the wealthy.

The coalition promise to the workers of this country that they would pay them $4 billion a year has been totally comprehensively and shamefully abandoned. Instead, they have offered a few peanuts while the wealthy receive bagfuls of macadamias. Those battlers who voted for the coalition, believing their interests would be protected, have every right to be utterly outraged by this government's action in cynically deceiving them into thinking it would pay them what Labor had promised and then ripping them off comprehensively.

This budget fails absolutely to deliver on what it claims to be the central feature of this budget—a boost to savings. This failure to boost national savings stems from two factors. Firstly, the government's failure to cover its new expenditure with sufficient expenditure decreases or tax increases to provide a boost to national savings; instead, it reduces national savings. Secondly, the government's abandonment of the previous government's policy to boost private savings and replace it with a much less effective alternative.

Let me go to the first of those two points. The government claims that its budget measures result in increased national savings but this is not so for the years beyond 1997-98. This is because the major expenditure reduction contained in the budget is the scrapping of the proposed co-contribution for employee superannuation contributions, which was to be phased in from 1998-99. But scrapping that co-contribution does not increase national saving.

To the extent that it is not spent on new measures, it increases public saving but it does not increase national saving because this payment was already going to be totally saved in private savings. Robbing private savings to increase public savings does not increase national savings. This is especially so when, as is the case in this budget, some of these purloined private savings are spent by the government when they are brought into the public sector.

Leaving aside the abandonment of the co-contribution payment, for the years 1998-99, 1999-2000 and 2000-01 the government's budget balance expansion measures—that is, new expenditure measures and revenue reduction measures—exceed the budget balance reduction measures, that is, the expenditure reduction and revenue increasing measures. It exceeds them by $197 million in 1998-99, by $1,755 million in 1999-2000 and by $2,887 million in 2000-01.

BREAK.PARA: The effect of this budget in those three years is to reduce national savings. The budget shows an increase in public savings but only by stealing from what was earmarked as private savings—that is, the co-contribution. The government will spend some of those earmarked savings, resulting in a reduction in total national savings.

The second reason for reduced national savings is, as I said, the abandonment of the previous government's policy to boost private savings through superannuation and to replace it with a less effective alternative. Labor's scheme had award superannuation, the superannuation guarantee and then the compulsory employee contributions and the government co-contribution. According to the retirement income modelling task force, the effect of this scheme on national savings was to increase it by 2.5 per cent of GDP by 2001-02 and by 4.2 per cent of GDP by 2020.

What this government has done is maintained the award superannuation guarantee reluctantly, scrapped the rest of it, brought in the rebate scheme and made some changes to superannuation arrangements. The combined effect of the government's new package, according to the budget statement Savings: choice and incentive, is said to be that national savings will be increased by 1.5 per cent of GDP by 2001-02. That is compared with Labor's 2.5 per cent—1.1 per cent of GDP less saving. By the year 2020 it will have a 3.6 per cent increase in saving compared to Labor's 4.2. This is a policy to reduce national savings over what they would have been if they had stuck with Labor's policy, as they promised to do.

This is the most extraordinary situation. You have a government breaking an absolutely central major election promise and then saying, `Having broken that we are going to boost national savings.' But what they are doing is reducing savings and they are admitting it in the document Savings: choice and incentive. It is all in there. The overall effect of it is to get a less savings boost than you would have got from Labor's program. This is a government that is reducing national savings.

We get no figure in there for what this rebate scheme is going to do because everyone knows this rebate scheme is a farce in terms of increasing savings. There is no estimate in there for that one alone. Treasury has said in reviewing the OECD report Taxation and household savings, which came out in November 1994, that there was no likelihood of increased savings. That OECD report said:

Treasury finds no clear evidence that cutting taxes on investment income leads to increased saving either by the household sector in isolation or at the level of the national economy after taking into account the effect of the revenue cost of tax breaks.

That is how Treasury summarised it in its Economic Roundup of summer 1995. Treasury said to this government that these schemes will not work. They have gone ahead with it anyway. They cannot publish a savings boost in their document because they know there isn't any. In fact, most likely it is going to reduce savings. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We have listened for the last 20 minutes or so to the emotional ravings of a person who suggested that we, this current government, should look to what the past government—the government resoundly defeated at the last election—did for jobs and savings. Therefore, I have to remind the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) just what they did for people who genuinely wanted to work who were out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: In my electorate of Murray I had decent young men wanting real work, wanting training to get that real work, put in the back of utes and trucks and driven out to forests under LEAP schemes—and God knows what else they were called at the time—supposedly to be trained as forestry type workers. In fact, they were to dig and install cattle grids, only one per day, and there were seven or eight people there to do it. They were not supervised. They did not get information or training on how to install cattle grids, not that that is a very long-term job prospect anyway. All they got was colds. They went back sick. Unfortunately, that is what Labor did to young people who genuinely wanted to work and who wanted to have access to training. I notice that the member for Gellibrand is leaving the chamber. I do not doubt for a minute that he would want to stay.

I am sure that too many people remember what they did in the previous 13 years with our unemployed: they failed to give them genuine work opportunities. What happened is that the books were cooked. There was more frantic book cooking as the election approached in 1996. More of these mickey mouse schemes were brought on. More of the people from the jobless queues were siphoned off into numerous programs and then called trainees, so the statistics looked better. But the outcomes for those people were just the same. It was a cruel and callous thing to do.

You were defeated at the last election because the country wants jobs for its people. We do not pretend for a moment that the work for the dole scheme is anything to do with creating work for young people that will be ongoing. What we talk about with work for the dole is giving young people in particular an experience of what it is like to contribute back to the communities that are, through their taxes, paying for their unemployment entitlements. We are giving young people a sense of what it is like to meet with others, to get back into the routine of work and to, perhaps, experience work for the first time. We are calling it work for the dole, and that is what the public wants to call it.

There are so many communities and non-profit organisations out there waiting to take up these younger unemployed people to give them that chance. But we are not pretending for a minute that that is how we are going to lower the unemployment statistics in this country. We are not callous and we will not pretend like Labor did for 13 years. So let us put that on the record and straighten it all up.

Let me talk about what our budget does. We now, as a nation, understand what it is like to be on the rollercoasters of massive bust and boom inflationary spirals that go up and down and eat into people's savings so that there is no sense of stability over time. What we have done in this budget is consolidate the principles established in our first year when we responded to the calls of the people and determined that Australia would once again be a nation that pays its own way. We committed ourselves to creating an economic environment of decades of low interest rates for people to borrow to build their homes and businesses and low inflation rates.

Last year's budget was tough, but in every way it was widely regarded as fair. We took a scalpel to government expenditure. We delivered substantial cuts, but we retained essential services, and we were fair. This year we have continued to deliver, particularly in ways that address some of the fundamental inequalities in Australian society.

I represent a rural community. For the 13 years of Labor, rural communities understood that they were out of sight and out of mind. The standards of the physical and social infrastructure in rural areas were run‐down. The inequalities in access to health services for country people really could not and cannot be tolerated any further. The unequal outcomes when it comes to access to higher education for rural people when compared to urban counterparts cannot continue to be tolerated.

I am also talking about the provision of services that are essential to ensure that we can compete in the cutthroat world of international agribusiness trade, which is of course a building block of all regional communities. We must have world best quarantine services, world best anti-dumping authorities that work and basic research capabilities or we cannot continue to compete in the highly competitive international agribusiness arenas.

The previous government ignored rural communities. Rural communities overwhelmingly reject Labor governments at each election, and the last election was no different. However, this government understands that Australians regard fair play and equality of opportunity as necessary for maximising people's independence and ensuring that they have a quality of life that is at least as good as, if not better than, that of the earlier generations. To do that, they need to have a sound economy.

Let us begin with the provision of health services and what this government, through this last budget and the budget before, has provided to ensure that an electorate like Murray does not fall further behind in offer ing basic health services to the newborn, children, adults and the elderly.

There seems to be some 4,000 too many doctors in Australian cities, but there are some 500 too few in country areas. In the country, as compared with the city, the chance of dying of heart disease is 18 per cent higher, the chance of dying of a stroke is 29 per cent higher and the chance of dying of pneumonia or influenza is at least 80 per cent higher. Death from respiratory diseases and its causes is 71 per cent higher and death from genito‐urinary causes is 86 per cent higher. Rural children are more prone to ailments, with a death rate, for example, among girls some 15 per cent higher than for girls in the city. Of course we all know about the sad facts of rural youth suicide rates.

Only yesterday I was very proud to announce that this government in this last budget has created six new departments of rural health that are to be distributed around Australia. In the Goulburn Valley, in the heart of the Murray electorate, we will see one of those departments of rural health established. Some $500,000 is to be expended in this financial year, with a further $1.5 million in the next and following financial years.

This new initiative will ensure that some of these metropolitan doctors will come and train in rural areas. They will experience rural life; they will train to deal with the different health issues that socioeconomic groups in country areas present with. We hope that when they come to train in Shepparton they will find that not only is their career prospect enhanced if they choose to stay in rural areas but so is their quality of life. This is an initiative that has been identified already throughout Australia as likely to make a substantial impact in future years.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report by Sir Ronald Wilson, as this is the first opportunity I have had to do so. My starting point for deliberation of this report is that the author tells us that it is not an `intellectual document'; it is `from the heart'. What this means, of course, is that the report is not constrained by fact or by evidence. In passing, it must be said that such a base is not an appropriate methodology for any government consideration or the running of a country.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is also greatly flawed in other ways. For instance, Ronald Wilson seems mainly to have interviewed the clients who were sent to him by the Aboriginal Legal Service, and he has made no attempt to interview those people who refused to testify because they knew that in their case it was the act of being taken away that saved their lives.

It is always easy on an issue such as this to trot out the highly emotional examples, as the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) did in his predictably sanctimonious contribution. I remember the recent words of

Isobel Lynnot who is now 95‐years‐old. She, along with her sister, were the first children to be taken to Beagle Bay, a Catholic mission, in 1909. Isobel's father was white and, when he died, her mother implored the local police officer to take her children as they would `otherwise surely die'. Isobel remembers Beagle Bay very warmly. `The nuns were very good to us,' she said. `They gave us clean clothes, taught us to read and write and to play musical instruments. They taught us to sew and to dance.' She has only gratitude for her deliverance.

Another hero of mine is Pearl Hamaguchi, a woman who, being an Aboriginal Asian, endured a far harder life than that of white half‐caste children. Pearl remembers all that she endured—but she does not dwell on it. She has made a name for herself. She, her Japanese husband and her family are highly regarded in Broome where they live. I think it is very, very important that people understand this: here is a person who knew and endured all those things, and triumphed. I know many cases where people have triumphed over disability, and I think theirs is just such testimony. I must say that Pearl Hamaguchi is a woman whom I admire greatly. Her example is one for the whole of society. She is a role model for all, not just for Aboriginal people.

I must take issue with the Governor-General. The Governor-General in the Mabo report spoke of our `unutterable shame'—not a legal term, but certainly words he could recognise as being ones from which he could dissociate himself. The recent apology given by Holy Billy I think was highly inappropriate.

—You obviously recognise the gentleman, Mr Speaker.
—I do not want an interplay of conversation. I want you to respect the conventions of the House, or resume your seat.
—If you let me get on with it, I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to condemn the actions of Telstra in seeking to ram through a proposal to deploy aerial broadband communications cable in Mornington and Mount Eliza, just weeks before the controls on cable deployment are substantially upgraded. Some of the 3,800 affected households in Mornington and Mount Eliza learnt just over a week ago that Telstra intended to commence the deployment of broadband cabling in the dying days of the revised telecommunications national code. Telstra plans to aerially deploy its cabling in 88 per cent of the Mount Eliza neighbourhoods and 75 per cent of the Mornington area covered by this ill‐conceived proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: With a mere few days notice, a public meeting was held on 21 May 1997 to inform residents from Mount Eliza and Mornington of Telstra's plans. An almost unanimous motion from the meeting called on Telstra to defer its activities until after June 30 to enable proper consultation to take place with the local community and the Mornington Peninsular Shire Council. At the information meeting, Telstra representatives were unable to provide costings on undergrounding alternatives, or to discuss cooperative proposals to reduce the impact of cabling on neighbourhood amenity as has been negotiated between the City of Booroondara and Optus. Not only is Telstra failing to comply with the provisions of the revised code, it is behaving as if `telco thuggery' is a way of enhancing consumer loyalty. Here is why.

Both Telstra and Optus advised me that they only had cabling plans for the Frankston city area and not into the Mornington Peninsular Shire area during round table discussions held on 24 and 30 September last year. Telstra spoke in terms of `keeping pace with its competitor' which involved expected work in the Frankston area this year. Optus has carried through this position. Telstra now claims that `competitive pressures' are behind its plans to go south of the Frankston city area.

I reject Telstra's argument of so-called competitive pressures as Optus is not in the area concerned, households already have telephony services, pay TV is available through other delivery systems, and current Telstra technology provides access to available on‐line services. The Telstra representatives may have let out of the bag the real source of pressure to deploy the cable when advising the public meeting at Mornington that `Telstra has a business obligation to Foxtel to roll out'.

For Mornington residents, Telstra appears to want to impose on them metropolitan technology, deployed with inner city sensitivity, while denying Mornington people access to metropolitan prices because the area concerned is outside the Melbourne 039 call zone. A reasonable opportunity has not been provided for the community to work through Telstra's proposals and certainly not to engage in the sort of substantive dialogue provided for by the post‐July 1 regulatory regime. No-one wants to deny the local community new technology. But there is no good reason for Telstra's indecent haste to avoid genuine consultation with the neighbourhoods concerned and the local council.

Telstra's activities are opportunistic. Telstra knows that the code it is trying to exploit would not still exist if the previous Labor government had not locked in the code until 30 June this year as part of the licence deal with Optus. Telstra is being heavy-handed in using this small window of opportunity to roll out aerial cable in Mornington and Mount Eliza.

I have been told by Telstra that `commercial concerns' mean that a delay is not on. Genuine consultation and dialogue with the local communities is being denied. A thoughtful and customer focused Telstra would provide a proper opportunity for the local community to work through its plans and to fully explore deployment alternatives in conjunction with the local council.

There is no good reason why the people I represent in Mornington and Mount Eliza should be denied this opportunity. Working through Telstra's plans without the immunity carriers have from state and planning environment laws would ensure that the proper consultation and dialogue occurs between the Mornington Peninsula Shire Council, Telstra and its Mornington and Mount Eliza customers. I call on Telstra to be more reasonable in its behaviour towards Mornington and Mount Eliza residents in regard to its deployment of broadband cabling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise following the contribution of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) at this stage more in sorrow than in anger that a representative of the Australian people could be so unfeeling in the way in which he has responded to the report produced by Sir Ronald Wilson. To suggest that the report is not supported by fact and evidence is clearly sheer nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, lest it be thought that we are talking about times long in the past or times long distant, let me refer to a few of the cases that are produced as evidence in the report that come from your and my home state of Victoria. In fact, some of them come from the leafy suburbs of Balwyn, Blackburn South and Kew. The case of Paul, in confidential submission 133, states:

I was born in May 1964. My Mother and I lived together within an inner suburb of Melbourne. At the age of five and a half months, both my Mother and I became ill. My Mother took me to the Royal Children's Hospital, where I was admitted.

Upon my recovery, the Social Welfare Department . . . persuaded my Mother to board me into St Gabriel's Babies' Home in Balwyn . . . just until Mum regained her health. If only Mum could've known the secret, deceitful agenda of the State welfare system that was about to be put into motion—18 years of forced separation between a loving mother and her son.
That is a very recent situation, Mr Speaker, I am sure you would agree, dealing with very familiar surroundings to you and me.
Confidential evidence 139, Victoria, tells of a person removed in 1967. The witness's mother died shortly after being reunited. The witness states:

When I first met my mother—when I was 14—she wasn't what they said she was. They made her sound like she was stupid, you know, they made her sound so bad. And when I saw her she was so beautiful. Mum said, `My baby's been crying' and she walked into the room and . . . my mother and we hugged . . . That was my first feeling of love . . .
Confidential evidence 139, Victoria, states:
I got told my Aboriginality when I got whipped and they'd say, `You Abo, you nigger'. This was the only time I got told my Aboriginality.
Confidential evidence 163, Victoria, states:

And for them to say she [mother] neglected us! I was neglected when I was in this government joint down here. I didn't end up 15 days in a hospital bed [with bronchitis] when I was with me mum and dad.
Confidential evidence 214, Victoria, states:

I ran away because my foster father used to tamper with me and I'd just had enough. I went to the police but they didn't believe me. So she [foster mother] just thought I was a wild child and she put me in one of those hostels and none of them believed me—I was the liar. So I've never talked about it to anyone. I don't go about telling lies, especially big lies like that.
These are cases of very contemporary nature in Australia. They are not from remote parts of this country. They are from Melbourne primarily, Mr Speaker, your home town and mine.

They are situations where, in the words of Sir William Deane—referred to in unacceptably derogatory terms by the member for Kalgoorlie and in similarly outrageous terms in the media tonight by the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey)—we as Australians ought to feel `unutterable shame' in the dealings with our Aboriginal citizens.

I believe this report to parliament ought to be dealt with against that background. It is an emotional debate. The issues are inevitably highly emotionally charged, but they deserve the detailed attention of this country in order for this country to really fulfil its potential of being a great and truly just nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elson, Kay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate tonight to acknowledge and bring to the attention of the parliament the extraordinary efforts of 14 young women in my electorate. Young people are the subject of much debate in this House, as well they should be: they are our most precious, valuable resource as a nation. Unfortunately, the media in this country very often focus on negative stories about today's youth rather than the many positive achievements that our young people are making today.

SPEECH.PARA: This fuels the misconception in some parts of the community that today's generation are lazy, uncooperative or just do not care about the communities in which they live. Nothing could be further from the truth, especially for the 14 young women I was pleased to meet last Saturday night.

In the past four months, these 14 young achievers aged between 17 and 22 have worked tirelessly to raise more than $45,000 for local charities as part of the Beenleigh Cane Festival—$45,000 in just four months is an incredible achievement in anyone's measures. It is a lot of raffle tickets and a lot of car washing.

I am pleased to be able to recognise their achievements in this place and would like to make special mention of each of these young people: Victoria Senden, Judith Andrews, Rita Brehmer, Faith Williams, Rebecca Engwicht, Nicole Lloyd, Karyn Oleinik, Diana Dewey, Michell Game, Dani‐Lee Menzies, Tonya Gilbert, Sharyn Burns, Anita Blackmur, who was awarded the festival title for her hard work, and Nicole Newberry, who was the top fund‐raiser. She deserves special congratulations for her remarkable effort.

The Beenleigh Cane Festival is truly a community based event with 15,000 people in attendance at the parade. These young women give a great deal of themselves to help promote our local area. They are a credit to themselves and a heartening example of the next generation for all of us. I would also like to mention the cane quest coordinator, Mrs Anne Hackwood, who helped these young people to achieve their goals. The most important point is that the local Police Citizens Youth Club, Rural Fire Brigade, Blue Nurses and the Air/Sea Rescue will be the beneficiaries of the girls' efforts. Which really means that the whole community are the beneficiaries.
