SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr ADAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —The report Bringing them home had some airing in the chamber today—although it was not enough and it went in a roundabout way. I would like to touch on the report this evening. This report does not just deal with areas in the outback of Australia or further out where we see the indigenous people today; it also deals with how we treated the indigenous people in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I quote from page 91, dealing with policies and practices:

BREAK.PARA: The forcible removal of Indigenous children from their families occurred during two periods in Tasmania. The first commenced with the European occupation of Van Dieman's Land (as Tasmania was called until 1856) in 1808 and lasted until the middle of the nineteenth century. The second commenced in the 1930s with the forcible removal of Indigenous children from Cape Barren Island under general child welfare legislation and continues into the present.
I would like to quote also some of the evidence that is in this report. The following comes from a woman in Tasmania who was removed when she was 18 months old:

I wasn't allowed to go to the same school where my natural siblings were attending school. I knew my siblings' names but I didn't know what they looked like. I was told not to contact my natural family . . . My foster family and the Welfare Officer said to me that I shouldn't get in touch with my natural family because they were not `any good'.
I quote another paragraph:

We seemed to have a lonely existence at the Home. They had children there who were under Legacy and things like that. Sadly, we didn't have any relatives to come and see us and, you know, we used to get a bit upset when other children could have relatives come, their mothers, and bring them toys and things, perhaps some fruit.
Those are the words of a man who was removed from his grandmother's care from Cape Barren Island in the 1930s. Another person said:

I remember when I was very young though, that there was a big thing going around the community then that the government wanted to get the people off the island. I can remember them saying, `Well, I'm not going'. And next thing you see families going off. And one of the ladies . . . she had a little girl out of wedlock, and the welfare came in and threatened her. They said to her she either had to marry the father of that baby or they would come and take the child, so she married. She was very young, and she married.
A man from Tasmania said:

Welfare just took the lot, no reason—just took us. They took mum and dad to court here for no reason. But there was no neglect. We was happy kids, you know. We just—we lived in the bush all our lives. Dad never believed in bringing his family to the city, he just loved the bush and that's where we stayed. We were always fed and happy there but I suppose they were looking for this other family and when they came to take them they just decided, `Well, we'll take these as well.'

As I said, this comes from evidence from Tasmania of the experiences of the 1930s and 1940s of some of the indigenous people. When Sir Ronald Wilson launched this report, he asked that all Australians read it with an open mind and an open heart. I certainly hope that all Australians do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Draper, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Major events at the turn of the century have focused our attention on the Australian identity. When Sydney hosts the 2000 Olympics and we celebrate the centenary of Federation in 2001, all Australians will feel a sense of pride in their nation and a sense of solid achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: Many constituents in my electorate of Makin have suggested to me that pride in our country and in its history and institutions should be encouraged not just when we host a major event or celebrate a date of historical significance but in our everyday lives. The Modbury/Golden Grove Apex Club recently proposed the establishment of a national citizenship project to promote pride in our national identity via the `Apex Aussie Proud' project.

Mr David Reed, from the Modbury/Golden Grove Apex Club, stated that the purpose of the project would be to foster national pride and identity. The club stressed, as has the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the importance of discussing and debating issues about our national identity in a tolerant and well‐reasoned manner. We should not use discussion about our history and national identity to divide our nation.

A national citizenship project, as proposed by the Modbury/Golden Grove Apex Club, would have three phases including: recognition of our flag, promotion of the national anthem, promotion of multicultural Australia—which is inclusive of our indigenous Australians—and promotion of Australian history and our future.

I am delighted to inform those members who may not be aware that this process has already begun with the recent launch by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Bruce Scott MP, of the commemorative program entitled `Their Service—Our Heritage'. This is a four‐year program designed to honour the sacrifice and service of Australia's veterans. As a member of the government committee on health, family services and veterans' affairs I am very proud to be a part of a government which is doing so much to honour those who fought to defend the liberties we now enjoy.

We all owe a debt to those men and women who served their country during time of war. This program will enable the entire Australian community to honour their contribution to the protection of our national independence and individual liberty. As a part of this initiative I am pleased to see that there will be major sponsorship of the national history challenge for school students and the provision of kits to all schools to assist with the commemoration of Anzac Day.

The Australian War Memorial will also present a travelling exhibition that will visit local communities around Australia, telling the history of our war effort and the heroism of our veterans. This and many other projects under the banner `Their Service—Our Heritage' will lead to a greater understanding of the history and the sacrifice made by the soldiers on the battlefield and by those who kept the home fires burning.

We need to ensure that all Australians have access to information about the history of Australia. We can start by ensuring that history is taught to all students and that they have a sound grasp of the fundamental origins and importance of Australia's institutions. This includes the contribution to our culture and nation by indigenous Australians so that there will be greater understanding of the need for reconciliation. This will also lead to a greater level of informed debate and discussion and help to cement in our society that spirit of tolerance that we all prize.

The arrival and integration of peoples from many different nations into the Australian community has been one of the great success stories of our history. Australia is one of the most tolerant societies in the world and we should highlight this fact and not dwell too much on the isolated incidents where some members of our community let us all down with their ill‐chosen remarks.

BREAK.PARA: The values we share reflect the true nature of the Australian community. We would do well at this time to remember the very many good things that unite us and which have helped to make this country such a great place in which to live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Some little while ago, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) tabled in this House the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families, which is entitled Bringing them home . Sir Ronald Wilson, the chairman of that inquiry, has spoken very eloquently about what that inquiry saw and heard, particularly from the people that they interviewed and the evidence that they received.

SPEECH.PARA: I think any person who reads this report cannot help being moved by it. Most Australians would have a very good idea of what happened in America with regard to the racism that occurred in the first half of this century, but very few of us would have known about the terrible things that happened in our own country. Sir Ronald Wilson's report makes this very clear. He said he thought that Australians should read this report with an open mind and an open heart.

I saw on the television tonight the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) saying that he thought all Australians should read this report. While the government bookshop sells copies of this report for a fair bit of money, I think it is very important that I read into the record the experiences of some of the people mentioned in the report.

I would like to talk about John, who was removed from his family as an infant in the 1940s. He spent his first years in Bomaderry Children's Home at Nowra. At 10, he was transferred to the Kinchela home. John says:

We didn't have a clue where we came from. We thought the Sisters were our parents. They didn't tell anybody—any of the kids—where they came from. Babies were coming in nearly every day. Some kids came in at two, three, four days old—not months—but days. They were just placed in the home and it was run by Christian women and all the kids thought it was one big family. We didn't know what it meant by `parents' cause we didn't have parents and we thought those women were our mothers.

I was definitely not told that I was Aboriginal. What the Sisters told us was that we had to be white. It was drummed into our heads that we were white. It didn't matter what shade you were. We thought we were white. They said you can't talk to any of them coloured people because you're white.

I can't remember anyone from the welfare coming there. If they did I can't remember . . . We hardly saw any visitors whatsoever. None of the other kids had visits from their parents. No visits from family. The worst part is, we didn't know we had a family.

When you got to a certain age—like I got to be 10 years old . . . they just told us we were going on a train trip . . . We all lined up with our little ports . . . with a bible inside. That's all that was in the ports, see. We really treasured that—we thought it was a good thing that we had something . . . the old man from La Perouse took us from Sydney—well actually from Bomaderry to Kinchela Boys' Home. That's when our problems really started—you know!

This is where we learned that we weren't white. First of all they took you in through these iron gates and took our little ports . . . off us. Stick it in the fire with your little bible inside. They took us around to a room and shaved our hair off . . . They gave you your clothes and stamped a number on them . . . They never called you by your name; they called you by your number. That number was stamped on everything.

If we answered an attendant back we were `sent up the line'. Now I don't know if you can imagine, 79 boys punching the hell out of you—just knuckling you. Even your brother, your cousin. They had to—if they didn't do it, they were sent up the line. When the boys who had broken ribs or broken noses—they'd have to pick you up and carry you right through to the last bloke. Now that didn't happen once—that happened every day.
Before I went to Kinchela, they used to use the cat‐o'‐nine‐tails on the boys instead of being sent up the line. This was in the 30s and early 40s.
I interrupt there to say that that was the 1930s and 1940s. John continues:

Kinchela was a place where they thought you were animals. You know it was like a place where they go around and kick us like a dog . . . It was just like a prison. Truthfully, there were boys having sex with boys . . . But these other dirty mongrels didn't care. We had a manager who was sent to prison because he was doing it to a lot of the boys, sexual abuse.
This is disgraceful. (Time expired)

Mr Beazley to move:
That:

(a) recalling the Australian people's overwhelming decision in the 1967 Referendum to confer upon the Commonwealth Parliament responsibility for enhancement of the rights and well being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(b) reaffirming the abhorrence of racism shared by the Australian people and their Federal and State Governments;

(c) reaffirming Australia's recognition of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the International Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide and the International Convention on the Prevention of All Forms of Racial Discrimination;
(d) recalling the Parliament's commitment in October 1996 to the principles of racial tolerance; and
(e) recognising the profound economic and social disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—
this House:

(1) affirms that the tabling of "Bringing them Home", the Report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from their Families, presents the nation with an unprecedented historical opportunity to render justice and restitution to Indigenous Australians, for the good of all Australians;

(2) acknowledges the immense trauma inflicted upon the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples of Australia as a result of the separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children from their families under past government policies in place from before the time of Federation until the early 1970s;
(3) affirms that these racially discriminatory policies and their continuing consequences are a matter of national shame;
(4) affirms that current and future Federal and State governments are responsible for assisting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to rectify the ongoing effects of those policies;
(5) affirms its commitment to a just and proper settlement of the grievances of people adversely affected by those policies; and
on behalf of the nation—
(6) unreservedly apologises to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for the separation policies;

(7) calls upon Federal and State governments to establish, in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, appropriate processes to provide compensation and restitution, including assistance for the reunification of families and counselling services;

(8) calls on the Federal Government and State governments to establish appropriate education programs to enhance community awareness of the history and continuing consequences of past practices and policies of racial discrimination; and

(9) calls upon the Federal Government to declare a National Day in recognition and remembrance of the great suffering which flowed from the separation policies, and to affirm our nation's commitment to justice for Indigenous Australians, today and for the future.

TITLE.XREF: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that we discuss this package of bills together. Essentially one matter is being dealt with and the proper parliamentary processes require it to be considered in a package of legislation. The opposition will be supporting the package of legislation and the government amendment, of which we have been advised and which will be formally considered in the consideration in detail stage.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation concerns the NICNAS—the industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme—that has been developed over the last decade. It is a worthwhile program for the improvement of the occupational health and safety of Australian men and women at work and as such it has had, and deserves, the bipartisan support of everybody in the parliament. We are talking about setting up proper processes for ensuring that these chemicals, which are necessarily used in the proper process of important production, are safe and are used safely, and that proper arrangements are put in place for industrial access and their use.

It is therefore appropriate that on this occasion we are in a position to respond positively to the government's initiative, which is really only in small part a variation from an initiative considered by the previous government, and which will implement a decision formulated by the previous government, concerning cost recovery in the industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme.

Under this scheme, all new industrial chemicals are assessed before their importation or manufacture so that recommendations about appropriate safeguards can be made before their use. Chemicals already in use and causing concern can be selected for assessment as priority existing chemicals. In total, over 700 industrial chemicals have been assessed in the six years NICNAS has been in operation.

The real purpose of this package is to replace the current cost recovery arrangements for funding the assessment of existing industrial chemicals with an industry based charge, which is another nice way of saying a tax. This government has a record for elegantly saying it is going to impose a tax without using the word `tax'. In this instance it is not something we disagree with at all, but if there were a euphemism contest the government would definitely win.

I think the move to full cost recovery is appropriate. I will say something briefly in a moment about a method but there is no question about the principle. It was decided in the context of the 1994‐95 budget of the previous government to move to full cost recovery, so there is no argument of principle about it. Nor is there any concern regarding the consequential amendments which flow from the need to ensure the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission's administration of the scheme and that the moneys are properly collected in accordance with the constitution and properly applied to the purposes of this scheme.

As I indicated, it was decided in the context of the 1994‐95 budget to move NICNAS to full cost recovery in the 1996‐97 financial year, aligning it with the cost recovery arrangements applying to agricultural and veterinary chemicals. There were reports about both the implications of that move by the so‐called Gwynne report and the mechanisms to achieve full cost recovery conducted by Access Economics. When you put all that material together, it certainly leads to the conclusion that the principle that this is a scheme that should operate on the basis of full cost recovery is appropriate, and the timing and the consequential amendments are quite adequate.

From the opposition's point of view we are relaxed about supporting these proposals. I just want to make two qualifications. They do not in any way constitute opposition; they constitute reservations to some extent caused by the lack of information. The government has been very cooperative in briefing us, but in opposition the access to information is more limited than in government. So I want to flag these two things while not in any way qualifying our support for the package and the amendment.

I am not convinced at this stage that, had we been implementing the decision of 1994‐95 ourselves, we would have gone down this route of cost recovery. We would have pursued cost recovery; I am not sure that this mechanism—with registration and a sort of two‐tier system—is the one we would have used. I have some qualification about that, but it is not an unfair or unreasonable proposal. The government has given it consideration. Its arguments for putting it forward are reasonable, and I have no quibble at this point with its rights to proceed in the way that it wishes to pursue cost recovery. As long as it does not come into fundamental conflict of principle, then the mechanism it chooses is essentially an administrative matter for it.

I did have a discussion with the officers of the department about the other reservation I have. I understand their argument and I do not have an alternative to put forward. But this reservation, which is more substantive than that about funding, is about the way in which the bill deals with the so‐called small quantities matter. I do not want to debate that in detail. People who are interested will know what I am referring to, and people who wish to research it will find it adequately covered in the explanatory memorandum. I simply want to say that that is the operative reservation I have.

The officers have put the explanation of why the government has proceeded in this way to me. I understand that point and I certainly do not intend at this stage to propose any amendment. It would take a lot more resources and independent research capacity to be able to develop an alternative, and this proposal may work very well. I would be delighted to find that my reservations are unfounded.

Overall, this is a package which we support. It implements a principle that the previous government had proposed. I notice, and I think this is appropriate, that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) said in his second reading speech that he has established what he called a non‐statutory industry consultative committee. I do not know in full its composition and I hope it is representative. But the point I want to make is not about that—I think it is appropriate that the minister has a consultative committee. I hope that if, as is referred to in the second reading, it makes recommendations for improvements to the scheme then those recommendations will be public or at least available to the industry, to employees and their organisations, and to the parliament.

The government has indicated to us that they intend to move, and they have distributed, a minor amendment. The opposition has no problem with that minor amendment; we understand its purpose and we support it. If the scheme is going to proceed, that amendment is necessary to make its operation proper and appropriate in accordance with the management of public moneys, so we have no problem with it. We will therefore be supporting this package of legislation and the government amendment through the Main Committee and when they return to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to participate in this cognate debate involving the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill 1997. It is good to hear the contribution of the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) in that he has basically signalled that the opposition supports the measure, but with some reservations.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, in matters of any nature that come before the House, one would be foolish to say that there are not some reservations about measures that are introduced, particularly about a measure that is basically moving in a different direction from what has been in the past. Therefore, we have to tread somewhat warily at times, particularly in an area like this, to ensure that ultimately the best result will be achieved not only for the consumers and for the workers who have to work with the chemicals but also for the industry, the marketing industry, research and development and so forth.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Canberra was a little uncharitable in his comment about euphemisms. Of course, if one is to enter into that debate, members of the previous government were past masters of the art of euphemisms.

The purpose of the bill is basically to bring into line an overall government philosophy of user pays, which is one I thoroughly endorse. Using chemicals in modern society is, some would say, a necessary hazard. So, consistent with modern trends, schemes need to encourage less hazardous chemicals entering the market. This bill addresses the need to provide a more effective assessment of new and existing chemicals. Constant development of new chemicals requires more cost-effective measures for that assessment.

The bill follows the recommendations of the Gwynne report involving the facilitating of movement to full cost recovery and improvement in the effectiveness of the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme, known as NICNAS. The scheme encourages a user pays philosophy, which I have already referred to and which characterises the government's general philosophy across a wide number of areas. It is a responsible budgetary measure in that context. It brings the scheme into line with comparable regulatory authorities such as the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals.

It should be noted in passing that in relation to constituent problems that I have encountered involving small businesses and the NRAAVC, it is important in an area which is aligned to that sort of regulatory authority to ensure that the scheme will work effectively and will not be a vehicle to discourage small businesses in their trading activity. The national registration authority has, unfortunately, in the past not been all that helpful, particularly to small businesses. This is not the place to go into that, but I do have some reservations about the operation of the labelling scheme that was brought in by the previous Labor government.

The charging mechanism for cost recovery for existing chemicals will bring program efficiencies and enable a variety of assessment approaches to be implemented, including the assessment of groups of chemicals and safer substitutes. The small businesses in my electorate are aware of the demanding needs of the public for safer chemicals and the overall strategy of the bill will assist these businesses to keep pace with a much more environmentally concerned consumer market.

More specifically, for new chemicals in the Australian inventory of chemical substances, the director will be able to remove chemicals wrongly included and add details of trade name products, making the inventory more accurate for users. An amendment adds additional exemption for research and development chemicals introduced solely in the course of a program of research, development or analysis, provided certain safeguards are met.

An additional exemption eliminates the need for notification and assessment for new chemicals introduced in quantities of less than 10 kilograms per year where no risk to occupational health and safety is involved, or any environmental risks are involved. This will particularly assist the cosmetic industry in making it more competitive. That industry is a developing one in this country and needs to be encouraged.

A further amendment permits the director to expedite new industrial chemicals within 28 days, pending completion of an assessment report, if the chemical is not hazardous or dangerous. Other amendments streamline assessment reports, remove the need for duplicate assessments, allow existing assessments to be extended to cover subsequent importers and for specific reports from an approved foreign scheme to be used. All of these will ultimately make for greater efficiency.

In relation to existing chemicals, proposals from the 1994 evaluation report on the existing chemicals program are being implemented. Information about the use and introduction of chemicals will be more readily available and there will be some cross flow of information about chemicals prior to their declaration as priority existing chemicals—PECs.

The further amendments in relation to the application for early introduction for non‐hazardous chemicals will facilitate the entry into Australia of new industrial chemicals that are considered to be non‐hazardous. In many cases, these new chemicals will replace older, hazardous chemicals. This is a very good system because it allows for faster replacement of hazardous chemicals and, as has been said by the minister, NICNAS has operated on partial cost recovery since its inception. This bill moves, of course, to full cost recovery. The current scheme for existing chemicals does not result in fair cost sharing in the industry and the 1995 review said it was an unworkable scheme.

A company registration will replace the current fee collecting mechanism. A new register called the Register of Industrial Chemical Introducers will mean that all persons who introduce industrial chemicals with the total value of more than half a million dollars will be required to register and pay a charge assessed at $1,200 if the value is between the range of $0.5 million and $5 million. The scale of charges goes up depending on the value of introduced chemicals.

In summary, as I have said before, this scheme will ensure that the industry is more cost efficient. It will encourage research and development. It will reduce the reliance on hazardous chemicals and ultimately will encourage, in my view, small businesses to provide products that the market—and particularly consumers—are seeking. The environment will be spared in the process from the extra dangers which an unbridled chemical industry would produce in a society increasingly concerned about chemical waste.

Most of all, given that many workers in my electorate are working with chemicals in the course of their employment in engineering and other workshops where the use of chemicals is fairly widespread, it is important to ensure that workers and their families are protected from hazardous chemicals. I believe that this process will assist in eliminating older, hazardous chemicals and bring with it the more modern and environmentally friendly chemicals, thus protecting workers and their families from unnecessary hazards. Having regard to comments that I have made and those that relate to the overall philosophy and direction of the bill, I support this measure and commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my job this morning to represent the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) in the debate on the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill and cognate bills, and to sum up in the Main Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme—NICNAS, as it is termed—was established in 1989 to assess the health and environment risks of all new industrial chemicals and selected existing chemicals. In total, over 700 industrial chemicals have been assessed in the six years that NICNAS has been in operation. NICNAS has operated on partial cost recovery since its inception, and this bill and its cognate bills will move NICNAS to full cost recovery, consistent with other Commonwealth chemical assessment schemes. Currently, costs are recovered by a system of application fees for the assessment carried out. This has worked well for new chemicals but not, however, for existing chemicals.

BREAK.PARA: The bill will implement a system of company registration to replace the current fee collection mechanism for existing chemicals. The bill also establishes a new register, the Register of Industrial Chemical Introducers. All persons who introduce industrial chemicals with an annual total value of more than $0.5 million will be required to register and pay a registration charge.

Company registration was first proposed by the previous government in 1995. Following extensive consultation with industry, we have refined the scheme to minimise its impact on business. A two‐tier system of registration charges will apply, with a lower charge of $1,200 and a higher charge of $7,000 for large introducers. The $0.5 million initial registration threshold will ensure that small businesses will not be affected. Company registration will enhance the operation of NICNAS by overcoming problems in its current cost recovery mechanism for existing chemicals. Costs will be shared more widely with the industry, as a result of this bill.

The bill amends the process of assessing existing industrial chemicals to ensure a better targeting of risks and a more flexible approach to assessment. New chemical assessment procedures will also be streamlined by allowing the early introduction of non‐hazardous chemicals, and additional exemptions for chemicals introduced in amounts of less than 10 kilograms per year. These amendments bring the Australian scheme into line with comparable schemes overseas and also enhance the efficiency of the scheme in moving to full cost recovery.

The bill also makes important changes to the Australian inventory of chemical substances. The inventory lists all chemicals imported or manufactured in Australia since 1977. The amendments will allow the continued listing of chemicals in the confidential section, subject to a review every five years. The test for inclusion in the confidential section has been strengthened. Currently, only the prejudice of the commercial interests of the person or company is considered. This will be changed to require the director to balance that prejudice against the public interests of disclosure.

The bill also makes minor amendments to improve the operation of the act, including by updating certain definitions. In summary, the bill and its cognate bills are aimed at further enhancing the operation of NICNAS while introducing full cost recovery and further streamlining assessment procedures. As a result of these reforms, assessments under NICNAS will be able to focus more on the chemicals posing the greatest risk to the Australian people and the environment.

In conclusion, I thank the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) and the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) for their contribution to this bill. I listened to the opposition spokesman, the member for Canberra, who seemed to get a little lost in his speech. He was suggesting that he and the opposition would be supporting—as they are—the bill, but seemed to go onto a tack of getting lost on policy, once again. Whilst they support full cost recovery—which was an area in which we, in opposition, supported their thrusts—he seemed to be saying, `We're not quite sure about that now.'

The opposition ought to take a good, hard look at where they are going, because the shadow spokesman seemed to be getting lost. He also suggested that this levy was a tax. I would remind the opposition that under their bills, which we supported, it was indeed a levy. They are trying to target the government with introducing a tax and we reject that assertion. I would suggest to the opposition that the bed levy introduced by the Labor Premier of New South Wales in Sydney is, in fact, a bed tax and should be properly labelled a tax and not a levy. So I think we should forget about the opposition until they really start to focus their policy and get a much greater focus on where they are going.

But we do accept their support. We thank them for their contribution. I would just like to remind the opposition that there was full and considerable consultation with the industry before the introduction of these amendments. I thank the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 2, page 61 (line 16), at the end of paragraph (1)(b), add:

PARA.TAB: ; and (c) any fees received under subsection 110(1) of that Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The government intends to amend the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill 1997 and the amendment has been circulated in the Main Committee. I would like to explain that this really is a minor technical amendment relating to the funding arrangements for the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme.

The scheme receives its funding through the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. As a result, schedule 2 to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill 1997 proposes to amend the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 to ensure that moneys collected from the registration charge can be applied for the purposes of the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme.

Item 1 of schedule 2 inserts a new section 58A in the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 which provides that in addition to the amounts appropriated from time to time by the parliament for the purposes of the commission, there is also payable to the commission, out of consolidated revenue, amounts equal to any amount paid on account of registration charge and any registration charge actually paid.

The amendment which I am proposing will insert an additional paragraph into new section 58A of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 to include in the moneys payable to the commission from consolidated revenue amounts equal to the fees paid under subsection 110(1) of the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989. That is, fees paid to the Commonwealth in respect of the various application, notifications and statements set out in section 110.

This means that amounts equal to the registration charge and any other fees collected and paid into the consolidated revenue fund may be appropriated out of the fund to the commission for the purposes of the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme.
Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TITLE.XREF: NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (RATITE SLAUGHTER) LEVY BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is not opposing the main thrust of the National Residue Survey (Ratite Slaughter) Levy Bill 1997, which is now before the House. The levy has been requested by the Emu Farmers Federation of Australia, and will be set at 75c per bird slaughtered for human consumption. As the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the bill points out, the function of the national residue survey is to monitor and assess the level of chemical residues in raw plant and animal products, and to give domestic and international consumers confidence in the quality and safety of those particular products.

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when non‐tariff barriers are increasingly being used by our trading partners to block access to their markets, this measure will go a long way towards securing access to those overseas markets for this industry. This is a relatively new industry in Australia, and it is one which shows considerable export potential. As I have said, this measure should be of assistance to the industry as it seeks to establish itself and consolidate its position in export markets.

In Australia and other industrialised countries, rising affluence has stimulated the demand for exotic meats. We know that particular niche demands exist in particular countries throughout the world for the exotic meats that are now the subject of the debate before the House. It is not too long ago that Australian tastes in meat were confined largely to beef, lamb and chicken. However, dining out today—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about rabbits?

—The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) would know all about rabbits because there are plenty in the Wannon electorate. They were clubbed to death there in the postwar era. I am sure, as a child, the member participated in the mass slaughter of the rabbit population of his electorate, as I did in the electorate of Corangamite where my father's dairy farm was located. We are dealing today with ostriches and emus, and we will keep the rabbits off the plate.

SPEECH.PARA: Dining out today, one is confronted with a range of exotic meats to test one's palate. The amount of meat consumed in Australia has not changed dramatically in recent years; however, the variety of meat that is being bought and consumed has. An important part of our more affluent lifestyle is that we eat out more often. That is accompanied by a desire to experiment with the specialty and exotic meats that are available in restaurants today. Once consumers enter the zone of trying exotic meats there is a natural tendency to try new cuts of meat.

The honourable member for Wannon mentioned rabbits and our upbringing. While I was growing up on a farm in the Western District, our family's meat consumption was largely confined to lamb and beef. We had chicken once a year at Christmas time, and we ate rabbit stew and we hunted ducks. That supplemented the meat diet.

However, in the last 12 months, I have become a consumer of exotic meats. On the odd occasion that I go out to dinner—and it is not as frequently, of course, as the honourable member for Wannon, whom I hear has been seen around the shopping malls of Manuka on many occasions—my meat consumption includes kangaroo, emu and venison.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what about—
—The honourable member for Wannon has made his point.
—I cannot quite see what the honourable member is—
—Yabbies.

—Yabbies do not really come under the ratite category, as the honourable member knows. As I was saying, my consumption of exotic meats has increased in the last 12 months as, as a consumer, I have experimented when I have gone out to dinner. I am part, as are we all, of the rising demand for these commodities in Australia. Often there is a consumer perception that these meats contain lower levels of fat and cholesterol, and so they are increasingly in demand from more sophisticated consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: The emu industry began in Australia in the early 1970s. Since then, the industry has developed into one supplying meat products, skins and oils to a highly specialised niche market. Emu meat is low in fat and cholesterol and obviously appeals to health‐conscious consumers, such as the member for Wannon, who are out there for a dining experience that features exotic meats.

BREAK.PARA: The skin and leather of the emu are also used in a variety of fashion clothes and in the manufacture of wallets, watchbands and other products. The oils are reputed to have healing powers for a range of skin disorders and muscular ailments. Being a keen Australian super rules player, I am certainly going to check out the emu oil and use it in that recovery period after each match that we play of a Sunday.

As far as the Australian ostrich industry is concerned—and that is another bird in the ratite family that is the subject of this legislation—it is estimated that over 70,000 birds are farmed annually in Australia. A relatively lucrative market exists overseas for ostrich meats, leather and feathers. I am not suggesting that the honourable member for Wannon would know much about ostrich feathers, but he certainly knows a lot about rabbit fur, being an old boy from the Western District of Victoria where rabbits existed in plague proportions.

The ostrich industry has undergone a resurgence in recent years. It has developed a sound marketing program to guide its development beyond the year 2000. As I mentioned before, exotic consumer tastes are the order of the day for the modern Australian palate and ostrich meat is rapidly becoming a favourite among many Australians and the meat is being used to produce sausages, pates and hams.

The ostrich industry has also become a destination for investors seeking out new opportunities in agricultural industry in Australia today. That investment is now developing and expanding the production base because of the export potential for the meats and other products, especially in substantial markets such as China. Investors are committing funds to develop the national herd and to supply those lucrative domestic markets.

There has been a word of caution sounded from the ASC on the rather extravagant claims of many promoters of these investment schemes in the industry. Nonetheless, there are investment funds flowing into the industry on the back of identified export potential in markets in Japan and, of course, China.

I attended the Alternative Farm Vision Expo that was held in Geelong recently. I congratulate the Herald and Weekly Times for their sponsorship of that particular event and the organisers who collected from all over Australia people who are currently involved in alternative farming. The industries that I mentioned, the ostrich and emu industries, were prominently featured at that Alternative Farm Vision Expo. Both of those industries are rapidly acquiring an important status in Australian agriculture as niche industries and highly specialised industries in the rural sector.

I think it is very important that we recognise the contribution of these industries to Australian agriculture and also that we encourage the diversity of agricultural production. If we go back 20, 30 or 40 years, Australian agriculture was pretty well confined. Now, in the 1990s, and as we go toward the year 2000, many farmers who have grown up in those traditional industries are seeking new opportunities in alternative forms of agriculture, which are typified by the industries that I have mentioned here today.

They are important industries because they give an export focus to Australian agriculture. Often these industries, as they get into highly specialised and lucrative overseas markets, reinforce the image of Australia as an agricultural producer of diversity and enhance the reputation of Australian producers who are able to supply quality products to these particular markets.

Let me also add that the development of these industries is also very important to regional economies such as my own in the electorate of Corio and the economies further out in the Western District, typified by the presence of the honourable member for Wannon here today. They are very important activities; they are part of the patchwork, the quilt of agricultural production that really has sustained and diversified many rural communities that over the course of time have suffered some hardship in the more traditional industries in those areas.
Mr Deputy Speaker, the opposition has no substantial objection to the legislation which is now before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Lest I should be thought a philistine, Mr Deputy Speaker, I understand the member for Corio is a great supporter of the Geelong Cats. It seems to me that that name is somewhat incongruous, given what we have heard from the honourable member and perhaps the Geelong Cats should look at some of the ratite names and become a little more Australianised. I have suggested the same with the Brisbane Broncos but that was not greeted too well.

—I do not want to uncharitably bring the member for Dickson back to the legislation, but I point out that, with the member for Port Adelaide in the chamber as well, this debate could go off the rails if you do not return to the ratite bill.

—I am a bit out of my territory—I am surrounded by that aerial ping‐pong game. To return to the National Residue Survey (Ratite Slaughter) Levy Bill, many members may wonder why I am interested in a bill of this nature. I have not canvassed honourable members but, as far as I am aware, I am the only member who lives next door to an emu farm.

SPEECH.PARA: This emu farm was established in 1995 by John and Betty Schmidt. It has become a significant focal point for tourist buses and local people. The restaurant at the farm serves emu steak, emu sausages and many varieties of emu meat. Anna and I were privileged to attend the opening of the Mount Samson Emu Farm in 1995. It was a momentous occasion for the Mount Samson and Samsonvale district, which is in the western part of my electorate.

I am happy to say that, while the emus do make a rather unusual noise, they are an added bonus to the tourism industry generally in south‐east Queensland because this is another stop‐off point for people who are looking to experience a slice of Australiana. The farm is also the genesis of an industry which is going to move Australia into the next century. It is significant in the case of John and Betty Schmidt that they and their father were dairy farming for many years and that they have now moved into this industry. It has not been easy to make that transition but they are innovative and entrepreneurial people. They are making a very solid go of it.

This legislation recognises significant changes in the propensity of Australians to change their eating habits, and that is shown by what we are now seeing in restaurants. I was in Sydney recently and noticed emu on the menu in a restaurant. I was told that it is not an unusual feature of restaurants in the Sydney area. It is also something that is becoming more prevalent in Brisbane and I imagine that generally it will catch on across Australia.

As has been said, emu meat in particular is low in cholesterol and fat and that fact will encourage an export industry. This particular measure is very much linked to that, because consumers worldwide expect a very solid standard of food quality and safety, as was said by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) in his second reading speech.

Markets require a residue monitoring program managed by government as a prerequisite for produce access. Chemical residues can also be used as a form of non‐tariff trade barrier, so this initiative has an important role, as was said by the minister, in developing and maintaining market access for this increasingly important industry. As has been mentioned, it is not just emus but it can include large flightless vertebrates such as ostriches, cassowaries, rhea and kiwi.

Not very far from my electorate, again in that north‐western area, is an ostrich farm run by Louise Willard and her husband. This indicates another progression in the use of native birds, not only for breeding—eggs, chicks and so forth—but into the development of a marketing industry.

It is interesting to see the way in which these developments are taking place and are progressing the primary industries of this country. Primary industry is, in many respects, the backbone of this country and it is good to see that it is moving with the times. I will mention here that the Cherbourg Aboriginal community, with which I have been significantly involved over the years, has an emu abattoir and farm—they have just over 300 birds. In my view, this process, particularly as I have related it to emus and the experience in my own electorate, and from my association with Cherbourg, will give confidence to the industry at a time when it needs confidence. It will progress the industry so that in time one may well expect that there will be a significant local domestic market in the consumption of these birds and in the use of by‐products. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this bill because I think I can claim to be one of the pioneers of the emu industry in Australia and I have watched with some concern its progress. Honourable member interjecting—

BREAK.PARA: When I convinced them that we would be providing them with a much bigger skin, a genuine emu skin, and that because the birds were in captivity the skins would generally be unblemished, the opening order was for a million skins. I suggested that three or four dozen would be more than we could handle at the time, but it was quite clear that we had to have volume. Manufacturers told me that nothing under 10,000 skins would be considered a worthwhile run, and unless we had volume, we were not going to be able to get the skins onto the market.

The emu skin has enormous potential. It is undoubtedly the best bookbinding skin in the world. It is a very soft skin that drapes well and therefore is also suitable in the clothing industry. The other product of great interest is oil. A mature bird will produce something like 10 litres of oil. The oil is very penetrating and it is suggested that as a subcutaneous carrier it will get through the skin perhaps 1½ to two per cent of a treatment, and that is probably 100 per cent more than is available at the moment. So it has enormous potential as a subcutaneous carrier of other medications and this, too, I believe, was never fully explored for the reasons that the industry was just selling chicks to itself.

The meat always had potential. It is cholesterol free. The meat you are talking about is off the breast of the bird; the great bulk of meat on the leg is only suitable for sausages. Sausages are being made in Western Australia and they are quite tasty—I actually tried to get them introduced to the parliamentary dining room without success.

Looking at this ratite levy, I think the Emu Farmers Federation of Australia is again making a very foolish mistake. The markets for emu are basically the United Kingdom, Europe and Japan, and I see no suggestion that either of those countries is likely to use non‐tariff barrier mechanisms to stop the entry. So I do not really see a threat there and I think they are foolish to involve the government. I notice the levy is set at 75c with a maximum of $5 per head, and they are wrong if they think that that levy is not going to rise. It will rise and they will find in years to come that the cost of having the government involved is a cost they did not need.

It is quite possible for the federation to do random checking itself with a voluntary levy and, in my view, it is all that is needed to get the necessary chemical analysis of the meat. If there were ever an opportunity to sell into markets that were using non‐tariff mechanisms they could specifically test in that area.

This is indicative of many people. They go running to the government for help when, in fact, they would be much better off doing it themselves. And I cite the efforts of Don Wieringa, the pioneer of human consumption crocodile meat. Don Wieringa used his own money to pay for research to try and eliminate salmonella from crocodile meat. Because of the nature of the animals, salmonella was very hard to eradicate from crocodiles—certainly in the wild it is always there. Through his own research, he came up with a feeding management program which eliminated salmonella from crocodile meat and, immediately, he was confronted with overseas orders which he simply could not meet. Interestingly enough, some of the big orders came from British Airways and Japanese Airways that wanted to offer it as a first class fare on their aeroplanes but would not do so while it had the association with salmonella.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I just briefly interrupt the member for Kalgoorlie. I do not wish to interrupt the flow of his remarks but it is an appropriate time. If he does not mind, I will call him again in just a moment without taking up too much of his time. I am alerted to the fact that we have in the Main Committee chamber a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Mozambique led by the President of the National Assembly of Mozambique. May I, on behalf of the parliament, extend to our distinguished visitors a very warm welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have taken the liberty of interrupting the member for Kalgoorlie because I understand that our visitors are here on a tight time frame and may have to leave and, for that reason, I hope the member for Kalgoorlie will not mind me interrupting his speech. Welcome, gentlemen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recently had an enjoyable holiday on the border of Mozambique—a fascinating country. Returning to the legislation before the Committee, I am not opposing the bill—it is the will of the Emu Farmers Federation. I just want to put on the record that I think they are making a mistake. Self‐management would have been a much better role for them.

BREAK.PARA: I also think that the government could have done much more in helping to develop the potential of the skin and the oil. Some government funded research on the use of the oil clearly would have been enormously beneficial to the whole country. The government has failed to do it—unfortunately it seems to be the nature of governments to miss these opportunities. The industry now is a much larger industry in the United States than it is here.

The ostriches, I think, have been somewhat better managed. Australia, of course, has a longer history of commercialising the ostrich than it has of commercialising the emu. Ostrich feather farms were in existence in Australia before the turn of the century. Most of them disappeared when ostrich feathers went out of fashion in the fashion industry. When you visit the South African ostrich industry, a lot of those feathers now are for things other than the fashion industry.

I might digress—emu feather is substantially different from ostrich feather. If it is stripped off the main stem, the feather has a lot of the properties of down for which, of course, there is an enormous market. I believe ostrich feathers too could have been commercialised to a far greater extent than has been the case.

As I said, we were exporting ostriches for the fashion industry but that went out of fashion—I was involved in actually catching ostriches for export to the world. The reason was that South Africa put a ban on the export of their ostrich. The ostrich used in South Africa for feather production is not a native, it is a hybrid bird, and the South Africans very sensibly were trying to limit its export. Those birds were, however, already in Australia and we exported them, mainly from a place called Port Augusta in South Australia.

An ostrich is a much bigger bird than the emu and much harder to handle. We found that the best way to handle them was to mark the nest, collect the eggs and incubate them just before hatching. The company I worked for had a very successful business in this line. It was put out of business in 1960 by a very foolish government action which banned the export of all Australian fauna and left the company only with canaries and ostriches. This was not big enough to support the company. We had a situation where it was quite permissible to kill Australian animals but illegal to export them. Of course, that is a nonsense. But it is interesting to note that in all these years—some 37 years—we have never been able to amend that bill to get any commonsense into the action.

The emu and the ostrich industries both have potential. They certainly have my goodwill. I believe that ostriches and emus are both compatible running with other stock. Certainly that is so with ostriches, which are in some sense amenable to the same sort of husbandry as sheep. The difference between the birds is that the male emu looks after the eggs during the night and the female during the day, whereas the male ostrich sits and hatches the eggs entirely on its own. I noticed in South Africa that there are quite a lot of people running stock sheep with ostriches, and I am sure that will be the case in Australia. I think it does represent a useful adjunct to our industry.

There is not much more I want to say on the bill. I think the federation is making a mistake, and I am sure that the ratite breeders will see that levy rise in the near future, even if only to fund the cost of government collection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the National Residue Survey (Ratite Slaughter) Bill 1997 before the Main Committee today. As the previous speaker has alluded to, the ostrich industry in Australia has grown dramatically over the years. I have learnt today that the earlier development of the industry was purely on the basis of providing ostrich feathers for fashion; but, certainly, the ostrich industry today is one that is developing at a very rapid rate.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand some of the statistics are very interesting, in that there are 2,008 ostrich farmers nationally. In New South Wales alone, in my home state, there are 450; and in the region that I represent, the mid north coast of New South Wales, there are 237. A couple of the leading ostrich farmers in New South Wales are in my area, particularly around the Hastings area based on Port Macquarie and Wauchope—and I talk of Steve and Janelle Gerke, John Pitkin and Howard Kerr, Kevin Gleeson, Peter Aitken and Peter Baber. They have some substantial investments in the ostrich industry.

I know that this bill has probably been put together at the instigation of the Federation of Emu Producers or the emu industry; but, because it has to refer to ratites generally, it includes ostriches as well. I probably agree to a certain extent with the sentiments of the previous speaker, that self‐regulation would be better. It is interesting to note that the emu federation has come to the government and asked the government to organise the collection of this levy, because it has been self‐regulation all the way as far as the ostrich industry is concerned, I understand. That has worked relatively well, particularly through the R&D phase.

As the industry has developed, it has grown beyond that, particularly in recent months, to the size it is now. A number of test slaughters have been undertaken; the meat that is being produced from the ostriches is being well and truly accepted; and, certainly, the by‐products of feather and leather are also very popular.

At the moment there are throughout Australia nine plants that process ostriches, and they include four export accredited plants. Three are for the European Union market and two are currently in the process of getting halal accreditation, particularly for those emerging South‐East Asian markets and the Middle East. There are another two undergoing export accreditation. There are three domestic accredited plants. Two are in New South Wales—one at Narrandera, in the electorate of my colleague the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), and the other at Frederickton, just north of my electorate, in Deputy Speaker Nehl's electorate of Cowper.

The Ostrich Association expects that there will be 12,000 birds processed this year and 20,000 in 1998. That gives you an idea of the size that the industry has developed itself to. I highlight the point that it has done this in a self‐regulatory manner as far as the development of the industry and the development of the export mechanisms go. I will come to the point about quarantine inspection within ports of developmental stock in a minute, and the role that AQIS has played in that.

I want to highlight a couple of other important elements of the industry. Australia leads the way in meat development through the Australian Ostrich Company, which is the commercial arm of the Ostrich Association, and has developed a meat description language that will become the basis of international meat language for ostrich meat. If that gets set in place and becomes universal—particularly if it becomes the single universal language across Australia—then they will be leading the beef industry, which at this stage still has not achieved the goal of setting a nationally accepted and universal grading system for the beef industry—a goal that this government is working towards.

The industry is also at the forefront of developing, through R&D, opportunities for the leather that is processed from the industry. Recently, Australian Exotic Leathers and the AOC secured a contract for providing 1,000 Australian farmed and tanned hides per month to Japan.

So the industry is going extremely well. It has, as I said, put in the hard yards to date. It has been going through the developmental stages, and all under self‐regulation as far as that is concerned.

The spirit of what this bill is trying to achieve is important—as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, representing a rural electorate. There are more than just tariff type trade barriers around the world. Again, I accept the comments of the previous speaker, the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), that at this stage there are no indications that these are being applied in any of the countries that we export ostrich or ratite product to, but we need to be ahead of the game in that regard.

This bill allows the imposition of the levy on all ratites. At the moment, it is set at 75c per head, with the opportunity to increase it to $5 per head. Ultimately it would be in the interests of everybody if that became a self‐regulatory process, and that will probably happen.

But, as previous speakers have indicated, the government has been asked to initiate this. A lot of the areas involving the development of industry and services in Australia require government initiation ultimately, with the responsibilities then being handed over to the industry. For instance, the government is in the process of doing that with the beef industry at the moment. So that in itself is important. If the ratite industry generally accepts the spirit of what is being done here and works with it in a professional manner, then we are going to see the development of a very important export industry.

I said earlier that I wanted to make some comments on the involvement AQIS has had in the development of this industry to date. The member for Kalgoorlie alluded to the fact that no birds were allowed to be exported out of South Africa. Most of the breeding stock in Australia, I understand, originally came from Canada, and we cannot import from the United States. All breeding stock are implanted with a microchip so they can track where those birds have come from and what the history of those birds is.

BREAK.PARA: I have worked with one of my local breeders, Kevin Gleeson. In conjunction with other breeders, he has been a major importer of breeding stock and a major player in developing the ostrich industry in Australia. I think we should recognise that fact—bearing in mind the terms we have discussed, the size this industry is going to be and the export income it is going to develop for Australia.

I know that in recent years Kevin Gleeson had a great deal of trouble with a shipment of imported birds coming from Canada through the quarantine station on the Cocos Islands. I undertook to conduct a bit of research into why—and I do not think we ever got to the bottom of it—there was undue delay in the processing of the importation of that group of birds through the Cocos Islands.

The birds went through the normal process of quarantine for X number of weeks but were held up for weeks and weeks and weeks on end. My understanding was that there was a concern, without justification and without documentary evidence, about the origin of some of those birds. Kevin bought all of those birds in Canada and brought them through the Cocos Islands on their way into Australia. AQIS seemed to believe at the time that the origin of a couple of the birds was suspect—that is, that they had come from the United States. My understanding is that that could not be substantiated and ultimately was not, yet the entire shipment was held up on the Cocos Islands—and this was a 747 aeroplane load of birds—and the cost to the importer was just unbelievable. It was tens of thousands of dollars extra.

I just highlight that example. I know there has been a review of the activities of AQIS, I know the government has allocated resources in that area, and I know there is going to be a refocusing and restructuring in that area. But that was just one example of an impediment to a fledgling industry that required an enormous amount of capital by way of investment in breeding stock. I thought that particular importer was being unduly impeded, and without substantiation speed bumps were being put in the way of him developing what he was trying to do in Australia.

At the time, we put up the proposition that, if there were a couple of birds that they were concerned about the origins of, they could have held those back and let the rest of the shipment go. However, there seemed to be all sorts of bureaucratic reasons as to why they could not. I wanted to make that comment because we are discussing the ratite industry, which includes ostriches and the ostrich industry in Australia.

In closing, I support this bill. On the sentiments expressed by members opposite with regard to self‐regulation, I imagine that that certainly will come in time. I highlight that, as far as the development of the ostrich industry in Australia is concerned, that has been the case, particularly with their research and development. In the case of some operators, like Kevin Gleeson in my electorate, the industry has developed in some isolated cases despite government bureaucracy and the hurdles that have been put in their way.

We accept that, because we are a safe and secure continent as far as exotic diseases are concerned, we absolutely need the protection of the Quarantine Inspection Service. All I ask is that, from time to time, it exercise a bit more commonsense and undertake its task in that manner. As far as the protection of primary industries in Australia is concerned, AQIS does its job in a very professional way but, because of the sheer costs involved, some flexibility must be exercised with regard to the ways in which it undertakes its duties. That experience would have sent a lesser operator broke. It was fortunate that the people involved had the resources to withstand the costs that were imposed by the decision taken.

In terms of trade, we need to be eternally vigilant about what is happening with regard to the non‐trade barriers that are put in the way of exports, as we do with trade in this country. It is an argument that cuts both ways. Debates are raging at the moment about imported salmon and imported chicken meat. That is exactly what we are talking about. We want to protect our industries from diseases, not from competition.

I understand that other countries are going to want to do the same. If we have self‐imposed quality assurance within Australia so that, as the product leaves, we can guarantee that there are no problems, then we may not face the hurdles which these export industries develop. With those words, I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr ADAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —I address the National Residue Survey (Ratite Slaughter) Levy Bill 1997. People are getting used to seeing a number of big birds as they drive around Tasmania. The development of these birds comes from farming—as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker—being more innovative and needing to raise income from things other than the traditional ways of farming because of the pressure of prices on some of the traditional incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of just seeing sheep and cattle on the farms, some pretty strange beasts are appearing. In Tasmania, the deer farming industry is coming on. It has been around for some time and deer is a respected game food domestically. Many of us enjoy a roast of venison on Sunday in place of some of the more traditional meats. In my family, venison is now a traditional meal. And the likes of emus, ostriches, llamas and other such animals are now becoming familiar outside zoos.

In Tasmania we have a fledgling industry in ostriches and emus. They have a very interesting future, if they can sort out some of the problems that they have. There is plenty of scope to use the oil from these birds. It is very useful to find an oil that can be used for a number of purposes including cosmetics. So, as I understand it, there is potential there but there are still a lot of issues to be dealt with. I have read about the qualities of the oil but it is not yet at a total commercial situation. The leather of ostriches is very soft and we have heard others speak about this. It has a very good skin pattern and it can be used for fashion accessories such as handbags, belts and shoes. From what I have seen, it looks as though there are very good opportunities out there. I heard my colleagues speak about the quality that it gives to the binding of books.

The meat side of the industry is still in its infancy. There are markets but there are problems to solve first. This bill may start to help the industry gain access to these markets. The idea was put forward by the Emu Farmers Federation of Australia. The purpose of the bill is to enable a national residue survey levy to be introduced. This allows for a levy of 75c per bird, slaughtered, which will go to monitoring the products. This certainly will help in the development of quality assurance in the marketing of the meat. I am honoured to have a minister here listening to the rest of my speech. The main functions of the residue survey are to monitor and assess the levels of chemical residue in raw Australian plant and animal commodities, and to give domestic and international consumers confidence in the quality and safety of these products. Consumers worldwide expect a high standard of assurance on food safety and quality. Some markets require a residue monitoring program, managed by government, as a prerequisite for product access. Chemical residue issues can also be used as a form of non‐tariff trade barrier.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that meat inspections in the future will certainly come down to a live inspection of residue within product. I believe the emu federation is getting in on the ground on this because there will certainly be a need in the future for those measurements. When we go into exporting to other countries, I believe that other countries will demand a certain level from us. This initiative by the emu industry has an important role in developing and maintaining market access for the emu farmers it represents.

At the moment, I am investigating ways to help achieve a secure and long‐term slaughter facility in Tasmania so that the industry there can start to develop. Things are a bit hit‐and‐miss at the moment and the industry in my state is seeking some new directions. However, I can see some good marketing angles in a chicken drumstick being compared to an emu drumstick: `feed the whole family on one emu leg!'—eat your heart out, Colonel Sanders—or `one emu leg on a plate and you could feed the whole family; finger‐licking good.' Just think of the marketing value in that!

I am not sure that you could use that old song Old Man Emu—who could run the pants off a kangaroo—because it may indicate that there might be a bit of toughness in the product. We would probably have to think of another angle for the marketing of that but I am sure that we will come up with something. However, it is a very Australian product. The emu, as is the kangaroo, is part of our coat of arms. But, by the same token, it is a very farmable animal and totally adaptable to the environment. The kangaroo, the emu, and some other species that breed quickly, and are plentiful, can be nicely adapted for farming. They have had plenty of time to become fully adapted to Australian conditions and would be immune to many of the diseases that affect introduced species.

There was a report in 1993 that pointed out the possibilities of farming our native animals, rather than treating them as farm pests. The funds raised by the levy will be directed back into the industry for further development. Therefore it will be of direct benefit to the growers. This has happened for a lot of other primary producers and those people have gained advantages in exchanges of information between growers nationwide.

Something similar may be necessary in Tasmania to allow growers to develop their own abattoir so they can take control of their industry. In Tasmania we have had some difficulties in getting an established abattoir to process the birds that we have in the state. People need to come together so that they can get on top of that, either by forming a company or a cooperative of members so that they can benefit from all the effort that they have put in. I do not necessarily think they always need a third party to control the killing and the shipping. They could take some control of this themselves and they would be able to direct the industry's future themselves.

I am excited about the possibilities here and I know that, with a little more work, there could be links developed with other growers to pool their energies in marketing and also in export. Only last Saturday I was addressing the deer farmers in my electorate, talking about the potential opportunities we need in relation to transport, and looking at the needs they have that need to be developed and the links that need to be put in place for that.

I think this bill will achieve what it set out to do: give opportunity for new industries which are emerging; give them protection in the export arena when they are dealing with other countries and access points; and give international consumers confidence in the quality and the safety of the product. I believe that, in the long term, this will be beneficial to the industry and to the growers that are in it. I wish them well in the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am responding to sum up this debate on the National Residue Survey (Ratite Slaughter) Levy Bill 1997 and acting on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). I want to say to the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) that I can agree that a leg of emu, particularly if it was a western Queensland emu, would certainly feed more than one family; but perhaps with a Tasmanian emu probably not quite a family.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank members from both sides of the House for their contributions to this important bill and also for the discussions that have contributed to this debate. It is a very new industry for Australia. It is great to see that it is going to be making a contribution to our export wealth in the future and that there is growing interest in Australia in the products from ratites.

The purpose of this bill is to enable the cost of a national residue survey chemical residue monitoring program to be recovered from the ratite emu industry by a national levy mechanism on a fee‐for‐service basis. This will allow for long‐term flexibility for the ratite emu industry in determining the cost of chemical residue programs, thus allowing access to all and any export and domestic market for emu meat products.

Concern about chemical residues in food is an increasingly important issue worldwide, as consumers expect a high standard of assurance about food safety and quality. Real or perceived public health issues, such as those involving residues in food, can rapidly alter product consumption patterns and disrupt domestic and international markets for primary products. By providing an independent and authoritative assessment of the residue status of Australian ratite products, the national residue survey puts residue issues in perspective and dispels or averts speculation about the safety of Australian food commodities.

Chemical residue issues also form the basis for non‐trade barriers against our primary products. I notice there were some comments from the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) on that issue. Some markets require a residue monitoring program managed by the government as a prerequisite for product access. Other markets consider these issues as trade negotiations. The national residue survey, the NRS, thus has an important role in developing and maintaining market access for these important and developing industries.
The ratite emu industry regards this mechanism as the best way to collect funds for its residue monitoring program and puts it on the most equitable basis. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
