SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has no substantial objections to the substance of the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 or the Wine Export Charge (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997, which are now proceeding through this House. The essential feature of the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 is to introduce a charge on the export of Australian wines to support the export promotion activities of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. This is an industry driven proposal to support the promotion program of the corporation, as grant funding for the generic promotion of Australian wines overseas from state and federal sources is coming to an end.

SPEECH.PARA: The compulsory export charge is expected to raise around $1 million per year, which will be used to fund part of the promotional program which will include the generic wine promotion, the wine labelling integrity program and wine export control measures. It is pleasing to note that widespread support for this proposal is coming from producers from within the industry itself. At the last meeting of the corporation, support for the proposal ran at some 96 per cent. That support was drawn from large producers, as well as the many small and medium producers who are very important to this particular industry. It is not always the case in rural industries that a proposal such as this can get widespread support within the industry itself.

This is an industry with a vision, and the key to that vision is the effective promotion of Australian wines in overseas markets. These activities are vital if Australian wines are to hold their own against strong competition, which is expected to come from producers in South Africa, the emerging producers in South America and producers in central Europe.

If there is one exciting story in Australian agricultural exporting today it would have to be the Australian wine industry. If we were to go back only 30 years, Australian table wine consumption amounted to little more than two bottles per head. As I was raised in a low-income rural household, with my father being a teetotaller, the consumption of alcohol beverages was not a priority in our household. That was the time that we bottled our own ginger beer on the farm. My only taste of wines was of the fortified kind around Christmas time when the sherries and brandies made their way to the table. As a youngster I used to scoot around after the adults had had their fill, making some very potent cocktails from which I suffered considerably later on. It was only in my teenage years that I became introduced to—well, I would not say an exotic alcoholic beverage in beer—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're past that now.

—Of course, I paid dearly for that. As the honourable member for Fowler interjects, I have passed through all of these phases and I have now reached the stage where I am one of those consumers who indulges in excellent Australian table wines. I guess it was only in the 1970s that many of our families got into the consumption of the superb wines that are being produced here in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, how things have changed over those 30 years, so that per capita consumption of table wines is now around 24 bottles. I acknowledge the contribution of the honourable member for Fowler in that particular statistic because I know he is a particular wine buff, along with the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) who is sitting beside him in the chamber today.

The factors which have contributed to this growth have been the rising population and rising income levels of Australians. Wine is a particular product that is not so much price elastic in economic terms but income elastic. That is, as the income of the nation rises so does domestic consumption, and overseas consumption as well. Australia's long‐term export performance in this particular industry is predicated on certain growth assumptions that we hope will be evident in overseas countries and major markets. That overseas export performance will be determined by rising incomes in our major markets—the USA, Japan, the United Kingdom and Sweden.

Another factor which has contributed to the growth in domestic wine consumption and production has been the postwar migration boom which has changed our diet and our patterns of wine consumption. Also, with rising disposable incomes, our entertainment and leisure patterns have changed considerably. Accompanying that change has been an increasing incidence of dining out and this has obviously stimulated the domestic consumption of wines.

There are many other factors that have contributed to this burgeoning growth, among them being the fact that the Australian population is becoming increasingly health conscious and, of course, a good glass of wine a day puts a bit of the cream on the cake, if I can use that term, as far as one's health is concerned. The stimulus has also come from within the industry itself, which has been able to increase productivity enormously through the introduction of innovative processing technologies and with improved growing practices.

We are indeed a nation that is blessed with many natural advantages which have given us those competitive advantages which we now enjoy in certain international markets. Among those natural advantages have been the productivity of our land base and the availability of suitable land in Australia in regional areas of the nation for wine production. We have developed over time a very skilled human resource with a long tradition that goes back to the 1800s in wine production and processing. More recently, we have become world leaders in the production and distribution of innovative technologies involved in the processing of wines. We have established ourselves, not as a large player in the international export arena, but as an influential and significant player.

The history of Australian winemaking goes back to the first European settlements in this nation. Wine production was introduced to Australia by Captain Arthur Phillip in 1788. The gold rushes in the 1850s were accompanied by an influx of European immigrants. It was that influx which laid the foundation of the vines and the expertise on which Australia's wine industry is currently built. As I have mentioned, the wave of European immigrants after World War II laid a further foundation for the development of the industry which has taken place in the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s in such a dramatic fashion.

This industry is very important and critical to the development of many regional areas around Australia, including my own. It has been a significant stimulator of employment in those regions and a major source of investment back from the metropolitan areas into the regions of this nation. We are used to hearing a great deal about the drain of investment funds out of regional areas in the form of superannuation that is paid by the rural work force which eventually finds its way into the commercial construction industry in major metropolitan centres. It is very important for regional areas to have industries that attract significant investment out of metropolitan areas back into the regions. The dairy industry is one good example of that. In the debate on the Dairy Produce Levy Bill in this chamber in the budget session, many speakers alluded to the very important fact of that investment and the importance to regional areas for it to take place. The wine industry is another example of the importance of that flow of investment into regional areas. With the spectacular export growth that is predicted for this particular industry, we will see an ever increasing investment taking place in regional areas.

The wine industry has contributed greatly to the growth of regional tourism and the job growth in related industries that service that particular growth. It is the linkage between the wine industry and tourism which offers great domestic potential. Apart from the consumption of wine itself in its various forms, it is the combination of these two particular industries that is going to deliver some very real benefits to regional areas. This particular industry has the added advantage of being a reasonably environmentally friendly form of productive activity, and that aids in stimulating consumption and encouraging investment as well.

Let me put in a plug for the wine growing areas around Geelong because, historically, the Geelong region was an important wine growing area in the state of Victoria in the 1800s and 1900s. Disease, unfortunately, wiped out many of the older vineyards, but we have seen in the last 20 years a resurgence in wine producing activities in the region. I do not profess to be an expert in this industry, or in the production of wine, but I am told that the limestone soil formations in the Geelong region are ideal for wine production. Of course, with the general growth in domestic and export demand, along with the various techniques that have been developed in the industry to control pests and disease, this has stimulated the resurgence in the industry in the Geelong region.

Many of the region's wineries are now household names among Australian wines, while others in the region are cutting the mustard very well in the export arena. I would like to mention a few of those wineries because I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, that as you go out to dine, not only in this fair city but in your own city and throughout the length and breadth of Australia, you might come across Idyll wines or wines that are produced at Scotchman's Hill, the Bannockburn wines and the Anakie wines. They are all excellent wines coming out of the region and they mix it with the best that are produced in the Barossa Valley and in the Hunter region.

I am very impressed with the vision that the Australian wine industry has developed which is encapsulated in its strategy 2025 document. It also establishes a strategic framework for the industry over the next five years, from 1997 to 2001. I would like to run through some of the objectives of this particular vision statement. It is very rare indeed within Australian agriculture today that you see an industry prepare such a detailed and comprehensive strategic plan that is going to guide its development, not only in the medium five-year term but right out to the year 2025.

The wine industry has identified a number of key objectives which it says will be important in the development of this industry. Those objectives are to enhance the image and reputation of Australian wines. I would say that that process is really under way, because internationally our wines are recognised as being very good wines in quality and very attractively priced.

I am reminded of my first term in this parliament. A French delegation came to this parliament, we had dinner in Parliament House and served them some very good Australian wines. The comment that they made was not only on the excellent quality of the wines, but also the attractive price. Bottles of superb quality wine that you were able to pick up in Australia then for about $A15 to $A20 would cost you the equivalent of $40 to $50 to $60 in France itself. They really regarded Australia as one of the hidden treasures of the world as far as wine production was concerned. I think that was an extraordinary compliment coming from the French for the Australian wine growing industry.

Another of the objectives that are listed in the vision statement is to entrench innovation as the growth driver of the industry's competitive advantage. I wish a lot of other agricultural industries would enshrine this particular objective in their practices. If there is one thing that is going to keep Australian agriculture ahead of the pack in the international marketplace it is its capacity to innovate—not only to produce new products, but also to produce new ways of producing those particular products. We are a very innovative nation, and Australian agriculture is extremely innovative, but there are very few industries in the agricultural sector that have prepared a plan such as this and have enshrined that sort of objective in it.

Another objective that has been mentioned in the 2025 vision statement is to enhance wine style in quality, purity, uniqueness and diversity. Another is to establish global leadership in specific branded market price segments. Interestingly, when you tie this objective to the plan this particular element does not come to fruition until some 25 to 30 years out. That is what I call real vision. Here is an industry that is prepared to look at its future 20 to 30 years out and set a strategic planning framework in which it will muster not only the human resources, but the productive and financial resources, to give effect to the dramatic growth which it expects over that particular period of time.

Another objective listed is to capitalise on market growth opportunities by expanding industry capacity. What this statement touches on is the importance of enlarging that productive capacity as the first platform for really expanding the growth of exports and getting to that position where the industry is a global leader in branded market price segments.

Another objective which has been listed is to extend the scope of industry participation in complementary business sectors. Here the wine industry is attempting to link itself to other industry sectors—that is, in the research and development areas, in manufacturing generally, in the construction of the innovative processing equipment it has being able to develop, and with the financial sector in providing the funds that are going to propel this development according to this plan, and with the tourism industry. Here is an industry that not only sees itself as an important player domestically in improving its production and, in an export sense, in expanding its export opportunities, but also sees itself linking not only with other agricultural industries but with other industries throughout the Australian economy.

The vision statement sets out clear directions for the development of the industry. Over the next five years, there will be a period of rapid vineyard expansion. That will mean an expansion of the productive base, and that will set the scene for a growth in the value of production which is expected from the years 2002 to 2015. That will build on the brand strength of Australian wines and cultivate greater market share. The plan goes to the years from 2015 to 2025, when Australia will seek to establish brand leadership in certain market segments.

The eventual goal of this plan is to expand production to achieve some $4.5 billion worth of sales by the year 2025. That is an extremely ambitious program of expansion for any industry. But it is coming off the back of a vision; it is coming off the back of a collective will of the industry to achieve; and it is coming off the back of an industry that sees itself at the forefront of agricultural industry development in this country.

The wine industry will require some $5 billion to finance that expansion. Obviously, some of that will come from within the industry itself, but it will have to rely on investment from private investors and new entrants into the industry who are prepared to commit money for this expansion, and from financial institutions in this country which in the past have not been great supporters of new industries and those primary producers in industries that are not top of the shelf, as we say, in an agricultural sense and are not the big powerhouse industries like wheat, sheep and wool. Nevertheless, this industry is a significant one. In the past, it has not been adequately serviced by the financial sector. It is pleasing to see now that many of the major banks are very keen to lend in regional areas because they understand that a lot of the innovation in Australian agriculture is being propelled out of the regions and a lot of the private investment is taking place there.

Many other rural industries could take a real leaf out of the wine industry book in its strategic planning. The growth of this industry is really reflected in the dramatic export performance which has been achieved in recent years. It has been quite staggering and it is projected to continue on its growth path. Australian wine exports are expected to double between 1996‐97 and 2001‐02. In 1996, exports were valued at around $471 million and they are expected to increase to around $896 million by 2001. That growth has been driven by rising incomes in domestic markets which have propelled demand and also rising incomes in overseas markets. It has been propelled by an expansion of Australia's wine production base and by the changing preferences in wines, moving from the fortified wines more into the table wines, in this country and overseas.

It is a very interesting and innovative industry; one which is export orientated, one which has demonstrated capacity to innovate, one which sees itself linking with other areas of economic activity, and one which I wish other industries in this country would take heed of. This bill will seek to generate revenues to consolidate and expand the promotional efforts of this industry in overseas markets.

We are going to come under increasing threat from other excellent wine producing nations throughout the world—in South America, South Africa and Europe. The industry is going to need this generic promotion which is going to establish its leadership position over the life of this strategic plan in certain market segments. So it is a very important piece of legislation from that point and it has the support of growers from within the industry. I congratulate the industry for its vision, its export drive and performance. Let us hope that the great and ambitious targets that are set in its industry plan are achieved over the life of that plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak in favour of the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 and the associated amendments. It is a bill specifically designed to introduce a charge on the exports of Australian wine to assist the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation in its funding of wine export promotions.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that because all sides of the political fence, all sides in the wine industry, the industry hierarchy and an overriding number of the 800 to 900 wineries agree that this is a positive step forward. It is a positive step forward because it is meant to take the wine industry forward. It is an industry that, as we heard the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) quite clearly say, is very competitive on the international marketplace, but is still one that Australia has positive direction for. So this bill is another positive step in the right direction for Australian viticulture.

The wine export charge is another piece fitted in the puzzle of the plan the Howard government has. To give due credit to the former government, they helped put in place this plan, particularly in relation to the wine industry and more importantly for Australian agriculture. The wine industry is dreaming big dreams at present and the plan portrayed under the wine industry's strategy 2025, where Australian wines will achieve some $4.5 billion in annual sales by being the world's most influential and profitable supplier of branded wines by the year 2025, is very visionary stuff.

These are dreams that Hunter vignerons, famous for their semillons, chardonnays and shirazes, will be looking to ride on the back of. Whilst presently holding around 2.5 per cent of the world trade in wine, or 3½ per cent in wholesale terms of trade by value, the plan by the Australian wine industry is to double that percentage hold on the world market and grasp some 6.5 per cent of total production by 2025.

What makes this vision even bolder—and it will reap amazing spin‐offs for the wine industry if it can pull it off—is that it will achieve it in a world marketplace where the total volume of world wine sales may actually drop, even though the world wine market will rise to around $69 billion in 2025 as consumers shift towards high quality premium wines. The shift will become not just a trickle or a trend, but a flood, and our aim is to push the Australian wine industry to be part of that.

I want to come back to that vision because, with wine export figures exploding like champagne corks—export figures that would make any other industry sector weep, in particular, local agribusinesses—it is important that we have plans. It is important that we stick to those plans to obtain the best communal benefit. Figures like those for the 1996 wine grape harvest, which was the foundation for new records for the Australian wine industry, undoubtedly explain that enthusiasm, with record production levels and exports totalling a record 129.5 million litres in 1995‐96, valued at some $470.7 million.

That trend is complemented by the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which showed total domestic sales of Australian wine rising in the March 1997 quarter by 1.2 per cent, with exports over that period of 12.4 million litres, valued at $48 million. That is some 13.6 per cent more than the February quantity and an 8.7 per cent rise in export volumes from the previous year. In the calendar year 1996, exports totalled 148 million litres, valued at $551 million, with exports now accounting for over 28 per cent of the total Australian domestic wine production—a figure that the industry should be truly proud of.

The United Kingdom still remains our largest export market, representing 46 per cent of the quantity and 43 per cent of our total wine export value of some $250 million. It is followed by the United States, where the market, on figures released in January this year, is now worth $97.4 million per year, and climbing rapidly. For New Zealand, it is $39.4 million; for Canada, $28.8 million; and Japan is up 11 per cent. In total, we now export our local wine to some 60 countries throughout the world.

The wine industry has developed the concept of an export charge proposal—a point highlighted by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) in the second reading speech for this bill—because of the concerns that the Wine and Brandy Corporation had to wind down its generic export promotion program for Australian wine as Commonwealth and state grant funding for export promotion came to an end.

The approach by the representatives of the wine industry shows an absolute maturity in picking up the ball and running with it rather than sitting and waiting for the government to hold their hand on the way through. They have determined that they will put it to the government to put this levy forward so that they can take their industry forward, reducing our national debt by exporting wines offshore and creating jobs in the turnaround through tourism and through the domestic industry. But the key element of this bill is that the introduction of a wine export charge will ensure that generic wine export promotion stays.

In my discussions with some of the Hunter's well‐known vignerons—people like Brian McGuigan of McGuigans Wines, Chris Barnes, the President of the Hunter Valley Vineyard Association, and Murray Robson, the opening of whose new winery at Rothbury I will be attending this weekend, and Mr Tony Griffiths, the marketing manager of Port Stephens Wines—I know that they are of one accord and are supportive of the philosophy underpinning the outcomes of this bill.

Pushing Australian wines forward as a generic brand is in their eyes something that will be of real benefit for them all to share. It will also benefit their shareholders and, more importantly, the Hunter, as Australian wines and Hunter wines continue to grab attention on the world stage.

Whilst my electorate of Paterson borders the Hunter's official wine establishment, for the record it is worth noting that, whilst the Pokolbin district and the Upper Hunter receive the lion's share of the accolades, tourist visitations and focus on their wines, areas within my electorate have an historic and very real link to the vine.

Port Stephens Wines is nestled at Bobs Farm within Port Stephens and has been an active winery since 1984. Its sandy soils, whilst not considered standard ground for grape growing, have a natural irrigation with a guaranteed yearly supply of water. After years of planned research, the temperate climate and the natural abundance of fresh, salt‐free bore water, are reaping them real dividends on the edge of the country's biggest tourist stage—that is, Port Stephens.
I will take this moment to digress. Their chardonnay is probably one of the best drops I have had the opportunity to drink. It is an excellent drop.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good drop, too.

—I am glad my friend over there, the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), agrees with me on that. Tony Griffiths, of Port Stephens Wines, has also indicated how research has found that one of the first commercial wine producing ventures was actually established in the Hunter. It was established at Williamtown, with the actual vineyards dating back to the 1830s in the Tahlee and nearby Tanilba Bay areas.

SPEECH.PARA: So the riches in both the history and the quality of wines right across the Hunter region are well recognised not just within Australia but throughout the world stage. I would say, rather parochially, that the Hunter wines are the best in the world. The industry sector is recognised from the highest echelons of government—which was categorised no better than when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) recently came to the Hunter Valley especially for the thanksgiving festival at the wine harvest dinner.

As I explained before, the value of the wine industry to the Hunter—to jobs growth; to fresh infrastructure investment, which is important across regional communities which are forever yearning for more income generation; and to enhancing our balance of payments bottom line—is very real. In seeking and chasing the vision, I do hope that the industry heads, the government and the players in the wine industry are observing that riding the bucking horse can also lead to you falling off.

The wine industry has successfully sought to think outside the square. It has taken its thinking to a totally different dimension in seeking and pursuing active markets in the offshore region. It is important that it continues to innovate and that the government recognises and helps where it can to foster the change.

Last December David Combe, the senior vice‐president of Southcorp Wines's international business division, not only lauded the important role small wineries play in relation to the dominant big four national wine makers—which control close to 80 per cent of our market and production—but he called on industry awareness to raise a campaign to inject absolute quality Australian wines into the burgeoning Asian marketplace. His sentiments were:
The industry needs to rethink where its priorities are in terms of generic promotion campaigns and recognising that something very special is happening in Asia.

His notoriety in the Australian political scene in the early 1980s should not be taken into account when considering such a statement, because he is right to keep the industry thinking totally ahead. His voice is not alone in the wilderness. In the Australian newspaper on 9 December 1996, Wolf Blass raised similar sentiments. He said we should consider innovative ways of marketing surplus wines into the emerging Asian markets, including a revival of the pearl style sparkling wines which were popular some 30 years ago. I am sure we all remember Barossa Pearl and the sparkling wines that we all drank. I was a very young person, but perhaps some of my colleagues over there—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was even younger.

—You were even younger? That is very good to see. Mr Blass says that the westernisation and rapid growth of the middle class in countries like China and Japan make the sweeter distinctly Australian pearl style wine, perhaps in a new screw‐top 200ml bottle style, an answer that could fulfil a niche market over there.

SPEECH.PARA: On a regional front, the immense value that wine tourism provides should never ever be forgotten. The June 1995 report by a committee of inquiry into the wine grape and wine industry estimated that approximately 850 direct jobs were created in the Hunter's wine industry alone, maturing to some 1,200 jobs during the vintage period.

Most of these local jobs hinge on the numbers flocking from Sydney and interstate to the Hunter's world class wineries. Marketing wine tourism and escapism to outside visitors has reaped great success, but I encourage our local wineries to not rest on their laurels. This has been supported by Hunter tourism in their initiative and push in promoting the Hunter as not just a wine region but a total region throughout Australia and to New Zealand.

What we need is even better service, enticements to sustain more sales from the cellar door, through better marketing and pricing, and the encouragement of overnight, weekend or even longer stays in the Hunter. That will provide more down the line employment and will build an even better reputation for the Hunter wineries. To want to be the best in business, you have to be the best in business, and I will obviously continue to encourage and seek to assist our Hunter wine industry in its endeavours to do that.

The Hunter wine industry has had some setbacks over the years. It has survived droughts and hailstorms but it continues. Whilst we all might be very parochial about our own individual wineries or regions and how good those blends are, the important focus here is that together, the Australian winery industry marches an assault on the overseas markets with our wines to show how good they are as a total concept.

As the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) said in his speech, Australia has one very large competitive advantage in the offshore market beside the fact that we produce the best quality wines in the world, and that is that they are very price competitive. In offshore markets Australian wines tend to be in the lower to medium price range and perform a lot better in some of those markets. This has led to the high export values that we have achieved in offshore markets.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, we will continue to support the wine industry and I am glad to see that the opposition does support this Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 and the consequential amendments, and we look forward to seeing a growing, developing and maturing wine industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other members in supporting this legislation. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) explained in his second reading speech, the legislation is to involve the introduction of a charge on exports for Australian wine to assist in funding the wine export promotion infrastructure and program with the corporation currently funded by levies paid under the Wine Grapes Levy Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of a wine export charge will, in the Minister's words, ensure continued funding for generic wine export promotion. The charges are expected to raise about a million a year to fund the infrastructure and part of the promotion program for the Australian Wine Export Council.

The Minister and other members speaking before me have indicated in this debate the very considerable success, particularly in recent times, of the Australian wine industry, and that is a success that all members of this parliament would want to continue to foster.

Perhaps, I could touch on a couple of very brief anecdotes and use them as lead‐ins to a couple of points I want to make about wine exports at the present time. In conjunction with a number of senators and members of both sides of this parliament, I visited Taiwan in an unofficial capacity last month. One of the things that was very noticeable on that particular visit to an Asian country, as compared with a number of earlier visits I had made, was that at banquets and other occasions, wine, particularly red wine was very much present and very clearly being enjoyed.

That was quite a stark contrast with previous occasions when it was always the pattern at a Chinese banquet of any sort that there would be fairly copious quantities of cognac or whisky—spirits—on the table. So, there has been, in my observation, anecdotally,—and I think it is probably supported by more systematic market research—a very significant shift in Asian tastes in terms of beverages.

The other anecdote I have to tell is not quite as encouraging. Whilst in Taipei I visited several wine shops. In those wine shops I had to look very hard to see Australian wines. The wines that were being promoted at the front of the shops were French wines and some other European wines. Eventually, in a couple wine shops I visited, I found some Australian wine stuck down the back of the shop without any obvious promotion. I suppose that reinforces the need for some of the exercises that are proposed in this bill—although, there is a qualification on that that I want to make. I flew on Eva Air, a Taiwan owned airline, in and out of Australia. No Australian wines were being served, only excellent French and Californian wines. Certainly, anecdotally, there is a great way for us to go.

What troubles me about how that challenge in Asia is being addressed—the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) referred to it—is that Austrade and the Australian Wine Export Council currently conduct, according to their literature, generic promotional programs in the UK, Ireland, Netherlands, Germany, Switzerland, Scandinavia, USA and Canada. There are no Asian cities there. The literature also talks about distributors. The Australian Wine Export Council has offices in London, Frankfurt, New York and, under contractual arrangements with Austrade offices, in Vancouver, Toronto, Stockholm and Copenhagen. Unless my geography is a singular failure, there are no Asian countries there.

When one looks at the 1995‐96 annual report of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation, and at the overseas visitors being sponsored to Australia, one can see that someone came in April 1996 from Thailand, some people came in June 1996 from Japan and a wine writer came from Singapore. But, overwhelmingly, the visitors that presumably were sponsored by the corporation to visit Australia, as part of the promotion of our wines, were not from Asia; they were from Europe or North America.

Let us look at the overseas travel of staff from Australia of the corporation. In December 1995, the general manager travelled to the US and Europe. In January and February of 1996, he travelled to the UK and Europe. There were no visits to Asia. I do not know whether the corporation was represented in the last month or so at the Hofex exhibition in Hong Kong. I am told that that is the major food and drink expo in Asia so it would be very useful to know whether Australia was officially represented at that. If we were not, frankly, it is a disgrace.

The point I am trying to make is that not enough is being done in terms of the relative priorities in promoting Asia. The latest ABS figures I have show that Europe and North America are certainly more significant markets at the present time. On my reading of the figures, which I have done fairly quickly—I have not had any opportunity to do any detailed analysis—the rate of growth in both South‐East Asia and north‐east Asia is dramatically greater, admittedly off a somewhat lower base.

That would seem to me to add very considerable strength to the argument that in this new fund for generic promotion particular emphasis ought to be given to Asian markets, without neglecting other markets. If my anecdote is correct about the shift under way in Asian drinking patterns, the potential gains there are very substantial indeed. That is not to say that it will be easy. A number of speakers have referred to the very excellent 2025 strategy plan prepared by the industry. That strategy plan, amongst other things, makes the comment that industry and government must work closely to dismantle the prohibitive tariff and taxation regimes which prevail in a large number of Asian markets.

I have had a very brief look at some of those barriers. For example, on the information I have, Hong Kong imposes a 100 per cent duty on alcoholic beverages. Japan operates, and I guess this is common with a number of other countries, a preferential system of duty which very much benefits countries such as Chile, as a competitor. From this information, countries such as Chile are regarded as less developed countries and therefore have a reduced or non‐applicable rate of duty applied by Japan. It seems to me that we ought to take up the particular observation in the strategy report about the need for aggressive action by both the industry and the government in Australia to ensure that prohibitive barriers or distortions of trade with Asian countries are addressed.

With respect to Japan, I think the benefits there are very substantial. I obtained from the library yesterday a press clipping from a Jiji Press service in Japan dated 28 November 1996 entitled `Wine imports growing at heady pace.' It said:

Wine from around the world is flowing into Japan at an intoxicating pace, according to the Yokohama Customhouse. Last year, total wine imports through Yokohama Port . . . topped 10 billion yen for the first time ever, rising to an estimated 11,196 million yen, the port authority said.
In the first nine months of this year, the volume of imported wine increased 9.9 pct over the same period last year. . .
That reinforces the observations I made about Asian patterns. It goes on to say:

France lead exporters with a 24.5 pct share of the local imported wine market. Next came Argentina with about 18.1 pct, Germany with 14.2 pct, Chile with 8.2 pct, Bulgaria with 7.4 pct and Italy with 7 pct, the authority said. Imports from South Africa and Chile have grown particularly fast, it said.

Wouldn't you know it, there was not a single mention of Australia! That reinforces the second anecdote I told about the need for some attention to the priorities of where we are putting our effort. It is not only a matter in relation to Taiwan or Hong Kong, it is a matter in relation to Japan as well.

Another observation I wanted to make arising out of the strategy report that I referred to earlier was a comment about the competitive edge that the Australian wine industry has. Before politicians get too involved with self-congratulation, it makes this particularly important remark:
Its greatest threat to competitiveness is a lack of government support. Halliday—
which is presumably the wine commentator—
points out that the federal bureaucracy is strongly antipathetic to the industry and Federal politicians are neutral. This is backed up by a punitive tax system and little facilitative support.
It goes on and says:
State governments are seen as more supportive
In the context of the strategy plan it refers to a range of taxation and other measures that the industry wants government to address.

That is a very salutary point to note in this particular debate because whilst all contributors to this debate want to see the industry flourish, we are being told pretty clearly by the industry that in its view, inadequate government support is a major threat to its competitiveness. That competitiveness, as other speakers have indicated, is absolutely crucial. We face competition from the traditional European wine nations, and there is a very substantial threat from South America, particularly from Chile, and from South African wines.

Whilst I endorse the remarks that have been made by other speakers in this debate, it seems to me that we ought to be ensuring that the appropriate bodies, the corporation and its offshoots, really put a little more attention on their marketing in Asia. We ought to be seeking more adequate explanations as to why Asia is not apparently receiving the attention that it would seem to deserve in that exercise. We ought to very much take to heart the comments of the industry in its strategy plan that government support is, in its view, still inadequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There will not be anyone in the House surprised to see me rise to participate in this cognate debate on the Wine Export Charge Bill 1997, although I must say I make that comment with a touch of irony because I grew up in a teetotal house in which the consumption of alcohol was unknown. My experience of this industry is something that I have had to acquire as the federal member for the electorate of Wakefield.

SPEECH.PARA: As most members in the chamber will be aware, Wakefield incorporates the Barossa Valley, the Riverland and parts of the Clare Valley, thereby making it one of South Australia's most enviable electorates. That means, of course, that there are lots of people who would gladly have a job like mine, representing an industry as prominent as it is in my electorate.

I am sorry the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) has had to leave the chamber—no doubt he has a legitimate reason for that—because he made a number of remarks that I would particularly like to focus on. He was critical of what he saw as government apathy towards the wine industry. They were remarks that particularly bristled with me.

This is an industry that has been prominent in the Australian federal parliament and in its representation for almost as long as it has been in existence. I well recall that, when I entered this place in 1983, this was an industry facing a number of what were seen to be overproduction problems. By 1984, those overproduction problems had become so acute that the government of the day agreed to a vine pull scheme in order to remove some of the surplus production, principally in reds.

It is a bit rich for the member for Maribyrnong to come in here and eyeball a 14‐month old government and suggest that it has done too little, when in 1983, when the Liberal and National parties lost power, there was no tax on the wine industry. Mark that.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no exports.

—And no exports—I will gladly pick up the point of the member for Fowler (Mr Grace). It is a matter that I am more than happy to address, but he might care to bear in mind my statement that there was no tax on the wine industry in 1983‐84, a position that had been proudly defended by my predecessor, the honourable Geoffrey O'Halloran Giles.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry had a vine pull scheme funded by the government. I freely concede that to the member for Fowler. But it also was followed in its recovery by a tax of 10 per cent, in spite of the assurances of the government of the day that that would not happen and, subsequently, another tax of 20 per cent.

I am one representing an industry—the member for Fowler will be interested to note—who did not vote against that tax, because I thought it was impossible to continue to have an alcoholic beverage industry that did not carry some tax bill. I stand here and quite frankly say I did not oppose that measure. It is a bit rich for the member for Maribyrnong to come in here and accuse us of not doing enough when what the former government did was burden this industry with a greater tax load than it had ever known before.

The member for Fowler interjected, `And no exports', and he is quite right. The industry, facing a vine pull scheme and a government taxation measure, determined to do what it should have done decades ago: that is pull together and develop an export strategy. In many ways, no thanks to the former government and no thanks to this government at this point in time, the industry has put together an export package that, as previous speakers have indicated, is the envy of most other industries in Australia, particularly primary industries. That package has had a real export focus. That package has thrived because the industry pulled together. The success of that package had nothing to do with the former government and a great deal to do with industry determination.

There is an irony that the member for Fowler has pointed out. The irony is that the tax went on and the industry thrived—not precisely what the government or the industry of the day predicted, but that was the end result. There is also an irony in the car industry, if I may digress, in that the government lowered the tariffs from 70 per cent to what is targeted to be 15 per cent, and the industry developed an export base that it previously had never imagined. But that is not the matter before the chair. The matter before the chamber right now is the question of what the wine industry does into the future, how it equips itself for the future, and what it sees as its likely export success into the future.

Not surprisingly, every speaker has mentioned the strategy 2025, the wine industry's plan which is very much the result of their having looked at their targets, potential markets and production in Australia and said, `This is what we can do with the reputation we have developed over the last decade as an effective export industry in Australia.'
There are incredible figures. The Financial Review of 10 April 1997 said:

The United States continues to provide a lucrative outlet for Australian wine with the average export price to the US of $5.21 per litre substantially higher than the $3.45 per litre achieved in the United Kingdom. Sales to the United Kingdom rose 32.5 per cent in volume to 74.8 million litres and 30 per cent in value to $258.2 million in the year to March 31. Sales to the United States rose 34.8 per cent in volume to 20.7 million litres and 48.8 per cent in value to $107.8 million in the same period.

It is a quite unprecedented success story and the industry has wisely come to this government and said, `What can we do to in some way ensure that that success continues?' They have come to us seeking the opportunity to have a wine export charge levied against the industry and this government has agreed. It would be fair to say that the government's agreement did not come instantly. Not because we wished in any way to frustrate the wine industry but because of two concerns that the government had. One was that the export charge may not necessarily be supported by the entire industry and the other that the export charge could be construed as a tax being placed on the industry. But the industry has made it perfectly clear to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) and to the government that this is a charge that is supported by almost the entire industry and that they do not construe it as a tax. There is an opportunity for them to work together from one revenue base with an eye to expanding export markets.

This year alone, the wine industry—a point I am sure the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) will want to make—will in fact generate something like $634 million in exports which is double that of two years ago and well on target to the $1 billion that they are hoping to reach by the year 2001.

Much has been made in this debate by the member for Maribyrnong of what he saw as the failure of the wine industry in Australia to make any inroads into the Asian markets. He recognised the progress that had been made in the UK and more latterly in the USA but he was critical of what he saw as a lack of aggression on the part of the wine industry in getting into the Asian market.

What the member for Maribyrnong fails to recognise is that whether we are in fact dealing as he did, with Taiwan, or with Japan, much of the difficulty that Australian exporters—not just the wine industry, but Australian exporters generally—have with the Asian market is the whole question of market access. Market access is denied them because in fact the countries do not want additional competition in their wine industry. The reason that the parliament—and I emphasise `the parliament'—has stuck by the WTO arrangements, conveniently ignored I must add by the Australian Democrats and some of the independents, is so that the parliament will be able to offer to all export industries, including the wine industry, better market access. It is quite true to say that in the wine area, as in any other export area, we do not have a level playing field—everyone knows that. But in fact as a result of the negotiations over the last decade, the playing field is more level than it has been in the lifetime of the member for Fowler (Mr Grace) or myself. That is to the credit of the parliament. It is to the credit of the government that in opposition we did not criticise the then government and the steps they were taking to level out the playing field. I would be a little less acidic in my remarks if I did not have the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) now criticising us for doing the very things in world trade that we supported him in doing when he was in government.

The reality is that the playing field is not level and we do not have the market access we would like in Asia—the very point made by the member for Maribyrnong. But that market access will only be gained as we abide by the rules of the WTO and that is bound to mean that there are some countries with tariff rates higher than we have. We do not like that and we cannot negotiate our way out of it as the member for Maribyrnong called on us to do as the previous speaker in this debate. We cannot negotiate our way out of it because, even in the wine industry, we are barely two per cent of world trade. We need to bear that in mind. We are not the tail on the end of the dog. We are scarcely even the flea on the end of the tail. We have no leverage in world markets. The best we can do is negotiate.

The WTO is part of that negotiating process. Much of the difficulty that the Australian industry has in getting a toehold in Asia is principally a result of the fact that we are not enjoying the market access there that we are in Europe and the USA. The risk we run when we want to modify the rules under the WTO that we have agreed to as a parliament is the risk of being denied the relatively free access that we have into the markets of the UK and the USA.

The bill before the chamber is a bill that has been supported by the industry. That is significant because the big four in the industry—and we are not talking about banks now, but about Orlando‐Wyndham, Southcorp, Mildara‐Blass and BRL Hardy—occupy 80 per cent of the wine industry's production in Australia. There was a real concern that this bill might merely facilitate them and not the smaller winemakers. But the smaller winemakers have indicated, by and large, their support for this bill as well, so the industry can be seen to offer an aggressive and cohesive approach to export market development.

The future of the Australian wine industry and, as a result, its capacity to generate export income for the Australian community depends entirely on the way the industry performs in the export markets. This bill is in place to facilitate that and I am pleased to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —No‐one in this place will be surprised to see me, like the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), seeking an opportunity to speak on the Wine Export Charge Bill, because the electorate I represent has within it some of the finest winemakers in the world. I think that is a point that is indisputable. That activity not only takes place in the Lower Hunter region these days, but has also grown very quickly in the Upper Hunter, so the Hunter is increasingly becoming a major player in the winemaking industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a very strong and undisputed link between the health of Australia's wine industry and the health of Australia's tourism industry. That is a link that is very important in my electorate. Towns like Cessnock, for example, which traditionally relied upon coalmining as its economic base, have increasingly come to rely on tourism for economic wealth and therefore for survival. So the very strong link between the health of the wine industry and the health of the tourism industry therefore means there is a very strong link between the health of the wine industry and the health of my local economy.

There is also an important relationship between the health of the wine industry and our ability to break into overseas markets. As many earlier speakers have indicated, at the moment our winemakers are exporting their heads off. Winemakers in my immediate area, like the Drayton family, the Tyrrells and of course the McGuigan company, have been very innovative and, indeed, very energetic in their approach to opening up new export markets for their family companies. Not only that, in the Upper Hunter we have Rosemount, which I think exports about 50 per cent of all wine it produces. So the Hunter is also becoming increasingly very prominent in the export industry.

If the Australian industry penetration into international markets is to continue to grow, the industry will need assistance. This bill does provide that extra push. I am pleased with the bipartisanship being displayed on this issue—it is almost a little scary; you do not see it too often—although I note that the member for Wakefield and the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) have had a word or two to say to one another. I am sorry that I missed a large part of the member for Maribyrnong's speech. But there has been a healthy bipartisan approach and I am delighted to stand here and lend my support to this government bill.

The export charge, of course, will raise about $1 million each year and will go a long way towards assisting the industry reach its objectives, as outlined in its document known as Strategy 2025 that I have heard a number of speakers refer to. The money will not only help the industry increase its current export markets but, of course, will assist it in establishing new export markets.

According to the document, by the year 2001 the industry hopes to increase its share of the German market by some 33 per cent, the Japanese market by 29 per cent, the US market by 16 per cent, the Swedish by 15 per cent and the UK market which of course is our largest export market, by around seven per cent. I recommend the document Strategy 2025 to all those with an interest in the industry. It is innovative, it shows vision, and it shows that this really is an industry prepared to help itself and get out there amongst it. It shows that it is not prepared to sit back and rely only on government assistance when attempting to establish additional export markets and expand its existing markets.

To move away from bipartisanship for just a moment, I could not understand why last year, in its first budget, the Howard government decided to simply chop the final payment due to winegrowers which was a compensation payment instituted by the former government to compensate for the changes in the tax regime as it applied to the wine industry. That saving to the government was only about $3.5 million, but to each of the individual winegrowers in my region, and in every other region around the country, it represented a loss of some $6,000—hardly the sort of incentive we are looking to give them at this particular time.

However, I want to digress just a little and talk very briefly about one very innovative project in the pipeline in my electorate, and that is an attempt to run water through a pipeline from the Hunter River into the Pokolbin area. One of the greatest difficulties the Pokolbin winegrowers have is the lack of water which, of course, impacts upon their ability to increase their volume. The project is an exciting venture that is valued at about $8 million. Again, it is a scheme that does not rely on government assistance. It is proposed to be put in place through either a cooperative—comprising a number of winegrowers and, therefore, investors in the region—or the bankable option.

The bankable option involves an outside investor. It is a more highly engineered scheme, and is a low risk but secure scheme. I recommend it to ministers of the government who, no doubt, will be asked to express an interest in it. I recommend that they give it their support in any way that they can. This is potentially a scheme that could have enjoyed assistance under the infrastructure bonds scheme—the scheme that we have effectively just seen abolished and replaced by a scheme that relates only to land, transport and infrastructure projects. That is disappointing and I would have thought this was a very worthy scheme that could have fitted very nicely into that scheme that has just been abolished. However, I do ask ministers to look favourably on any request for assistance that might be sought from the government in relation to the project for the Pokolbin area.

Once again, I am delighted that on this issue there has been a large degree of bipartisanship. This is a very important industry to Australia. It is a burgeoning export industry and a very important industry to my electorate. I am delighted that we see members on both sides of the House working closely together to ensure a healthy future for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wine Export Charge Bill 1997 is to introduce, at the request of the wine industry, a charge on exports to assist in funding the wine export promotion infrastructure and program of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The corporation's statutory responsibilities include wine promotion, wine export control, the wine label integrity program, and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine. The Australian wine industry has asked that the bill be introduced because, as successful as the industry has been in exporting wine, there will be a continuing need for generic wine export promotion.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) said in his second reading speech, the Australian wine industry is currently enjoying unprecedented international recognition and is achieving rapid growth in exports. It needs repeating that, between 1985‐86 and 1995‐96, exports grew more than 10‐fold in value from 11 million litres worth $21 million, to 130 million litres worth $471 million. While Australian wines may be found in many countries, Australia's major export markets are Europe, North America and New Zealand. An indication of the rapid increase is that exports in 1996 totalling 148 million litres were valued at $551 million—an increase over the previous year of 28 per cent by volume and 36 per cent by value.

The bill gives me the opportunity to speak about a wine producing area that has in the past obtained very little recognition. I am pleased to see, however, that over the past several years, this situation has started to change, mainly due to the quality of grapes produced and the quality of the special vintages of the area—quality that can no longer be denied. There are a number of well‐known wineries within the Riverina, and the names may surprise some people: De Bortoli Wines, Casella Wines, Cranswick Estate Wines, Lillypilly Estate Wines, McWilliams Wines, Miranda Wines, Orlando Wines, Riverina Wines, Rossetto Wines, Southcorp Wines, Toorak Wines, West End Wines, Stanbridge Estate Wines and, of course, Charles Sturt University. I may have missed a few, and I apologise for that. There are also a number of boutique wineries.

I am pleased to report that the 1997 vintage in the MIA has ended on a high note, with the May rains starting noble rot running in late hanging semillon grapes. This noble rot will produce yet another line of sweet Riverina wine that has become internationally famous. While in the MIA a vintage of around 125,000 tonnes was hoped for, a lesser amount of 118,000 tonnes was achieved. This was still pleasing, given that it was a record vintage. According to the Wine Grapes Marketing Board chairman, Mr Gary Smellie, all the grapes were taken; most of the winemakers obtained the fruit they wanted; and growers obtained good prices for working hard to produce better quality grapes.

BREAK.PARA: In speaking of the New South Wales Grapes Marketing Board, I am pleased to see that its term has been extended for three years by the State Minister for Agriculture, Richard Amery. This extension has been welcomed by wine grape growers and it followed a review of the vesting powers of the board; but the government at the end of the day accepted that having a statutory authority in place did not disadvantage wine consumers.

The Wine Grape Marketing Board has in recent years brought about harmony and stability in the wine industry during an unprecedented growth phase. Grape prices that peaked in the 1995‐96 vintage—fuelled by international demand for Australian wine—were sustained and climbed to new heights during the 1997 vintage, due to winemaker competition for premium fruit. However, the 1997 national grape tonnage fell from an estimated 900,000 tonnes to only about 800,000 tonnes. This fall has created a scramble for grapes, especially premium whites and all reds, which were in very short supply. The problem for the Wine Grapes Marketing Board may come once more favourable seasonal conditions return across all grape producing regions, and there may be a surplus of unfashionable grapes.

Along with the growing of rice, fruit and vegetables, wine production is a key industry within the Riverina and, more particularly, the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area. Wine grape production in the MIA accounts for almost 13 per cent of Australia's yield. Apart from the actual wineries, there are many spin‐offs that assist the local communities. An example is A&G Industries, a company in Griffith that is recognised as a world leader in the manufacture and installation of state‐of‐the‐art stainless steel winemaking equipment. I understand they are one of the largest users of stainless steel in Australia, and their products are exported throughout the world.

The Charles Sturt University, located in Wagga Wagga, is already famous for its wine science and viticultural courses, which have trained many of Australia's top winemakers, who are now making a name for themselves in this nation and overseas. The university not only provides courses for Australians, but also is involved in distance education in other parts of the world including—would you believe—Portugal. The winery attached to the university has, over the past several years, produced some excellent medal winning wines and is recognised by the emblem of Sturt's desert pea on its label.

Charles Sturt University and other learning centres throughout Australia are pivotal in ensuring that Australia is recognised as a nation that produces quality wines. The advances in techniques using modern science are giving Australia an advantage in quality wine production that we must seek to maintain if we are to continue to be successful in placing our wines on the world market. While Australian trained wine makers are now spread throughout the world, it is hoped that the edge we have developed will be maintained.

As most Australians, particularly wine lovers, would know, family companies are the life blood of an industry, and some families have been making wine for five generations. This may not be a long time by European standards. I remember talking to a gentleman on a train going between Florence and Rome one day whose family had been making candy since Christopher Columbus travelled to the Americas. Nevertheless, by Australian benchmarks, it shows a wealth of experience and knowledge handed down through the generations, to which is added the new technologies developed through institutions like Charles Sturt University.

One of these family wineries within the Riverina to boast five generations is that of the famous McWilliams family. Not only are they good corporate citizens, but their contribution to the community within the MIA is legendary. Three generation families are also evident, some of the better known ones being the De Bortolis and Mirandas, who are in the top 10 largest wineries in Australia and still find time to support local communities.

We who live in the Riverina are very proud of the food and the beverages that the area produces. On Saturday, 14 June a dinner is to be held in Wagga Wagga to celebrate that fact. At the dinner, the Golden Plate Awards will be presented to recognise this excellence in the food and beverage industry of the Riverina. The dinner is being organised by the Riverina Food Group, which is one of Australia's peak food networks, comprising companies in the Riverina region who produce and process food and beverage products. Formed in 1993, the Riverina Food Group is an initiative of local producers, the Riverina Regional Development Board and the Chamber of Manufacturers of New South Wales.

The chairman of the group, Louis Marangon of Griffith, has stated that the awards presented have two objectives: firstly, to highlight the achievements of food and beverage producers and manufacturers in the Riverina; secondly, to give local people a taste of the wonderful diversity of food and wines the Riverina has to offer.

The Riverina Gold Plate Awards, which are being presented for the first time, will give the community the opportunity to recognise the efforts of the producers and manufacturers who have contributed to the success of the Riverina in its production of fine food and fine wine. By holding functions such as this, it is hoped the quality of both the food and wines of the Riverina will become more widely known and their quality appreciated.

I would like to congratulate the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation on the work it does, including wine promotion, wine export control, the wine label integrity program and determining Australia's geographical indications for use in describing and presenting wine.

Finally, may I say the wine industry is a good example of what Australian initiative and drive can do in promoting and successfully marketing Australian products on a highly competitive international market. It is an example that many industries could follow and the industry deserves congratulations. I would particularly like to congratulate all involved in wine grape production, wine making and associated industries in the Riverina and throughout Australia, who add so much to the prosperity of our Riverina region and to the prosperity of Australia. I strongly support the bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Overseas Travel

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister undertaken ministerial travel overseas since 18 September 1996; if so (a) how many visits has the Minister undertaken, (b) what was the duration of each visit and (c) which countries were visited.
(2) What has been the cost of each overseas visit the Minister has undertaken since entering the Ministry.

(3) Has the Minister utilised frequent flyer points for overseas or internal flights on official business in accordance with the direction issued by the Minister for Administrative Services in April 1996; if so, to what extent were points used and on which overseas visits were they used; if not, why not and what action is being taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I have undertaken one overseas trip. The cost of my travel was $14,135. This amount includes accommodation, meals, telephone and fax calls, airfares, passport costs, baggage insurance, ground transport, incidentals and personal hospitality for myself and one member of my personal staff.
(3) Yes.

Consistent with Government policy, I look to the opportunity to use frequent flyer points to offset the cost of official travel wherever possible, and will continue to do so. The opportunity to redeem points, however, is restricted by the airlines' conditions e.g. not all flights have seats available for frequent flyer use, not all destinations can be reached using a specific carrier and their partner airlines, and there are `block out' periods by the airlines (peak times) when no seats are available.
